column10: Review

column9: Poor product, Worst customer service and warranty by Netgear
column10: I bought this product 4 months back and already the dual band does not work properly. 5GHz band keeps dropping the internet connection and 2.4GHz too gave up after sometime.Netgear customer support is the WORST i have ever seen. They expect customer to ship the defective product at customer's expense. Ridiculous!!!!Thank God I got square trade coverage, who are going to reimburse the shipping fees, or else i would have to suffer with this dirty product or pay $10-20 bucks to replace this one.
Firmware software update useless. Spoke to Pakistan on 4 different occasions , no joy for a fix.This may be a good router for a PC, but not a Mac.

This router never did work right mostly because of dropped internet signals and complicated set up with instructions written in geek speak. After three weeks of frustration I gave up and returned this 'top of the line' router. Looking at the other reviews, I'm seem not to be alone. Thanks to Amazon for their no quibble return policy. I would not recommend anyone buy this router.
Device is a lemon. Works for a little while and then dies. No tech support for help after 90 days. Save yourself the money and aggravation from my experience.

The router is easy to set up and connect your equipment to it and maintains a stable network, however you will lose internet connectivity regularly.  There is an issue with the firmware that Netgear doesn't seem to want to recognize.  My father bought this router at the same time as me and he has the same issues as I do.  I would not recommend as it can cause you a major headache...

I bought this product about 2 months ago after reading the positive reviews on this site. It worked well for a month and then the problem started. Every few minutes it drops the connection and takes several minutes to reconnect again. I called the customer service several times and after changing the settings several times the problem did not get resolved. Netgear asked me send back the product for which I ended up spending $17 for no fault of mine. When the product is defective Netgear should make the returns free instead of trying to make money even on their defective products. I am waiting for my replacement and hope it will work.
Seller was great! Product is nothing but problems. Netgear support has not been able to repair the internet dropping issue.

column9: don't buy this router if you want the 90 day free tech support
column10: don't buy this router if you want the 90 day free tech support. They will only help you set up your computer. If you have any peripherals such as a printer they will not help you without a minumim $35 charge

column9: Avoid at all costs!  Known defects!
column10: Like many out there, my Wireless G signal keeps dropping.  It's random but it happened 3 times today.  Stock firmware was horrible and the updates were even worse- sometimes causing more problems.  Replaced with DD-WRT, still no luck.  People say they've reported this to Netgear, who responded 'It's a known issue, just return the product'.  That's if within 60 days, otherwise Netgear won't talk to you- besides the sales pitch for their IT support program!I'm not sure why many have defects and many have no problems.  It may be that 25% are defects, and/or those that aren't having problems use the Wireless N signal only, which does work fine for me.  Plus they may not use advanced options that also have problems (port fwd/trig, virtual srvr, dynDNS, monitoring- some of these are not even available).  Bottom line is that Netgear has been promising fixes for 2 years... In the meantime, people faithfully waited, surpassing return periods. Even if they didn't, they already set up the router, etc. and are committed.  They'd rather wait for a fix than deal with return hassles.It's a win-win for Netgear: sell a defective product with a low return rate and increase memberships for their IT support program.  Do not buy and return if possible.  It is the effective and moral thing to do.  Netgear doesn't value their customers.Pro:- Wireless N signal works for meCon:- Wireless G signal drops constantly- Stock firmware and GUI are horrible- Customer support is poor, if available at all- Some advanced features are unavailable or problematic- No monitoring support- PriceyCustomers shouldn't think that dealing with all of these problems is normal.Yeah I miss my Linksys WRT54G too.
What a disappointment and shocking that a modern router at this price point can't handle SIP/VOIP. If you plan to do any internet phone calls, this router will most definitely not get the job done.

Folks,I have had this router for 5 months.  I was hoping to take advantage of the latest gigabit speeds and the USB storage capabilities.  I have three major issues:1.  USB drive performance is terrible.  Also, requires a reboot every few days as the USB drive disappears from sight for no apparent reason.  My drive is a supported device.2.  The 2.5 ghz wireless speed fluctuates massively forcing you to reduce wireless access speed to get a solid and reliable connection.3.  The router blips out when pumping large amounts of data through it and disappears completely.  You can't ping it.  You have to reboot the router by pulling the power.I have unplugged this router and taken it out of my network.  I have reinstalled my old Zyxel X-550 as it gave me two years of excellent performance.  I can not recommend this router.As so much of the stuff we buy these days, this router is made in China.  Perhaps the quality isn't what we would expect from Netgear due to this being outsourced to a country not known for high quality.  That said, however... I think there is a lack of solid engineering here as the product just doesn't perform up to expectations.Thank you.

Even Netgear support rep agreed that there is a bug in the firmware which makes the router drop connection with the internet (wired and wireless). I spent hours trying to figure out whether it is my ISP or Router and at the end bought Belkin N600 and have no issues of connection drops. I did not expect such a product from a company like Netgear. Probably this was my last netgear product.

I tried setting up this router but it refused to recognize my DCHP.  I then spent hours talking to both Netgear and my ISP.  Netgear told me I needed to contact my ISP and get them to bridge the modem to the router.  My ISP told me that was not going to happen.  I then tried to set up the router with an new modem and a different ISP and it still only recognized a static connection.  I returned the router and most likely never buy a Netgear router. I could understand if Netgear admitted that their router was defective, and this would have saved me a lot of time if Netgear would have pointed me in the right direction.

Thing is a piece of junk.  After 1 month, the 2.4ghz radios started going out and dropping connection frequently.  You'd basically have to reset the thing.  Updated the firmware, and the issue persisted.Netgear's 'fix' was to run the router at it's minimum capabilities, cutting its speed and radio range below the default and pretty much hindering its performance to that of a $30 router.  I tried to get a replacement and they wanted me to send mine back AND CHARGE ME to do it.  Screw that.  I'm getting a different router and selling this one ASAP.DO NOT BUY.

column9: Don't buy! Several bugs on firmware will keep you upset!
column10: I started using WiFi technology 11 years ago and tried several standards and vendors of this technology, such as DLink, Belkin and Linksys, and always have decent coverage, throughput and features at a reasonable price. Since I entered into the HiDef world I've got a chance to Netgear due the specifications and feedbacks, as well as I assumed that a such priced equipment should perform as announced. But I was wrong. It don't give you decent coverage: my old Pre-N Belkin coveraged all my two story apartment and this one don't. It don't give you throughput: ten feet away and you can't have more than 75 Mbps for the 2.4GHz band and it is impossible to work with the 5GHz band if you far away than 30 feet. The upload and download through the file server is ridiculous and you can't have more than 1.5MBs of upload to the USB drive attached to it. It means that one of the supposed differentiator feature for this router doesn't work and you have terrible experience trying to backup things - it doesn't matter if through wireless or wired connection. Last but not least it don't give you the features it promisses and even a reset button doesn't exist on its management interface. The firmware is deffective and keep losing the 2.4GHz band and DNS forwarding and you have to reset it. Look into Netgear forums e see by yourself what I mean. Those issues are well known by Netgear but they can't issue a new and robust firmware, instead they keep change the name of the router. There are cheaper and better options in the market so keep away.

column9: Consider this your warning... If you want hours of pain and frustraiton. BUY this router now.
column10: I bought this router on the recomendation of my business VOIP provider.  I was having some VOIP problems at work and they suggested I upgrade my router.  I have 10 networked computers and 10 phone lines.  I also bought this for my home.  I have 3 networked computers and Voip phone.I have had two weeks of problems with this router at the office.  Interestingly enough I have had 2 'firmware' upgrades that the router identified that it needed within this period of time, which I think is odd.  I had to call in a network tech to install it because when I tried it wouldn't work.  I am not a techie but I am not a novice at technology issues either.  I do feel comfortable with intermediate technology work.I had to hire another network tech to get it operational.  We are still experiencing connectivity problems and reduced internet speed. total coast at this point as been $850 and that doesn't include all the downtime which in my line of work would add about another $3000 to the current losses.As soon as I set it up at home my printer no longer worked.  As I am writing this i am talking with tech support.  I have been on the phone with three different departments, one of which wanted to charge me to get the thing operationalI have set up no less than 10 other routers, switches and modems in the last 5 years and have never had to call technical support or had this many problems.

column9: God help you if anything goes wrong with it
column10: Worked great for three months, then all the wired ports died, and I entered Netgear support hell.  Call the 1-800 number, wait on hold for tech.  Get walked through 'troubleshooting'.  (Basic things like turn it on and off, see what IP address you get, try to ping things.)  Sure enough, it's broken.  Get told you have to call Amazon to exchange it under warranty.  Call Amazon.  They don't know what you're talking about; it's a manufacturer warranty.  Call Netgear back.  Wait on hold for a while.  Give the case number, ask for RMA. They claim to be transferring you, then hang up.  Call back.  Give them the case number.  Apparently they don't bother to record anything, because the new guy says he was to walk you through 'troubleshooting' as well before he can give you an RMA.  Go through the useless troubleshooting again.  Still broken.  Rep claims he'll transfer you to a supervisor.  Spend 15 minutes on hold, then they hang up you.  Call back.  Give case number to another rep.  She can't do anything unless you go through 'troubleshooting'.  Waste another 20 minutes.  Make the mistake of telling them you have a laptop as well, now we have to 'troubleshoot' with the laptop.  Yep, router doesn't work with it either.Have been on phone with one netgear rep or another for 2 solid hours now.  No end in sight.  At this point I'm ready to toss this router into the trash can and go buy anything but a Netgear.

I love this router but god help you if you need technical support and I would never pay them for technical support. I called under the 90 day free support after purchase period. My router does not display the devices connected to it. It should display all of the wireless and wired devices such as computers and laptops connected to it.First I called and they told me that I did not have a Netgear router because my serial number was not in their database. They implied that Amazon had sold me a refurbished router and the only way I could get support was to pay for it. The person I spoke to was not a native english person and it was almost impossible to understand her. She flatly refused to send me to technical support since she could not find my serial number in her data base. I asked to speak to her supervisor and pretty much got the same answer but finally she admitted that they have a problem with their database and agreed to put me through to technical support. At this point I had been on the phone for 30 1/2 minutes.The L1 technical support person appeared to be from India and after 12 minutes  of talking and one question was what kind of modem do you have. I said that I will have to walk down downstairs to get the manufacturer's name. When I did that and told him the manufacturer, that's all he wanted to know. Didn't need the serial number or anything. So back upstairs to my PC before he said that he would have to talk to his L2 tech support person.He came back and told me that I needed to do a factory reset which deletes all of the password and security, everything in the router and reconfigure it. He also said that the next software upgrade would fix the problem. I said why should I have to reset the router and then have to fully reconfigure my network when they know it is a problem that is currently being worked on. No answer to that one except his L2 person told him that.Best I could tell he understood nothing about computers and was reading a script of questions. I don't think he ever really understood what my question was.Bottom line I like the router, it seems to work well except for the attached devices listing part but I would not recommend purchasing this router unless you are a computer professional who has a lot of patience.I did a Google search for their technical support and CustomerServicesScoreboard.com gives them a bottom of the barrel rating and I agree (304 out of 386). If you don't believe me Google for 'netgear technical service sucks' and see how many hits you get.Total time out of my life: Almost an hour! Good thing I wasn't paying by the minute.

column9: Watch out if you have WNDR3700v2
column10: Purchased this and set it up. Very easy. Great product till I tried to setup Parental controls. I had to use their CD to set up Live Parental Controls. However it would not let me set this up stating Live Parental Controls were not supported by this router. Looked at their website and it states WNDR3700 supports it. Does not state WNDR3700v2 does not support it. It was only after placing a call to Tech Support that I find out this feature is not supported in their latest version that gets shipped. They asked me to go to the earlier version WNDR3700v1.The challenge is this:The version number is on the CD and not on the box. So you have to buy the product open it and then open the CD to find out what version you have. Thank goodness I bought it at Costco so I am returning it. Netgear does not know when they will have a fix for the Parental Controls for the latest version available. Now why does a company knowingly sell a product and advertise that the features are available when they do not even have a scheduled fix for the issues? Why bother with the customer aggravation and distaste left with the customer? This is beyond me.Having proper parental controls is very important to me with kids in the home. Only Live Parental Controls will let you do the combination of :1. Deny access to websites AND2. Restrict access to websites based on time of day (eg no Facebook when kids are supposed to be doing homework).So Netgear sorry but I have to return your product and hopefully next time you will not release a home use product without keeping in mind that parents amongst others buy home based products.Did not try any other features if they worked properly or not since it did not have the one most important feature I wanted - Parental controls.Otherwise this product seemed great in terms of the features it has (untested by me)

column9: Read this before you buy major flaw in this product
column10: Pros: fast hardware, easy to setup, no installation CD necessary, increases internet speed, good range when it was working.Cons: it will lose connection and from then on the wireless connection on all bands will have a short range, like 1m or less. I've gone through 2 of these routers at Best Buy and Amazon, same thing. Even the new v2 has this problem. You don't know when it will crop up but when it does you'll know it.For that reason alone DO NOT BUY! Wait until they figure this out at Netgear. Or skip this product since its high in price for this kind of flaw. Check the forums at NETGEAR if you don't believe me. This is a 130$ paperweight.

Purchased in June 2010. Stopped working in February 2011. Great product when it works, but eight months makes it horribly expensive. If you're going to buy this, buy two at a time..... March 1, 2011: received reply from Netgear technical support telling me to do all the normal things that one would do BEFORE asking for technical support. So I would say that their technical support does not exist. Bad product with no support.

column9: Firmware Nightmare... you have been warned!
column10: Terrible firmware! Seem like they shipped this router out during development! It is ok if you are NOT... I repeat NOT going to do anything fancy like port forwarding or tiggering, and if this is the case you are way better off getting a router that is less than 100 bucks. I run a web server and it will block all incoming traffic after a while. If you are going to use this router to just surf the web then you are going to be OK with this unit. The firmware is sooo shotty that they already have like 4 or 5 different versions of it out, and the worst part is that non of them work properly anyway ( I downloaded all of them ).  I went with what I had before a linksys(cisco) router and I no longer have any problems! If you are looking to buy this I totally recommend the linksys e3000 instead!
The range is only about 12' on a consistent basis. I bought it to replace a less expensive router which turned out to out perform this new one.

I was getting about 2 bars when I was sitting right next to it.I also tried ddwrt, and openwrt on this. (restored the factory firmware).It seems like, overall, this is a nice wifi router, in general. But my particular unit had a weak radio.  I was forced to return it.
lasted 8 weeks, 3 weeks after I bought it the wireless quit and 8 weeks later port 1 is gone.

column9: Basically only has a 90 day warranty
column10: Worked great for the 3 1/2 months.  Easy to set up. Had great range.  Then we starting losing wireless signal, ocassionally, then we had none.  You can literally sit a laptop right next to this unit and the signal is unavailable.  Their tech support is a joke.  They outsoure their tech support for the first 90 days and after that they out-souce it again and want you to pay for their 'premium support' even though you went thru the e-mail support and have a claim # and an e-mail saying you have a defective unit that is still under warranty (they won't give you an RMA via e-mail you have to call) good luck getting to a person who can help you.  You call the first phone # - they give you another #, there isn't a phone option for requesting a RMA so you have to pick and choose - they transfer you to another #, then got disconnected and got to start all over again.

This is the first time I've written a review for an item, sad to say..it's because it's a terrible item and I feel like some people need to be warned about it.The router was great...when it worked or when it feels like working I guess.  The WNDR3700 router constantly drops signal, cannot even give proper wifi speeds to anything (i.e ipad, iphone, xbox 360 etc...) it's very frustrating and extremely unusable.To be honest I'm surprised that there are so many people posting great reviews for this...I've tried to contact Netgear for help, but I had to leave a voice mail, after being put on hold for 30 mins???  Who does that?  I've never had happen to me, ever...also they've yet to return my call about the issue (3 weeks ago).  I tried the forums, next to no help there, besides 'power cycle modem and router'...Not really much to say about it besides that...I've switched back to my 5 year old linksys router...and it's still giving faster Wi-Fi speeds than the WNDR3700...very sad.  Also tried to do a firmware update, but router was already running latest firmware.  From what most other customers who've bought the item say on forums it's because of interference from other signals and such so I've also tried to switch channels and double check settings, but no help.Pros :+ easy installCons :- Terrible Wi-fi speeds- Constant signal drops*This review was meant to be short and to the point.

I have been a long time Netgear fan I started with my first one being the MR814 a wireless B router which was amazing for the time.Solid performance and great security features well before the other companies like mac address filtering.  The interface over the years has not really changed features added but by far the most easy to use and understand of the routers out there.That being said I had read reports that this router may have hardware issues in REV 1.  that was when it was originally called WNDR-3700.When I saw the name change to N600 I assumed this was the REV 2 that resolved some of the issues but it was up in the air as to whether or not it was still suspect.Well when this unit arrived labeled as N600 I quickly found out it was still REV 1.  Now I still dont know if REV 2 truly fixes the issue but here is what I tested and determined.Throughput of this device was atrocious on wireless and very suspect on wired.  With my old Netgear WNDR-3500 my Gig Nic Performance was great.  Id get a burst of 130 MB / a sec off my RAIDed archive server and it would settle down to about 70 MB/sec for the duration of the transfer.  This is honestly great performance which is what I expected but the new router WNDR-3700/n600 only started at 90 MB/sec and quickly dropped to the 40 MB/sec area and in some cases the transfers PAUSED then resumed.  This had me highly suspicious as to whether data would be getting corrupted.  I also bought an E3000 from linksys to test and saw that the perf on that was identical to my original router on the wired so it did point out an issue on the netgear n600.Now the BIG ISSUE was the wireless the highest through put I got off that wireless was 4 MB/sec.  Well my old router the 3500 was no great performer either similar in speed but I expected a high performance router to welll ..... perform better.At times I noticed transfers of only 500 KB / sec when doing sustained transfers on my local network.  This was completely unacceptable since I bought this strictly for my media center extenders since the 3500 had issues sustaining HD quality network traffic.  I then set up the E3000 for identical through put tests and was able to tweak that router to delivering 20 MB/s sustained over the 2.4GHZ wireless.  This was a huge differance in bandwidth.I am very upset about this because I didnt really want to go with linksys but the bandwidth of the n600 is a problem similar to all the reports on their forums and other sites.  I guess its a crap shoot if it works or not.I will say this if they can fix those Issues I ll buy one in a second as the WIRELESS signal strength was truly amazing it has to be the strongest router i have ever seen when it comes to signal.I already am prepared to give my e3000 away for when netgear gets their act together.Keep in mind this I flashed it with the most recent firmware and it still functioned the same.  I also used DD-WRT on it and the router performance stayed the same so this is completely hardware based.  I can see if you only use the router to surf the internet that you would think this is the most amazing router because the signal can literally penetrate two houses away but even then it at times hampered my 8 Mbit connection.

column9: Does not work: Tech support can't make it work either
column10: I replaced a old (NEATGEAR) router with this product.  I could connect things up and get a wired connection.  I could not get anything in the house to see the router wirelessly.  I called there tech support and went through many settings all of which did not work.  My tech speaks english as a second laugange which made things go very slow (what?/what?/what?).  I personly feel the tech did not know much about the windows 7 operating system so I didn't think we even troubled shot if it was a network setting issue.  A long time later the tech advise me to return the router, which I will.  I put back my old router and yes virgina a get a wired connection but now nothing sees the wireless connection which worked before. So I will return this now and again later for a refund when no one can tell how to configure it and then go Ill go to BEST BUY and purchase it and then pay someone to connect it correctly.  Generaly it is easy to connect, hard to configure and understand what all the setting are and there relationship to why things are not working. In the mean time I will start looking at other products which maybe easer to use.

This is the worst router in the world. I get random horrible lag...sometimes in the worst of times(ie when I buy something and the page won't load so I have to refresh). I'm using the stock firmware. I don't care if DD-WRT is better, I believe the router should work and be functional first with it's firmware. I wish companies like this would have better quality control...even if it is just a firmware issue.
Short and sweet: This router's wireless G connection lasted a week then completely died. The N connection never worked. Very disappointing. Amazon was wonderful on the return.

First let me say that I cannot argue with the speed of this router.  It is without question the fastest router I have ever owned.  Having said that, the number of issues I have have had with the hardware and firmware for this router are just not worth the price.  This is an expensive router so set your expectations accordingly.  Be prepared for Tech Support looking to get rid of you telling you it's a PC, printer setup issue and not the router.  Be prepared to have issues fixed as new firmware comes out and all of the sudden your other hardware is functional again.  Prepare yourself for loosing your internet connection periodically for seconds at a time.  And prepare yourself for a product that just fails to deliver on all levels of quality.  Yes this router is feature rich, yes it's speed is crazy but is it worth the trouble?  I'm on my third one and about to call three strikes.  I wish you better luck.

column9: No Software Updates, Horrible Customer Service""
column10: I purchased this router 4 1/2 months ago.  The cost was higher than most, but the offered benefits seemed to warrant the additional cost.  Fortunately, I have a wireless connection that allows me to access the web from my laptop while in different rooms of my house, but that's where the product benefits stop.  I am no longer able to use the readyshare option (that stopped working after about a month) and I get constant error messages with regards to an internet connection, even though I am connected.  I tried updating the firmware from the Netgear website, hoping that would solve these issues, but I kept receiving error messages with that as well.  I called tech support, which provided no help whatsoever.  I was told that the firmware that was installed with initial setup is flawed and the additional 'support' that's been put out is also flawed, so it was removed from the company website.  I was told I would continue to receive the errors and not be able to fully use my product until the engineers at Netgear are able to put out a product that doesn't have these fundamental flaws, even though I was reporting additional problems that weren't listed on the support website.  When I pointed out that I paid for product features and services that I am not getting, and have not gotten for quite some time, I was told, in very poor, broken English, that Netgear only has to provide support for 90 days, and that essentially I was lucky I was even getting the information I was.  I have serious issue with a company that sells a product that does not function as indicated in the product specs.  I was also told by tech support that the engineers are 'well aware' of the problem and 'have been working on it.'  Considering the length of time these issues have been occurring, I have little confidence that a true resolution will ever be rolled out.  I will never buy Netgear in the future and rank their customer service as some of the worst.

[...]The most recent revision of the firmware for this product (**6.98) has known problems with constantly dropping connections.  Next firmware update not expect until Q2 2011 according to the forum post above.  I didn't investigate much further than that.I think it's pathetic for a company to release firmware which has such an obvious flaw that end users are able to find it and post about it within 4 days of the firmware release, particularly when the problem IS THAT THE ROUTER DROPS THE NETWORK CONNECTION EVERY MINUTE.  I will not be purchasing any netgear products in the future, as their testing and QA are clearly sub par.Other than not being able to maintain a network connection, this network router worked great.UPDATE: 1/22/2011:  I decided to live without simultaneous dual-band, and got a DIR-655 which I operate at 2.4 ghz.  It is stable and meets my needs.

column9: It has all the features I'm looking for but......
column10: I bought WNDR 3700 to upgrade my 7 year old but very reliable D-Link DI-624. This is one product that is suppose to be the flagship router of Netgear. It has all the bells and whistles and every features you would like in a router. Long range, gigabit, dual band, advance security features, USB for NAS and guest access. The only problem is, It won't connect to any of my wireless devices (laptop, desktop, phone, PDA, Kindle or gaming console).  I spent days trying to make it work because I really want to keep this router.  I failed on this one. I installed many routers for friends, relatives and my own,  This is the only one that is either defective or just plain garbage.  I did some research and found out that many people had problem with this model. I returned it and will try my luck on the WNDR 37AV also by Netgear.  I hope that one works fine.  For now, I'm back to using my old reliable DI-624.

column9: Nice looking unit, not so great router
column10: I don't often write reviews on things I buy but I felt the need to write a review on this terrible failure of a router.  I purchased this router based on different reviews I've read on the internet.  My previous router was a DLink DIR-825.  I'm not a long worded person so here are the facts.Pros- This router is great to look at.  The styling is better than any other in the category.- It is easy for a novice to master.  The thing basically configures itself on first power up which is cool if you don't know what you're doing.- Web interface is also easy and concise.- Cables included appears to be high quality.Cons- Web interface is extremely slow.  Every time you make a small change to the router it takes forever to return to the main page.- DHCP Reservation doesn't work at all.  I commonly set up a DHCP reservation list.  It is often easier than setting all your devices up as static.  Problem is this router often has trouble releasing the device after you have set the reservation IP address and the device keeps grabbing the dynamic address it had.  Very annoying to cycle power on the router before it accepts the reservation list.- NO REMOTE REBOOT!!!!  WTF is that?  You can not reset this unit remotely.  Every single router I've owned for 10 years now has had a remote reboot.  Unbelievable!- It has a feature called 'attached devices'.  This is great if you want to see what computers are currently attached.  Problem is it is terribly unreliable which makes it useless.  Half the time it works and displays the computers that are connected properly the other half of the time it shows some of the computers and just displays <unknown> as the computer name.  This makes it hard to reserve IP's if you don't know the computers named.- The 5Ghz has virtually no range!  I had a Netgear WNDA3100 USB WIFI stick which is Netgear's high end, high speed stick.  Wouldn't even connect to the router that has 10 feet away through one drywall wall!- The cost is VERY high for the limited 'advanced' features this router has.Conclusion?I had a netgear hardwired router about 8 years ago and swore I'd never own another netgear product.  Based on the reviews I thought I'd give them another chance.  WHAT A MISTAKE!!  If you don't know or care about any 'advanced' settings on a router and just want a standard DHCP for your home, I guess this would fit the bill but for the cost, it seems to me to be a rip off.  Netgear should be ashamed at this product!  The ONLY way I could stabilize this POS was to switch all devices to static IP.  This is a PITA for something that is supposed to be easy.

No problems setting up the NetGear WNDR3700 initially. I'm very familiar with this process on other routers. After a few hours the NetGear WNDR3700 went offline, amber light, and through various attempts cannot connect wirelessly, via cable, update firmware or even reset default factory settings to troubleshoot issues with the router. Maybe the router is defective as I've exhausted all troubleshooting options. Offshore customer support in India hung-up various times and other times put me on hold for long periods. Am returning it to BestBuy for a refund.

column9: Don't get this unless you love to type
column10: Negatives1) When configuring the device, or changing practically anything the device asks for the password CONSTANTLY, not just to log in, but for operations on the menu afterwards. All the while, the password is transmitted in the clear on the LAN. So, on the one hand they are so serious about security that the device doesn't trust that the person who logged on 4 seconds ago hasn't been pushed out of the chair by bad guys, but they completely trust the LAN so it's all a big joke anyway. A little balance would have gone a long way when designing this device.2) Forget anything you've heard about spread spectrum or frequency hopping. Pick up a wireless phone and this thing is DEAD until the call ends.PositiveIt has a seperate WiFi lan for a DMZ, which is nice for a consumer grade device.

column9: Works fine, but setup was atrocious.
column10: The router seems to work fine, BUT: the setup was a totally atrocious mess.  Although Netgear recommends this product for 'Large homes' with 'multiple floors,' the cable that is required for connecting the PC to the router during the setup is all of 4ft long!  If the router is for a large home, couldn't the engineers at Netgear have surmised that the distance between the modem/router location and the PC might be more than 4ft, and have included a longer ethernet cable?!  Even in a 'small home,' this distance might exceed 4ft.  In a rather insulting way, the instructions assume that you are connecting a laptop to the router, and hence you should have no probelm bringing the PC to the router and using the dwarf-length ethernet cord ... but perhaps Netgear is aware that there is another category of PCs known as 'desktops' that are NOT easy to transport around a 'large home?'Moving on, the software on the CD runs extremely slowly and is geared towards Windows XP only.  Of course, Windows 7 has been out and about for months and months.  Surely Netgear could have made the minor effort of writing a CD setup for this not uncommon version of Windows?

I've had bad experience with netgear product before,6month ago, my Dlink router died on me after only 2 years, so i decided to try a different major brand router and went with netgear again.After 6 month, on the first day of 2014, it died, and it didn't just died, it died fabulously with the lights on.I thought it was my modem first but i plug ethernet directly from pc to modem and i have internet access, so yes, it is the routerFiled a ticket online, lack of response, called them, automated system lacks options for you to choose from, and it doesn't tell u how long the wait time is.  When i finally got to an agent, guess what, Netgear doesn't refund, they would only exchange - why would i want more of your product?terrible experience

column9: NOT AT ALL WHAT IS ADVERTISED!
column10: First of all this had no installation instructions!Second, once I was finally able to get connected we do not get uninterrupted video streaming to our tv, we have Charter 30MBPS speed!Third, I downloaded the Netgear Genie and according to that my router does not have Guest Access as advertised, it also does not have ReadyShare access as advertised.Tried contacting Netgear for support and was told that because it is refurbished they cannot help us!More than likely going to return it and buy something else!

This router worked great for 14 months, then we noticed our internet speed was a lot slower than it used to be. We have a 15Mbps connection, but with this router we would rarely get 15Mbps. Sometimes it would be 8 Mbps, 6 Mbps, 2 Mbps, or even less than 1 Mbps. Bypassing the router gave us a speed of 15 Mbps. I contacted Netgear and they replaced this router with another one of the same model. To my surprise we had the same issue. Maybe it is a problem only with this model, but I've decided to steer clear of Netgear for now and I purchased a Medialink Wireless-N Broadband Router to replace this failed Netgear router.

I ordered this router because it was time to upgrade from my older router that had a good run of about 5 years. It worked fine for a few months but at this point It only works well for about a day at a time if I'm lucky. Most of the time, my connection to the internet on my xbox and laptop/iPad is very spotty. I've tried different configurations, setting it to stay on one wireless channel, and resetting it multiple times. Customer service for netgear is terrible (person from another country with a weird accent terrible) and they wanted to charge me $30+ for any sort of assistance since my 1 year warranty was expired. I'm ready to launch this router straight into the garbage can and never buy another netgear product ever again.

If you try to follow the instruction on how to set your router and type in [...], it will get re-direct to other page. All I need is to get to my router configurations..it should be straightforward but it was not. Fortunately, my profession is 'IT' and even with years of experience, I was frustrated...although I got to where I wanted to go....eventually.This is my first NetGear and will be my last. I happened to spent a lot of time on the road during this time of year and by the time I got some time it was too late to return it. I don't know what I was thinking. For consumer grade wireless router, I should have stayed with LinkSys.I give it a lowest rating because of two things.1] It shuts down occasionally for some unknown reason.2] I also purchased a NetGear USB adapter in hope that it will be less likely to give me trouble because these two products are from same manufacture. To my disappointment, sometimes it tooks almost five minutes before the light on the NetGear USB adapter turns from blue to amber (which mean connected).3] Their Tech Support is not very helpful.

column9: Good product but BROKE IN 3 MONTHS
column10: all the positive reviews for this product are mostly true with ONE FATAL FLAW.  good setup, good features, good range, etc. etc.  HOWEVER, after a few months, it stopped working and started making a weird high pitched sound, due to my Time Warner cable which resets it's signal every 6-12 months.  This is normal and I've dealt with that many times with other routers by just plugging and unplugging the modem and router, no problems after.  To have such a universal and normal thing blow up the modem is a major failure...you KNOW it will break, which sucks after paying 2-3 times the price of other n routers.  FAIL.

column9: Stay away from this router if you do not have time to waste
column10: Did my usual research on Amazon, Cnet and Newegg before choosing a new wireless router as I was hoping to get a better wireless range than the one I get with my old and trusted Linksys wrt54g router.Based on users rating, I picked the Netgear WNDR3700.Install and set-up were really easy and range was great but got problems right away as I started to lose my internet connection every other day. After much time spent researching the issue and talking to Netgear support in India, I am almost ready to give up and ask for a refund.Last chance attempt: ask for a replacement from Amazon and see if the new one works better.For the time being can just caution potential buyers to stay away from product.

column9: Does not play well with others
column10: A not high-end appliance. Provides for little to no flexibility in performing a role in an existing network.
It's a good product, but LAN (and WAN) transfer speeds are soooooo soooooooooo soooooooo soooooooo slow. don't expect to get anything over 1.5MB on your local wireless LAN. That's just pathetic.

I'll keep it simple: I purchased, 10 year DSL user with several wireless routers successfully working.  Every day I've had to restart this thing. After trying many things and working with Netgear support, they acknowledged that there is a probably memory leak on this unit with no known fix.Be warned that this 'leak' has been going on now for as long as the device has been on the market with no fix in sight.

After shopping around for a while and reading all the reviews I decided on the Netgear WNDR3700. Good value or the options it offers, though certainly not the cheapest. Followed the setup word for word.  Got to where the cd is supposed to recognize the router and it said it was not the router. Unclear if its incompatible with windows 7 or not. The main issue I have is tech support guy twice tried to get me to call back later when it would be someone else's problem. Finally after several wires and different computers he admitted it was a bum router.  Its ok to have some out of the box failures, how many they have I don't know. But the hassle factor is large. No off to pack it up and wait for the refund.

Received this router and hooked it up with the help of customer support...finally. It took a couple hours and was frustrating.It was working fine but nothing spectacular considering I have the fastest speed cable internet Cox has to offer. Then I went to change the priorities and from that point on the router is almost useless. I even changed back to the original settings and nothing. Then I updated the firmware and it even got worse.Now my internet is slow, I can't play one single round of Bomberman on my PS3 without it freezing up completely to the point of having to hold down the power button on the Playstation to turn it off.Called back support and now they tell me I need to pay another $69 for special tech support or they can't help me. I can probably call back and get that straightened out where I don't have to pay but this is ridiculous to go through this for a supposed high end router.This piece of junk is going back. To be honest my cheap $20 belkin I purchased from Walmart 2 years ago out performed this overall.I just ordered a SMC gigabit router from Amazon and will let you know how it works out.

I bought this router. It worked fine, for 4 month. Then one day the wifi lose the signal. They claim it has 1 year warranty. So I called Netgear. To my surprise, they claims it only has 90 days warranty. I have to pay 35.00 for half hour to talk to their support guy! the 1 year labor and month warranty does not cover the talk! There is no Netgear document mentions this 90 days warranty. To me it is just bold cheating! I expect better on this high-end router!

column9: Netgear N600 wireless dual band gigabite ADSL2+modem router
column10: This is the WORST router I have ever owned, died on me after 14 months, when I called Netgear tech support, they were unable to help me resolve the problems because the lights on the modem were not coming on. One of the worst companies to deal with, go buy your modem/router elsewhere.I was on the phone with tech support for half an hour & was switched around few times.This is bad business. I'm sure other manufacturers will love to have my business
Can't get it to work and the instructions that came with it do not help at all. I am very frustrated.

I have had this for 2 weeks now and it is the worst router I ever had.  The program is nice but I keep getting dropped signal. I try to click on a link and the page will not load right and have to keep hitting F5 to refresh.  I have not found anything in my house including a new tv that uses the 5G part of the second band of the router.  I am ready to trash this thing if Amazon don't replace it with a different brand. Going to try to return it asap.

Usually, i like NetGear Products. That's reason i bought it. But, this one has lots of issue of dropping connection and we cause interfere with Vonage and Surfing over the Internet. I tried everything what was i supposed to do. But Did not work. Finally gave up..

Sales document failed to mention a critical issue...something that pops up as soon as you load the installation disk: if you are using replacing a router attached to a cable modem, you cannot change brands. I had a lynksys router. On screen instructions said I had to stay with a lynksys router! That would have been helpful information BEFORE I bought it!

column9: Wireless dies when bandwidth exceeds 2.4MBPS, Lousy tech support
column10: Let me start out this review with an old Latin proverb: Caveat emptor!I bought this router because it supplied the latest features for the least amount of money. I was wary of purchasing another Netgear product because I have not had the best of luck with the brand in the past (on three different occasions), however a majority of tech review websites and individuals alike gave it positive reviews and I decided to give the brand another shot.To that end, I very much regret my purchasing decision and I am extremely disappointed in this product. I will never buy another Netgear device for the rest of my days.Whenever total bandwidth on all wireless devices (all channels combined) exceeds 2.4 megabytes per second, the router resets itself. It just flat out dies and does a hard reboot. This will happen at sustained download speeds of 1.5 megabytes per second as well if you give it enough time. In fact, as I am writing this, I am downloading World of Warcraft: Wrath of the Lich King, and it has died numerous times already - and I am obviously not very far into writing this review!I have tested this on three different computers: two desktops, one connected to the 2.4 ghz wireless N, another connected to the 5 ghz wireless N, and a laptop connected to the 2.4 ghz wireless N. The two desktops are currently connecting via a Linksys AE1000 dual band wireless N adapter, and the laptop is connected by a Gigabyte internal 2.4 ghz wireless N adapter. When any one of them or all of them combined are taking up 2.4MBPS in bandwidth, the router resets. As you can imagine, this is quite infuriating.Worse yet, when I called Netgear tech support they had me jump through hoops for two hours over two different sessions just to change the basic wireless settings and executing power cycles on both the router and the modem. They even told me to try plugging the router's power in to a different outlet! Keep in mind also, that this was all after I had gathered and shared with them the information I had about the mysterious cap to download speeds! How ridiculous! They ultimately told me that my hardware was faulty - a no-brainer if I ever heard one - and they would replace it free of cost, but I had to mail them my router first and wait for them to process and diagnose it and ship me another one, which would take up to 2 weeks. They did have an option to ship a router to me, but I would have to pay them $20 for express mailing it, and I had a one-week grace period from the date they ship it to me for me to get my broken one to them, or they would charge me the full MSRP of the unit! Completely ludicrous from a consumer's standpoint.Aside from these two issues, all the gigabit ports work completely fine, but the 5 ghz broadcast has terrible range - about half that of the 2.4 ghz broadcast. I have not tested the USB ReadyShare feature, but if it works as advertised, it should prove useful to individuals who share a lot of computers and files over a household, or would like a simple wireless backup option.So there's my review. Practically all negative. Shame on Netgear for putting out such a terrible product (and shame on me for giving them more of my money when they had failed me multiple times in the past). If I could return this product, I would, and I would get the Apple Airport Extreme instead. From everything I have heard it is the most reliable router on the market.

column9: Beware: Does not work with Acer
column10: I replace a Belkin router with this Netgear router yesterday. Two HP Laptops connected quite easily.  However, I have not be able to get my Acer access to the internet if any security is enabled. It connects to the router, but cannot get out on the net.  I have searched the internet, and the problem has been encountered by many people, and so far I have not found an answer.What is even worse is the combination of rudeness and incompetency of the tech support line.  They insisted it was my Norton firewall causing this problem.  when I asked if Netgear was incompatible with Norton, he asked me 'what do you think is causing the problem'.  After the 5th time he asked me that, I asked to speak to the supervisor, who was not rude, but no more helpful.  We shut off the firewall, and of course it still didn't work.  He was going to call me back within 2 hours, and that was 8 hours ago.  I do not expect to hear from them, and have wasted enough time on this router.  Fortunately there are other brands out there.  This one goes back tomorrow.  If you own an ACER, please search the internet to see how prevalent this problem is before purchasing this router, unless you do not need to enable security.

column9: This router is not compatible with VOIP phone
column10: I bought this router because I trusted all the good reviews from Amazon reviews. Nothing has been true, believe me. This router gave me lots of headache and costs me lots of time and the problem has not been solved yet as of today. I have spent many times and hours talking to tech support and still I could not get connection with my VOIP phone. How can the customers contact me if my phone is not working? The router could not push the DNS address to the VOIP phone. The VOIP phone kept displaying 'Checking DNS'. Netgear tech support (many techs) could not help me to solve the problem after unchecking all the firewall, ect. At home I have a 6-year old D-link router, it works like charm. This router never gave me any problem when I connect my VOIP business phone and private VOIP adapter for home line to it. Does anyone encounter this problem when trying to connect VOIP with this Netgear router?There was another minor problem when I first tried to set up the router. The automatic set up was not compatible with my 64-bit Window Vista.This router simply does not reflect any good reviews or fulfill product description. I wonder whether some of the good reviews were written by Netgear themselves.The tech supports were patient, understandable and providing good customer service even they are not native English speakers BUT THE PRODUCT IS VERY BAD.I never wrote any review before because of time consuming. This is the first time I write a review because I want to share my bad experience which could help other potential buyer.

The guest service disables the wifi.Tech support is ONLY from India.  I spoke with 3 people.The connection is terrible. They can't hear me, I can barely hear them.5 second delay with every sentence.What a struggle.  They promised me a 30 minutes call back.  FOUR hours later nothing.Does any wifi router have US based tech support?

column9: JUST SAY NO!  UNLESS YOU LIKE CALLING TECH SUPPORT!
column10: As of 6/7/10 there is a known glitch that makes the proudly trumpeted guest network inoperable and/or removes secure wireless encryption.  It has been known about at least since March of 2010 but they are still selling this junk.  When that is fixed (3 months and counting), it may be ok.  The 5 GHz frequency has a range of about 20 feet so that is also a big disappointment.  Here is a thread complaining about the guest network.  Notice the start date of this thread also.  [...]

column9: 2 out of 3 FAILED TO WORK. It's a waste of time.
column10: This is an amazing router, if the one you have actually works. I got one in April and it worked wonderfully. It's jam packed with features like guest network, USB disk mount, N router on different channels, etc etc. I loved it. I've used Linksys, Belkin, and Dlink, and they all work ok but this is one of the best routers I've ever used. The menus are a bit awkward, but that's normal for a router that is jam packed with great features that I need.In fact, I loved my first WNDR3700 so much I got two more for my workplace. I got one from Amazon and another one from Fry's Electronics. I configured both to be identical configurations (except for SSID names, etc). Both had the same problem-- the b/g network SSID fail to pop up when I'm on AUTO channel mode. When I set it to channel 11, it would show up except trying to connect to it via WPA2 would not connect at all! To make matters worse, every time I try to change a wireless configuration, the router would halt 2 minutes, then shut off the wireless automatically for no particular reason! I would then have to turn the wireless back on manually. On my good WNDR3700, it would only wait 5 seconds and voila, it simply worked. Here's my question for you techies at Netgear-- why is it that the wireless for these two router turn off automatically after I configure anything on it? Why is it that WPA doesn't connect? Why does the g network disappear if I set to AUTO? Why does it take 2 minutes for each configuration change to occur? I don't have any of these problems on my first WNDR3700.I returned both of these junk and now I'm considering DLINK. FYI, at Fry's MOST of the WNDR3700 routers were returned routers, which says a lot about the quality of these routers. It's great that Netgear comes out with great products but if they don't have any quality control, their superb products are just junk. I wasted an entire day trying to figure out why the two routers didn't work like my first one. What a waste of time.JUNK.

I purchased this product because I have a long history with Netgear, their features, and their reliability.  The basic features of this router work very well and are easy to set up.  One of the key new features, support for a guest SSID, DOES NOT WORK.  And this has not worked on any of the Netgear WNDR routers they have sold since February.  And they have known this, since their own forum is the source.  (See [...])I am appalled that Netgear would knowingly sell a defective product, one where one of the key selling features did not work, to their customers.  And then make them figure this out, call their customer support line, and either have to live without this feature or return the router.DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT TILL THEY FIX THIS ISSUE.

I bought the WNDR3700 to replace an old but reliable WRT54G running dd-wrt firmware.At first I was put off by the antiquated user interface, but after a while I was able to find the essential settings.  Most of the useful features I need were there and I was able to set up things like static IP addresses fairly easily.Most changes to settings seem to take an eternity to take effect.  It's hard to believe that the router has a fast processor when the 200MHz processor in the Linksys is so much more responsive.Then the problems started.  I tried to turn on the guest network and both radios shut off.  I tried the button on the front of the router as well as the settings on the admin pages and couldn't get the radios to turn on until I shut off the guest network.  Netgear provided a beta firmware which solved this problem, but it didn't fix any of the other problems.I found that my new LG BD570 Blu-ray player could connect to the router, but couldn't auto assign an IP address.  Then I noticed that my old Palm T|X couldn't see the SSID nine times out of ten and was never able to connect no matter which combination of WPA settings I used.The combination of a slow and unattractive user interface, bugs and compatibility problems have forced me to return this router.

Unit looked good from specs and other reviews, HOWEVER...After I completed setup, I noticed that this router would not list my network printer as a device that could be assigned a DHCP reservation, so I accepted the suggestion on the internal management website to check for a firmware upgrade.  An 'upgrade' was automatically found, and I accepted the suggestion to install it.  This was a mistake, as the 'upgrade' bricked the box unrecoverably.  After a long session with tech support, I finally was told that the firmware recovery utility on the CD is apparently not expected to ever work, and they asked me to return the unit for a refund, which I did and ordered a D-Link.I think it's truly pathetic that a manufacturer coudl design a product that's capable of bricking itself.  I know what I'm talking about, as engineering manager for a company that makes (not networking) products that have updatable firmware.  Not taking the precautions to check the file, have a fall-back position, etc., is just irresponsible.  Will avoid Netgear in the future.

They falsely advertise this product as having a usable installation CD to make it easy. DOES NOT WORK WITH WINDOWS 7!! Very pricey for nothing.  Tried 3 days to install, but would not work. Their customer service techs were unable to help.  Told me to call the Geek Squad. You can set it up alright, just can't connect.I returned it to Amazon with no questions asked. My account showed a credit in less than 3 days.I ended up purchasing the Cisco-Linksys E2000. Took about 2 minutes to get it working.  The Cisco router has been great for my home network.  It has been a month and no problems at all!

column9: Really mad at Netgear, and this box
column10: I bet you think I'm over the top here ... but I am not, I have legitimate reasons to trash thisdevice and here they are:1) First, out of the box ... and I just got this a week or so ago, some features, which Netgear made me  promise in an email not to discuss - DO NOT WORK.  I had to go through talking to three or four  really novice support people before I finally got someone that gave me a firmware upgrade so that  the box would work.2)  There is no feature to test your email address.alerts and warnings, like there used to be on the other  two netgear routers I used to own.3) The wireless will not work unless you manually press the enable button on the front panel.  This  means that you have to be in pressing distance of that button any time you reboot, power off,  have a power failure, or in some cases even change your configuration, because I found under  several circumstances the wireless disables itself when changes are made to the configuration of  the box.4) The monitoring capability is the same as an over 10 year old router that I used to have.  This is  supposed to be state of the art, and all it can do is tell me what devices on my local net are  'connected' ... whatever that is supposed to mean ... 'connected' how.5) There is no software reboot as well.6) The configuration of the proxies and ports is about the same as the 10 year old router, but  the interface is more clumsy.There is so much about this product that is irritating, I am sure that I am leaving somethingsignificant out, but I am not going to spend all day on this review.I can tell you I would rather go to the dentist with no novacaine while having my leg amputatedthat deal with Netgear support.  What happened to Netgear's network products?  Where is theprogress, the innovation??The ReadyNAS Pioneer Pro is such an amazing piece of hardware that I cannot really believethat it was made by the same company, and it really was not.The design decisions in this router are two or three giant leaps backwards from whatNetgear already had.Find something else ... and if you cannot find anything better, at least find somethingcheaper.  Maybe Hawking Technologies, they are the up and coming hungry tech companythat is actually trying to make decent products.UPDATE ... after all the BS I had to go through, now I am getting a series of emails fromNetgear asking about my customer experience.  But I have to log in and create an accountin their webasite to be able to do that.  Why on Earth should I have to do that when theyhave my email address and sent me the link.  These people are idiots, and their uppermanagement will never figure out how bad their customer sat. ratings are because it isway too much trouble to leave any feedback.What happened to this company.  This thing should never have made it out the door.The router had been out for almost a year before I bought mine and still there was nota fix for the guest network, and not to mention again the daft design choices or notbeing able to reboot the the device or turn on the wireless without pressing a hardwarebutton.

column9: iPhone, iPad and Drobo users - beware! Doesn't work!
column10: I'm a computer guy. I've always set up my own home networks and I'm always the one my friends call to troubleshoot theirs. So if I can't get this working at my house - you will probably have issues too.THE GOOD:The internet (via hard connection) works fine. The Gigabit transfer speed from one computer (PC) to another (Mac) is blazing fast. It took about 4 seconds to move a 700mb movie from one computer to the other.THE BAD:The Modem/Router settings interface is terrible and looks totally out of date. Like a webpage that was designed 10 years ago. My Linksys settings interface was much nicer and more user friendly.THE UGLY:Some features just simply won't work. I tried connecting my Drobo to the USB port to turn it into a NAS. It wouldn't even show up in the router settings. I connected a regular HD via a USB dock and it could read that just fine. If you're a Drobo owner beware this setup probably won't work for you.My 3G (2nd gen) iPhone can't even see the network. Any of them. b/g/n doesn't matter. None of them even show up, even with SSID broadcasting and even when I tried to enter the network name manually. My iPad can see the '5G' network (their name for N), but it can't connect to it. The other networks (b/g) don't show up at all.My iMac is hard wired, but it's wireless router can see the 5G network and connects to it without asking for a password (I've got WEP turned on but for some strange reason the network shows up as unlocked and unsecured). My Mac Mini can also see the 5G and sees it as unsecured. It can connect to it, but I can't load a browser window. Firefox shows I'm not connected to the internet despite the fact that my AirPort indicator shows me  as connected with full signal strength.I simply can't believe how impossible this router has been to get working. I've spend about 5 hours trying to figure it out and no luck. It's getting returned tomorrow.

column9: Don't waste your time and money
column10: I setup two wired and three wireless computers. All of them lost connectivity within the first couple of hours. Not just to the internet, I could not even reach the router's configuration page.So I rebooted the router and everything was fine. Couple of hours later same issue. I can understand various things can go wrong with internet and wireless connections such as interferences etc. but a wired connection to the router.. come on.. networking 101. I ran my linksys for over an year without ever touching or rebooting it.I am running the latest firmware as of May 19 2010.Don't even get me started on the software configuration issues. Just as an example, the firmware updater checks and prompts me to upgrade to a newer version everytime I reboot the router. If I click yes, it goes to the website wastes few minutes and then prompts that there is nothing to update and I know that because I just updated an hour ago.Please don't waste your time and money.

I bought the NETGEAR WNDR3700 as an upgrade to my NETGEAR WNR854T N GB router, which has been working fine for over a year.  The WNDR3700 worked fine at first and then started dying a few hours after the initial install.  At that point, I spent a whole Sunday afternoon with three Netgear techs, going down one dead end checklist after another.  After I was told to unplug all of the USB devices connected to my desktop system I asked why.  They said it was to selectively test for radio interference. At that point, I'm asking myself what's wrong with this picture?In my neighborhood, I've got several wi-fis broadcasting.  The shoe drops.  This router is does not play well with others.  I reinstalled my NETGEAR WNR854Trouter and returned this installation nightmare to Amazon.

DO NOT BUT ANYTHING FROM NETGEARNetgear has the worst customer service I have ever experienced.The 1st unit I received was broken. The motherboard was completely loose in the case.The second unit crashed. The customer rep kept asking me the same question over & over. I asked for a supervisor, I had to ask 7 times to get this incompetent person to transfer me. I waited over 20 minutes - NO SUPERVISOR.  I called back and again asked for a supervisor - this time I had to ask 18 times!!! After another 20 minutes on hold FINALLY the supervisor Bob Hill got on the line. When I asked who to file a complaint with he refused to tell me and hung up on me.I WILL NEVER BUY ANYTHING FROM NETGEAR AGAIN!!!THERE EQUIPMENT DOES NOT WORK AND THE HAVE NO CUSTOMER SERVICE.If I could give 0 or negative stars I would.

I had issues with the router since day one and thought it was my fault since I had it connected to a Home Server, two laptops, and PS3.  The router would constantly reset on its own or when I tried to view a movie that was downloaded to the home server and played back on the PS3 (Connected by LAN) or to the laptop (Wireless N).  Thinking, the issue was with the Home Server I kept the unit.  About a month later the router would constantly restart when I did a search on the web.I finally called the customer service and went through all the steps.  The final straw came when they told be to do a hard reset and reload the firmware.  Then the router stopped working.  I ended up getting a RMA with Netgear but had to pay an extra $30 for express shipping.  They sent me a replacement that was re-furbished and scratched up.Now, I am able to view movies using my laptop but not with my PS3.  Now I get lost connection issues and the movie stops playing and of course the router resets again only on the PS3.Save yourself the pain and anguish.  Research and go to the Netgear forum before you buy this router.  Too many problems.Recommended you do not buy this router!

Purchased product several months ago and finally got some time to upgrade from my old router yesterday. After initial success getting the product to work for about twenty minutes it then failed and could no longer be recognized by it's own set up software.  Contacted Help desk for Netgear twice and got disconnected both times. They have my phone number but when we got disconnected they did not call me back and I had to start over. After going through all the basics the technician asked to reset the router defaults back to factory and then we were disconnected. At that point I called customer support and asked if they would give me a refund - they declined since it would require additional verification that the product was defective. At that time I decided not to waste anymore time and eat the $175 cost of the router. Netgear Case #11821288. I'll be looking for a replacement from a different company.

column9: Stopped Working all of a sudden
column10: After reading several reviews on Amazon from people who were experiencing problems, I figured I would save the energy and go straight to the source, I tried emailing Netgear using their email address through Amazon but got no reply, I guess you have to write a bad review to get help from them.  My NetGear router stopped working on 12/13/13.  I have had the router that I bought from Amazon since September 18, 2012.  I really like the router which I bought because it was recommended from a friend, and I have recommended it to others as well.  This is the first time ever experiencing any problems.  This is a huge inconvenience to our household because of the high internet traffic.  We do not have cable TV or satellite TV service we use internet to watch Netflix, HuluPlus, and Amazon Prime.  I have all 4 ports with 2 blu-ray players, VoIP phone, and a desktop PC hardwired in.  We use tablets and smartphones on the same wireless network.  This is all powered from Charters 30meg internet.  I am currently using the internet by bypassing the router, which is an inconvenience to us.  I paid $90 about a year ago for this router.  I figure I will just chock this up to a lost and buy another router.  I will be reading all reviews to see which is the best.  I will be shopping for a high end industrial strength wireless router this week.  I will not spend much time messing with troubleshooting my current router, I will just go buy a new router and be done.

There was a slight increase in wifi range with this router, but didn't notice any other clear differences.My MAJOR issue with this router is that it would disconnect ALL computers from the internet, multiple times a day. The internet was fine, and the router/modem lights actually showed there was still an active connection. However, this isn't a new problem with NETGEAR apparently... on here and their forums people are posting about the same problem. The good reviews outweighed the bad though, so I gave it a chance. I also saw that NETGEAR support was posting and saying to contact them.NETGEAR CHARGES YOU TO CALL TECH SUPPORT... $39.99 for one phone call. No thanks. Returned. Thanks Amazon.

column9: Don't waste your money! I'll never buy Netgear again.
column10: I have had this router for two years and it is garbage. It constantly drops wifi connections even if you are less than 5 feet away, it has issues resolving IP addresses, and the list goes on and on. I have to restart it almost everyday to get it to accept the 2 smartphones and tablets that connect to it. I have read hundreds of posts with people experiencing the same problem with no resolution available from Netgear.Every time I spoke to Netgear tech support it was do this or that to the firmware. I've upgraded and downgraded the firmware more times than I can count and it never solved the issue. One tech support guy told me to not use the USB because it has issues. When I asked for my money back because of the USB issue he told me that wasn't possible.I had a Linksys router for years and never had problems like this. I will never waste a single dime on a product or service from this company again.Overall, terrible company, support, and product.

column9: 5 weeks old and DEAD, KAPUT, MUERTE!!!!!!
column10: We had rated it at about a four prior to today.  The reason why we only would have given four stars is that they shipped it out without the requisite firmware.  My computer guru( #3 son) had to update the firmware a couple of times, the last time last night.  This morning, no Internet, just a buzzing router with no lights flashing!  So, since we are just under the wire w/ Amazon, we're going to send it back and get a replacement, hopefully it will not behave the same way.  There should have been no problems, but we did have 12 wireless devices running on it.  That's why we got it, so it would handle our heavy wireless use.Will update with info on replacement...

I never write reviews, but given my horrible experience with this router I felt I must.  First, the product was easy to setup as well as configure.  I was really happy that finally I would not have dropped connections and have better range.  To my utter dismay, after everything was setup and working, the router started dropping connections every 3 minutes and the range was about 1 foot.  Luckily Amazon is pretty good about returns and this product is going back.  Bottom line: I think that for the price the quality control should be much better as this router was totally defective and I am going to go with Linksys.  DO NOT BUY!!!

I bought this router with a few simple expectations over my old D-Link 524 wireless G router: 1) Increased signal strength 2) Increased range 3) Freedom from microwave interference and 4) Faster Ethernet.  Unfortunately, it fell short in almost all aspects.First, when I installed the router, the automatic firmware installation indicated that there was a new firmware update, but that the system could not find the file specified.  I downloaded the firmware update from the Netgear website, but when I refreshed the configuration page, I got redirected to kb.netgear.com and could not get back to the configuration page until after refreshing my IP address!Next, when navigating through the configuration pages, I kept getting a message that stated 'The system cannot find the file specified'  I refreshed the page and got bounced to kb.netgear.com and was only able to get back to the configuration page by refreshing the IP address!After finally getting the firmware updated, I set up the wireless connections.  There is a wireless network for each band (2.4 and 5), which is not what I expected, but I could live with that if the range and speed were good.  Not so.  The 5GHz band barely showed up in my office, which had a decent signal with my old router.  The 2.4GHz signal showed up a bit better than the 5GHz signal did, but still not as good as my old one.  A huge disappointment.On the positive side, the gigabit Ethernet was fast, and when I was able to connect to the 5GHz signal, I did not have interference from the microwave.This was definitely not what I expected from a much newer device promising so many great features, and with so many great reviews.  With all the other routers out there with almost an equal number of positive and negative reviews, I'm going to take a wild guess that some routers work better in some houses than others.  Despite that, the setup frustration I experienced would be enough for the average user to stay clear of this router.

When it works, this router is fine. The 2.4ghz range and throughput is everything one could want. As written about other routers, 5ghz range is quite limited. The usb hard drive functiality is very very slow. Nowhere near a replacement for a NAS.I've been experiencing lockups about once a week. After multiple calls, tech said probably a hardware problem. That's when I find out that it is Netgear's policy to charge for swapping the router. If I want to send it in and wait for a replacement,its free. If I want them to send me working router first, and then send back the defective unit, they charge $16.00! This is a first in my experience. In addition,their own community shows lots of postings about this weekly lock up problem (see : [...])All in all, not very happy to have to throw more money at a one month old router that is supposed to be Netgear's top of the line.Update: received replacement RMA router. It still has the same problem, and now my 90 day support window is closed. There is no email for netgear support to even inform them of a bug. Looks like I'll be spending more money on a Linksys soon. Netgear = buggy router, and infuriating support and support policies.

I purchased this router and within 3 days it was constantly achieving very slow speeds.  My wireless clients would drop to 1Mbps when any traffic was put through it and as soon as a download was paused it would revert back to 135-150Mbps (the max for this adapter).  Even after restoring factory settings and having an hour or so of success, it still went back to this behavior.  Their online forums were no help at all, and I did not pay $160 to sit there and troubleshoot it, so I returned it.  I do not recommend this router, even if most people gave it 5 stars.  I went by their recommendations and got burned.  I'll be going with a Linksys instead.

I've never written a review but all the reviews and netgear materials failed to mention that this router doesn't not support port translation. Case in point, when I tried to set up SSH connection to two computers connected to the router at port 2000 and 2001 and forward the ports to 22 on two ip addresses, the router would complain that my end port number is smaller than start port and refuse to do so. Now my 4 year-old D-link G router can do this simple thing but not this brand new top-of-the-line router! The only way around this is to configure sshd on two computers to listen to different ports. But to me this is purely unacceptable such a pricey router wouldn't do simple port translation. On netgear forum, their staff simply says port translation is an 'enterprise' feature and suggest those of us who need this function look at their business line - What an excuse! I am returning this router because it's missing such an important function.

NETGEAR should prominately display that their software does not work with Windows 7 - 64 bit.  The installation reviews are obviously for older versions of Windows.  Amazon should also be more forthright.

This looks like a good router, but the fact is that it is not reliable.  I have had this device just over 30 days and today it started rebooting constantly and even after powering off and on, etc. it is not working.  I called NetGear and picked the correct selections and got hung up on three times!  Later I got server errors trying to submit an online case!This company should be ashamed.  I have owned multiple Linksys devices and not had any problems for years.  Both NetGear products I have owned have been junk! Pray you don't run this on a separate segment (not directly connected to the Internet), because if you do it assigns itself as the DNS server and it has no clue about SRV records.  This device is not worth the box it was sent in!I would stay away from this device at all costs, unless you enjoy pain.

This router was not any better than my previous cheaper router.  I did not notice significant speed increase.
