I don't know if this has to do with that fact that its refurbished, either way for any of you who do not have issues i am happy to hear that for the rest of us, i feel bad having to deal with slow response and bad customer service from Netgear. My next router will definitely not be from Netgear.

column9: Great, at first, but then sucks
column10: I bought this router in December 2010.  It worked fantastically right from the start.  It is now, November 5, 2011 (11 months after purchasing the router).  Two days ago, my wife unplugged the router in order to clean up the area where it was stored.  She then plugged the router back in, and, all of a sudden it's wireless range cratered and has since not returned.  We have no problem using the router to connect to the internet wirelessly so long as we're in the same room as the router.  But once we move into an adjacent room, all bets are off- we get no wireless connection.As stated earlier, this was not a problem until two days ago, before that I was happy.  A router that costs as much as this one does should not have this kind of problem only one year after it was purchased.

column9: Great for 9 months. Then it goes in the trash.
column10: So I purchased this item in December of last year from Best Buy. 2 weeks ago, the range for the wireless died and I am unable to get a wireless connection unless I am in the same room as the router. After reading the reviews from the customers here, this is a common issue. It seems the wireless antenna lasts about 9 months. I have contacted Tech Support via phone and email only to have them put me through hours of wasted efforts. First, I was told to manually try all 11 channels this router can utilize from their routerlogin site. After this failed, I was told to try a couple firmware updates.To top it all off, tech support will not give me a replacement unit. In their system, it shows that I purchased this unit in September of last year. I know I did not purchase this till December because that is when I moved into my new house. I am assuming they go off of the sell date to the reseller.Make a long story short...Do not buy this unit. If you do, purchase it from Amazon where it will keep a record of all your purchases. That way you can prove your purchase date beacuse this thing will die on you within the year and atleast you can get a replacement. To the trash she goes.

I have the similar 3800 which has all kinds of features but that doesn't matter b/c it's not reliable.  Every few days the wireless networks stop working.  I'm contacting netgear's support now to see what's happening and will update this review once I've heard from them.

column9: Warranty worth less than monopoly money
column10: The device failed after 4 months of use. When I called Netgear, they said that my warranty expired (which isn't true) and that the only way to get support was to pay them $79 per year. After several phone calls and much arguing, someone agreed to help. I was then transferred to an incredibly incompetent 'technician' who made me change wireless settings when I clearly told him that the connection between my computer and the router is actually wired. After much back and forth, firmware upgrades, etc. he agreed to transfer me to a supervisor. We then went through the same process and the supervisor was clearly no more competent, so he transferred me to 'Level 1' support. I tell you, there are more layers of bureaucracy in this company then all third-world governments combined. And the problem is that every time the call is disconnected - which happens frequently - you have to renavigate that maze (i.e. argue again that you shouldn't need to pay $79 to have your warranty honored) in order to get to the same level you were at. Finally after about 6 hours on the phone somebody agreed to send me a replacement but I had to ship my router to them at my expense, which I did. Two weeks later they claimed to still have not received my shipment although it was actually delivered the next day. When I provided tracking details to the agent, they finally acknowledged receipt of my package, and shipped me a 'refurbished' router. To my horror, I discovered that the refurbished router was my own router and that it was not fixed in any way and still had the same problem! So back to square one with the sleazy salesperson trying to get me to pay $79 for support again. This time, with more experience under my belt, I managed to get to 'Level 1' support within about 3 hours. When they could not solve my problem, I was transferred to a 'Level 2' technician who also could not figure it out - although this was the first time I felt that the person on the other end knew anything about computer networking but still much less than needed - and suggested escalating to 'Level 3' support. I never got the privilege to speak with Level 3 but I got relayed instructions from them through my Level 2 technician which included things like 'try the router in another home instead', or 'send us proof that it's not working', or the worst one, 'sign the following confidentiality agreement before we are able to send you a software update that MAY solve your problem'. I didn't go for that because I had already tried the router somewhere else and used DD-WRT firmware which didn't work either so I knew it was not a software issue. I asked for a refund instead as it was clear the case was hopeless. I was told that someone from 'customer service' will call me back within a few hours to work with me on that. It's been 2 weeks and I still haven't heard back, even after calling them to check the status a couple of times. So basically the Netgear strategy seems to be:1- design unreliable products that often fail after a few months of use2- when they eventually break, make more money from the customer by charging them an arm and a leg for completely incompetent technical support3- whatever you do, don't let them get in touch with someone in the US or at least someone who is able to make a decision. Keep them lost between all the different levels of customer support while not acknowledging that their problem could be due to faulty hardware until they realize they've already wasted 13 hours dealing with you and remember that there are much better uses of their time.Finally, to paraphrase another reviewer, 'I would rather have several teeth pulled at the dentist's without pain relievers while having my leg amputated at the same time than having to deal with Netgear support'

column9: Refurbished Product sometimes not a good deal
column10: The Netgear WNDR3700 is a highly rated item and the reviews are good and bad. You have to remember when reading reviews about a router from other users their experience is based on their location and any interference around the router. I have bought refurbished before and have always received a very good products, that is up until now. I have used Netgear products for years and was always happy so I tried this router. It connected easy and was up and running quickly, but the signal was poor, even with my laptop sitting just 4 feet from the router. my older WGR614 Netgear router preformed for years at an excellent signal up to 30 feet from the router and I had to change back to using it. The Netgear service tech tried and help we correct the signal issues with a firmware update and other tips. In the end the router never preformed up to the standards so I returned it. I believe this happens to be a one time defective router and it was a refurbished router. It makes me wonder if Netgear is really looking at hardware issues or just software when the refurbish the items. I would try another one but only newly manufactured.

The worst performanace ever.  Clearly has flawed firmware.  I have to reset daily.  Lots of great features - but who cares?  Primary function should be reliable operation.  Only bought this thing due to a friends urging.  Back to Linksys/Cisco for me.  I used to be an SE for Cisco and the old saying is true - you never get fired for buying cisco.

Unit was working fine upon purchase but apparently underwent hardware failure. As of 2 days ago the 2.4ghz band only transmits sufficiently when devices are in the same room, near the unit. You can actually watch the signal strength die when walking a device with a signal image about 10 feet away. Bottom line, our second floor laptops no longer operate nor does our Roku.  Very disappointed and now too late for warranty coverage.

column9: Don't waste your money on this piece of junk
column10: This item was easy to set up and offered fast surfing but firmware updates are far and few between, I have owned for one year, constantly loses internet connectivity, crashes, the customer support is worthless, don't waste your money on this one.

This is yet another shoddily built router that malfunctions frequently.  I set up wireless repeating on it and it sometimes works and sometimes doesn't.  The box seems to overwhelm itself just booting up.  I tried to fix it for a few hours but eventually gave up and tossed it in the trash.

This morning, it died. I called Netgear and they said I did everything correct to troubleshoot and I should return it to Amazon. I checked Amazon and I'm only able to get a partial refund. Needless to say, don't buy this router.

Although I'm not an IT professional I work in microelectronics for a living so I'm not uncomfortable around technology.I was initially really happy with this router. It has great features and was easy to set up.  But... my whole family soon noticed internet connections would randomly stall every 10 to 20 mins for about a minute which is long enough for internet pages time time out.  Very frustrating and lots of experiments, googling and reading message boards has not found an answer.  Netgear support did have a beta firmware patch but that also didn't work.I would try netgear support but judging from the feedback on this and other forums they know about this issue and just string folks along with non-answers.  Not good for my blood pressure.I'm switching back to my old linksys router

I consider myself as tech-savy.  I've had my first wireless router in 2003 and had upgraded to several brands of router past years.  Maybe I was lucky, all my routers Linksys, D-Link, Belkin, and Asus has survived 2+ years.  But not this one.  After 9 month of good service, it drops internet connection every couple of hours both wired and wireless connection.  First, I thought it was my cable modem but same problem occured after Time Warner changed modem to brand new one.  I am ready to give up after trying to fix this problem by flashing latest firmware and resetting router(30-30-30) several times.I realized that under the bad review, Netgear makes a comment saying email them netgear@amazon.com to fix the problem.  Well.. no words after 10 days.. I am 100% certain that this would be my last Netgear gadget I am gonna get.Correction:I did send the email to correct address: amazon@netgear.com.  I've resent the email I will post again if I get a proper response.

I just bought this router to replace a failing D-Link DIR-655 that I have had for a couple of years.  My D-Link router using a Belkin 150 mbps USD Adapter would routinely get the full 20 mbps of my cable internet.  I set the Netgear router up in the same location and can only get 12 mbps down????.  So I move the router to within 5 ft of the computer, and guess what....12 mbps still.  I plugged my old D-Link back in which is 30 ft away through multiple walls and back to 20 mbps.  This is supposed to be the latest and greatest and doesn't work as well as a two year old router!!!!  It's getting packaged for return right now.

Set up was a nightmare.  Over an hour on the phone with customer service for what should have taken a few minutes.  Once running though, it worked great...for all of four months.  Now I'm past my warranty, they wanted to charge me to talk me through how I might be able to fix it, unless I purchased an extended warranty.  A quick search of the web (and the comments here) show that a decent percentage of these have a short life span, and Netgear seems to have figured out a way to profit from it.  Sell you a product that craps out after a few months, then charge you to even talk about fixing it. Nice try, I fell for it once, not again.  My new router will not be a Netgear product.

I purchased this router to replace my Linksys WRT54GS.  Never had a drop off issue with the Linksys but have to often reconnect my Notebook PC to the Wireless and often loose internet access via wireless.  Router works GREAT hard wired but the wireless is very unreliable just like other reviews on here have warned.  Firmware is up to date but issues are consistent. I am not using the Wireless N to connect only Wireless G, but again never had an issue with the Linksys WRT54GS.  Also, I had much better range on wireless G on the Linksys than I do on this router.  Not been able to test the range using Wireless N yet.

I purchased the WNDR3700 v1 nine months ago.  Although there were some challenges in the setup relating to using static IP addresses for my SBS network, it generally worked well for about six months.  I did not contact the free 3-month tech assistance because I knew that my network settings would befuddle the tech's script-driven process that assumes simple setups.Several months ago the internet (cable modem) would go out for a period of time.  I initially believed it was Comcast.  Recently it completely stopped and I was forced to do a thorough diagnostic routine.  I pin-pointed a faulty internet connection function of the WNDR3700, even though the rest of it worked as expected.  Swapping out my old/slower router confirmed the diagnosis.Netgear tech support refused to honor the 1-year parts warranty unless I purchased a $70 extension of the 'software' warranty to confirm that I had it configured correctly.  Explaining the above facts made no difference to them.  From their perspective: as long as the lights glow, then the hardware is working perfectly.  Summary: No warranty.I purchased a Belkin N750 DB for half the price of Netgear's current top-end gigabit wireless router.  The Belkin worked immediately and was easy to tweak.  I will also hold onto my 5-year old Belkin F5D8230 as a reliable backup (albeit slower wireless).Bottom line: the Netgear is fine as long as it works, but do not rely on their warranty because of the mandatory 'software' warranty before they will honor the 'hardware' warranty.

DO NOT BUY FROM NETGEAR! Horrible customer service - worse than horrible!  This router worked fine for about 4 months.  Then it died suddenly.  After checking out settings, etc., I was pretty certain that the problem was with the hardware.  Called customer service only to find that they only will offer free support for 3 months, though the hardware is warranteed for 1 year.  But they wouldn't even speak to me about the hardware issue until I paid the $100 support fee. And they kept telling me that since the lights were on that it couldnt' be a hardware issue.  So I paid the $100.  Then the nightmare started.  I ended up having to call them about 30 times over the course of a month. The technicians knew less than I do about computers, and they didn't have me do anything that I hadn't already done (except spend a lot of time reinstalling and rebooting). I swear I almost had a heart attack dealing with them.  They barely speak English, transfer you a million times, don't follow through on what they say, etc.  Even worse, they won't look at or don't keep a record of previous transactions, so every time you call or are transferred, you have to tell your entire story all over again.  I have never been rude to customer service people over the phone before, but I ended up screaming and swearing at these people.  Even when they said they would replace the router, they would not send me the information I needed to actually get it without many more phone calls.  Then, I told them I wanted my support fee refunded since it was a hardware issue and under warranty.  That was a million more phone calls, and still it appeared on my credit card report.  So back to the phone and explaining everything from the beginning since they refuse to read the records.  Maddening.  I pray that this one doesn't break, but if it does, I will throw it out and buy another brand.  Oh, and the ability to use the second frequency is pretty useless since there are few devices out there that support it.  Stay away from this Netgear product and any other!

column9: DO NOT BUY.  Warranty is worthless. Tech Support costs more than the router.
column10: I purchased this router because I have a large house and needed something with good range.  It did an OK job reaching the other end of the house, and when functioning properly, transmission speed is adequate.  My real complaint, however, is with warranty/customer support.  After about six months, the router started dropping the internet connection at random intervals, sometimes for just a few seconds, sometimes for a couple of minutes.  So, I called tech support to see if anything could be done.  However, I was told that even though the warranty is supposed to be good for one year, it only covers the hardware, and this was a software problem.  How did they know it wasn't a hardware problem?  Because the lights still turned on!  If I wanted tech support, I was invited to purchase one year of it--at a cost about equal to the original purchase price of the router.  If I preferred, I could purchase 30 minutes of support for 'only' $39.99.I have also discovered that this is a known issue with these modems, which makes it even harder to believe that it's a software rather than a hardware problem.  So, bottom line: it's a decent enough router as long as it keeps working for you, but you are SOL if something goes wrong and you are outside the 90-day technical support window.

I have given this router more than a fair shot. I will start with some background information. I am a MAC user and live at an apartment building in a major city. A 5G connection is almost a must to block out all of the other competing connections from other renters. I purchased this router because of it's duel band capabilities and relatively fair price for use.So, the first router I received was in September of 2013. It worked great for a week then, on a weekly basis, it would constantly drop the connection and require a manual restart. After two weeks, it would then begin to drop the connection on a 3-4 day basis, then every other day and all the way down to a connection drop every day (this was over the course of about a month and a half). Netgear tech support tried repeatedly to fix it (and were great, the only redeeming quality here), however they were unable to diagnose the issue. Tech support actually suggested that I exchange it for a new one (since they have a 1 year warranty) and send the original router back as 'defective'. I did that and Amazon did a great job doing the exchange for me.Now, the second router. The second router seemed to be a fix. For the next two months I had maybe one restart issue (which is common). At the turn of the new year, however, I experienced a restart( okay, no big issue) That being said, I am now, just before I wrote this, on my third restart this month at what appears to be a once a week to once every four days schedule. I am falling back into the same routine I was on with the original. Also, the firmware upgrade did nothing. It seems as if the router itself just degrades in its ability to carry signal over a hastened period of time. I've never experienced anything like this with an electronic device.That all being said, i will continue to use this router and most likely exchange it for another one until I get out of the warranty window (that's my way of at least getting my $80 worth out of this stupid thing). Once I move on to a new router, I will probably never buy another Netgear product again. Given how many they make and sell, the chances of me getting two lemons in a row should be incredibly rare. This reflects a massive quality and control issues at Netgear. I would highly recommend another router, especially if you're willing to spend anywhere from $60-$100.Additional note: My ISP and modem are fine. I originally thought they might be the problem but had them checked multiple times. Additionally, whenever I would restart the router my internet would come right back on after the restart, this means the issue is at the router and not one of the modem or ISP.

The range that this was supposed to go to, didn't go as promised. We were very disappointed that it didn't go to our building outside, which was not very far. It's only a few hundred feet from the office.

With this being my 3rd unit that has failed, I feel compelled to write a quick review.  These are without a doubt the WORST routers I have EVER used!  Each and every one has failed within the first 30~45 days, just outside of Amazon's return policy of course.  I've experienced everything from dropped WiFi every 5 or so minutes on one unit to complete failure of the wired hub on it's replacement.  Pure junk, plain and simple.  I've used Belkin and Linksys prior to this Netgear and have to say, I'll never buy another one.  I find it hard to believe that this unit receives such high praise from the likes of MaximumPC, etc.  Obviously, they only test theirs for a few days during which it works flawlessly...Save yourself the trouble and avoid this junk at all costs!  I'm going back to Cisco/Linksys.

column9: Negative stars? Worst router I've ever owned
column10: This router is a disaster. If you don't believe me, check out Netgear's own forum. I had to replace this router with a Belkin that has worked flawlessly. Poor equipment and even worse customer service. I will never purchase anything manufactured by Netgear ever again.

column9: Even the Chinese are embarrased about this one
column10: This router will last you 6 months.  Bought mine in January, and it worked fine until July when it started dropping the internet port connection.  Tried multiple solutions but only a router reboot would resolve the problem.  Reboots became necessary once a week then after a few weeks went to once a day then graduated to multiple times a day and then even rebooting wouldn't solve the problem.  No new firmware available and I'm not wasting my time with Netgear netfools on the phone.  Now after drilling 3/4 of the way through the middle of it with a 3 inch hole saw, it makes for a nice cup holder.In my world, I shouldn't have to pay 150 bucks for 6 months of use.

RECENT UPDATE (Nov. 2011): Read initial review (below) to see the positive aspects of this router. AVOID NETGEAR!!! It has been 3 months since I purchased this router. Two weeks ago I noticed that the router would randomly drop the signals on both channels, so I called tech support. The Netgear representative said my product was no longer under warranty since it was 96 days old, i.e. the 'warranty' expired 6 DAYS AGO! To make a long story short, the representative very rudely explained that I need to PURCHASE a Netgear Warranty and that talking to a supervisor would not make difference. It is almost unbelievable that this router appears to be failing at the 90-day warranty period! I guess I should have called 6 days sooner?Initial, positive review (August 2011):This router is incredibly fast, it almost feels like it is plugged into the ethernet port. I have owned several Linksys routers over the years (all failed at 2-3 years of use) and I think this router runs circles around any Linksys product. My last Linksys N-router seemed only a little faster than the previous G-router I owned, but this Netgear N-router is much, much faster. The signal is strong and stable in both the 2.4GHz & 5GHz frequencies (no failures yet). My old Linksys had a weaker signal that occasionally dropped since the first day I owned it(especially if the microwave oven was on two rooms away?). Based on my experience so far, I cannot imagine ever buying another Linksys product again.The are a couple problems with the Netgear router: (1) the set-up is terrible since it is very slow and you have no idea what is happening (no progress bar or anything); (2) no instruction manual (the digital version that comes with the CD requires a lengthy boot-up); and (3) it is VERY difficult to locate a Netgear customer support phone number anywhere (I did not see anything on the box or the very few papers that came with the router), even online--this is a serious problem that needs to be corrected ASAP.
The router functioned well until 4 months. Then one day suddenly it just stoped working. Besides this, I did not experienced other problems with this device at least while it was still working.

column9: Do NOT waste your time with this product!
column10: I purchased this router and have spent 4 hours on the tech support with net gear.  After the four hours, over 2 days, the product still is not working.  I was told it was my internet service providers issues.  However, I have internet until I hook up this router.  I was then told to update the firmware from a friends computer and then try again.  This also did not work.  I have read the forums and see the same problem by others.  I can not believe that netgear can not make this product work.p.s. the tech support is also very hard to understand due to the language barrier.Do NOT waste your time on this product!

column9: OK if you don't need a wireless connection
column10: In some ways, this wireless router works as you might expect. It has most of the features you could want, has an adequate management interface, and some useful though primitive usage reporting. It was easy to set up and get devices connected.Where this device falls down is reliability. After a month of usage, the router decides that, every evening at some point, it would no longer connect any wireless devices. When the wireless connectivity drops out, no wireless devices will connect to it our even see the connection in the list of those available. The only way to get the connectivity back is cycle the power on the router. After a week, this was no longer fun, and neither was trying to deal with Netgear's tech support. I have a low tolerance for bad customer service, and after half an hour on the phone with no results, I put the router in it's new home (recycle bin) and got something else. The new router, an Asus RT-N56U, is fabulous. No dropped wireless, faster than the Netgear (even when it was working), and has, hands-down, the best router management UI of any router I've had (and there have been quite a few). And it's about the same price as the Netgear.This is my second Netgear device (also had a gigabit switch of theirs for about 20 minutes), both of which have failed to work properly. I'm pretty sure I'm done with them and their sub-standard products and support.

I have Verizon FIOS and have a problem with losing internet connectivity when I'm furthest from the router. Verizon refuses to send me an 'N' band router, stating that the current router works fine. I decided to purchase an N600 due to reading reviews indicating an increased coverage area. After using the install CD it would not work. I spoke to a support agent for over 2 hours and she could not get it going. She informed me that a senior engineer would call me the next day. After waiting from 7am to 2pm with no call, I called them back. The agent refused to transfer me to a senior engineer, attempting to assist me herself. After insisting to be transferred to the senior, I was put on hold and disconnected. I was not called back by Netgear. I called back and reached a lady that barely spoke English. She eventually transferred me to the senior engineer. I spent over 2 MORE hours on the phone with the engineer, was put on hold and disconnected. When the support call was initated the agent asked me for my phone number 'in case we are disconnected'. I was disconnected at around 4pm on Tuesday 8-16. It is now 4:15pm on 8-17 and I'm still waiting for a callback. It is quite obvious that if the agent runs out of options they simply disconnect the caller and move on. The router was returned for a refund today. I will not purchase Netgear products in the future. BTW I own (5) PC's. This is another indication of the poor customer service practices so prevalent today in the USA.**** Part 2 **** I sent an email to the Amazon/Netgear address and provided Netgear with the appropriate case and customer numbers. It is now Friday night at 9:40pm and I have heard nothing from Netgear. No phone call, no email. I am now finished.

I have two of these routers. One of the v1's and one of the v2's. The v1 is setup as a master base station while the v2 is setup as a repeater.Both routers perform beautifully. The product is sound. Please note that the 'auto-firmware check' does not detect the latest firmware. You will need to go to netgear.com and put your model number in to download the latest firmware. I give the router itself 5 stars. Note that the advertised range is not quite there. Especially in the 5Ghz band in my experience.The reason for 1 star:I dont think I have ever dealt with worse customer support in my life. These guys make Dell look like a 2011 lamborghini vs a 79' pinto. I called Netgear support because I was trying to setup a repeater for both the 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz bands (Note: this is NOT supported. You can only use a repeater for one band or the other). When you call support they make you wade through a rediculous number of menus, and then when you finally reach the menu you need (i.e. techsupport), they force to hang and up and call a differnt number! That is gripe 1. Next, I hung up and called the second number and had to hold almost 20min to get a human. Once I got a human it was obvious I was speaking to some outsourced contractor in India. I had to give the guy just about everything except my blood type before he would even listen to my problem. Thats gripe 2. Next, I explained my problem about trying to setup a repeater for dual bands. It took me about 10 mins to clearly exaplin the problem. He said he understood and asked me if I could hold for a moment. I said 'yes, I'll hold'. I was then transferred without warning to some other tech (again, obviously indian contractor). He asked what my problem was. I said, 'didnt the guy I was just talking to for 45 mins tell you anything?!'. He said 'no'. So I had to go through the same process of giving him all the information about me, the serial numbers, model numbers, firmware version, phone number, blah blah - Again! Thats gripe 3. Finally I spend another 15 mins or so explaining the problem and now he asks me if I can hold a moment. So, I reluctantly said 'sure, I'll hold'. So, I am tranferred somewhere else, the phone rings and rings, and then the call disconnects. Almost 90 mins on the phone with support and the most information I got from them was 'please hold' and I was hung up on. I tried calling back twice, and it was the same thing. They just kept transferring me. Thats the final gripe. So, I will not be buying a Netgear product again for the rest of my life.Anyhow, if you have problems, be prepared to resolve it on your own! Netgear support is worse than Dell! I repeat, worse than Dell!Good Luck-----M-------

column9: Could be a great router if the firmware worked properly
column10: This review is about the Netgear N600 (WNDR3700) router: http://www.amazon.com/Netgear-Wireless-Gigabit-Router-WNDR3700/dp/B002HWRJY4/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1312438873&sr=8-1After having no problems for about 6months, I upgraded router's firmware to the latest firmware (1.0.6.98) to hopefully some well known issues with the USB drive - but the upgrade resulted in my laptop dropping the connection about every five minutes (it was working fine prior to the upgrade -v 1.04.68). After going through the Netgear forums and finding the same firmware problem was happening to several owners of the same router, I backed out of the upgrade and installed the prior version (1.0.4.68), but the intermittent connectivity still remained.I called Netgear and the technician asked me to do a ping test between a wired host and router to determine if the intermittent connectivity I was experiencing on the wireless was a router hardware problem. The ping was successful (5 pkts, 0% loss), so he deemed the router to be ok. Since I was past the firmware warranty (the what?), he said that was all he could do unless I paid $60 for a software/firmware support contract because the software is only convered for 6 months after you purchase the router.  If I paid for the support I he would help me fix the problem. Hmmm, you would think the software support would last as long as the hardware (1 year). I double checked with a supervisor and she confirmed they would only help with firmware for 6 months.This is a first for the industry as far as I know. If you effectively brick your router after following the vendor's instructions to upgrade to their software and they will not help you unless you pay 50% of the router's original cost for 6 months of software support - they do not need my business. I went to them on a friend's recommendation - I'd been using Linksys/Cisco for years. Too Bad.I will go back to Linksys or try one of the new ASUS black diamonds mentioned in the Netgear forums - where members were leaving behind their Netgear WNDR3700's. More research on my part would have shown that performance was better with the other two as well - my bad.Asus: http://www.amazon.com/Processor-Hardware-Internal-Antennas-RT-N56U/dp/B0049YQVHE/ref=sr_1_1?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1312439062&sr=1-1Cisco : http://www.amazon.com/Cisco-Linksys-E4200-Performance-Simultaneous-Wireless-N/dp/B004K1EZDS/ref=sr_1_4?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1312439062&sr=1-4I peeked at the Netgear 40000, but can't get past the short and costly support policy.So, I would encourage potential buyers to compare the Netgear warranty and router with other vendors before buying. -Steve

I bought this Dual band router to replace my old Cisco WRT45G router. It was really easy to set up out of the box and I got all my wireless devices (2 laptops, 1 desktop and 2 smartphones) connected to the internet in minutes. Everything was great until it started dropping internet connection sporadically. Every few minutes wireless devices would stop receiving data from the router. I called the tech support who took me through a few scripted steps (upgrade firmware, downgrade firmware, set a permanent channel etc.); none of these suggestions worked. A number of angry phone calls router Netgear agreed to replace my WNDR3700v2 router with a refurbished WNDR3700v1 router. The new router worked well for 2 months after which it had failed. I am having the same problem with the router dropping connection every few minutes. Its annoying when you pay $100+ for a router and it doesn't work as it is supposed straight out of the box! I am so tired of Netgear's product quality & customer service that I would NEVER recommend netgear products to anyone I know. All in all, bad device, bad customer service...run like hell from this product.

Don't believe the paid reviews.  This product is a lemon.  I called customer support to get help because the connection kept dropping off.  Because it was beyond their 90-day customer support, Netgear offered me their plan for $99.95 to fix the problem.  I opted for the plan since the router is less than 4 months old.  After unplugging and plugging, disconnecting and connecting, and all kinds of shenanigans, they could not fix the problem.  Don't let Netgear steal your money.  I opted for a Linksys.  The set-up was easier than the Netgear and I have no connection problems whatsoever.

column9: Disappointing Waste of Money.. DO NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT!!!
column10: Aug 5:  Device's feature set is nice.  Simultaneously supports two physically separate wireless networks at different frequencies.  Good set of security features.User documentation is weak.  Some sleuthing needed to configure for some advanced features (e.g., MAC filtering).The device frequently (once or twice per day) locks up and must be reset.  During these period the web-based administrative application is not accessible either through wireless or ethernet circuits.Have used for since about July 15 and am considering shopping for a replacement.AUG 25 Update:  Am shopping for a replacement.  The device is completely unreliable.  Have given up.  This is my first and last NetGear Purchase.AUG 28 Update:  Purchased replacement.  Went to cnet.com and looked at product reviews.  Selected [...], which was their Editors' choice.

column9: DNS problems after 16 months...  solution in comments
column10: Worked perfectly for 16 months, now it's dead. I specifically bought this one because at the time, it was supposed to be the most reliable. Oh well.Update: I've found a solution and posted it in the comments. Who knows, maybe for a mere $39 Netgear would have been able to tell me how to make their product work. You'd think they'd provide free information on bugs like this, but oh well. For the lucky few that find this, you won't have to trash your router.

This router worked great for about a month. Now it disconnects at least once a day. Have to reboot then it works for another day. There are NO cordless phones or microwaves operating in the house. This is the second Netgear router I've had this year and WILL be the last. Are you reading this NETGEAR!!!!!JUNK JUNK JUNK!!! Over 35% negative reviews on this product!UPDATEOK Netgear Team. I downloaded the latest firmware update, V1.0.0.10, A little better. Never really disconnects but slows way down to a crawl until I reboot. Worked ok for the first two days now this. Also I sent an email to amazon@netgear.com and NEVER heard a word! It sounds like YOU want to help but the rest of your team is lacking in communication and designing the right firmware.So I'm still telling everybody, DON'T BUY THIS ROUTER!!!!!!!!!!!

column9: Unreliable: Frequent Loss of Connectivity & Poor Signal Strength
column10: We purchased a Netgear N600 Wirreless Dual Band Gigabit Router (WNDR3700) less than one month ago. While the router was very easy to install, it has proven to be highly unreliable with frequent losses of connectivity (occurring about once every 10 minutes) and webpage download delays. Our primary reason for wanting to get this router was its alleged high speed and performance, neither of which has proven to be valid: the 5-GHz antenna has very low signal strength as compared with the 2.4 GHz band making it unusable and the 802.11n capability is non-existent.We will be returning this router for a refund and have resumed using our older and far more reliable Linksys WRT54GL router.

I read reviews and trust Maximum PC mag to influence my buying decisions but in this case they were WRONG! I install, build and maintain my equipment not only for my home but commercially since the 80's. I know what I am doing. This piece of junk arrived and right out of the box started having connect problems and shut downs. I spent a few hours trying to stop this thing from shutting down. Searching the web for an answer, I read a firmware update corrected some of the problems (why did I get one with known problems?) I am tired of manufactures sending out faulty products and having the consumer spend hours on the phone with reps from another country who can't speak english very well and even less knowledge about the product, trying to fix it. During the attempt of updating the firmware it shut down again, guess that froze up the router for sure. At that point it went back in the box and was returned. You have to ask yourself why half the reviews get 5 stars and the rest have varying dissatisfaction down to 1 star?

I purchased this product (WNDR3700v2) about two months ago based on the positive reviews it received here on Amazon. While the router was easy to setup and provides decent connection speeds when actually working, it periodically drops wifi connectivity on the 5ghz band for no apparent reason.I have two laptops connected to this router on the 5ghz band and each experiences the same problem. I have to reset the wireless connection on each computer in order to reestablish wireless communication with the router. The issues surfaced not long after I first setup the router -straight out of the box- and despite two subsequent firmware updates (1.0.0.08 and 1.0.0.10) and resets, the issue persists. I believe firmware version 1.0.0.10 was released specifically to address this issue but it hasn't worked for me and many other customers.I'm extremely disappointed by Netgear and this product. Given its relative cost and the positive reviews here, I expected a quality product. Instead, I got a router that is worse than the 5 year old router it replaced. At least that one worked reliably, albeit providing a slow connection.While Netgear appears to have tacitly acknowledge the issue on their customer support message boards, as well as released new firmware, it hasn't fixed the problem.Don't spend good money on a faulty product.

column9: DON'T BUY THIS PIECE OF JUNK
column10: I purchased this router from Amazon in December 2010. It worked well for 7 months and then stopped working. Started intermittently with messages stating 'web site not found, unable to resolve DNS name'. Called Netgear support and was told unit was out of warranty (only 90 days) and that I would have to upgrade the warranty for $99.99 for 1 year. The router is completely useless now and I cannot even browse to the login page for the router. This is the first and last Netgear device that I will ever purchase.Netgear is junk!!!

I bought this product based on the good reviews on AMAZON website and a prosumer router, but for me the router didn't work from the very begining, the wire lan is ok and internet connection, but the WIFI last 5 minutes and then didn't work again anymore. Seems that the hardware is not reliable and the software has problems, if you update is even worse, beacuse has other new issues like not working internet, the customer support say to return but for me is is more expensive than buy a new one, due I'm outside US. If you look at the forum of NETGEAR or make a search on Google you will this discover a lot of peolple with particular router having a lot of issues.If want a reliabe router don't buy this!!!

column9: All good things come to an end...
column10: When I first purchased this product N600 WNDR3700, it was working great!  About nine months later that's when things started to get messy.  I've used Netgear products in the past, I tried to be level headed and optimistic with the device.  The issues I've have now is.* Without any changes to my setup, my router decides that the 2.4g wireless will now sporatically connect.  Sometimes it doesn't even want to connect to any machine.* Listening to the Netgear help number sends you to the pay money to get help number.* Describing the issue on Netgear was useless, since once I hit 'submit' a fatal error on their form occured.* I've asked their Netgear forum and have yet to hear back from any of their tech peopleI've tried many...many time to debug the device.  Changing the firmware, using a new password, restoring factory default...and it seems to work ok for a minute(like it's taunting me) and the connection dies.Reasoning for the stars:Reliability = 1 (Product should last a year or more)Price vs Quality = 1 (If it can't even last a year, it's not worth the price.  Especially as a flagship unit.)Speed of Connection = 1 (Can't connect or infrequently)Customer Service = 1 (Phone = Automated, Web = Form won't let you submit, Help cost money and will ask for a credit card)Overall = 1 (I believe this review pretty much sums it.)Sigh...

column9: Horrible product, hasn't worked since day 1
column10: I did my research before hand and thought this was the best high quality product for me.  I have several computers in my house as well as an ipad and a Home theater PC that was going to be streaming HD video a lot so I figured this would do the trick.  If it works it probably would have.  The hard wired connections are great, very fast and always work.  However the main reason I bought this is for wireless.  Which I've had problems with it turning off byu itself randomlt.  It started working for me and stayed that way for a few weeks, then it started acting up again and disconnecting.  This time it was disconnecting once a day and I couldn't figure out how to get it to come back on.  I call tech support from netgear and they told me if I needed it fixed that I had to pay for shipping since it was outside my 1 month even though it has a 1 year warrantee.  Plus if I got it back and it happened again I would have to pay again.  I sat on tech support for over 2 hours and they finally fixed it only for it to go out again the next day.  I call back and they said a new firmware came out that was supposed to fix this very problem.  So I download it and it fixed the problem for 3 days.  Now my lights on my router say both wireless connections are working and on but nothing can even see the SSID from the router even though its set to display the SSID.  I try entering it manually and they still won't connect.  This is where I;m at now still not working.  This will be the last netgear product I ever own.  If you want an expensive wired router go for it and buy this it'll do you good but if you want wireless I wouldn't touch this device.

column9: WNDR3700 Died while doing a firmware upgrade.
column10: Worked like charm for couple months, and then just dropped connections every now and then. Router was resetting even with in 30 minutes of power reset.Tried different firmware's from .58 to .68 to latest .98 and back to .68 no luck.I am a power user with all the functions enabled on the router while it was functional.Router died while going through firmware upgrade (reset by itself while in the middle of firmware upgrade) Pathetic piece of equipment. Followed all the tips on the netgear forums to overcome the dropped connection problems no luck.Router is dead no luck with the included utility to revive the piece of junk.Buyers beware if you have constant reset problems on this router do not upgrade the firmware on it.

Do not buy this router.  Do not buy ANYTHING from Netgear.I had this router for 9 months.  Although the connection was flaky, the range and speed were reasonbly decent.  Then suddenly, the 2.4 GH transmitter stopped working (to be completely accurate, it did not go away entirely, but the transmission power dropped so low that you have to stand right next to the router to detect it at all).  I had not made any changes to the router - it simply suddenly dropped away to almost nothing.After extensinve troubleshooting, I called customer support.  Oh, the router is more than 90 days old? No, we can't help you then. I was given another number and told that I had to call that number for warranty support. I called the number and the lies began.  They told me that my 90 days of free support had expired (the only true thing they ever said) and that I needed to pay 69 dollars for six months of 'gearhead' support.  I told them that I didn't need support - I needed a replacement router (the router is still well within the warranty period).  Oh, no, they told me, there can't be a hardware problem.  The reason?  The lights on the front of the router are lit (apparently they're magic LEDs) That means it must be a configuration problem.  And they can fix it in minutes, if I just pay them first. When I refused to pay them to honor their warranty, they refused to help.  Over the span of multiple calls over the next several days, nothing changed.  They lied. (promising to call back on multiple occasions which never happened, for example)  They made outrageous claims:  I hadn't secured it properly (despite having set it to use WPA2 encryption). No details were given, just insinuations that somehow magical hackers had caused my signal to disappear.  They woudn't explain, of course, as to how this was happening (details would cost me a support contract), just angry retorts telling me about their many years of experience and their incredulity that I was daring to question their expertise. And that's just the highlights of many hours of frustration.The bottom line is this: Netgear appears to have decided that the only thing that matters to them is selling support contracts, no matter how many lies they have to tell and promises they have to break and that their warranty is meaningless.  If you buy one of their products, you'd better hope it doesn't break.

Don't waste your money or time. My 4 year-old Cisco/Linksys 'G' router out performed this by a long shot. It rates high at the rating sites, but is not easy to install, not easy to manage, offers a slow connection speed and lousy range. The dual band doen't work without a special adapter so don't bother with it. IF I upgrade to an 'N' router, it will be a Linksys.

I purchased this from amazon in Jan 2011. Worked great, but now in june the wireless craped out. Rebooted no luck. Reinstalled the firmware and no luck. A pile of junk. And before you say it I am a professional IT guy for over 15 years. I hate to deal with the moran tech person in netgear who will basically make me repeat all the steps I have taken as he will be reading a script on his computer and after a long time will transfer me to advance tech and then they will monkey and finally after 2 to 4 hours of loss of time on phone they might issue a RMA.

DO NOT BUY IT, IT IS THE WORST WI-FI ROUTER EVER.I first bought it, and after many attempts of installing it I gave up and returned it to Amazon. I wasn't able to install it using the CD (tried on 3 different computers - 2 PC and 1 Mac). And tried configuring manually and it also didn't work.So, as I said I've returned it to Amazon and a few days later I received the new router. I had the same problems on the installation, but insisting on the idea that the problem was me and not the router, I didn't give up, so, after 2 days trying, it was finally on. I was very excited, but not for so long. On my 3 computers and on an iTouch and 2 iPhones, the signal is one time online, and 10 min. later it is offline. It stays like that all the day. And often I have the signal, but not the internet connection, and that's a problem of the router, because when installing again my old router, all these problems stops.I'm Brazilian, so sorry about my bad English.

column9: works but the gigbyte lan and wan ports are a lie
column10: The router is great piece technology except when it comes to gaming it drops crucial packets which in turn cause problems. The other bad thing about this router is that the wan and lan ports are only have 500mbps throughput and i looked on the box and it says nothing about this do not buy this if you have epbfi gig internet or google fiber gig internet

I have owned this router for about a year.  Connectivity in a house is poor.  This modem would be great in a 400 sq ft. apartment.  Then again,  I could be watching a movie on my phone next to the router surfing the web on my desktop (hard wired to the router), and the Wi-Fi loses connection on my phone.I bought this one due to the "extended range"  Extended range only works about 50% of the time and it fluctuates. (extended range means getting wi-fi to my garage or to the porch).My 3 year old 20 dollar router worked better then this one.  unfortunately times changes and I had to upgrade to a better security protocol.The Family protection software is not what you expect.  The software has to be installed in the computer that you want to monitor .  Router does nothing on controlling content of the webpages.  You can go to an open DNS service and choose a free dns service that blocks "bad" websites.  That DNS service can be used on the majority of routers on the market.  DNS service has flaws too,  so its not a "catch all".I rated it a two because the product is still working.  70% of the time I am happy with the product.  For the price that I paid, I expected more.Last netgear product that I will ever buy.

I purchased this router 2 years ago, and was pleased with its 4-star performance. It recently stopped operating, apparently due to a phone line power surge, despite protection on a UPS. I requested out-of-warranty repair. Netgear replied that they do not offer repair service at any price. This is the first time that I have encountered such an unacceptable policy, the reason for my 2-star rating of this unfortunately but clearly "disposable" product.

column9: At least it broke withing the warranty period!
column10: WNDR 3700 v.1  After the initial setup, requiring a call to tech support to deal with issues regarding my Vista platform laptop (apparently, Vista has 'bugs' which render it finicky to setup with the Netgear router), it worked fine.  Alas, two weeks from the end of the warranty (90 days) it ceased being a wireless hub, and became a lowly wired internet hub.  Tech Support worked with me for nearly two hours, when it was determined that no amount of resetting/rebooting was going to fix the problem.  OK, I can get a replacement.  Hold on, I have to pay shipping back to Netgear - with delivery confirmation, amounting to most of $10.00, additionally, I have no router until they receive my return and ship the replacement to me.  Lame.  New unit warranty is good only for the remainder of the original time - in my case, meaning no warranty.  Netgear does allow 1 free tech support call after receiving the replacement router.  It was reasonably easy to connect with Tech Support in my two interactions with them.
This is a highly rated router, but you can't attach and share a USB printer to it?!?That is a deal-breaker for me.

Don't purchase this router.  The firmware is full of issues, connections drop often, every few minutes in some cases.  See write ups across the web documenting the issue and the lack of Net Gear response.  Go with another router

I bought this router because i was not getting good signals from my old Linksys router and other sites said this router is one of the best online gaming routers. This router would give me full connections on my ps3 occasionally but never continuously. Was getting bad connections from pingtest.net so i returned the router. You have to keep in mind though, i do have Time Warner Cable and they could possibly be the worst internet service provider known to man.

I don't know what to say. I guess I can voice my discontent on the forums here so the Netgear engineers and prospective customers can see what is going on. This is the question... why do you need to spend $150 for a router that will continue to have bad firmware updates? Every single firmware update for the WNDR3700 series router has been a complete flop, incapable of doing what is advertised.I bought the WNDR3700v1 when it first came out because it was going to be the best of the best. Other than the occasional lockups, it worked great. Hardly any problems until these bad firmware updates started coming out. Here is my history:31 Stock FirmwareWorked great as advertised but would have occasional lockups.49 ReleaseLocked up daily and cut network throughput to a quarter. Went back to 31.55 ReleaseNetwork throughput cut back to a quarter again. Didn't lock up on me but the web GUI was unreachable until a reboot. Back to stock 31.68 ReleaseWhat a joke! Throughput went up but gaming and other items would boot you off after 10-30 minutes. Back to stock 31 again.75 ReleaseWow, pretty stable... if you like the throughput to be cut in half. Another waste in time. Back to stock 31.98 ReleaseI was shortly amazed for at least a week. Throughput was good but after that week my VoIP phone dropped after 15 minutes on every call and multiple devices online at the same time were slow slow slow. The range went down too. QoS was a joke. I guess 30 feet through a ceiling was too much for this top of the line equipment to handle. Back to stock 31.Now, I have seen some tricks to clear the NAND and 30-30-30 and none of them have worked. The only firmware that [U][B]EVER[/B][/U] worked right on this router is the stock 31 firmware. I don't use the USB drive access, traffic meter, logs, or any of that stuff and the firmware releases still fail miserably.If you are a consumer and want this router to function as it should, do not bother with any firmware other than [B]1.0.4.31[/B]. Downgrade it to 31 at the first sign of any trouble. We are talking about radio here, it's been around a long time. I just can't believe ever release sucks so bad :mad:.The entire staff of Netgear firmware engineers should be fired. I will never buy a Netgear product again because your company has ruined my confidence. Do they even test this stuff before they release it? Why do they release firmware and immediately pull it off the server? Is this outfit a joke or what?  It's like every update makes this router even worst. Do you have a bunch of engineers in a room saying stuff like, 'what can we do to make our product even worst... ah, this should be funny.'Don't worry. I know a company doesn't like bad PR and this will probably be removed shortly. No worries, I will post this as a review on your seller web sites. I even considered going back to my Linksys WRT350N, which has not needed a firmware update for 2 years.

column9: Netgear N600 Wireless Dual Band Gigabit Router WNDR3700
column10: Installation is easy and realiability is good.However the speed is awful.Wired speed is about 1/3 of speed without router.Wireless speed is about 1/10 of speed without router.Tried everything I could to improve speeds and nothing helps.This makes use of this router to be totally unacceptable.

I had a setup in my home with a 2 Linksys WRT54G's (these are 2.4GHz Wireless-G routers) - one upstairs and one downstairs. I had switched both of these to the Tomato firmware which has significantly more features and allows WRT54G's to be setup in WDS mode. WDS mode basically allows the wireless network to be expanded (i.e. increased range) by using multiple access points. The setup has worked wonderfully for the last 4 years - with perhaps one reboot of the routers every six months.With a growing stable of wireless and wired devices (Desktop PCs, laptops, Mobile phones, iPads, PS3, BluRay players ...) I figured it was time to upgrade to a wireless router that would support both G and N, and also includes Gigabit wired switch. Looked at various reviews here in Amazon and finally settled on the Netgear WNDR3700v2 based on it's simultaneous dual Band (2.4 and 5 GHz)capability, higher range of the channels, and the Gigabit wired switch. Bought it at Fry's Electronics since it was cheaper there.Setup of the device was quick, as it should be. The device automatically detected that there was a newer version of firmware available when it first booted up. Download and installation was uneventful. Completed the setup of both the bands and had the various devices connecting to it in about 30 minutes - quite reasonable. The range of the 2.4 Ghz band was higher than the 5.0 Ghz, but not as large as the 2 Linksys I originally had. However the range for sufficient for my needs - don't work from my backyard that much :).  Overall I was happy. The device worked quite well for the first 3 hours and that is when the problems first started. My son told me that his laptop (which was originally connected on the 2.4 Ghz channel) was no longer detecting the channel. Sure enough, none of the devices could. So rebooted the router and things were back to normal. However, another few hours and the problem resurfaced. This time, I downgraded the firmware to the previous version hoping that would fix this problem. Well, it didn't. Over the next week, the router has to be reset (mainly because the 2.4 Ghz channel gives up) every few hours. Longest it ran without a reboot was 14 hours. Researched whether others were having this issue and YES, it seems like a lot of others have similar problems. So, that settled it -- I didn't get a lemon, this seems like a systemic issue with this router. Not sure how a company can release a product that cannot do it's primary function for more than a few hours. Anyways, returned the device to Fry's and switched back to my old setup. No more complaints from the wife and kids.  Here's the summary of my experience: THE GOOD:  -- Looks great. It really does.  -- The range of the bands is pretty decent.  -- Setup is easy.  -- Gigabit ports work as advertised. Helped a lot with the wired connections (Have a NAS drive with photos and Videos)  -- Didn't test the throughput of the wireless bands but didn't see anything slow down when they were working THE BAD  -- The data monitor built into the device is pretty useless. THE UGLY  -- Extremely unreliable. Has to be reset every few hours because the 2.4 Ghz channel quites broadcasting. Shame on Netgear for releasing such an unreliable product.  My recommendation is to stay away from this device. However, if you are tempted to try it out, buy it from your neighborhood store (Fry's will match any local or internet price, Walmart has the cheapest price for this) so that you can return it easily if you end up experiencing problems similar to the ones I encountered.
This router consistently assigns invalid ip addresses to attached devices, necessitating multiple restarts of the router to resolve the problem.  Support is virtually nonexistent.

column9: Don't buy it for the USB connected storage
column10: Netgear advertises that you can connect this to attached storage via USB. Unfortunately most USB storage devices are not readable by the router. Including mine.Here's a list of connectable devices: [...]If you want to connect via ReadyShare, wait to buy a storage device -- and buy one that's on the list. Otherwise you're out of luck.

Ordered this one to increase the speed of my Tivo Wirelss N transfers (5Ghz), my ipad2 (5Ghz) and my computer and ipod touch (2.4 Ghz).Out of the box, the router was a quick and easy install. I did a few quick transfers on the Tivo and surfed the net on the other devices. Everything was really fast. I was happy.Sometime that night, the router stopped broadcasting the SSID's. I rebooted it, everything worked again for a few hours. It locked up again. I decided to try the latest firmware (1.0.0.8) to see if that would stop the freezes. Things got worse. Everything slowed to a crawl. I went back to the older firmware (1.0.0.6), but no luck. The 2.4Ghz ssid came back, but not the 5Ghz.I don't know if it burned out after a day or what. After a quick internet search, I found many more people with freeze issues so I just decided to return it.

I have a home office that runs a voip server where I needed this router to forward certain ports to it within my private network.  After installing the latest firmware, this router worked for 2 weeks before my remote extensions all went dead on me (failed to come through the router and register), while internet connection (both LAN & WLAN) was still intact.  After messing around its settings for 2 days to no vail, I came back Amazon to read more reviews and to my surprise, I found several others sharing the similar frustration.  I immediately took one of the reviewers' recommendation and bought a Linksys E3000 so I could try it out side by side with Netgear to confirm it's indeed a hardware failure.  Waited 5 days, E3000 came to my door.  After 15 minutes of programing the same settings into E3000, my remote extensions were back on line.I noticed the advanced features are much richer and the web GUI is more sophisticated with a lot more control over sharing contents locally and/or remotely.  On top of it, my wife immediately noticed the web surfing speed was better than Netgear's.To sum up, if you only use it for basic wireless networking and internet gateway, it does the job fine, but anything beyond this point, Linksys E3000 wins hands down.  If you are in the similar situation, don't even bother calling the Netgear tech support, which I did (wasted at least 20 hours of my time spread across a week), as it's the product that has the problem, not you.

I've been a fan of Netgear for years. I purchased the WNDR3700v2 to replace a WNDR2000 which was operating fine, I was just ready for an upgrade.After opening and setting up the new router, it seemed to be working well. Immediately out of the box there was a firmware update. After about a day of use, however, the wireless dropped and none of my devices could find the SSID. Being a new product, I figured the router just needed to be reboot and everything would work fine. After a reboot, things worked fine again for a while and suddenly, the problem repeated itself - wireless dropped and SSID missing (though the indicator light for wireless broadcast was illuminated).This being my 4th or 5th Netgear router, I am familiar enough with their router management software to have attempted to tweak some settings (security, broadcast, and otherwise) to attempt to resolve the issue but was unable to successfully keep my router transmitting a wireless signal. Figuring it was a faulty device, I returned the item to amazon and got a replacement. Sadly, the replacement item had the same issue. After three days with the replacement product and several more troubleshooting trials, I opted to return the item to Amazon for a refund. I'm just going back to my WNDR2000.A couple of things to note:1) I think this router, if it worked properly, would be fantastic. With gigabit connection ability several advanced features, it is clearly the beginning of a new generation of routers. I'm not sure why the two routers I received did not work - but if I knew the problem would be resolved, I'd gladly purchase it again.2) While the 5 Ghz wireless signal is a nice option, of my 10+ wireless capable devices, only one is capable of finding and utilizing 5 Ghz. If you are buying this router for the dual-band option, I'd suggest you make sure your devices are capable of taking advantage of this feature and, if not, a different router (that is less expensive) may be a better option. In the future, I'm sure 5 Ghz will be more utilized but until then, it's far from 'must-have' selling point.

Router died within 4 months of use. Netgear support just wastes my time. They only want to sell me more phone support, instead of offer me an RMA. It is under hardware warranty until October 2011 :/Please spare yourselves the headache of dealing with support and just buy a different brand router.Only pro's would be that when it worked it sent out the wireless signal a lot farther then some of the linksys routers that I have used. It also had a decent amount of options in the firmware.

I had high hopes for this beauty. When I first got it going it was fantastic!It streamed to all my computers and other internet connected devices with reliable high speed.The ONLY problem, and this was a show stopper, was I had to reset it every so often. Sometimes it was good for a few days, other times I'd have to unplug and plug back in in under 12 hours.I wouldn't mind the reset so much if only it WOULD reset after I unplugged and plugged back in.Sometimes it took SEVERAL times before it would finally get back to transmitting -- very frustrating.I've used an Airport Extreme (from Apple) for a number of years, but it doesn't have the range that I need in my newer, larger home. That NEVER needed to be reset, but again, the range was insufficient.I'm going to try Medialink's solution (ordered on Amazon yesterday) -- it has the highest ratings of any router I could find on Amazon - fingers crossed.(full disclosure: I bought the Netgear N600 at my local Best Buy, not on Amazon).

column9: Poor behavior, dropped connections, connections timeout
column10: I was pretty excited to get this router based on all the favorable Amazon reviews and from the word of friends, but the example I received was very flaky.  Setting it up was pretty easy even with both this and my old router on the same network.  Wired performance is fine, same with wireless, though I didn't exhaustively test either of these.The biggest problem for me was it made basic surfing painful.  Every few minutes all connections/page loads would simply timeout for about a minute until the router woke itself up again.  I figured I could put DD-WRT on it instead of Netgear's FW but this version of the hardware isn't yet supported.If you have no interest in loading custom firmware then stay away from this unit for now.  If you do have interest, make sure that your firmware of choice has support for this newer version (FCC ID is PY308300092).

column9: Don't buy it if you do ssh/telnet types of connection.
column10: Everything is good or reasonable. But don't buy it if you need ssh/telnet types of connections.The router drops ssh/telnet connections if idles for 30 seconds. It might be a hardware problem and it cannot be fixed by firmware upgrade.Hope this will save your time in dealing with these problems.

Setting up this router was much more difficult than expected and working with NetGear's customer service (in India) was marginal when we encountered our first problem - getting the PC to talk to the router. It got worse when we tried to bring in the laptop as part of the network and became a nightmare when we tried to resolve the issue of why the laptop couldn't print through the router/wirelessly.  We had to terminate our conversations with tech support after being transferred four times and being reprimanded for not calling on the correct line.  Finally we gave up and tried to get the answer on the Netgear online forum - more stress in getting the unfriendly website to acknowledge our registration and let us logon.  It seemed there was no answer although a lot of people seemed to have the same problem.  In desparation, we turned to HP product support since the printer was theirs.  Lo and behold.  A very competent, user friendly service rep diagnosed the problem through a remote session as a missing ethernet cable. Fixed!  Bottom line: stay away from Netgear unless you have unlimited time, are a computer techie and or speak multiple languages.

column9: Good if you're in a 1000sqft apartment
column10: Unfortunately, I don't live in a 1000sqft apartment.  This thing has terrible range and has terrible throughput.  I even went out and bought the matching n600 usb adapters that this is supposed to go with.  Takes longer than it should to connect.  Feature set is average.Not to go off on a rant here, but why does every network mfr. make these routers and only crappy usb adapters to go with them?Anyway, the thing paired well... but the router is on the 1st floor of my house and my bedroom is on the 3rd.  I was getting 1MB/s transfers tops, even when the router showed I  had 4 bars and 135mbit connection.  The transmit power is too low to penetrate two floors.I went out and got a d-link 665 router to go with my old dwa-556 pci-e adapter, and now I'm getting 10-12MB/s transfers on the network.

Bought the dual band for HD streaming, but can't get past the archaic setup.  Buying Netgear for the first time in many Cisco years, I have reminded myself why I swore at one point that would never buy Netgear again - should have checked my diary if indeed I ever had written one. Spent the past hour trying to set this box up, and a memory of frustration floods my brain cells. Will not cooperate. Might be great once up and running, but I'll never know. Is going back to Amazon.

I purchased this router with high hopes.  This router checked all of the boxes that I wanted- dual band, dlna, usb for a hard drive and great performance.  Setup was very easy (if you've ever set up a router before, this one is pretty self-explanatory).  Range was excellent, even on 5ghz.  There were several problems.  If I was using a lot of bandwidth downloading a file, the other radio had a tendency to turn off (if I was downloading on the 5ghz band, both of the radios for 2.4 would turn off and drop their connections to other devices).  I would also intermittently lose my connection to the internet, causing frequent timeouts.  I decided to just throw in the towel and return it rather than deal with another one with questionable build quality and firmware.

column9: works great ... for a few minutes at a time.
column10: Very fast and feature rich when it works. I bought mine from bestbuy where i will be returning it today.  It would be a perfect machine if the internet would stay connected but it constantly cuts out then makes you wait two minutes to reconnect.  Very frustrating.

column9: Died after 16 hours, and it gets worse
column10: The package arrived. I unboxed my new  NETGEAR wndr3700 and spent over an hour setting it up. About 45 minutes too long in my opinion. Sixteen hours later it is dead, kaput, bricked! After 30 minutes on the phone with NETGEAR, I learned that during the first 30 days they don't accept warranty replacements from Amazon customers. The reason, according to the NETGEAR representative, is that Amazon packages refurbished products as new. If I'd purchased the router from Best Buy, NETGEAR would have happily replaced it. But after I completed Amazon's truly painless return process, I guess I'm happy NETGEAR didn't want it back. I expect NETGEAR would have kept me on the phone for another 30 minutes to complete the return paperwork.If you're still considering a purchase, these are my impressions after briefly owning the wndr3700. This router is much more complicated to configure than the Apple AirPort it replaced. (The AirPort recently began to drop connections after eight years of solid service. I became tired of power cycling it every few days.)The NETGEAR also has limitations that the Apple base station did not. The NETGEAR must be connected to a cable/DSL modem or a gateway router. It will not work otherwise. I had the AirPort hanging off an 8-port switch in the den which was connected to the gateway router downstairs. The NETGEAR wouldn't even respond until I swapped it for the switch. Also, the NETGEAR didn't work correctly when I turned off DHCP which I expected to be handled by the gateway router. It was only happy when it also provided DHCP. On the other hand, the NETGEAR router has a huge feature set. But making use of the advanced ones is not something the average computer user will want or need to attempt. In the very brief time it worked the wi-fi range was excellent and the throughput seemed good; I never had a chance to try streaming video or anything else that would tax the connection.Updated - I can't believe I'm back updating this review. I received a replacement for the defective router from Amazon. To my surprise, the item was not new. It was an open box return. There was no tape or wrapping holding the router box closed. In fact, the plastic wrapping was stuffed inside the box along with the cling film that protects the router from scratches. The power adapter was unwrapped and missing its twist tie. The factory tape sealing the router in its plastic bag was unsealed. Finally, the included ethernet cable was missing. Even if I'd not unboxed a new unit a week earlier, it would have been obvious that this router was not packed at the factory.This time I called Amazon customer service instead of using the web site. I explained the the condition of the clearly not new item to the courteous CSR who agreed to send me another router. He then put me on hold while he looked into why I'd received an open box item. Five minutes later, he was back on the line saying that the warehouse told him the unpacking must have happened during shipping. I opined that it was unlikely the UPS driver had unboxed the router to test it in the truck. Maybe the state-side warehouse crew thinks it very funny to pawn off crazy excuses on the gullible India CSR staff? Either that or they need to write down more believable stories in their call scripts.So now I'm wait for another router to arrive. Maybe the third time will be the charm.

The wired networking element of this router is five stars.  It's a 680 MHz processor with gigabit ethernet ports; this thing hauls and when dealing with wired networking, performs as well or slightly better than some of the Cisco SOHO products I've used.  But that's only part of why you buy a wireless router.If your TA number is V17 or less, don't buy this router.  Don't even open it because the range on this thing will surely disappoint.  Not only that, but the throughput is just horrible, and that's on the 2.4 GHz radio.  The 5 GHz radio is next to worthless.The web interface is still typical Netgear klunky.  It works, but it's not particularly intuitive nor elegant.  It's annoying that in this day and age that only one login at a time is permitted.  There is no syslog to an external server, which I like to do in order to keep the logs off the router.  But port forwarding, dynamic DNS are all supported. The DHCP server works well, but DHCP reservation is a bit strange in that you can only reserve addresses out of the DHCP lease pool range. Not exactly a deal breaker, but it is one of those little 'gotchas' that make you wonder what they were thinking.This router is supported by DD-WRT.  However, the current version (v24-sp2 12/18/10) is so buggy that I can't recommend it.  If you load that firmware, your wireless throughput will drop even further, and many of the functions like creating secondary ethernet bridges will completely cause the WAN to quit working.  Just stay away from it (the forums on DD-WRT will confirm this).So, should you consider this router?  Only if you are able to purchase a later version unit which hopefully has corrected the wirless issue.  Everything about this box is fast, but for the price paid it should be simply flawless.  And it isn't anywhere near flawless.  Netgear should be issuing refunds to customers who bought V15-V17 units.

column9: When it works is superb, but....
column10: I don't need to add to the excellent descriptions already posted. When the router worked it was superb. But, it quit working after less than a year. I would expect better from a device at this price tier. My first and last Netgear product.

I bought this router to form a wireless bridge between a netgear WNR3500L and this unit. While I was able to get the bridge to work without too many annoyances, the transfer rate between units was very poor (generally less than or around 1 MB/s). I also attempted to pair this with a wireless N adapter to connect a machine in the same remote room. I was totally unable to get this to cooperate with a the dlink extreme wireless N PCI express adapter. They would connect, but every single data packet was lost. By contrast, with the WNR3500L acting as my master router, the dlink wireless N card functioned okay with a average throughput around 3.5 MB/s. Signal strength was an issue for the WNR3500L. I generally got around 75% signal strength with that unit, whereas the WNDR3700 did achieve a signal strength into the room around 95% (it just did not get along with the dlink adapter). I cannot advise using this unit to form a wireless bridge. It might work fine if paired with a different wireless N adapter. On a side note, I bought a second WNR3500L in order or form a wireless bridge and found the performance similar to pairing the WNDR3700 with a WNR3500L.
