I bought this to replace an old Belkin 'Pre-N' router that I bought in 2004. The Belkin still works but I wanted some newer features like simultaneous 802.11a, UPnP. Manual setup was easy using its decent Web interface; I didn't use the installation CD. Its range was very good - about the same as the old Belkin Pre-N router (which has always had very good range) on the 2.4-GHz band. (The 5-GHz range was less than the 2.4-GHz range, as expected. This is normal for the 5-GHz band.) Data throughput was very good, both on Ethernet and WiFi - much better than the old Belkin, which seemed to bog down at times. I used the built-in utility to check the firmware and it told me that I already had the latest. So far, so good.Well, after a couple of days, one of my WiFi-connected computers would no longer connect to the router. Examined both the PC and the router - both were still set up correctly. Rebooting the PC did nothing. Rebooting the Netgear router fixed the problem. A couple days later a different WiFi-connected PC wouldn't connect. Rebooting the Netgear fixed the problem. A couple days after that, all the WiFi-connected PCs lost Internet connection (although they still had LAN connectivity), yet the Ethernet-connected PCs did not lose the Internet. Rebooting the Netgear was again necessary to fix the problem.This is unacceptable behavior; I want the thing to just sit there and work and not require constant attention. I returned it to Amazon. I'm back on the old Belkin, and I'll have to try something else for those modern features that I want.

column9: Uncertain of the true speed, constantly drops communication
column10: Setup was simple. Haven't realized any speed increase that I can detect.  After setup, it was not clear to me how to access all of the features. Would have liked to see some indication of performance or system test but maybe that is by design.After further use, I am even more disappointed.  It seems as though the router can't maintain communication very well during streaming videos so it stalls on virtually every play.  You have to reload the page in order to complete the vid.  Since the web is loaded with videos now, it is a constant reminder of how poor the performance is on this router.  I would gladly settle for my old Cisco now, except I gave it to a friend....Oh well, another data point.  Stay away from this router is my recommendation.

The router died a sudden death when both radios stopped working.  Web support was lacking but I was able to get an RMA over the phone although attempting to get info. through their product registration page was useless because that portion of the website was down.  After getting the RMA via email I attempted to complete the process only to a get a Server Error when I used the link in the email.  I can't find an address on their website for returns so I guess I'll wait until they fix the other part of the web site.  Fortunately I kept my ancient Linksys router which is up and running at close to the speed of the Netgear.  My opinion of Netgear products and support is pretty low.

column9: Does not integrate well with non-simple networks.
column10: My objective was dual-band 11N, this seemed like a good choice. I now know better.I have spent 2 sessions of 3+ hours each attempting to add this device to an existing network. My network already has a boundary firewall, DNS server, and DHCP server. The installation procedure of this device assumes it, itself, is the single network manager inside a residential cable modem arrangement.  ( PC<-->WNDR3700<-->Internet)In my configuration, this was 1 of multiple APs; in a network with existing DNS and DHCP.(PC<->3700<->(servers,DHCP,DNS,Firewall)<->Internet)The problems I had with the configuration are:-- NO static IP for the 'Internet' interface. I could find no configuration web server on this interface. This really was just 'UpStream'. There is a section called'Remote Management', but is not clear what 'remote' meant. I could hard-wire my DHCP to the 3700's MAC, but that is a kludge and out of scope.-- Regardless of the setting in the 'LAN SetUp' the router did private DHCP on the 4 LAN ports and WiFi. This gave all connected devices useless IPs. And NATed everyone to the same IP. It couldn't simple pass the requests up stream.-- The installation leaves a link to [...]. If you attempt to resolve that to an IP on the internet, it fails. It probably only works if you use the device as your DNS server!-- Reviewing the 'setupmanual.pdf' included with the device does not present the actual installation procedure (it diverges at Page 17, step 6)In the end, after configuring and rebooting, the WiFi accepted connections, but never assigned an IP to that connection. The management interface could not be found on the wan ports due to not knowing what IPs the device was naming itself. On my second attempt, I was able to connect from an Android phone through the WiFi. Unfortunately, it assigned a 192.168.1.2 address, even though DHCP was not active by configuration.It probably does everything it advertises. It just doesn't do things to allow the user much flexibility. And the supplied doc do not match the actual installation.

column9: netgear sucks, the admin software is buggy; but the router hardware itself is decent
column10: Update 2:ok, i still get 'no devices attached' when trying to list all the devices on my network, when i know there should be at least 4. this is sometimes important info, but the admin software is buggy for some reason. netgear sucks!! how hard is it to make that page work consistently. damn!I'm giving 1 star for the crappy company, software, firmware buggy junk.And 4 star for the hardware itself. That averages to 2 stars.Netgear sucks!Update 1:ok, I head this over a month now. a couple more things to add. i dont like netgear as a company. this router is pretty stable for me, but the firmware, the admin console has a few bugs and inconveniences, and it seems netgear doesn't really respond to fixing them all that quickly.  i just get the feeling, more than other companies, netgear tries to squeeze every last drop of profit from their customers. one issue is when i try to do an update, it says no connection to the internet. on the netgear forum, some people say its because the server is down, but thats been several days. its been down for 4 days so far. what the heck!!?? a few other people including me sometimes get a 'no devices attached' situation where the firmware doesn't 'see' the connected devices. most of these issues are due to maybe a buggy firmware version.  if netgear is smart they better come out with a firmware update that fixes these problems fast.  other than this gripe, for me, on a day to day basis, its running alright.Original:This was worth the upgrade. I got 5x the speed on wired ports now (had to use cat6 cables), as well as 5x the speed on wifi. A couple of things I don't like though. When you change a setting, then save, it seems to take a long time, like 20 seconds to save, seems kind of long. My old router took under 5 seconds to save settings. Another small thing... to configure port forwarding is flexible but tedious compared to my old router. You have to make a couple of clicks to add a forward, and also each forward you add is always enabled, if you want to disable it, you have to delete it. I don't like that as I want to keep the setting even though its disabled. I made a workaround for that though. Just set some inaccessible ip to forward to so in effect its not active. Overall love the speed. 5x the old wifi and wired speeds! Happy with it.

Replaced DIR-655 (which I had for a couple of years) because wireless printer in basement could not be 'found'.  In short, this router was everything I hoped for: great range (using printer again), EASY setup and configuration and doesn't run 'hot' like the 655. Not a single complaint.**Update Oct 2011** Well, after 9 months of usage I got tired of the constant tinkering (particularly the last couple of months) with settings, disconnects, router reboots, etc....bought a Belkin N750 and haven't looked back.  This router firmware is just plain bad (check out the netgear forums to see the multitude of complaints) - physically the router was fine - nice range, etc... I could have rolled WAY back in firmware but that in itself had limitations in product functionality.  Lesson learned - I will never purchase a Netgear router again.

column9: Doesn't handle HD videos well (youtube, vimeo)
column10: The setup I must say was a charm and the easy functioning of the router was a plus. The router itself was lightweight and wonderful to look at.I however was extremely disappointed with this router's price and what the company claimed it could do in exchange.The range was actually very small even using the 2.4 Ghz band. I live in a studio, and the strength signal bars (Mac computer)would go down considerably by just going to my back porch. I'd previously bought a smaller netgear router which I had exchanged for the new one, as that one was only 150 mbps and couldn't read HD videos well.  The bigger one didn't fare any better in terms of covering more range and watching HD videos online.On the 5 Ghz band, the coverage wouldn't even extend any further than the room I was in, and it's a tiny room; I was really surprised at that.But then, and this was the most frustrating issue with this router, was the fact that the HD videos would systematically stall on youtube when this router was clearly advertised as being able to handle HD videos. I use cable, and usually HD videos function quasi-seamlessly when plugged in directly from modem to computer so it wasn't a modem issue.On the 5 Ghz band, the HD videos would stall just as well and in fact just as bad as the previous smaller, cheaper netgear router that I'd bought for only $40 some bucks.I tried dealing with this for almost a month, until a friend gave me his Linksys ($60) router.  I must say I finally returned the dual band guy, and I can actually say that the Linksys (much cheaper router) is quite smoother and handles videos better than the bigexpensive guy. So all in all, I find that Netgear didn't try their product well before releasing it. It's definitely not worth the money, it has great potential to be an awesome router, but it isn't in spite of all of its good qualities, and from I've read from other enchanted reviews.It didn't do some of the most important things it was advertised as. This is a typical case of companies overly eager to either make money from a product that's initially a good idea, but falls short of what it's supposed to do, or companies that focus more on the competition than actually making a solid product that does basic stuff, but does it well at least.Just a thought.

I got this router May 22nd. It is now June 18th and the router is dead, lying on my bed. In those three and a half weeks, I have had one of the best wireless router experiences of my life. This thing was rock solid. No disconnections at all, and great speeds. Wireless coverage was a little limiting, but it could easily hand my apartment. But now, the lights are not blinking, and it is dead. This is unacceptable for a router of this price. Consumer wireless routers are crap in general, so I was hoping spending $150 bucks on a router would be the ticket home, but alas, once again, I am let down. I am kind of tempted to replace it with the same model, but I absolutely cannot spend $150 dollars on a router to only have it die withing a year.

column9: Easy to set up, looks great, but doesn't operate great.
column10: Bought this wireless router as I was seeking a dual band router with a dedicated N band and guest network.Initially impressed with the ease of installation and simple interface. Easy set up and quickly able to configure for the G and N SSID's, passwords, etc. Plus the unit looks great and is able to lay flat or stand on its side with the optional bracket.  Another real plus was the range of the wireless signal on both G and N.Unfortunately, beyond this it simply doesn't work - or work properly. As others have pointed out, many of the features are not accessible or flat out don't work.  But most frustrating was that the router kept dropping the connection from one or more computers at any given time. This required constant resetting of the router to regain the connection with the computers.NetGear support was non-existent.  No recent firmware release to correct the issues.  Internet searches and NetGear's support forums indicate that this router has issues but there are no fixes (at least yet).Fortunately, Amazon has great customer service and took my defective router back.

I bought this based on the positive reviews up here and elsewhere.  My experience has been a sharp contrast with all the positives I've read.1.  Limited range.  I replaced a Belkin Pre-N wireless router that I've used forever.  I put it in the exact same spot as the Belkin.  This one has less range and limited connectivity.  It will not reach all the rooms in my home that the Belkin did.  I may have to send it back if I can't find a solution.2.  Ease of installation.  Everyone says this is so easy.  I launched the installation wizard and discovered to my dismay that it does not support Vista 64-bit operating systems.  So, installation required two phone calls to India.3.  Technical support.  It took two phone calls because the first guy -- who was impatient and short-tempered -- hung up on me while I was away from the phone trying to find a power point to plug in the router.  The problem was that the transformer is oddly configured (in the plug) so that it took too much space to plug into the one open slot on my surge protector.  I will say that the second tech I got was much more helpful and stuck with me until we got the router installed successfully.4.  Too little bandwidth.  I bought this router to upgrade to dual band to transmit to a new Samsung TV.  We watched one Netflick using the old Belkin and we had about 6 interruptions for dropped signals.  With the new router, we were unable to watch a single Netflick on either band -- we had maybe six interruptions within the first five minutes.5.  No documentation.  There is no user manual or installation manual in the box.  This is absurd to pay $150 for a router and not even receive a paper manual on how to install and use it.All-in-all this has been extremely depressing, especially considering the high expectations that I had based on the reviews.  I will stick with it a while longer, reading the on-line user manual for tips on how to improve the range and bandwidth.  If that fails I'm willing to call India again, but so far this product is inferior to outdated technology that was working almost adequately.

I wanted to like this router.  Really, I did.  After doing hours of research, it came down between this one and the Apple Airport Extreme (simultaneous dual band).  I decided to get the Netgear based on glowing reviews. Got it all set up, current firmware and all.  It's nice having a simultaneous dual band router - wireless G for range (reaches 3rd floor from basement) and wireless N for fast data transfer.  One thing to note is N has pretty short range.  This isn't necessarily the router, rather the spectrum N uses.  One of the main things I need a good, reliable router for is Ooma VOIP.This router reboots randomly during VOIP calls, disconnecting the call.  Pretty frustrating when you are on conference calls.  I've tried every setting with QOS, etc, and it still does it.  Also it tends to get 'paralyzed' at times which prevents you from loading any web pages.  The signal is there, but it won't connect to the web.  Solution?  Unplug, wait, plug back in.  Then it works for another few days (but still disconnects Ooma VOIP calls).I finally had it with this thing.  I bought the Apple Airport Extreme and it works wonderfully.  I can Ooma, stream from my two Squeezeboxes, Have four computers connected, stream Netflix, and stream a movie from my Windows Home Server to my PS3...all at the same time with no reboots, etc.I can't recommend this router because the firmware is just too buggy.  It's unreliable as a business tool.  Once Tomato or DD-WRT makes its way to it, my guess is it will be better (the hardware specs are impressive).My two cents.  It's great on paper, but falls short for serious applications (home office use).

column9: Fast wireless, not so stable, not so featureful
column10: I bought this router as a replacement for my aging linksys wrt-54, and while the router is easy to setup and use, and the speed is pretty good when using a newer 'n' wireless capable machine, the featureset and stability is less than great.Firstly, the router randomly stops allowing new connections, while existing connections remain up. New connections simply fail to resolve dns. The only solution is to reboot/powercycle the router. I've had it go for a couple months or so, then fail several times in a week. If I get a month between reboots, I feel lucky.Secondly, this high end, expensive router, fails to have the basic feature of Port Address Translation (PAT). Meaning you can not map/re-direct external ports to internal port/ips. You can only do a straight ip map. This means you can not setup multiple external SSH, VNC, remote desktop or other services without reconfiguring each of the equipment to listen on non-standard ports.Thirdly, while I knew this router did not have in/outbound VPN support, its very disappointing for something of this expense and class to not have it.Forth, I've had the router auto-reconfigure the LAN ip from 192.168.1.x to 10.x.x.x on occasion when my dsl modem fails to connect or pickup right away (typically after a power outage when both router and dsl have been down). I have to switch a PC manually over to 10.x and reconfigure the router back to 192.168.x network. Its extremely aggravating.I've seen 2 firmware updates, but neither made any apparent improvement in stability or features.

In short, if you're just someone that's a little afraid of technology, and you just want a router to get online, do basic networking and play mafiawars and browse myspace all day, this router is great for you.More than likely, if you are forking over the money for this router, you have higher needs and expectations, which this router doesn't meet.  My experiences are as follows...I wanted to upgrade my old linksys router (wrt54g) to something a little bit more on par with todays technology.  With our new HP Home Mediaserver (EX495) serving out our files, our 2 laptops, 2 desktops, 2 PS3's, 1 Xbox, and our slew of Netflix junkies, we especially needed something with gigabit speeds for all the internal network trafic that was going on.Guest Network.  First I was a bit suprised when I saw this, and I thought it would be a great idea for our next door neighbor that we share our network with for a small monthly fee.  Simply pop her on it, and not have to worry about her stumbling on our shared media.  Well the theory was great, but upon enabling the guest network, things stopped working.  With it enabled, anytime we made changes to the router, we had to manually press the 'turn on radio' button on the front of the router because the GUI one wouldn't work.  This would be okay I suppose.... IF it worked.  Any time we turned on the guest network, all of our default networking died so we ended up turning off this feature and pretending like we never found it and got all suprised in the first place.UPNP.  In short, it doesn't work (properly).  Our Mediaserver has an option to program our router for the port forwarding for remote access.  The old router (wrt54g) worked fine.  I manually ended up forwarding the ports and this worked fine.USB Network storage - 'supposedly' it's slow.  I'd tell you myself my experiences but the router waiting to go back to the store so I never got far enough to try this.  I was looking forward to it even if all the other reviews already said it was slow.  Hey, I like to make my own opinions.SLOW GUI - Be prepared to wait approximately 90 seconds every time you change one of the sub menu items and click that dreaded 'apply' button... yes, 1 1/2 minutes!-----------------Speeds/Throughput:  I didn't have any complaints.  It was nice to have the faster internal network speeds while we tested this router (which was for all of about 3 hours while trying to get everything to work properly).Due to the lack of support for WHS / UPNP / Guestnetwork, and having just dropped the bones for this router, I was very unimpressed.  I could have spent <$50 and gotten a router that did everything this one was able to do.  Had this one done what it claimed, I'd have been very satisfied....NOTE: My problems were on both the initial BIOS (V1.0.4.43NA) and on the upgraded latest bios (V1.0.4.55NA)

For those looking to use this as a wireless repeater base station with Netgear's own wireless bridges, please note: WPA/WPA2 security is NOT supported, only WEP.  WEP security was compromised and out of date a decade ago; lacking this feature makes the repeater function useless.

column9: Works for a while, then dies.
column10: While this router is fairly easy to setup and use, and has some nice features, like guest Wi-Fi network, it does not last long, and after about 18-24 months, the radios and Wi-Fi die, such that you can no longer make connections to the router anymore. There also has been a lot of problems with the firmware releases which cause the router to "brick". Not worth the money when it just does not last.

Based on the strength of the review on [...] and the advertised feature set I ponied up the extra cash for what I thought would be a fantastic piece of networking gear. Unfortunately I found that the execution lagged far behind the promise. Many of the basic features of the router were suggested to be turned off by tech support as a means of fixing the myriad problems many have experienced, features such as UPnP, SPI, and Traffic monitor. Not to mention suggestions that using bit torrent is not a supported use of the router. The firmware was drastically lacking as well with many strange options missing such as being able to turn off the radios as desired.In short the troubles I had were only exacerbated by the support staff who failed to read my submission carefully on multiple occasions. I'm not a networking professional but I have a much higher level of knowledge than the average home user so it is somewhat annoying to be told that my modem is not handing an IP address to the router when I have already provided a depth of information that proves absolutely otherwise.I'll not be buying any netgear products until I get reliable word of mouth recommendations from my acquaintances. I expect much better quality of product for this price and failing that a good customer service experience when things go wrong. On both counts netgear failed me miserably.

column9: Appears promising, but not ready for prime-time.
column10: As you have no doubt read in other reviews, the firmware on this model is buggy but is progressively getting better.  I am currently able to use the 2.4GHz and 5GHz bands without problems.  I am also able to use the network file server feature without problems.My main gripe is that the media server feature does not work currently, and will cause the issue where the router suddenly stops working (but will still respond to ping and appear on the local network).  The only fix when the router freezes like this is to turn it off and on.If you want to read more, type 'NETGEAR WNDR3700 freeze' into your favorite search engine (no quotes) and navigate to the Netgear forums link that is returned.My opinion is that Netgear pushed this router out too fast, and figured the early adopter's testing would be enough for them to work out all the issues.  If that is the case, they were wrong this time.

column9: Very Impressive Quick Look, but died after a year.
column10: I just replaced my Linksys WRT600N this morning.  Before the swap, I did an internet speed test on all three of my computers (desktop on a 1GB Cat 5E line, laptop using 2.4 GHz N, and TouchSmart All-in-One on a 2.4 GHz N).  I was getting about 7 Mbs on the desktop and 5 Mbs on the wireless devices.  Immediately after the router swap I ran the tests again and had over 10 Mbs on all three (50% improvement on the desk top and 100% improvement on the wireless devices).  I also used to get intermittent Netflix HD quality streaming over my LG BD Player (wired), but the first (and only so far) time I tried it with the new router it went right to HD.  So far it looks like the best $150 I've spent in a while.The setup disk didn't like my 64 bit Win 7 Home, but the manual set up was straight forward (I guess I could have tried the 32 bit emulation mode, but didn't think of it in time).UPDATE:After a year, I started having intermittent network issues that would usually clear up if I rebooted the router.  I finally replaced it with an older Linksys WRT320N that I had, and all of my network issues disappeared.  I'm now getting 20+ Mbs downlink, and the VERY annoying stuttering that I was constantly getting when streaming recorded TV from my WHS to my HP Media Center Extender is completely gone.  I'll miss having the dual band N capability, but being able to use my WHS/MCE setup the way I had intended is so sweet!  Hopefully the WRT320N will last a while, but when it dies, I'll be getting whatever Linksys's state of the art router is.

column9: It worked.  But...It was a bandwidth bottleneck.
column10: I purchased this router to upgrade from my old Linksys 54G.  I wanted to step up to N, finally, and thought all the extra bells and whistles would be great.  It seems they come at a cost.  I had the cable guy out to make sure I was getting a strong signal to my cable modem.  After a few splitters were removed from my coax [...] was reporting 20+ Mps download rates.  I installed the RangeMax and re-ran the speedtest.  I got 5Mps?!  I tried turning off all but the essential features on the rangemax.  Still 5Mps?!  So I hooked the linksys back up, and back to 20+.  So I returned the Rangemax.  I've, since, installed an Apple Airport Extreme Base Station.  It's got all the features of the RangeMax, is easier to configure, and just works, back to 20+!

column9: No Port Redirection... do not buy
column10: Port Redirection is missing on this expensive router, so I recommend you do not buyVerizon blocks my port 80, and I use 81 to get to my camera, and this router DOES not support Port Redirection at all.see the following at the forum on this topic:[...].

I had the WNR2000 and I wanted to upgrade to this POS hoping to get a better reception for my X Box wireless connection which I use for HD Streaming. My WNR 2000 was giving me Moderate Signal around 50-70% and this unit gave poor reception in the range of 20-40%. I tried just about everything, including updating the latest firmware, but still no luck with signal improvement. It is going back to store tomorrow. Not worth the money.

Poor performance. Buggy Software.I gave it a rating of 2 stars because of its fast connection speed within a short range. Anyone having a simple system with all computers within a close vicinity and needing the 5ghz mode would be happy. Anyone else: Beware.I have had a D-Link DI-624 router which has performed well for 5 years. I expected that newer wireless routers with the latest technology should show a big improvement. As a result I decided to upgrade and ended up purchasing the NETGEAR WNDR-3700 router because of its advertised features, recent release, and that it had dual mode capability of both 2.4 and 5GHz to allow streaming video.  Bad mistake.The 2.4 and 5 GHZ modes perform very well in Wireless N and Wireless A but only within a short distance of about 20 feet.  Beyond 25 feet, like in a bedroom, the 5GHZ signal drastically dropped to less than 33 Mbps and often disconnected making that mode useless.  NETGEAR touts the 5GHZ mode for streaming video but you can forget about that unless you are in the same room as the router or an adjacent room.Switching to the 2.4GHZ mode, at the same distance increased the signal but only to 54Mbps, which is the same as with my old D-Link router.  Tech Support finger pointed to my computer (it's never their product) but I have three late model computers, two running Vista, and they all received the same signal strength. Perhaps the poor performance is due to NetGear using internal antennas.  The manufacturer claims internal antennas do not impact signal performance but as an Electrical Engineer I know it does. The main reason, not mentioned, is manufacturing cost as everything including antennas can be placed on one circuit board rather than using discrete wiring and external antennas.  Even these limitations would have been tolerable (since it is fast at close range) if it were not for other problems listed below.NETGEAR advertises a super fast processor but it appears to have no effect. The router takes a minute or more to reboot and reboots for every configuration change. My five year old DLink reboots in less than 20 seconds and it can accept multiple configuration changes before it reboots.For initial setup the so called Smart Wizard Setup program automatically walks you through the setup, connecting the router to the Internet. It is so easy that anyone without any computer or network knowledge should have no difficulty.  It is so basic that there is  a separate screen for each cable connection. But It also gives an option, for persons with some computer knowledge,  to bypass the basic steps.  Even though I have network experience I opted for the basic setup so as not to accidentally miss anything.  During the setup the program asked if this were to be a new installation, or a replacement for an existing router. I checked: Existing router, assuming that it would copy the DHCP IP settings from the old router. But it did not. Instead it issued completely new configuration settings as if the old router never existed.  This caused problems since all D-Link and other routers use IP settings of 0 instead of a 1.  IE: 192.168.0.1 instead of 192.168.1.1. This caused the assigned IP's of all client devices to change. Video cameras which had static IP's could no longer be accessed.  Manually setting the router IP to 192.168.0.1 and entering static IP addresses for the Video Cameras allowed these devices to again function.  No mention of this was made in the documentation.  The documentation stated that fixed IP address for client devices may be entered into the Address Reservation block and the router would then assign those fixed addresses to the various devices.  This did not work. The router continued to randomly assign DHCP addresses and ignored the fixed addresses that had been entered. Therefore direct or remote access of devices, using a browser such as Firefox or Internet Explorer, could not be done as the addresses would change each time a device or the router was rebooted. Remote access of Video Cameras could not be accomplished as one would not know the correct IP to enter.Incomplete Wireless Security modes were another problem. WEP is supposed to have both an Open and Shared option. Only the Shared mode was allowed by the software. Therefore devices which require an Open key had to have the pass phrase entered each time the system was booted.  WPA-PSK mode is supposed to have both a TKIP and AES option. However the NETGEAR router only allowed a TKIP option. Devices which used the AES option could not be accessed.  WPA-PSK mode is supposed to be backward compatible with WEP in order to allow legacy devices, which only used WEP, to access the system.  No backward compatibility existed with this router. Therefore Video cameras could not be accessed.One of the features advertised by NETGEAR is a Push to Connect feature. A special button and indicator light is present on the router. NETGEAR states in their advertising, that pushing this button would automatically connect all client devices.  Only in the documentation is it stated that client devices must have special software (not included) to make this happen. Acquiring and installing the software for each client computer is much more difficult than simply booting each client computer and clicking Connect when the Connection to Network message pops up.A minor annoyance is the extremely bright amber lights supplying almost useless information.  Who cares if a wired LAN connection is operating at 1GHZ or 100 Mhz.  Add those 4 lights, if there are 4 LAN connections, then add other functioning lights for power, 2.4ghz, 5ghz, Internet, USB  and the unit lights up like a Christmas tree. Plus the lights are constantly blinking whenever there is any activity and there is no way to dim the lights.This NETGEAR WNDR 3700 router was returned as defective for poor performance, weak signal connection, and buggy software.  Apparently the device was rushed to market with inadequate testing.Bottom Line:  Save your money. A $40 router with external antennas should work better.

column9: Nice features, but performance poor - no useful range.
column10: Our cable comes into the house on one side, but the kids and family computers are on the other side and depend on wireless.  Over the years, we have had a few routers, all with mostly good but not perfect wireless performance.  Our current Linksys has been the most dependable for 2 years, gving us better than 95% connect time on the other side of the house.  It is that other 5% down time that prompted a purchase of this new router.The features are wonderful in principle.  The ability to set up guest networks, detailed permissions, and plug in a USB storage device are terrific.  Basic performance over a direct ethernet cable was as expected.  Laptops and wireless connected just fine when they were in the same room as the router.  The problem was that outside of the same room, performance degraded quickly.  For the desktop computers on the other side of the house, about 40 feet away, there was NO connection to the internet - period.Calls to Netgear tech support did not help.  The support tech was polite but only read through typical boilerplate screens and was not useful.  The bottom line from the support guy was that if a laptop nearby could connect, then the router was working properly.  I even ordered new dual band Netgear adapters to replace the current Linksys adapters on the other machines, but that did not solve the problem.  The bottom line was that using any other combination of computers, routers, adapters, and positioning of the devices resulted in our typical 1-2 bar signal strength with a positive internet connection.  But when the Netgear WNDR3700 router was used to deliver the signals, no go.With my current router, I have a connection which is on 95% of the time, and usually easy to restore by fiddling with antennas or restarting the router.  I had hoped that the new Netgear router would give me a 100% dependable connection.  Instead, it gave me an unfixable zero percent connection for anything more than 30 feet away.  Depending on the size and shape of your house and where the router will sit in relationship to the computers may make the difference for you whether the device performs or not.If you will have your computers all connected by ethernet cable, or if you will be using a laptop in the same room, then this may a good item to get, for the variety of features.  But if you are going to depend on wide area coverage, this looks like a dud.  The price is quite high compared to other routers, presumably because it is a newer model with many features, but it is of no value if it cannot connect.I have no idea if my particular unit was defective or if this is a generic fault in this model.  It has gotten many nice reviews here, so perhaps my unit was bad, or perhaps everyone else has a better house geometry.  In the end, tech support was useless, and so was the router for my rather humble needs, so I returned it.  Because it was sold by Buy.com, not in-house by Amazon, the return had to be handled by Buy.com, but all went well.  If you buy it and it works well for you, good!  But if your adapters are 40 feet away and they cannot connect to the internet, don't waste time looking for a fix - just return it and try something else.

I bought this to replace an aging Netgear WGR614; I use the router as both an internal router for my home LAN (behind a separate router which functions as my firewall) and as a wireless access point.I skipped right past the setup wizard and configured the router to operate like my previous one:  DHCP for internal machines, a static IP connected to the outside world, and a pair of static routes to enable my VPN connection to my office.  It's this last one that causes the two star rating:  the static routing is broken, and it makes most features of my VPN unusable.  Some traffic, like ICMP, makes it through fine; other traffic, like port 139 smb traffic, only makes it partially through.  It took lots of time using Wireshark on several computers to figure out exactly what was wrong, but it's pretty obvious when some TCP packets show up on one side of the router but not the other where things are getting stuck.  A posting to Netgear's forums has gone unanswered, attempts to log it with Netgear support ran into a server error on their web site.  It looks like their software skills could use help in more than one place.Foolishly, I discarded the packaging as soon as I had basic connectivity up and running, so no return for me.  The router is pretty and has lots of nice blinking lights, but it looks like I'm off to the store to get one from a different manufacturer.

I got this shipped today. I find everything going fine except the following two- Extremely sensitive power socket, even a little push to the router restarts the router. I find that the DC power socket is defective- The USB based Network storage sounds great, but both the 5G/2.4g wifi chokes and becomes unresponsive when transferring music files from one of the connected devices (like ps3 or a laptop).I am thinking about returning this back to Amazon...not sure how easy that is going to be.

Mine died barely over a year after having it.  Even before it died, it seemed glitchy and would need to be rebooted every so often.  Not impressed with the performance, or lifespan of this product - will look at other brands when I buy a replacement.
Not going to go with Netgear next time around a 1 year warranty is abysmal.  While it lasted it was decent.

This WNDR3700 wifi router worked well for 2 years. Then it started to lose the wifi connection to the Internet, requiring me to power down and restart the wifi router once every few months. Finally, today, 3 years after purchase it simply has failed to establish wifi access to the Internet despite multiple reboots of modem and router. The Motorola cable modem purchased 3 years ago at the same time, continues to work reliably.I notice that since my original purchase, this router has amassed 1381 amazon reviews, 660 five stars, 330 one star.  That is a troubling distribution of ratings.After researching current options, I replaced this with the 2013 Apple AirPort Extreme.  The setup took 5 min using an IPad.  Quality of experience is no comparison. The $199 price of the apple router is a bargain, compared to the $149 I paid for this Netgear unit in 2010.

I am sorry I did not listen to the poor reviews of this router.  My router constantly looses connection, and I have to reset it.  This happens once a day on average.  I have tried loading different versions of the firmware and it still has problems.  I am going to take a loss and buy another brand.  Besides the loss of connection problems the router works normally.

SLOW Wired connection.  Reset reboot retried everything, returning. Forums abound with same issue.  Wireless is great, no problem at all. Great range, but any ethernet connection and it's dial up days speed.

column9: Worked great for over a year, now the wifi system fails sproradically.
column10: Set up was relatively straight forward for this type of product, and I had it configured for home and guest wifi networks soon enough.It has worked quite well and required zero management for over a year.However, in the past 2 months, the wifi functionality on the router has been becomming very unreliable... but only with some devices, which is the odd part.I have made no changes to the configuration and rebooted the router as well, but the issues continue.Wired functionality continues to work just fine.  No new wireless equipment in the house either, that I could attribute the flakey behavior to either.Its a WNDR3700 V2.Symptoms: what I noticed most/first was that wireless connectivity from my iOS devices (iPhone, iPad) to only certain hardwired devices, stopped working.  So connecting from my iPhone via wifi to the network wired xlink print device that lets me print to my hard wired networked laser printer would stop working.  Using the browswer on the iphone I could got the built in website of the 3700 router.. though it loaded slowly, but the iPhone could not bring up the website on the laser printer.  From a hardwired PC, I could bring up the website of the laser printer just fine.  So something about that connection and/or protocol from the iOS device to the laser printer was not working.  Using the iPhone to tell the 3700 (via its website) to reboot worked well, and after the reboot, I could see the printer again (and recall I could always see the printer from hardwired computers.. so the printer isn't the problem).  Then after several days the connectivity would go down again. I could see the internet but not my printer (from my iOS devices).First I figured, this may be something pecuilar to iOS WiFi and the 3700, as even the wifi connectivity to my MacMini would similary become unavailable, but I soon discovered the network connectivity from my Nest wifi thermostat also lost wifi connectivity.  Thats not an apple product.So the wireless connectivity between some devices went away, very strange.  I could always connect wifi from the iPhone to the router, and have it reset, and then things worked again, but eventually, now almost once a day, I need to reset the router.I've got to think its something that went bad on the hardware that some specific type of wifi feature set fails after some time.  Quite shame,as the router seems to be pretty decent otherwise.

Let me start off by saying I have had 4 other Netgear routers.  This is the only one that did not last.  I had mine for 54 weeks before it would not keep the internet up.  It looks nice and has good features.  I am not happy that it failed right after the warranty expired.  I tried everything to get it to work.  I updated firmware, tried static addressing, the works.  I feel like I wasted my money on this thing.  I would think it reasonable to think it should last at least 3 years before it conked out but a year is an embarrassment.

column9: Cost Too High For Such Short Lifespan
column10: The router didn't perform poorly for me. It produced a strong signal and the dual band stuff worked great. Was able to stream Netflix and play games without any issue. The performance wasn't any better or worse from cheap $30 routers I've used. Not a knock on them, just that I didn't get some unique experience. I do find their control panel to be atrocious. It's slow, clunky, and times out frequently.My biggest gripe however is with the lifespan. Just around 18 months. Sure routers die out, but considering this was one of their high end options and at a cost of just under $100, I expected a little more use. Now I'm not a heavy user, so it's not like it was being taxed too hard. And reading other reviews it seems like this is a common problem. Perhaps it's a design flaw or maybe they just went cheap with materials. But you definitely should get more than 18 months out of a router of that price.If you're going to buy Netgear for home use, my suggestion is to stick to their cheaper models. At least when they die out, you're only out $30. If you're looking for high performance, Asus makes a nice one for a bit more and D-Link has a solid dual band router in the DIR-868L. This router gets 2 stars because it did work for awhile although was nothing special and died too soon.

column9: Dual band will not work for long...
column10: After 2.5 years of use, all of my devices that use 2.4 GHz (Internet Radio, Roku, older laptops, wireless printer, etc.) connectivity is unreliable = from full full bars to 1-2 bars and most of the time signal just disappears. I did not make any changes to the router or my network setup. However, there are no issues with 5 GHz.I confirmed that the issue is hardware after reading numerous forums (including NETGEAR's) and testing numerous firmware versions (and configuration settings).I upgraded my Linksys Wireless G after 6 years of use with absolutely no issues. I expected that this will be better and more reliable considering the price that I paid for it.Do you research before buying this product. Query 'wndr3700 2.4 not working' and you will see.

Never did figure out what was wrong, but one of my laptops would not see either band, another would only see the 2.4 GHz and a PC would only see the 2.4GHz. A 3rd laptop saw both but the 5GHz was always such a weak signal it dropped constantly. Tried them in the same room as the router so it was not walls causing the problem. Apart from the hassle of ordering, testing and repackaging, my account was credited instantly so no complaints there.

Here, I thought I was moving up from an cheap $20 Ativa to this nearly $100 Netgear. All it did was tied me up all afternoon and nearly killed one of my newest Samsung laptops. Why can't it be plug and play in this day and age? Now, I put it all back in the box and am using the el cheapo.

I admit, I ordered this refurbed because it was cheap, but the reason it was cheap was because it was broken. It will work for a little while, but every so often, it will drop in and out. Both my computer and my PS3 will lose their connection, up to several times an hour. This past Sunday, my PS3 dropped out over 20 times, and my computer at least 10, and that was just for the times I was online. Next time, I won't order anything that is Amazon refurbed.

I purchased this product in December of 2011 to replace my blue and gray Linksys router ("My First Wireless Router"), I think you know the one. It worked great. It was a solid upgrade. It was feature rich compared to that old router. After about 18 months the router occasionally drops the connection from the modem and needs to be reset. This is frustrating and irritating for everyone. Especially when you want to start watching something but you need to go through the motions of resetting your router. I do not recommend this router to anyone that needs it to stream content through a Roku, Apple TV, Blu-Ray, Smart TV, etc.

Setup and use was fast and easy, but I purchased this to replace an old, low-end Netgear G router. I placed the new 3700 in the exact same spot the old WGR61 was. Even using devices in the same room were not getting a full range signal. 20 feet outside of the room and devices drop signal periodically or just get "out of range". I chained my old router to this new one and was instantly back to being able to access wireless on the old router from anywhere in the house. I am returning the 3700 - what good is a wireless router with faster speeds if you can only use it if you are sitting next to it?

Router works fine and setup was easy.  The problem is if you have a wireless HP Printer do not buy this product.  It will drop your internet connection and it is very difficult to re-establish it.  HP web side documents this and their solution may or may not work for you.  I have tried numerous suggestions and nothing has worked.

column9: wired internet is great but wireless sucks
column10: Recently I updated my internet to 50 Mbps and with my old medialink router I could not get the speed that I am supposed to get I use to get around 10 Mbps so I started looking into Dual band routers based in the suggestion by an medialink associate.my first pick was Netgear 3700, while the wired internet is great around 52 Mbps but wireless always ranges from 12 Mbps - 30Mbps so I called netgear support and the support could not fix the issues and want me to reset and then I learned that hard reset does not work and support could not help me either.So will be returning it..

I have to reboot this every morning as it will lose its IP address from the cable modem. It started off decent and worked fine for about 5 months, then this last month its had problems with both keeping an IP and handling DHCP requests within the network. Randomly reassigning IP addresses to my devices and forcing the leases to expire. Im getting pretty fed up with it.

I really wanted to like this router, and I did for about 1 year.  The features were good, I found it fairly easy to set up, all was good.  After about a year, however, it began to have ever more frequent issues, such as lost connections and the most recent issue, loss of wireless signal power.  I have performed significant trouble shooting and network analyzing.  What I learned is that the 2.4Ghz signal strength, which is the one for range, is woefully inadequate now.  Disappointing because this is not exactly an entry level device for Netgear.  I had thought that maybe the issue was related to interference on the channel, but no, network analysis revealed that there was no interference.  Just plain old weak signal strength.  I also tried installing the new firmware, again, to no avail.  I am forced to say that this router appears to be good for a year, maybe a little more, and then the issues start.  Sadly, I have owned numerous Netgear routers in the past, but this will likely be my last.  I have to recommend based on my experience that you look for a different manufacturer.Bill

column9: Worked for a while but now completely unreliable
column10: I bought this router almost 3 years ago.  Despite some initial difficulty setting it up at home, the router worked great for almost 2 years. I recently started using the router again, though, and now it constantly drops signal.  Like other users, I have to power cycle at least once a day and usually several times a day.  I've tried updating firmware and other tricks, but to no avail. I don't think I'll be buying from Netgear again.

I rate this router bad! I did some homework onit and it posted as a great grab for the money. It cuts out all the time I lose signals on my laptop while Im downstairs. I have to go all the way up to the second floor and unplugged the router allow it to reset to get it to function again. A very big inconvenience...

column9: Works well until it stops working well
column10: Owned for about 2 years. First year was peachy. Second year, I had to intermittently restart it due to slowing speeds and lagging issues.Over the past month it has required daily restarts, frequently stalling.I restored factory settings to no avail. Yes, the firmware is updated. I'm happy I bought it refurbished.

I'm writing this after having it for about 1 year and 3 months. It was working great up until the last 2 months or so in which it began to randomly lose signal and shut down for no reason. As of this moment I had to connect to my PHONES data connection in order to write this because the wifi capabilities on the netgear are NULL. Thus, I am about to look for another wireless router from a different brand because after having similar problems from 3 different netgear products, I am done. I am the type of person that is willing to spend a little more money to get a better product, however, this time it seems to have bit me in the rear. Can't recommend this product to anyone.

column9: Keeps dropping wireless connections - its gone
column10: First NetGear router I have bought. Work for a while then the wireless connections kept dropping - first to my laptops, then to my wireless printers.  Was rebooting twice a day.  Also the USB connection to attached drive was very slow. Am now replacing with a competitors router.

column9: Hope you dont need any product support
column10: This is a great product, if you don't have any porting, homegroup identification needs, or IP issues .Cons: If you need technical support. Forget it they will question you to death. I was surprised they did not ask for what type of routers and internet my neighbors have. Then they put you on hold forever.Pros: it works great for streaming with all devices.

column9: don't buy it. i did and regret it.
column10: customer support costs you money after 90 days and it costs you the same amount of money it costs to buy a new one...horrible!

Worked ok at first. The new features made up for not being able to vpn to my work network. My old 3500 made the vpn conection every time. THE READYSHARE JUST STOPED WORKING. Their helpdesk is not usefull at all. Buy another 3500.

I had trouble setting this up and getting it to work with the Comcast Modem.  Made several calls and finally they sent a replacement.  After still having trouble it was suggested by a friend that I change the IP address to not conflict with the modem.  This done, it is now working most of the time.  I still have to unplug it to reset it and make it work about once a week.  Why did the Netgear  tech people not know this?

This is a very good router, until the radio dies! I bought it 2 years ago and never had any complaints. I loved it!! Until last week when the radio suddenly died. Online forums suggest this is a known issue with some devices in some batches, but still you never know if its your lucky day or not when you buy this.When I spent $140 2 years back, I expected it to last more than 2 years. My comcast supplied, free (after MIR) D-Link 802.11g router is 8 years old and still works like a charm. So beware!

column9: Could've been great, but way too unreliable...
column10: This router is fast when it works, but it locks up several times per day, requiring it to be rebooted. I'm replacing it.

I had to exchange this unit twice. Still the new unit disconnects from Internet. Even their Tech Support was not much help.Tossed it aside and bought a new one from Netgear's competitorNot recommended at all.---------------------------------------------------------------An Update to my post above:Few days after I wrote this comment, I received the email below from Netgear representatives. I received a phone call from Dinesh Kannappan, whom, I had never communicated with before - nor heard of him. He is a technical support engineer from Netgear's HQ in San Jose CA.Dinesh asked to sent the new unit to his lab for test (which I did). Few days later, he informed me that, he flashed the PROM in the Router, and made sure all the Software is update-to-date. Also he run a two day continued rigorous test, after which he found it working fine.After receiving the Router, Dinesh advised me to contact my Internet provider, to 'Reset & Restart' my account. Then I tried the unit with no problem - while he kept in touch with me, to monitor, and make sure the unit works as promised. He also suggested to keep the case open for 10 days, to make sure everything is fine with my unit.What is fair is fair. Netgrear did stand behind its product. So far, I am very pleased with the way Dinesh & Netgear had handle this problem. This company is fortunate to have dedicated employees as Dinesh.I will buy another netgear product, and will recommend them to others.

column9: Almost works, tech support non existent
column10: This router is fast and all, but the software is pretty poor and the tech support is awful, worse than nothing in fact. Parental controls don't really do anything but send you through Open DNS. The claim that you can use 'Time based' controls is kinda useless because it is only based on web page addresses. Kids today ain't use the router that way, they're using apps. I've got one windows machine that can see the USB drive, one that can but won't FTP or map to it, and not sure yet about the Mac, though it doesn't look promising. Debating whether to send it back for another brand. In any case, it is fast hardwired to my computer but doing nothing to improve my Netgear media box. sigh.UPDATEDon't be fooled by the appearance of customer service from Netgear indicated by their comment on this review. I emailed them on the 22nd and have yet to hear. I've just printed my return label and am buying the comparable ASUS model. From what I can see, these routers all have 5 and 1-star reviews, so they're all tricky depending on your needs.UPDATE AGAINGot my UPS Label and it's going back. Purchased the Asus instead. All is well.

It was a great upgrade from my previous router until recently it just wouldn't connect to my devices (IPhone/PSV/PSP).  Then it would connect to my laptop and lastly it wouldn't connect to my consoles.  It only connects wireless to my Smart TV and any type of wired connection.  I dont know if its a firmware update or if the small devices that i have had updates that did something.  I have tried everything.  I HATE THIS PRODUCT....only reason i gave it 2 stars is because it worked for 2 months.  I do not recommend this product.  I used to like Netgear maybe the product was faulty.  Im going to check the warranty and see if i can return it if not ill just give up and buy a product from a different company.Bottom line do not get this!

I purchased this router over a year ago.  I finally left Linksys and decided that I would go with a company that many in my field said was one of the best.  CNET and other online web sources rated it one of the better choices.  I can't argue that the router performed okay for the first 3 months.  I did start to see patterns where the router would loose connection to the internet and I would have to reboot it once every three days or so.  I tried working with fios and seemed that all their settings worked perfectly which lead me to believe that there was another root issue.  This didn't change the constant rebooting I had to do with my router.  What really added a game changing opinion here was the addition of 4 new wireless devices on my network.  For some reason this device had issues allowing all types of hardware to connect to it. At any given point it would slow my internet to a crawling stop and even hose my Vonage. I made the decision to move off this router and get a new one.  I recommend the MediaLink over this router any day of the week on performance and price comparison alone.What I had plugged in wirelessly:-  3 laptops-  Wireless print server-  2 Iphones-  2 Androids-  Ipad-  Galaxy 10-  wireless scale-  Heart rate monitor-  wireless thermostat-  Google boxAt any given point 4 devices would always fail and I would have to reboot this router.  Additionally the user interface is very complicated and frustrating.  Making changes take forever and the unit seems to overheat at times.  All and all I was extremely disappointed.

Purchased this router about 3 weeks ago and am disappointed I did.  I purchased this device in order to consolidate my Linksys WRT54G (2.4Ghz G) and Apple Time Capsule (5Ghz N) into one device with the dual band capability.I setup the device when I got it for dual band with the 2.4 Ghz and 5 Ghz frequencies operating separately.  Unfortunately, I was unable to ever come close to the advertised speed of 300Mbps on the 5Ghz wireless N side.  The closest I ever get is around 108Mbps and I am only about 10 feet away from the router.  I've tried to change the channel to every single channel available and still was unsuccessful at getting the network speed to go above 108Mbps.My old Time Capsule ran at 5Ghz only and I was able to get the 300Mbps speed without any issue sitting in the same exact spot.  It appears that there is some sort of issue here and I will most likely be sending this device back and looking into something else.I even checked to see if there was a firmware update but it looks like this device is still using the original version of the firmware and that there is no update since that firmware.

I have had a WNDR3700 for about 1-1/2 years and for a while it appeared to be fine.  Recently I have experienced issues with my Panasonic TV and a Epson WF-3540 wireless printer.  Seems I was blaming those products for continual issues when, after reviewing other buyer's issues, it appears to be the Netgear.  I am very tired of having to redo my TV wireless setup each time, and the printer will only recognize my network sporadically.  It seems that this router has DHCP issues...now I don't profess to be an expert, but this things seems to reassign addresses randomly.  That's as technical as I'll get here.  The Netgear website incorrectly led me to a firmware upgrade which was not even valid.Time is too precious to waste much more time on this thing, so I am probably going to do some research and make another purchase.  Maybe the IT folks that recommended Netgear to me had better experiences with older models (or are savvy enough to get around the issues), but after this I doubt I will go down this road again.

column9: Problems with 2.4 GHz range decrease after 10 months ownership
column10: My WNDR3700v2 had good range for both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz wireless devices at first.  About 10 months into ownership my two laptops using the 2.4 wireless connection to my router started losing the signal.  I would get it back strong enough to connect calling up the router with [...] and refreshing the wireless or rebooting.  Now, even that is not working.  Using MetaGeek's InSSIDer I see the signal is -50 Amplitude right next to the router and down to -90 thirty feet away.  That -90 is too low for a reliable connection on 2.4.  My iPad will hold at thirty feet using the 5 GHz channel, but the laptops only have 2.4 wireless.This signal loss can occur on some of this model soon after install or later as on mine, see [...] for more on this.  I am negotiating with Netgear support for a repair or new router.Your later post: Feb 5, 2013Netgear warranty RMA'd me a replacement wndr3700v2, but that too has this low 2.4G signal issue. It appears they just took another router sent back with an issue, reflashed it and sent it to me as a placebo. In responding to my later emails asking for a real fix, such as sending me a wndr3700 of a later ver. that has good wireless signals, support has ignored me. I now would rate this router with only one star. Buyers beware.

I bought this router from staples, because I decided I couldnt wait the three days for Amazon to ship it to me.  It was fairly easy to setup, had good wireless range, a multitude of advanced features, and appeared to be the best router Ive ever bought.  Well about a week into using it I noticed that I didnt have any internet connection.  Both the wired and wireless connections were down.  Not thinking much of it I just powercycled the router and in a few minutes it was back up and running.  In about two hours it was down again.  It doesnt keep the connection and constantly disconnects.  I decided to call netgear tech support and they had me change some of the settings.  It didnt help, I had the same issue.  When I tried to return it to Staples I was one day over their limit for returning an item.  Now Im stuck going back and forth with netgear trying to get them to replace it.  I recently bought a linksys router, one of the cheaper ones, and I havent had any problems yet.  In conclusion the router works great when its working.  If you like to constantly loose your internet and reboot your router this is the one for you.

column9: works just as good as the previous Asus router, that cost me half as much
column10: installed the product; performed the firmware upgrade, rebooted the router a couple of times; it offers two channels (bands) <ssid> and <ssid>_5G...but both are slower than the mysterious <SSId>_EXT that appears out of no where and is the fastest of all 3, but not faster than the Asus router that I had before....only problem is I paid twice as much for this equipment.

column9: 2yrs Until Failure - Netgear Has The Worst Customer Support
column10: Like most Netgear products, this router is a nice looking piece of hardware with a nice group of features. I enjoyed it well for 2 years until one of the two radios died. This unit has two radios. One radio supports B and G networks and includes the guest network, the other radio supports N networks which are faster. Unfortunately, it was the radio that supported the guest network feature that croaked. It's not totally dead but the chip is fried to the point where it drops constantly. I used it as an AP in my living room supporting about 8 clients consisting of smartphones, laptops and tablets. No heavy use at all. One radio still works (802.11 N) and the gigabit ethernet ports still work so it's useful in my bedroom as an AP since the range of the N radio is so weak.NOTE- If you aren't tech savvy enough to follow manuals and figure out basic troubleshooting on your own, DO NOT BUY ANY NETGEAR PRODUCTS! Netgear has the worst customer support. They have a system where you get a really short term of support and after that they charge you to answer any questions at all. They will constantly try to sell you a worthless support contract where they promise to help you with any network problem on any device. Don't buy it. It is a total ripoff because their support staff are completely clueless. Trying to get an RMA from these guys is a total PITA and you will get the runaround from some less than friendly folks in third world countries. I can't tell you how many hours and lies I've gotten from these people.Buyer beware. Don't say I didn't warn you.Overall, I'd say pass on this Wifi router. There are many sub-$50 gigabit ethernet routers/switches and sub-$50 Wifi router/APs out there that won't die within two years of usage, from manufacturers that won't make you want to go postal. I used to be a fan of Netgear products but after investing in a NAS and this router and seeing them both have serious problems with no support and horrible firmware updates I won't be giving them any of my money again.

column9: Hard to Configure, Poor Documentation for Advanced Functions, and Difficult to Extend Existing Network
column10: This product should be fine as a basic router, but does not serve well in any advanced capacity.  The configuration UI is very hard to navigate, and the product comes with only bare-bones documentation.  It is not capable of automatically switching between 2.4 and 5 GHz networks, so you must have *two* separate SSID's and pick manually with your devices which one to use.  Though the documentation claims that it can act to extend an existing wireless network, there are no instructions for enabling this fairly complicated feature; when I discovered how, it turns out that it can only extend an *unencrypted* network (i.e. no WPA2).  Given that this is not Netgear's "basic" offering and the high price, I was disappointed.

column9: works great for about 1 year then dies
column10: I see lots of people have these and they work just fine. Forget the usb port, I got it to work but it is so slow. Use Drop box. After a year the 2.4g band just died. Buy it from bestbuy and get a 2 year warrenty, glad I did.Now I have the 6200r with AC band. had initial problem with the limited speed to 73ghz but got it sorted and now speed testing shows a major improvement. One thing. TECH SUPPORT is a joke. They don't know there own products. The are idiots who tell you to do what is on there screen even if it has nothing to do with the problem you have. wasted hours and then they hang up. ask for someone who speaks english and you might have a chance of them understanding your specific problem, but they still may noy have an answer. So far it was worth the cost of the 6200r in terms of REAL speed improvment. Hope it lasts longer than a year. No there is not a better router available currently. I even tried the apple airport v5 and it suffered from the limited speed problem and there is not way to get to any setting to fix it.also the 6300r has 2 usb ports that are just as useless for an extra $50.00. stick to the 6200r

column9: Looking for Parental Controls? Look elsewhere
column10: Bought this router (WNDR3700v4) to replace the Asus RT-N56U which was replacing my Linksys WRT54G. After two purchases, the WRT54G, while dying, is still in action. Why? The consumer networking industry has forgotten how to build Parental Control into a router.If you saw the claim by Netgear for their Live Parental Controls that has 'Centralized & easy-to-use website filtering for all devices connected to the Internet via the router' and thought that it would be great for your family? Think again. Those Live Parental Controls require OpenDNS and other external setup and configuration. It is NOT built into the router firmware. Very disappointing.Also a major head scratcher is that the WNDR3700v4's Keyword filtering and Block Sites is NOT done with MAC Address, but IP Address! To make matters worse, instead of creating a list of blacklisted devices that have policies assigned to them, Netgear has you add all the devices you want to Whitelist. Are you kidding me? Finally, in the keyword filtering, there is a box that says 'Allow Trusted IP Address to view blocked sites', and you only get to add ONE of your Trusted IPs. WTF are you thinking Netgear?I only made it far enough to let the WNDR3700 detect my connection and let me start setting things up, first and foremost the above. I cannot comment on the wireless/wired performance or anything else about this hardware. I'm returning this and moving on to the next vendor. Maybe I'll go back to Cisco/Linksys and see if they still have it figured out after all this time. Netgear, I hope you see this and do something about it.

The product worked great at first. It out-performed the Linksys router that it replaced. However, after about 2 months, it stopped working. I called Netgear and they sent me another (not the best customer service) It took about 2 weeks to get a replacement router through Netgear. They offer expedited shipping for some absorbent charge, not free as they should. The replacement never worked. Good thing I kept the old Linksys as a back-up. Not sure that Netgear products are worth it...If you have been satisfied with a different brand and are just looking to upgrade, recommend sticking to a non-Netgear brand.UPDATE - Netgear, after seeing my review,  contacted me to offer another replacement for the product. I appreciate their commitment to their product, but I have decided not to accept it. A company only gets a second chance with me, and their second chance (the replacement) failed.

This router performs well.  However, its missing many configuration features that I've seen on routers 5 years older then it.  The firmware tries so hard to be stupid proof that its actually harder to use of you know what your looking for.  The DHCP and port mapping features are bare bones and not very robust.

column9: Edit: not as solid as I thought
column10: I'm no router expert, but my last Linksys draft G router was dropping connectivity a lot, and firmware upgrades didn't seem to fix it. Decided to try this, and our connectivity is much better. Range reads as a bit less than that linksys, possibly owing to the fact that that one had 3 big antennas poking out of it, and this one's got everything tucked inside.-----------------------------------Edit: been running this for a couple months now. Seems fairly solid, but range has been lacking a bit, and some of the alleged features don't actually work at all.For instance: 'Guess access' doesn't work. If you enable it, guests have access to your entire LAN, as if it weren't guest access at all. When you tick off the boxes to restrict access to the local network, then no one can connect to the guest channel at all. There are forum posts about this issue at netgear suggesting a firmware upgrade BUT there are many, many more forum posts detailing that the firmware upgrade can be a nightmare, and rolling back (if necessary) and even bigger nightmare. It was a non-issue for me anyway as Netgear's support site is broken and didn't let me get the firmware files. (lucky me, I guess).

Pros:With the prior firmware, it's reliable but some functions do not work.Good coverage and throughput.###################Con:Many functions do not work as expected. Namely, 'attached devices' does not register all devices on the network no all of the DHCP leases. The router does strange things with ICMP on the local lan. Basically, I cannot scan the network for live hosts. It seems to rewrite the ACK ICMP with the originating device's IP. DHCP reservation does not work at all.###################Other ThoughtsDD-WRT is not stable on the router.SSH would be nice###################Conclusion:I'm considering shelving this router and going back to my WNR3500 with Tomato. The only reason I upgraded was for the dual band availability. However, broken features cause a lot of issues with my network.

This would be my last Netgear product bought, I've bought other Netgear prodccts s.a. swtitches and other routers, hoping that they would have improved upon their previous models, sadly that is not the case.  With regards to the current router, I can't make it port forward to different computers on the LAN using the same internal port number 3389 for RDP, it seems the interface wants to have a different internal port number for each computer that I want to remote desktop, that's stupid.  I'll try if DD-WRT can get around this.  Otherwise, the router has been ok, I just hate the interface and its limited capability.

I received the above product(Netgear Router) and it said there should be a CD enclosed and there was NONE.  Also where it said serial number there was none so I now can not register it.Have it hooked up now after hours of trying because of no CD to show me how to lock others out.

the features for this product are great, and they would've been better if the router didn't keep disconnecting.the router keeps resetting, and stays in a state where you can't use it.say 15 minutes usage, and 5 minutes disconnected.

I bought one of these in July of 2011 and have been using it as the only wireless access for two teenagers and two adults.  It hosts both Ethernet and wireless devices on both 2.5GHz and 5GHz wireless networks.  It is now June 2012 and in the last 2-3 weeks we have all been noticing that the wireless access has become very flaky.  There are times when all devices get dropped and other times when devices appear connected but are unable to transmit/receive data.  I haven't changed any settings lately, it just seems to have become unstable.  I have power cycled the Netgear AP a couple of times but it doesn't seem to help.  In a different part of the house I have another wireless network that passes its traffic back to this Netgear access point over Ethernet and find that this second wireless device is very stable and fast.  It isn't a conflict between the two devices because they coexisted for several months without problems until recently.  Also, I live in a rural area where my neighbors aren't very close so I don't believe there is any interference introduced by them.  If you want a device that you can setup and forget, this may not be the one.  I was very happy with it until recently and now I'm going to have to play with settings to try and figure out if it is a firmware configuration  problem or if the hardware is just bad.

column9: Great and highly customizable, but dead within the year
column10: When this device first arrived it worked great. Strong signal, good interface, and streamed data perfectly. As an added perk this router allows you to change the firmware and install DDWRT on it and enable dozens of more features only found in very expensive wi-fi equipment. However, the radios that are built into this device have continued to get weaker and weaker and now only devices in the same room are able to connect to the router. Now I need to buy a new router. :(
I bought this router to solve performance problems with another router. It performed very well for two years and five months and then died. I'd have given it a 5 if it had lasted longer.

column9: You pay for what you get. Not a DNLA server
column10: Great price and took no time to set-up! Very straight forward set-up. Do have an issue once and a while that I need to re-boot the Router once and a while cause I lose my speeds of downloading, but from what I have experienced with most Routers it needs to be done!!LOVE the USB port on the back for an external hard drive. the DNLA is a little crappy doesn't show the list of complete videos on the Hard Drive when trying to access it from a TV, but works GREAT just to be able to have access for numerous computers all at one time.After owning ths thing for over a year, I must say the only good thing it does, is be a WIRELESS ROUTER, other wise it is a total CRAP DNLA Server. I had used if for over a year as that and no matter what I did only 5% of my video files were accessible from any TV.So the past week I have purchased a Seagate FlexGo Home and everything works good now.So if your buying this to be a DNLA server for a extra hard drive, DON'T waster your money, it's a ROUTER and that is the only good thing it does.After over a year using this product I have decided to go back to Linksys. I loved the idea of the DNLA service, but when ONLY the router allows you to see 5% of what's on a 2 TB hard drive, no sense of wasting my money. no updates, and seems like Netgear doesn't care about customers.

I got this Router in July 2011, and it has been very reliable initially.I did not experienced any 'Drops' for the first Year, while having all the following devices connected:1) ROKU: Wired2) SONY DVD: Wired3) NETTALK DUO VoIP (2 of them): Wired4) Dell Inspiron ONE AOI Computer: Wireless5) Dell XPS M1330 Laptop: Wireless6) HP OfficeJet 6500A Plus Printer: Wireless7) IPAD2; Wireless8) Iphone 3GS: Wireless9) Iphone 4: Wireless10) Nintendo 3DS: WirelessI am using a MODEM provided by COX Cable, MODEL: AMBIT (U10C018)I was initially getting excellent connections in all the rooms in my Condo, and even by the Swimming Pool and Club House (~100 Feet away)which allows me to use my free WiFi in my IPAD and Iphones.At teh time of purchase I got excellent Technical Support from NETGEAR just prior to purchasing the Router to ensure Compatibility with the MODEM Model I have, and I did not have any need to call them back ever since.One NOTE worthwhile here as advised by the NETGEAR Technical Support is to NOT UPDATE the FIRMWARE during Installation,or after installation.I initially gave it 5 Stars a Year ago and strongly recommended this product...until the range performance changed dramatically recently.See 15-Oct-2012 UPDATE Below.______________________________________________________________________________________UDPATE 15-Oct-2012 (BE CAUTIOUS: Reliability Issues after 1 Year !!! Can not Recommend this Product Anymore.)The Range of the WiFi Router has dropped significantly after ~13months of use for no apparent reason, apart from having new Neighbots in adjacent Appts moving in during the past year.Now I can hardly get any signal in 2 of the Rooms in my 2 Bdr Apt (~12 Feet away) while the Signal Sterngth drops to about half when more than 6ft away from Router.
