The Router has remained at same location at all times, with no changes to any hardware settings or mving any other applioances in close proximity.Since I have an Electronics Engineering background, I tried the following to check if the Signal would improve from 1 Bar at 12 ft away to Full Bars being normal again:1)'Updated Firmware' from V1.0.0.6 to V1.0.0.12Result: No Observable Signal Range Improvement (still get Full Bars at 6ft and 1 Bar at 12ft)2)Changed 'Wireless Port' Channels on both b/g/n and a/n one at a timeResult: No Observable Signal Improvement Change for any Port Channel Number combination. Reset it back to Auto Default for b/g/n and Channel 44 for a/n3)In 'Advanced Wireless Setting' I switched 'Preamble Mode' from 'Auto' to 'Short'Result: No Observable Wireless Signal Range Improvement. Reset back to AUTOMATIC.4)In 'Wireless Settings' I Switched from WPA2-PSK [AES] to NONE.Result:No Observable Wireless Signal Range Improvement. Reset back to WPA2-PSK [AES]5) Elevated Physical Height of Router by 2ft (No Change)6) Rebooted Router and Modem several times. (No Change).7) Performed 'PING TEST':PING: 13ms, with 2ms Jitter (Very Good)8) Performed 'INTERNET SPEED TEST' (Better than Specs of COX/COMSAT Service Provider) :Download Speed: 32 MbpsUpload Spedd: ~6 MbpsSo I figure that I either now I have 'Strong Interference' from my Neighbor's Electronics and/or Routers, or the WNDR37v2 is slowly Dying...after 1 Year...but I am afraid is the later...Very Dissapointing Reliability for a High End Router...Hopefully a Netgear Technical Savvy Engineering Tech/Customer Support can offer some short of explanation and recommendations...on why the Router Signal Strength drops so radically after 1 Year of great use...and what needs to be done to fix it...as to me it looks like that Routers are Build by Design to Last only 1 Year so you go out and buy a newer Model...to keep Router Company Revenues going strong...(Hope that this is not the Case...)__________________________________________________________________________________UDPATE 17-Oct-2012After reading more reviews with similar issues for this Netgear Model it appears that there is a Poor Hardware Design for the 2.4Ghz Radio which starts failing after a period of time...I am in a way lucky that mine lasted at least 1 Year at great range...as others report the same issue after only a few months...Very dissapointing to say the least as at the time I paid premium $$$ for this Router ~$160... and the ROI is not there...I would not be surprised if it was build Overseas...to increase the company's Profit Margins at the expense of manufactuirng Poor Quality Products without any decent Reliability for the money paid for...My next Router will not be a NETGEAR (that was my 3rd Netgear Router that lasted only about a Year or less) as NETGEAR seem to have Low Quality Standards when it comes to building Reliable Routers that last more than 1 Year...One would expect that at least for the Higher End $$$ Routers they would run 'Accelarated Life Tests' to at least see whether the Hardware Design and Materials used would justify the High Value of the Product.

column9: Good as long as you avoid using the USB
column10: WNDR3700V2 - Bought March 2012 - Despite some years ago a previous Netgear Router(WPN824) starting to drop service after just over a year, and necessitating the reversion to the D Link DI-624, it was meant to replace, thought would try Netgear again.Setup was not quite as straightworward as would have hoped and eventually got it up and running within an hour.Wireless connectivity was great and an improvement on the DI-624.Problems arose when connected a storage device (Seagate Freeagent Go Flex 500GB - on the Netgear 'compatible' list for this Router) to the USB port.  It originally worked but was incredibly slow and then on about the third time of use it could not be found.  Following which the wire connection to a laptop on a docking station failed to work - the laptop on the docking station could 'see' the Router but not the network or internet, other wired computers were fine and turning the wireless on (and then off) on the docking station laptop resolved the problem.  But it occurred every time the laptop was undocked/docked.  The USB storage could still not be accessed from any computer.OK so it probably has something to do with the laptop being taken back and forth on and off the docking station, and if all it had required was a reboot of the laptop each time then that could have been lived with but with paying extra and the USB not working, it is going back before being stuck with it and the (almost ten years old now) DI-624 is back in service.

column9: Poor tech service - defective equipment - bad combination
column10: I bought one of these to replace a G rated Linksys that I had for 7 years, working fine, but needed N band.  Could not get it to work as it kept kicking off the devices after about 2-5 minutes.  I spent over 2 hours on tech support, working my way up the food chain to senior techs.  Same drill, no resolution.  They would never acknowledge that the unit could be faulty.  Fed up, I finally returned it for a refund.  I would point out that at one point, the Netgear tech claimed my computer was at fault and tried to sell me a $300 off site computer service.  Anyway, I bought an Asus after investigating (model RT56u), hooked it up in a few minutes following easy instructions.  Amazingly, every device worked immediately: desktop, laptop, 2 smartphones, mac and smart tv.  No problems at all.  This proves that either the Netgear device was defective, too hard to set up or just buggy.  What angers me is the time that I spent on this equipment and the inadequate tech help that they provide at Netgear.  So remember that if you have a problem with this router, it might not be you after all but a defect in the router.  Personally, I am really happy with the Asus.  A bit hard to find, but worth the wait for me.

Bought Router, worked great for several months, then I started having devices drop off the WiFi signal.  Reset router and all is good for a few weeks, then devices start dropping the WiFi signal again.  Called Netgear for support, but surprise, after 90 days I have  to pay for support.  Service options are $35 for one incident (limited to 30 minutes support), $70 for 6 months or $100 for a year.  I signed up for a year of support, what a mistake.  1st call, they had me reboot my router (which always fixes the problem for a short while).  2nd call, they try to sell me a contract extension and then leave me sitting on hold for 55 minutes before a foreign tech support finally gets on the phone.  Fifty Five minutes wait time for tech support that I just paid for, on a product that is still under its manufactures warrantee.  Completely unacceptable.

I bought this brand new back in April 2010 from another store, for $140.  It was the fastest WiFi AP that I had ever used.  However, just a month ago, both the 2.4GHz and 5GHz radio died.  Quite suddenly, too.  Unfortunately, it's out of warranty, so I'm stuck with a box that's essentially now a Gigabit hub (which I can pick up from Amazon for $30).The reason I don't give a 1-star because Netgear support did try their best to help me troubleshoot it over the phone.  It's too bad they couldn't help me replace the hardware.I read on the internet the earlier versions of this router (v1 - which is mine), had many premature radio deaths. I'm not sure if I could avoid it back then, but now you can.

Transmitter got very weak during the year I've owned it. the web site offers support but  pushes forums very hard  and takes extraordinary efforts in avoiding  an actual tech support interaction with a customer. Eventually  it was replaced under warranty after a month of emails. Hopefully the new one will work more than a year. I'd go with the Asus  router if I had to do it again.

I purchased this so I could stream netflix to my TV. Well I still cannot because it doesn't work right and is a PIA to set up. Last, it caused my DSL to go down. When I disconnected it DSL started working fine again. I am not happy. I am going to try again but regardless it should be easy to set up.

I bought this a couple of months ago but was not able to install it until last week.  I called support twice before I installed it because somebody mentioned that this dual band will automatically find the appropriate band for each device. My devices are set up to automatically connect to my single band router so I asked if I can give the use the same SSID I have in my old Netgear router and also use the same SSID for both bands of the new one.  I was told it was fine.  When I installed the router, it would not allow me to use the same SSID for both, so I called again.  I was told it should be ok and she walked me through the Netgear Genie (same steps that I did before) and of course with the same result.  After she place me on hold, she asked me to add "-5G" to the other SSID and of course it accepted.  She told me that it will be separate login for the 2 bands.  I told her that the previous Tech told me that the switching will be automatic.  After several reiterations of the issue, she finally told me  that once logged into one band the router should be able to figure what band to use.When I started using the router,  I noticed that my devices have slowed down (Ipad, Google TV, Laptop),  The laptop is directly wired to the router and it is still slow compared to my old Netgear N300.  I tried to login to the 5Ghz band and it ran faster.  All my devices were set up to connect with the 2.4Ghz band.  When I ran a speedtest I was only getting 1.8 with this router when my modem is doing 12.x to 15.x.I was pleased with my N300 and quite disappointed this N600.

Same issue as some of the other negative reviewers. The router worked great for about 6 months and then began to drop connections several times per hour through out the day. Not only does it drop wireless connections, it drops wired connections as well. When the connection goes down you'll know because you'll lose the ability to use the internet as well as the ability to use the network to access other devices and files. I can verify this as well by trying to log in to the router console via routerlogin.net through a hard wired computer. It's a sure thing the router is not working when you can't even access the router log-in itself. I will say that tech support has been great. They have actively emailed me and they even sent me a replacement model. Needless to say, the replacement model has the exact same problems(sure wish I was one of these lucky reviewers with no problems). I've updated firmware, followed all tech support steps, tried new cables, tried computers other than my own and in the end, it's the router that is malfunctioning.Unfortunately, this type of issue seems to occur in similar products by other manufacturers based on reviews I've read from other brands/models. Don't know that you'll find a router that doesn't have negative reviews of this sort but at least I've informed you of my experience with this one. Gave it two stars because it's a great product when it's working and I've been happy with the support but the main thing is that it only works about 30 minutes out of every hour. When the connections go down, they stay down for about 10 minutes typically and then come back up again. Technically, this router only works half of the time. For the price and the brand, this device should work correctly.Note: Did not purchase this item off of Amazon but I did purchase it new from another retailer. I wanted to leave a review since I use Amazon frequently and know how important these reviews are to so many of us.

I bought this router and it worked fine until a just recently.  My laptops (Mac/Windows) lose connection 2-3 times per hour.  The Wan port loses connectivity and resets. The customer support is terrible I have already been elevated to tier III and had no luck fixing the problem.  I'm going to go with a Cisco product instead

column9: Worked OK for about a year then bottoms up
column10: Worked OK for about a year then bottoms up.  I never did get portable drives attached to the integral USB port to be recognized or useable over the network.  I owned this device for about a year, then it started dropping connections several times a day.  I'm not happy that a 'top of the line' consumer wireless router lasted a year.  If I had to replace all my electronics every year, I'd be broke.  I expect to get at least 3 years usable service from something priced so high.I haven't given up entirely on Netgear products, however.  I'm about to try the WNDR3400.

If you set the 2.4GHz radio to use channel 11 you won't be able to connect to it or it locks up!I tried 3 different ones and they all have the same problem, so I decided to return it.  Netgear was no help.I bought the cheaper WNDR3400 which has all the same features as this one except the ethernet is only 100MB instead of gigabit, and it works properly.  The range on the WNDR3400 was even a little better than this one.

After one year this router is dropping both wireless and wired connections at random times. The unit was working ok until about nine months in use and then began to drop connections, requiring a restart each time. Now it drops three or more times each day, and it is impossible to watch Netflix movies all the way through or use the internet for an extended period. When it works it is very fast, but I cannot have these dropped connections especially since they seem to be getting more frequent. I have purchased a Cisco-Linksys E4200 router that hopefully will last longer than a year and offer more reliable performance.

column9: Be careful - this only APPEARS to be a good deal
column10: My brand new Netgear N600 (WNDR3700) purchased from Amazon last month now only works when I'm within about 10-15 feet of it. Because it's over 30 days, Amazon isn't offering a complete refund. It appears to be a known problem with this model.The issue: the 2.4Ghz radio on my WNDR3700v2 has lost so much power so that I can now connect only if I'm within about 10 feet of the router. I'm a computer engineer by training and tried everything I could think of - changing the the channels (one by one), updating the firmware to v10, hardware reset, playing with the preamble and tuning other parameters - all to no avail. Measured the dbm: the signal for the 2.4 radio barely registers, although it's fine for the 5Ghz.There are many many people with this exact problem; it is most likely a hardware issue. See, for example threads even in the NETGEAR support forums - just run a Google search on 'WNDR3700 2.4Ghz radio problem'. Usually happens about 3-9 months after purchase, although mine happened in about 45 days.NETGEAR's response (according to online complaints) has been to ship people refurbished models that develop the same problem over time. Some people are onto their third router. I've put in a complaint with NETGEAR and will see how their customer service treats me. For now, I would suggest prospective buyers avoid this model to avoid having to deal with the hassle. I've put in two stars because it was an awesome router - until it died.

I've had the router for a couple years and I will point out the down side first which is DLNA.  I have a hard drive hooked into the unit's USB port with DLNA enabled.  This feature is unreliable.  I have a DLNA enabled TV and my PS3.  There are media files missing when accessing through either device.  I work in technology and have my own hobbies so I can say with 99% certainty that I'm not the problem.  I can run a DLNA server on my computer and access and play these files through my TV and PS3.  I can even point my DLNA server on the PC to the network folder which is my hard drive attached to the wndr3700 and both devices can see all files but not play the files reliably because the traffic is going back and forth in order to reach the devices (going in circles).  I've had some success in moving files around in order to have them indexed by the router's DLNA but this is also hit and miss.  I've read forums where I'm not the only one with this issue.  Any advice Netgear Team?  I've also read that V2 of this router may not have the issue.  Is that true?  Please help.Now the good.  Simply put, everything but DLNA.  The attached storage works well and I can access all files unlike with the DLNA.  It is a reliable router with good features.  I've only given this item 2 stars because DLNA is a very important feature to me and would hope it gets Netgear's attention.

I bought this router in late February.  Amazon shipped it quickly and it arrived in just a few days.  It was very easy to setup, had a great range and worked flawlesly.  Now 7 months later it is dead.  The router is buzzing and the wireless is dead.  The wired method works but I need wireless.  I don't know if I would buy a Netgear again because its life was so short.

column9: Not as good as it is made out to be
column10: I got this router back in Feb 2011. I was very excited to get it because so a lot of the positive reviews and for the speeds. I got the router and it took forever to setup. NOT because I didn't know how to set it up but because it wouldn't let me go to routerlogin (whatever the site is) to set it up! After an hour or so I was able to get on the site to set it up.As for speeds, the first few weeks were great. I got pretty decent speeds and connections. However, as soon as I did the update, I lost all my good internet speeds. Eventually, I wasn't even able to stream from Netflix or play a game online without being interrupted at least once or if I wasn't interrupted, I would have terrible internet connections.Hard-lining into the router did not help at all and I got the same speeds hard-lining. I tried resetting the router to its factory conditions, but this has only made the router worse. When I tried calling the customer service, I was put on hold and after 20 minutes I gave up.Lately, my router is completely unreliable! It drops out no less then three times a day, making me have to shut off the router and then reboot it. I am so frustrated at this point because I am still not getting fast connections and it is completely unreliable. I am going to get rid of this router as soon as I can.Be warned that while some people are getting great connections and like the router, for some people like myself it is terrible!

Product is too expensive for the service delivered.  Installation was easy enough but actual function became difficult because of the two frequencies.  I was unable to make both frequencies secure and after several attempts managed to render one frequency totally inoperable.

I've had this router for nearly a year and it worked perfectly until about a month ago. Now, it 'drops connection' about once per hour and I have to 'power cycle' it to restore connectivity. I have updated firmware (no effect on the problem) and I am out of ideas on how to address the problem. It still works great - when it works, but it sure is a nuisance to have to reboot it every time I want to use the internet.

I have mixed views on this device. Directly connected ports and ethernet over powerline adapters seem to work well. However, the wifi part (both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz) seem shaky, with frequent connection slowdowns and drops as compared with my 2.4 GHz DSL wifi modem (connection never drops EVER).Above average technical savvy needed with this device to set up, establish secure WPA passwords, etc. Seems to need a power cycle periodically to restore decent wifi access, especially with my wireless network printer.I bought a second laptop (high end Dell XPS 17), but I have the same issues with sluggish/dropped connections. I cannot tell if this is wifi coverage issue or interference with other devices in the home (2.4 GHz PS3 wireless controllers, DSL wifi modem, 5.8 GHz cordless phone).Compared to my 2WIRE and Motorola Netopia DSL wifi router, this is a very unstable device. Note that the technical support groups in Dell, Comcast and Netgear all suggest the problem is with the other company's devices:-)

column9: Nice features, but too many network drops
column10: After 5 or so years of putting up with a Cisco/Linksys WRT54GS2V1 that overheats (ran a laptop fan under it), I decided to try the Netgear N600 (WNDR3700v2 or whatever it's called) based on friends' recommendations for the brand.  I've been maintaining wired and wireless networks in my home for over 15 years so I was pleasantly surprised by the ease of installation, support for both 2.4 and 5 Mhz networks at the same time, and being able to easily configure a guest network.  I connected my cable modem to the router's WAN port, and my desktop PC, OOMA, HP Printer and DISH satellite receiver (via RF wireless) to the 4 LAN ports.  My work laptop, Android phone, wife's iPod and my son's two desktops were all configured to access the wireless network, although typically no more than 3 or 4 of these devices would use it at once.  Once it was all up and running and I upgraded the firmware to 1.0.0.8, my son's computers picked up 3 bars of 5 instead of 2 in wireless signal strength, I no longer needed the fan and all was well ... for about 3 hours.  That's when wireless or both the wired and wireless networks started dropping from the internet.After multiple resets and re-checking the configs, I finally called Netgear tech support. I reviewed my network device environment, router setup, firmware level and my problem.  She had had me change some advanced network settings and the wireless channel. (.soapbox on:  Now I work for a multi-national company and have traveled the world so I generally don't have a big problem with accents, but I found myself having to ask Netgear's support staff in India to repeat themselves A LOT.  And when I'm having a problem with your equipment, let's focus on that and not ask me about my holiday weekend or my hobbies.  .soapbox off:)Now instead of needing a reset every couple of hours, the N600 needed a reset just a couple of times a day. Better, but still a problem since a) my home phone is on this network via the Ooma, and b) Internet access is like electricity and water in my house ... it just *has* to work all of the time.  I called Support again and got new settings to try and was informed of yet another firmware upgrade to download and install manually, which apparently the N600 didn't know existed.  I installed the 1.0.0.10 firmware, and called Support one last time where I got a guy with the thickest accent of all, and began to get frustrated when he started asking all of the same questions about my network set up and devices (I have a case # ... don't they write any of this stuff down?).  He put me on hold to talk to Level 2 Support then came back several minutes later, proclaimed it 'defective', and said to take it back to the store and get another one.  Well I took it back and got a refund (glad I bought it at Wal-mart!).  I'm not sure I believe the problem is just this device, but if I can't trust Linksys or Netgear, my options are getting thin.  D-Link?

column9: Refurbished Netgear N600 Wireless Dual Band Router Woe's
column10: I ordered this router refurbished from Amazon, refurbished by NetGear. The unit did not work properly, not allowing me to install the encryption for security. I contacted Amazon, they said contact Netgear. Netgear said the item was not covered by any kind of warrenty even though it came from them. They tried to sell me a maintenace program in order to troubleshoot. I return the unit, and purchased one from my local internet provider (new) and have not had any problems except for it dropping out and haveing to be reset every now and then due to a conflict in ip adresses I have not been able to sort out.

column9: Very good product while the wifi does not fail.
column10: I bought this router, here at Amazon on May 2011, suggested by a friend who was very pleased with it.The setup was straight forward, although I find the web interface of my old LINKSYS router cleaner and more intuitive than this NETGEAR one. Nevertheless I did not face any difficulties setting it up.But guess what. My friends router wifi interface stopped working, and then one month latter mine also stopped working. The problem is related to its coverage range which dropped to less than few feet from the router. My notebook can only access the router via wifi if it is beside the router, even worse the signal is not strong.I searched for support in the manufacturer site to find out that the problem we had has been a recurring problem since early versions of this router. From NETGEAR support I found out that this is not a problem with the routers software. That is a hardware problem.So if you are thinking about buying this router, be advised, you will be very happy.......for only one or two month.
Product's 2.4 ghz bandwidth died. Literally need to stand next to it to receive full signal strength. Would have been a 5 star product if it worked.

This is the 2nd 3700 router from Netgear that I have.  The first one worked great for the first month, after that I was getting constant connection drops which required me to reboot router.  Over time the router would drop connections more frequently until it was finally rendered useless.  The company sent me another router (after I shipped the old one back at my expense) and the problem seems to be starting up again.BUYER BEWARE.

Not as good as my old Belkin router.  Won't always recognize home network.  Have to hard wire it sometimes to gain recognition.  Much slower recongition of some sites, such that I get timed out.  Based on reviews and reputation, I thought it would be a great improvement.  Not at all.  Easy to set up, but performance is inferior.  Cannot recommend it.

Let start off by saying I had my doubts about purchasing this router after some of the reviews I saw here, but noting the NetGear support person on here was trying to show some interest, I figured I'd be just fine. I purchased the router and tried using the CD to do the setup and it couldn't get beyond my having two motherboard ethernet connections. I then called Tech Support. I should have guessed it would have been over a pond as I have trouble with understanding accents. The lady tech person would ask a question and then there always was a huge pause, like being on hold, before I would hear back from her. She said the CD won't work for the install and we will have to manually install. I asked her if I do a reinstall then I should avoid the CD and she said yes. I then asked her if I should do a firmware update and she said I would need to go to their website and match up the firmware I have with what is current on their site. I asked why I couldn't just let the software download a update and she said do it the way she said. We finally got the router up and running, with her help, manually. She said she would send an email asking me to rate her service and was concerned it would be a good response. I then asked her to hold on so I could check to make sure the router was still working. The connection to the Internet had dropped. She then said I would have to go to the site and look up my problem under support or call back and give my case number again. I said it appears your trying to get rid of me and she didn't respond. I never did get an email asking for me to rate her, but I did get a couple of emails that acknowledged my request for support.After several hours and a firmware update through the software I got the router up and running. It has stayed running for several days now, but I'm not sure I'll ever be confident in the router again and will not purchase a NetGear product  because of the lack of decent tech support.The region in the router software shows Africa grayed out with no way to select another country. I called Tech Support back to ask if this would make any difference in how the router would operate in the U.S. They said don't worry about it and it will have no affect. Seems to me they would upgrade their software to fix this as it is something the customer won't be comfortable with and probably generates phone calls to their Tech Support.I always had Linksys routers before and will stay with them in the future. I rarely take the time and effort to post, but I spend a lot of time and effort doing my research before making a purchase and I must say this wasn't what I expected.

First I should add that the unit I bought was a factory refurb. It was easy to set up and has decent G range the N range is very limited. When the unit worked--it worked great, but most of the time it would lose its internet connection, and would stop talking to the roadrunner modem. I tried to work with their overseas Customer service, but they were not helpful and it made communication very difficult. I returned the unit, and I am back to using my 6 year old reliable Linksys wrts54G model.

I got this to replace my old Apple Airport which finally died after 4 or 5 or so years of use. I was excited by the fact that the WNDR3700 could do 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz at the same time as well as supported guest networks.Got it home, hooked up, updated the firmware and started to configure my port forwarding for my remote access but it turns out their port forwarding is pretty limited. One example of this limitation is I map port 80 to port 22 for SSH tunneling over proxy servers, no matter what I tried I couldn't get this work. After searching the support forums I found it wasn't supported and was only available in 'Higher End Routers'. Every router I've owned no matter the cost has supported this and I guess I kind of assumed it would be a standard feature by now.The other issue I had with this device is that we would lose our internet connectivity every 5 to 10 minutes unless you were streaming something. For example, I was using the Hang Out option in G+ and video chatting with some friends just fine but when I opened a new tab the page failed to resolve. When I tried my desktop it to failed to resolve the page. Another example is that I was connected on my work laptop through VPN and everything worked great, but every other device in my house responded as if my internet connection was down. I was reading another review stating that the frequent disconnects could be related to the latest firmware. First thing I did was update the firmware to the latest and greatest version.As a side not: the device seems to work rather well if you install DD-WRT but the signal strength isn't nearly as good my old Airport even after using a configuration guide.I'll probably end up trying out a Cisco/Linksys router or if worse comes to worse I'll break down and fork over the retarded amount of money for the new version of the Apple Airport.

column9: Great Router, would be better if it kepts its connection
column10: I purchased this router because I had an earlier model that worked well. I did read in the reviews that some folks had loss of internet connections. Well they were correct. It seems it will lose connections from 0-5 times a day. It seems you can ping an outside address, but the DNS will not issue an IP to the computer. You must re-start the router. I have upgraded to the .10 version of international firmware and still have the issues. I would say if you can go with another router do. It is working well enough where I don't feel like going through the hassle of a return.

column9: Good Product but pushy extended warranty salesman
column10: When I was unable to get my new Netgear WNDR3700 wireless router to recognize my internet ready TV, I went to Netgear's warranty service number.  Since I have never had experience with wireless components for my home LAN (Local area network), I was hoping to resolve the issue quickly by the Netgear experts.  Well guess what, Netgear's one-year warranty (according to their tech service) does not cover connections to 'third party components' like Interenet ready TVs.  I had to purchase a 6 mo, $69.95 or one-year service contract to get help.  I reluctantly purchased the 6 mo. contract, because I didn't know what else to do.  Then I found out all I had to do was update my router firmware and everything would have worked just fine. All the tech person had to do to help me was to say 'Have you updated your firmware?'  No, the tech person wanted the contract before tipping his hand. Shame on you, Netgear.

The router was easy to setup and connected to all my devices in both 2.4 and 5 ghz.  However, if you are a gamer do not buy this router.  Even with the latest firmware update the connection will drop randomly.  This is not a router for use with online gaming.

I got this router about a month ago. The router is okay but the sharing server is definitely not what is advertised. I wanted to use it to access files on any hard drive. It turned out it does not read the ext4 file system. This is really a shame as all Linux distributions use this filesystem now and this means that if you plug the hard drive from any Linux machine it will not be read. I don't understand why, as it must be enough to just upgrade the kernel in the firmware, nothing more complicated than that.Last time I used it to transfer files on the external device, I got no permission to write. I had to reset the USB device in the end but there was no indication that something was wrong on the USB Storage -> Advanced Settings section. It is hard to say where the fault is, but definitely the device is not user friendly and I would definitely not recommend this product to share your files on the network.The router overall works fine and it replaced my previous one with no quirks. But I bought this version excited about the sharing features and it fell short of my expectations. I also tried the DLNA server with my Google TV and that at least seemed to work fine, so far.

column9: iPhone 4 won't connect & 5Ghz is worthless if you have multiple walls
column10: I live in a neighborhood in a small 2 story house where the houses are about 10 feet apart so I see a lot of networks.  I heard that 5Ghz is a less used frequency so I spent the extra money.The one thing I didn't know about is the effect of walls on higher frequencies.  The 2.8Ghz signal was 2 bars higher than the 5Ghz just one room away.  It seems like if you have a large one room apartment or office, the 5Ghz might help you, but if you have a house with multiple stories and rooms, don't even bother with the 5Ghz option unless you are going to get a $$ repeater for every room.  This router is going back for a WNDR3500L so I can keep wired Gigabit.Update:----------------After 2 weeks, my iPhone 4 won't connect to the router.  It has never had trouble connecting to my routers until this one.  Apparently the 3700v1 router had problems with iPhones, but it was fixed.  I'm not sure why this v2 is having problems although one other user mentioned the same problem last week (6-11-11).Router StatusHardware Version WNDR3700v2Firmware Version  V1.0.0.8GUI Language Version V1.0.0.67

column9: Decent router if you don't use VPN.
column10: Having an issue ith this router and my VPN software (Cisco) fo work.DNS lookups randoly go thru VPN or ou thru internet.Can't blame the router specifically, but since I put my old router in place, the issue hasn't happened again.Need to swap hem agan to cofirm.

column9: Fast Router but a Bit Pricey
column10: There 500+ reviews on this product that cover every aspect or possible issue with this router, so my review will be brief.The Netgear N600 is a fast router that seems reliable so far. Easy set-up which is a really big thing, and fast..fast...fast.The only negative is that for a lot less money, the MediaLink router which I've discovered recently, is probably almost as good for peanuts.

I purchased the original model ( version 1 ) last year. It worked well until the past month. I would stay connected via wireless however it would randomly say ' No Internet Connection '. It became worse each day until I was literally sitting right next to the router and only showing two wireless bars on my laptop ( which is a brand new MacBookPro by the way ). So I returned it to BestBuy without my receipt ( as I had lost it ), they exchanged it without any hassle! My purchase was in the computer system and I luckily took it back in time as the one year warranty expired the following week! So I got the same model, but it was the newer version ( version 2 ). I plugged it in and it connected right away. However I still have the same problem as before but not as often. I have to cycle the power on the router for it to work. I am now on my trusty back-up ( Linksys WRT54G ) without incident!

column9: Setup fine, but periodically loses connection.
column10: Setup CD very helpful.  Thought I was all set.  We were loosing connection to the web periodically throughout the day. (We were not utilizing the wireless side - we're all CAT 5 hard wired).  Contacted tech support (their English is marginal) and we reinstalled the router.  Tweaked a couple of settings and again everything seemed fine - but later that day we started losing connection to the web.  Another call to tech support and we changed one or two more things but the net result was the same.  Finally swapped out my Netgear 3700 with a Cisco router and it has run flawlessly since.  (We had checked the modem status throughout and found it consistently 'on-line'.)

column9: great if you didn't have to keep rebooting
column10: You literally have to reboot this router twice to three times a week.  Why does it just go out for no reason??

column9: It no better than my previous Linksys G router
column10: I found G is better than N in range of signal. By Speed and Range I dont see huge again from the previous generations. But it does the job.

Netgear has been my router of choice for years. I think they provide the security and features that leave some others behind. The range is just awesome without weak signals but in this model I have reserved complaint for the fact that my wireless printer was being blocked. I tried to locate it using my desktop and laptop without no avail. I disconnected my new router and placed the older version and just like that my printer was seen and working. I have to do some more investigating and if I find out the problem maybe it might get a better rating.sincerely,Samuel Medinadogdaddy42@hotmail.com
Port forwarding will not work. I looked online saw a lot of other people having same issue. Its a good router but port forwarding not working is just ridiculous.

It worked perfectly when connected via cable to the computer. When  wire was removed the wifi aspect did not work. Tech examined it and said it was defective for wireless use. Thus it worthless to me.

Very easy to setup and maintain, however it constantly drops it's inernet connection. I will routinely have full wireless signal strength, but the router will lose it's internet connection. Just had the new firmware pushed to the router so hopefully that fixes some issues. When it's fully functioning it's great...if and when that occurs

I picked this router because it was recommended by a tech list, and I'm sure it's great, but the install disk didn't work on my Mac. It made the Internet connection disconnect. I had to use the installation from the Internet so I don't have the program on my computer. A little disappointed, but the speed seems to have improved as promised. I'm certainly experiencing less down time as I watch videos.

The unit worked great for about three weeks then the WiFi dropped connections and started to have slow speeds on N-G. I checked the signal and I had 2 bars of signal. When the unit was first installed I had 5 bars of signal everywhere in the apartment. The unit has hardware v1 and the latest firmware. Since it is past the 30 days, return of the unit is not a option because of the money I would loss (50%). Netgear wants me to jump threw hoops to prove the unit does not work. They say the problem is Interference. I do not know what could have changed to cause loss of 75% signal. A friend gave me a D-Link 2100 to use and it works great and 5 bars everywhere. I have found my great reviews and still believe this is a great product but Netgear support just gives you a negitive of the company. I did read that they came out with the 37AV because some reviews of the 3700 were not good. I do not see what the difference is with the replacement 3800 and the 3700 but it looks like the 3700 is being replaced.So check for the latest reviews and make sure you get the 3700 or 37AV with hardware v2 up or just wait for the 3800 to come out.

column9: What a shame.. Netgear WNDR3700 router..
column10: I have been a loyal Netgear guy for years with my RangeMax WNR834v2 router.. works great and never had any issues with it.. I decided to go get a newer model to handle my new XBOX needs, future streaming video for my new internet TV i am getting and the Gigabit LAN connections as i have 4 hard LAN lines to my existing router. I figured it would be seamless with alot of time spent specing out what I needed and reading what the Netgear WNDR3700 would offer.. and it was a great start when I received it over the holidays. The setup was easy and connecting to the internet was no problem at all. Security was easy to setup and have great features on this model. I then made sure the latest firmware was on the router and then that's where the problems materialized.Speeds were horrible with the wireless option turned on or off. I was getting half the speed on the new router than the old one was getting!! Hard lined or wireless i should have been getting something better since i have anywhere from 10mb to 20mb cable modem speeds..it was so bad i was at one point, I was only getting 1mb download speed!!! So i started reading... found out the version 1 model has alot of issues with the current firmware. I rolled back to the older firmware and still had speed issues. Come to find out that they might be discontinuing this V1 model for a V2 with a new different motherboard. Glad i found out after i bought it!! So i was still in my 30 day refund window from Amazon and decided to not mess around instead of trying to work out the issues and have a brick to balance the coffee table..Thanks Amazon BTW for a great setup you have and service!!! When you buy a new product you shouldn't struggle out of the box like this.. I worked on all the options and settings and read all the tech rags for 4 days to no avail. So i had no choice.....So unfortunately, i am highly disappointed to say the least.. and it is a shame. They have good products but this one for me anyway was a dud. I would like to select a different product to try but i got cold feet as most of their new products look like the same product build but with different features. I am looking at the new line of D-Link routers that are coming out the 1st quarter and 3rd quarter this year 2011 for their respective models.Here is the link of the review from CNET. D-Link DIR-857[...]Good luck to you all and make sure to READ READ READ your product to the fullest.. the customer reviews are one of your best guides.. and any tech rags you can find on the net..

column9: Lots of features - doesnt add much speed to my network
column10: This is a very nice router in terms of features, but I was hoping it would give me as good as wired speeds, which it has not. I've had the router for several months after owning a Linksys and a Belkin. It is definitely a step up in terms of features, but I'm just not seeing a significant speed increase. I'm copying files to my Dlink-NAS, which has a hardwired Ethernet cable to the router. I'm currently getting 403kb/second transfer speeds according to Windows File Copy. Not exactly breathtaking speeds. Also, when it checks for upgrades it reports it cannot connect but I'm able to get to the Internet from my laptop no problem. If I were to do this over again I'd look at hiring someone to lay down Ethernet throughout the house.

column9: No Longevity (Listed in my review is the router type)
column10: Okay so I purchased this item (Netgear Wireless Router- N600 Dual Band Gigabit (WNDR3700v2) in February of 2012.  I have been using it & it did wonderfully for almost 2 years.  I'm not sure what happened but it crashed & crashed hard.  After reading several other reviews & forum posts, it seems that some firmware update ruined it.  Now I tried over & over again to set it back to default settings but no luck.  It is done.I guess I am giving it 3 stars only because after spending almost $100 on it, I expected it to last more than under 2 years.  I mean I have past routers last over 5 years & spend a fraction of the cost.Because of this I found myself running out to the local big store to get a cheap router to get us through until I can research what router would do best for my family.  I won't jump into another router so quickly without finding out if it is worth it.

I notice on the Netgear website that the the latest model of the WNDR3700 is now at v2 with Memory: 16 MB flash and 64 MB RAM.  I believe the v1 model had 8MB flash.  So is this the v1 or v2 model being sold here?

I bought this to replace an old Linksys WRT54G, and was hoping to also be able to decommission an old Windows box which now only hosts a shared drive.  As a router replacement it's fine - easy setup, and a bit faster than the older one, but for file serving it won't do.  I'm a heavy OneNote user, and the notebooks are stored on my shared USB drive.  After moving the shared drive to the WNDR3700, I found that every few minutes OneNote would complain that the section I was working on had been corrupted.  It didn't take long me to move it back to the shared Windows box, where all is once again fine.  So, router yes, but file server, no.

column9: Finally, a full-featured router that's reliable and has fairly usable web access control
column10: AN UPDATE:Just after a little bit over a year, the Netgear router stopped working properly. Without any change in the network conditions, the router started to drop Internet connections frequently. I tried everything to no avail. Did a factory reset and started with making extremely minimal customization. But the problem persisted. I've no idea what caused this. The router was absolutely stable in the last year.The unique parental control offered by the Netgear now poses a serious dilemma for me. On one hand, I no longer feel comfortable to buy another Netgear router as a replacement because I somehow feel that the new one is going to have the same problem. On the other hand, I don't want to go without a reasonable solution for parental control..My temporary solution is to use an old SMC router and set up an OpenDNS parental control account on the SMC router. This is the same cloud-based parental control as what Netgear uses. But unfortunately, it does not offer the following two important features (not even with the paid account): (1) customizable time schedules; and (2) bypass user accounts on individual computers.After all these 15 years and more than 10 routers, I haven't found a satisfactory router for home networking! There is something fundamentally wrong with this industry.THE ORIGINAL REVIEW:I have gone through an embarrassing number of routers in the last 10 years, possibly averaging one every year. The last few routers, a D-Link DIR-655 and a SMC WGBR14-N, all proved to be quite good, but the D-Link did not last very long (the thing run untouchablly hot when it was on, so it probably got fried with no surprise), and the SMC, although very reliable, had completely useless web access control. The D-Link was slightly better but also very bad in this aspect.I hesitated quite a bit to buy yet another router, but the need of customizable Web access control finally won the argument so I got the Netgear. And I am fairly satisfied.Overall:Even without considering the much-better-than-others web access control, which I will discuss in detail below, this router easily ranks among the best. Many strong points altogether make it a top choice.- Dual band operation (simultaneously) at 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz. This gives you better compatibility, and in the 5 GHz mode, does offer the benefit of less interferences in the radio background, although at a cost of a significantly shorter range.- Very reliable and stable connections. And fast. I don't know why some uses are not satisfied with the speed. This actually approaches 300Mbps speed at close range. Even the laptop used at downstairs can achieve well over 100Mbps. It is important that you not use WEP security mode. Like most other wireless-n devices, this router is not compatible with the old WEP security and would default to 54M maximum speed.- The ability to set up a separate guest account with a different SSID with a different password. If you do have guests who need Wi-Fi, this is a very nice feature because, first, you can have a very easy to remember password for the guest account, and second, you don't need to be concerned that anyone might get onto your network. In reality, the first benefit is more practical. On a number of occasions when I was at other people's places, a much-needed guest access to Wi-Fi couldn't be easily had because the host couldn't remember the password. The family computers were set up a long time ago, so it is quite common that the password is either forgotten, or not known by everyone in the house.- Easy setup and reliable access to control. This is one of the routers that you can reliably access by directly connecting a computer to the router using an Ethernet cable without having to manually set an IP address of the computer in the TCP settings of the network connections. This is so important for straightforward router setting up and management. You just plug in the cable, open a browser and enter the right IP address or URL of the router (preferably bookmarked on your browser), and you are in control of the router. You don't need to run any CDs or software. You can access the router anytime without any assistance. So simple and predictable. Strangely enough, most routers do not have this seemingly simple ability (Note: I'm talking about accessing non-configured router to configure it here. Once the router is configured, of course, you should be able to access its control through any computer connected to it. That is a given on all routers today.)  The other routers would require you to manually set the IP address of the computer to be in the same IP address range (subnet) in order to access the router before the router is configured, unless you take the trouble of running a proprietary setup software, which of course you usually don't have with you unless it is the first time you have opened the box to install it. And even if you somehow manage to find the CD, running the software implies a complicated process in which many things can go wrong, and that's one of the reasons why people complain about routers so much in general.- The radio range is comparable to the SMC, which is very good. It covers a two-story home with signal strength over 50% every corner.- Unlike the D-Link, the Netgear runs very cool.- The black box is also the best looking router I've seen. Also, I appreciate the fact that it doesn't have antennas sticking out.- And lastly, the Live Parental Control offered by Netgear with OpenDNS. The Netgear router's own built-in net access control has nothing worth mentioning, completely unusable like you would find in most other routers.  The Live Parental Control has quite a lot to like and is the first ever Web access control that I feel is usable. It is still far from being perfect by any standard, but this is many times better than the best built-in access control in any router I've ever seen, and the only one that is actually usable in my opinion.This is the reason why I abandoned the extremely reliable SMC and bought the Netgear.  But I'm only partially satisfied. I don't regret buying it, as it really achieved some of the goals I had. But there is a lot of room for improvement. I will discuss this major feature separately below.Live Parental Control:When it comes to web access control, it is not in a 'anything-is-better-than-nothing' category. If it is not good enough, you just don't want to use it, because you would mess up you and your family's Internet life. My experience with the previous routers was unbelievably frustrating, not because the setting up was difficult (it was), but because the overall design was terribly bad and essentially incompetent without exception.There are three different types of approaches to web access control. The first is local computer-based using software installed on the local computer; the second is router-based using router programming to allow centralized control over all computers in the same LAN; and the third is server-based service (typically for subscriptions) to allow easy remote access. Netgear uses an interesting'blend of all these three approaches, and based on my experience I think they are onto something. If implemented well, they would be able to offer the best in the world.Live Parental Control is easily the best I have seen so far that is offered free along with a router. I have not used the subscription-based solutions offered by other companies because I believe fundamentally the right way to do this is at the router level.To use Live Parental Control, you create a user account at opendns.com. The account is associated with your router. A management utility program needs to be installed on a computer for basic management. But for full control of the account, you need to log on to the web-based account. Each account is given a main account with customizable filtration levels. This is the default filtration on any computer that is connected to the same'router. The filtration levels are based on selection of more than 50 categories. I found the filtration to be very effective. In addition, the user may also grade a'blacklist and a whitelist of websites.What really makes Live Parental Control unique is its use of bypass user accounts which function as modifiers on top of the default filtration. You may create a bypass user account for each individual. The filtration of the individual account is customizable just like the main account. You install a user utility program on a computer, and if the user logs onto the bypass account, the filtration settings of the bypass account overwrites that of the default main account. This is a great design that allows a great deal of flexibility.The 'bypass account' feature is easy to set up for each individual user (family members) to have customized web access with multiple and flexible time schedules. Yes, not only does each user have his own schedule, but also each user may have multiple time slots scheduled for customizable filtration settings. This is far better than the scheduling capability of access controls built in the routers.Note that the management utility program needs to be installed on only one computer that is used for management of the network, but the user utility program needs to be installed on every computer in order for the bypass account to work on each computer.However, as it stands now, Live Parental Control is still far from being perfect. It still has some basic problems with the design concept, and I don't know what all these product architects and programmers are thinking.In the following, I'll identify several major problems, which can all be solved quite easily once they recognize the problems.(1) Still has sadly inflexible time schedules. On the first blush, the thing seemingly allows a great deal of customization in time schedules, both in the default account and individual user accounts. But a slightly deeper look shows that all time schedules without exception are recurring daily schedules. There is no provision of a weekly schedule for different weekdays and weekend, and there is also no provision of a single time (nonrecurring) schedule. Why? Is it so difficult to realize people's lives don't run according to a fixed mechanical clock every day? Certainly I don't think it is difficult to program it once they realize the need for such flexibility (or reality, I would say). I must say that I'm disappointed, although this is overall far better than the previous ones I used because at least it allows easy setup for individual users.(2) The 'bypass account' feature works only on computers, not on other devices such as game consoles. You can't install a bypass account on a game counsel such as Wii, or an Internet TV box. So these devices will always be operating according to whatever you set up in the default account. Then again, this is only an imperfection of a fairly usable solution. Other guys don't even have a meaningful solution on this yet.(3) The bypass account feature does not work with a wireless bridge in combination with the router. I tried Live Parental Control on a Netgear Rangemax WNDR3700 Router in combination with a NETGEAR Access Point/Bridge WNHDE111. To my disappointment, although the bypass user accounts would work well on computers that directly connect to the router, but don't work on computers that connect through the bridge to the router. The default settings work through the entire network. But the bypass accounts simply don't have any effect on computers that are connected to the bridge. Yes, I was certain that the user utility software was properly installed and the user account was logged on. In fact, I did some test by connecting the same computer directly to the router and found that the bypass account would immediately start to work. But once the direct connecting is cut and the computer is put back to connect through the bridge, the bypass account would immediately stop working. This is rather disappointing. I eventually had to take the computers off the bridge and used wireless adapters on each computer to do the work. The bridge ended up connecting to print servers only, greatly limiting its potential use.Overall, this is good progress, but still has much to be desired. I think the market desperately needs a web access control system that meets the needs of today's families. So far, I haven't seen one. Netgear's Live Parental Control come pretty close, and I think if they would only read my review, they would realize that it doesn't take that much for them to improve this vastly, because fundamentally they are on the right platform.

Purchased router to set up local network with a neighbor for data sharing.  Was unable to get enough signal strength to go 200 ft.  Very disappointing.  Could not find a distance specification in the documentation.  A RangeMax it is not.  I even bought a second router to set up as a repeater.  Still could not get sufficient range from the pair.I attempted to set up the guest network.  Was disappointed in the functionality of that, since it did not support several of the encryption options.After extensive testing, I returned the second unit and decided to keep the first one.  I gave up on the extended network, and am just using the router for an upgrade to my local network.  The basic functions of the router do work satisfactorily and the two of my computers that have 'Gigabit' capability do exchange data much faster.  The Wireless N interface works great, too.I also hooked a 1TB external drive to the router for data sharing.  Had no problem with that interface at all.In my opinion, Netgear released this product, and it's latest firmware revision, before they were sufficiently tested.  I believe it is still buggy.

I bought one router for my home and it worked so well (and continues to work well after 6 months), I recommended and replaced a glitchy and annoying Cisco E4500 at my workplace, however, the second router (3 months in use) appears to be glitchy and has loose ports in the rear which were not really apparent at first - my company does not rely on wireless, but is essentially hardwired using one (simple) program to serve 5 client computers from the server unit. Today was the day, I believe the router went haywire, multiple reboots, endlessly re-establishing connections, it was nuts - not good in a busy vet clinic using one simple database program. Ended up having to swap out the router to a (NetGear) switch from the host - will see tomorrow if this resolves today's awful issues - I have a feeling it will. Incidentally, I updated the router's firmware and it behaved even worse following that little jaunt.I chose NetGear products because, over many years, they have worked reliably and lasted a fairly long time (as in, never actually had an issue before). Frankly I don't really care for Cisco products, all promise - hopefully NetGear isn't choosing the same path. Am very experienced in IT and sys admin, but work with a limited budget in a busy environment, hope never to have a day like today again. I absolutely understand the conflicted review numbers. Maybe we should make stuff in America again!

column9: Great product, scary firmware policy and poor customer support
column10: I love netgear routers and switches and keep using them for many years now.With this thing, however, I had my first netgear customer support experience.Yesterday the box suggested me updating the firmware (automatically inside the GUI). once downloaded, it complained about 'version not for this device' and.. died.It took me 5 calls to customer service, running through stupid troubleshooting steps like connecting/disconnecting internet cable or hard-resetting for minutes. 3 times my call was dropped and it turned out that the agend did not update the case file, requiring me to run through all steps again. The agent also told me to never update firmware through GUI because that could 'destabilize' the device :-)They do provide RMA (after extensive phone troubleshooting), but you'd have to pay $30 in case you'd like a replacement device being delivered the next day. choosing the free-delivery option does not give you a time window.Therefore.. great product but poor service.

column9: Just bought this and am impressed indeed, but...
column10: Ok, an update 8/21/2010:Now I see why I hate doing reviews so fast after getting a product.  Just an update to my below review and I'll try to be brief. I've had this router for a few months now and pretty much everything I said in my review has to be modified for the worse except the setup. The ready share function often is not ready at all.  A connected drive only appears visible on the network for about two days max and the you don't see it.  I have found most video streaming I do on the Internet experiences non stop buffeting when using the 5ghz channel with the wndrs so called video streaming algorithm enabled, which is supposed to improve HD video playback. The 2.4ghz network does not have that feature, but I seem to get much better video playback using 2.4 for some reason.  I do not have any 5ghz interference in my neighborhood, but have tons of 2.4, and the signal strength is full-on (at least that is consistent), so I don't see why I am not getting better performance. Even with better performance at 2.4 it still gives buffering, just not as much at 5ghz (it's practically unwatchable). My joy with this router is starting to turn to frustration.Original review:Ok, I just bought this router last night. I normally wouldn't write a review so quickly until I had a product for awhile, but this has me excited.  IT has been on my mind ever since it came out and I just went out and decided to buy since the price has dropped by $40 and fell right into my purchasing sweeetspot.  This may sound weird, but this thing looks sexy to me.  It's sleek and just looks like it going to hit you with power, so kudos to the designers.  I love it.  Like most routers these days it comes with a quick setup CD. What I liked about this one though, unlike some of the others that come with the CD, is the startup guide also prominently displays the access path if you want to set it up manually.  I recently setup a wireless router for my father (he bought an entry level Belkin which was perfect for his needs..pretty good router too in that space) and it had a quick start CD, but no info on how to setup manually and it would be hard to figure out if you didn't know what you were doing.  I've done a bunch of them so I knew how to get it, but I could just imagine my father trying to figure that out, but I guess that's why they have the quick start CD! Anyway, I chose to setup my 3700 manually, not because I think I'm a tech god or anything, I just like to see everything that the router can do and get familiar with its feature set from the start.  This thing is pretty loaded with features.  So in that department I am satisfied.  The items I like: it can host 4 networks simultaneously, it can be used as a media server (haven't tried this yet), can be used host attached storage via the usb port (was messing around with that last night.ummmm), it has long range!!!  You can adjust the signal strength and monitor bandwidth usage.  You can update the firmware directly from the router!!  Speaking of which, it needed an immediate firmware update because the one that shipped had a bug that would turn off the antennaes when a guest network was enabled, but no worries, it was corrected in the update.  Generally I like everything about this router in terms of what it can do.  The problem, and the big 'but' in my title is that not everything executes as smoothly as I would have expected.The first nagging issue I encountered is that the router toggles the antennas off and on whenever you apply certain configuration changes.  This is not much of an issue on initial setup since you are connect via ethernet, but you may have issues if you access the config wirelessly because iyou may lose the connection.  On my laptop that was not much of an issue because it would eventually reconnect (but it takes awhile, so the issue is speed there).  However, this morning I made a change from my iPAd (I have to tell you it was pretty cool to be able to configure this from a touch screen. It was an unexpected and surprising experience actually!)  The issue here had nothing to do with the wndr though.  The iPad frequently drops wifi or won't automatically reconnect to known networks (apple needs to fix this asap or the device is a useless hinderance to productivity), so when the wndr resets the antennas, the ipad does not reconnect, so it will sit on the 'please wait' screen because the session is broken.  The plus side is that the settings took (mac addr addition), but i wouldn't recommend doing any substantial changes wirelessly. One, its just quicker doing it wired (albeit inconvenient) and two, you don't want to risk screwing things up while it writes the change to flash (not saying that is a confirmed issue, just a practice not to disturb a write operation from experience programming large Cisco routers and switches in the past as part of my job at that tine).  So for now I'll just have to give up making config changes quickly. The router I replaced was wrt54gs and I did config changes wirelessly all the time because my wife was always buying some new wireless gadget so I constantly adding to the network.  The linksys did not reset the antennas for those kind of changes though.  Despite the inconvenience of having to do it wired, the wndr has a pretty cool feature that will make adding some of my wife's devices a breeze.  When adding a device to the access list, if it is a PC and has acquired an ip address from the router, it will automatically create a list of the computer names and mac addresses and make them available for selection.  So you can add multiple devices in one go. This is an improvement over my old linksys because I had to add them one at a time and it didn't have friendly names associated with the mac addresses, so after awhile I couldn't tell what device was which (had over 30 mac addresses).  I found non-pc device had to be entered manually.The second nagging issue I had was with the attached storage feature that they brand as 'readyshare'.  It is a cool feature that allows you to connect a usb storage device to the router and make the storage available to your network.  It works as  advertised, but i ran into a small hiccup that took several hours for me to figure out.  The default setting allows you to access the storage via the path \\readyshare.  Enter it Windows explorer and the contents of the drive appears. Simple.  If you enable the password feature, it will prompt for the password and then display the files.  The wndr allows you to edit the name used to access the attached storage. I took them up on the option since I don't like leaving in the default settings.  Afterward I could no longer authenticate and gain access to the drive.  It kept saying 'access denied' even before I had the opportunity to enter the password (this is on Windows 7 by the way, so this behavior may be exclusive to 7). To make a long story short, it basically came down to the facet that it wouldn't work if any name other than 'readyshare' was used.  Changed it back to 'readyshare' it worked fine. Changed to anything else, it would automatically pass forward my windows logon which is why I was getting access denied even before entering any credentials in the prompts.  Weird indeed.  I did a search and stumbled on a FAQ for the wndr at Netgear that discussed this very issue, but whatever they were saying was the issue made zero logical sense and didn't work (they recommended logon/log off and/or reboot and said the cause was due to using two different authorisation methods and that it was a Windows problem--I was using admin auth on both setttings and reboot logon/logoff did not remedy the issue). Not convinced it is a windows problem, but using the default name 'readyshare' worked and any other name didn't--so it seems more like the router not acknowledging the new name so Windows then assumes it is another resource on the network.  That is just speculation though.  So again, just be aware of this if you happen to run into the same thing.  You might not.  In the end the feature does work and that is all the matters. It would be different if it were completely not functioning.With that said, despite the above nags, I am very impressed with this router feature set and performance thus far.  I definitely would recommend it to everyone.Even my father. :)

column9: Needed beta Firmware update, THEN great router
column10: This router is now working fine, but I had a very frustrating time with getting the Guest network to work.  I had no problem in setting up the router initially, but when I set up Guest network access, the wireless radio was disabled for all SSIDs.  The only way to get it back was to do a hard reset and set up the router again.  Then, when trying to enable the Guest network again, the wireless again went down.  I spent a lot of time trouble shooting, including updating firmware, but to no avail.I returned the first router, and purchased a second from a different vendor, only to have the very same problem.  I called Netgear's technical support line.  After 40 minutes on hold, they 'escalated' my call immediately to a higher level tech.  She then had me download a beta version firmware update, Version 1.0.4.66, which is not yet posted on the web site.  This firmware update immediately fixed the problem, and I now have a stable Guest network running alongside the regular wireless SSIDs- the principal reason I upgraded to this router.So, five stars for the router, one star to Netgear for shipping it with such a huge bug.  Hopefully the new firmware version will be posted soon on their website.

column9: Good hardware but firmware is really bad
column10: This router has great hardware. The range of both radios is excellent and the speeds are very quick. Unfortunately, the router firmware is pretty bad. Activating features such as traffic monitoring or the DLNA media server cause the router to lock up. These are apparently 'known issues' to Netgear, however there is no ETA for fixes to either of these issues. Also, I am surprised at the very basic level of configuration provided in the admin tools. It lacks even basic port remapping which even most $30 routers have. As a concrete example of why this is important: With my previous Linksys router I allowed remote desktop connections to come in, but on a different port to reduce the chance of an attacker finding it and trying to break in. I can't do that with this router. I am really hoping a third-party firmware comes out soon that works on this router.

column9: Good router that could be a great router
column10: I had been using a D-Link Xtreme N Gigabit Router (DIR-655) when I noticed that the LAN throughput had significantly decreased. After a bunch of testing and frustration with the lack of support (it was out of warranty at this point) I began looking at other Wireless routers.[...] provided a weatlth of useful comparison information on the newer routers on the market and the Netgear WNDR3700 was at the top of the list.Hardware spec wise this router is at the top of the heap and the dual band spec. N radios is a nice feature. I haven't been able to use the 5 Ghz band yet since I don't have a suitable wireless adapter but the 2.5 Ghz band has very good range and throughput and I haven't had any dropout problems like I did with the DIR-655 even after switching to the Ralink drivers and wireless manager.The WNDR3700 setup very easily with a Win7x64 Pro system and was very easy to configure. It offers WPA2 for wireless security and I was up and running under 5 minutes of turning it on.To make this easy to configure Netgear went to far in the direction of simplicity. What keeps this from being a great router is the lack of customization options in the user interface. The DIR-655 had a multitude of more advanced options and was highly configurable while the Netgear doesn't even allow me to change the default user login name (admin) which isn't great for security.If you are looking for a wireless router that has great hardware performance and is easy to setup and use this is a great product. If you want a wireless router that has a lot of configuration options look elsewhere.

Amazons fast service was great as usual. The items set up CD did not work. Spent a hour on the phone with Netgears tech support.The phone line volume keeps changing and the techs accent make it very difficult to hear them. The tech was very polite and did my machines to get the internet. The only problem is the next time I tried to log in it would not take the password. Support will not just update the password. They want me to start the set up all over. The entire support contact process is very difficult.n Next time I will try a different brand.

I replaced my Trendnet 633GR router because I had a lot of high volume devices that were all consuming bandwidth and bogging each other down (Netflix, XBOX, Slingbox, laptops, etc. etc)  I wasn't getting full 'G' speed with the Trendnet 633GR on my primary laptop so I figured I'd try out the Netgear WNDR3700.The big plus for this router is the 680MHZ CPU.  Even though I can only get data from my broadband router just so fast, the router seems to be effortlessly routing everything in my network without any slowdowns.  Unfortunately, I didn't get any range improvement in one area of my house and my main laptop is still around -60db (and about 1 MB/s)  I was hoping to get a little more but the faster router processor seems to keep the data flowing very steadily.  If I use a USB network adapter on my laptop, I get full speed.  I suppose I could blame my laptop network card for a weak antenna.As for the 5GHZ secondary band, I didn't find any use for it.  If I got further than 30 feet from the router and had any obstructions, the signal was just about useless.  I was -90db at 40 feet thru one wall and the ROKU XR failed to hook up.  I eventually just turned the 5ghz radio off on the router.One other thing I like is a guest network feature.  I can turn on a generic guest network when we have visitors and let them get on the internet.  I still have all encryption methods available.Overall, very solid router, I am happy and this router will probably last me a long time.  I found that Amazon actually beat Newegg prices by 15$...UPDATE 2/4/2010 :  I had a VPN server running with no problem on a Windows 7 64bit machine and a Trendnet 633GR Router.  I switched to this WNDR3700 for reasons listed above.  The WNDR was ALMOST perfect except I was simply unable to get the WNDR3700 to passthru a VPN connection.  I have to have VPN for my situation so the router is going back.  I noticed after a lot of hair pulling that others are waiting on dd-wrt firmware to rectify this VPN issue.  I'm surprised that this router couldn't do VPN, it seems so necessary??  I suppose I'll try it again when it has VPN capability.UPDATE 9/10/2010 : Somehow during a firmware update VPN is now working in Windows 7 64bit.  My network is flying.  5ghz is turned off because the range is so short that it is practically unusable.  5 STARS otherwise.

I don't have much to add b/c I returned it after 30 minutes.  On paper its an awesome router and I'm sure that's true in most cases, but the 5g band's range is less than 50 feet.  So I bought and ran a 50 foot ethernet cable for 21.99.  I really liked the idea of setting up a home network with the shared storage via the usb port.  However I originally took the plunge to stream hd netflix to a samsung 3600 on the 5g channel and have my laptops on the 2.4 channel.  I returned because at a buck seventy, it better damn well blow my hair back and it didn't.  Such high hopes too...

The basic wireless (A/G/N) seems to work well, though the A/N range is disappointing.  The guest network also worked nicely (on 2.4G band, didn't try 5G).  The install CD won't work from a static IP, like the server I use to manage the network, so that was annoying but not a show-stopper.The USB storage connection was the big problem: the router's services were hanging up every 15 minutes or so, requiring a power cycle.  I isolated it to the USB storage, a bug that was supposedly fixed in the latest firmware but was apparently not fixed.  I disabled the media server option, per the workaround for the original problem, and things are working now.  Tech support said that the problem was (a) my USB drive was not on the rather small approved list and (b) the external power supply of a USB drive conflicts with the power on the router's USB port... that's an interesting spin... especially since disabling media server seems to have resolved the problem.So, given the high price of this router, I'd say 'average'.  If I have any further issues, back it goes.

I bought this router to gain gigabit speed, and replace an older Netgear router.  I have mixed opinions on it so far.Setup was a hassle.  The wizard did not work, as I didn't have the latest version of flash.  It did not offer to install it from the cd, and as I had unplugged the old router, I had no internet to download it.  So I did the manual setup.  As I mentioned I was replacing another Netgear router, the web interface is essentially identical.  However, the software locked up constantly, in both Firefox and IE.  When I added a MAC address, lock; view the logs, lock; and so it went...
