It would not connect to the internet until I did a full reset of my modem, not just unplug it like that manual recommended.Once it was finally setup things work ok.  The power plug seems to be a little loose, I knocked it out easily moving the router a couple of inches...  Performance has improved on my network, and after the setup headaches it has been stable.

I really hoped that this router would be all I needed to get a good WiFi signal in my master bedroom.  Unfortunately, the living room is on the opposite side of our 4 bedroom house.  The signal is better than with our old router, but it still is not sufficient.  Our cell phones will not pick up the WiFi, but luckily my laptop and iPad do, so half the battle is won.
Works good but the range is not very good on it. Just going outside the house signal drops to 1 bar if any at all...
THE DEVICE WORKS REALL GOOD FOR THE PRICE, ITS FAST AND HAS A PRETTY GOOD RANGE, I AM ABLE TO USE MY LAPTOP OUTSIDE IN THE FRONT YARD OR BACK YARD

column9: ehhh go for the top of the line model
column10: The range was not as far as I expected. I'm returning this and going all out to get the R6300 instead. I've also initially encountered many drops until the settings were changed up. There are still frequent lag spikes though while gaming as well.

But even though it says for Medium to Large Homes, the signal does not reach the entire house. The house is just over 2,100 sq feet. In my opinion and experiences, this falls in the Medium to Large category. Works great otherwise.

While I found the functionality and ease of setup to be quite good, my router started to fail daily when I moved to a warmer environment with room temperatures at 75 degrees or more.  By focusing a fan directly on the unit, I could keep the thing running, but that solution is a nuisance.  I suspect they need an internal fan in the unit.  This could be a design problem for other routers in the NetGear lineup, but I do not know for sure.

The router worked spectaculary well for about 2.5yrs.  Within the last 6 months it's been rebooting itself occasionally, then it started rebooting itself sporatically, now it's constantly rebooting itself.During the period when it worked, it was terrific.  No issues at all.  I've just come to the realization that they don't build them like they use to (e.g. LINKSYS WRT54G, that router lasted 10 years).The next router I get will hopefully last 5 yrs. We'll see.
it doesn't reach as far as I'd like and I have to reset it quite often.Don't know the reason for that.But it is better than not having a wifi for my nook

Bought this to replace a Cisco E3000, but it didn't have anywhere near the range of the Cisco, so I gave it to my niece for use in a small apartment.The router's built in interface is great, with easy to advanced settings all laid out in a browser application, with full help and details available.Had no problem connecting any device to it, even my Sony Bluray DVD in another room, but like I said, it didn't have the signal strength to stream Amazon video or Netflix without pauses, unlike the Cisco E3000.

I ordered a used WNDR3700 router in April and it arrived with a non-Netgear power adapter and without the stand. Then it stopped working last week (June) which was outside the return window. I then did some research and realized that I had received an older version (v3). Version 4 has a Qualcomm Atheros AR9344 processor running at 560 MHz which is faster than the Broadcom BCM4718A (480 MHz) processor that was in version 3. The RAM is bumped up to 128 MB from 64 MB as well. The reviews on v4 are positive so I am rating this as okay, but Netgear and Amazon should sell each version separately. The model number listed should be WNDR3700v4 or WNDR3700v3 to make this clear. The original Netgear box a new WNDR3700v4 arrives in does show that WNDR3700v4 model number on the side panel in the Package Contents list. Return it if it says that you have received an earlier version.

column9: NETGEAR WNDR3700 - worked great for a year, then 2.4GHz band died
column10: Loved it until it broke my heart. It always ran hot, did my best to keep it cool, but like a lot of folks, it did me wrong. My 2.4GHz phone and tablet won't connect, while my wife's iPad2 keeps chugging along.Maybe it's for the best. We have a big old brick house and will soon be getting Google Fiber. I like Netgear but the ASUS RT-AC66U should provide great coverage and plenty of bandwith. Sure, it's more than twice as expensive, but with a gig down and a gig up I feel the need...all together now...the need for speed.

column9: If this is the best, Then
column10: If this is suppose to be the best well it is not. The wireless is very weak, in site of devise 10 feet away my laptop only gets 4 out of 5 bars. I am not pleased with product. On the good side it does work and I am not being charged for the use of cable company's box.

column9: NETGEAR Wireless Router - N600 Dual Band Gigabit (WNDR3700)
column10: Bought this used ...  NETGEAR won't provide customer support.  In order to make this order in the 4 or 5 STAR category, it would have required a product transfer from NETGEAR.

Worked like a dream for the first 3 weeks, but now it disconnects from the internet constantly, forcing me to unplug the power, then plug it back in and wait a few minutes for it to boot up.  I spent 50 minutes on the phone with my ISP, Cox, trying to figure out why my connection was gone, and they finally determined that it was the router, as the modem is only a year old.I'll give it another shot with the replacement when it arrives, but if the same issues arise, Amazon can keep it and I'll look for something more reliable.

column9: Three stars for how well it worked, when it actually worked
column10: Just a little bit of background, I work as an network engineer for an ISP who I have an internet connection with. I am capable of troubleshooting equipment and have a strong opinion based upon my experience.That being said, I have had this for about 2 years, but it is at its end of life. I kept up on the firmware and everything was fine until about 2 months ago. The wifi would stop working. The SSID would stop broadcasting, although the wired connections would still stay operational. However, when the wifi would cut out, the USB drive attached to it would become unavailable. On top of that, when it was in this state, I was not able to log into the router to check and see if it detected anything. A reset would correct the issue, and everything would be fine. At first it started to occur every week, then every few days, and now it happens 3-6 times a day. This is a hassle for me as I use my network drive to stream movies and music to my tv. I just upgraded the firmware to the latest version again today, with no success.When it worked, it was great. I was VERY skeptical about buying a Netgear, as when I worked customer support at my ISP it seemed that Netgear was consistently the brand of router (varying models of course) that had the most issues. I had a small, entry level Linksys that only did G wireless for almost 7 years before it died. I paid $60 bucks for it, and although it had no frills, it lasted FOREVER. I put a lot of thought into this model, and was convinced by a co worker who said it was a really good bang for your buck. At the time, I think I paid almost $160 bucks for it, and it only lasted a few years. I would not recommend purchasing a Netgear router again. Stick with big hardware manufacturers (Cisco, Asus, Linksys, etc).

Shipping was ver quick; however, the used product we recieved  did not work to its full potential. It could only provide network to our PS3, which by the way was in the same location as the router. It would not work on any other system in our house. We live in a 1 story home, and the N600 should cover a 2 story home. We paid too much for something that does not work completely.

column9: Not bad, but could be better
column10: This router has a lot of features, but I'm a bit disappointed in the range and speed.  Sometimes, I get the full 5mps that my provider supplies, but other times the speed drops and I have to restart my modem and router to get back up to speed.I do like the 'guest network' feature and the ability to run 2 different SSID's from the same router.My neighbor has a 5 year old WRTG54 Linksys that gets twice the range.For the price this item does the job, but I think I could have got the same performance out of an regular 'N' wireless router and spent about 24% less.

This is my first review of a product sold on Amazon. Based upon my experience with this product I felt compelled to provide my basic review. It might be fine for you but for me I have my own subjective concerns.Upgrade Reason -Originally had a Netgear 814V2 and needed to upgrade due to faster ISP service. Needed a gigabyte connection to my desktop to obtain the benefit of increased ISP bandwith. Note that you need to have a high speed Ethernet card if you want to obtain maximum benefit of increased ISP bandwidth. Some people may not know that.GUI -Upgraded to newest firmware release which changed the GUI from the older (IMO better) GUI. There was no option to keep the old interface. Downgraded to what you see below. Spoke to Tech Support and they said that they will contact engineering so they can consider putting an option in the next release.  I liked the old interface but that is my personal preference.WNDR3700 -Firmware:Hardware Version  WNDR3700v3Firmware Version  V1.0.0.18_1.0.14GUI Language Version  V1.0.0.18_2.1.13.1IP Range -The 814v2 had an IP range beginning with 192.168.0This one starts at 192.168.1I have an HP 5000n printer with an IP of 192.168.0.71. I could not connect my printer. Tech support said that is because of the beginning range of the router IP addresses. Now I have to (if I don't return it) to figure out how to change my HP printer IP address to 192.168.1.71.At times when you save settings in the GUI it take a long time and it loses connection to the router and it's brutal to get that connection back sometimes having to do a reset. Sorry, I can't be more specific and I apologize. Called Tech support and they had me reset the router to the connection back to the new router.Logging -There are a lot of options to review logs but its missing sites visited as there was on the 814v2. I like to see a record of sites visited and sites blocked by URL/DNS name. Example if [...] was visited it would in my 814v2 show that site name in the log. If I blocked facebook then I want to see blocked [...] for example. Again, this was available on my old router. This type of logging is not available on this router not even with the Genie interface. I consider this a step backward. If you know of specific software that will allow me to see this type of log maybe I can live with this router.Wireless -No problems. Fast and reliable so far. I use Access Control and do no broadcast the SSID. Connected to Dell Laptop, iPhones and Itouch no problem. Super easy. I have a small house so I cannot provide an opinion on range.Tech Support -I had almost no wait time and the Technical Rep. was excellent. I had Eric from the Philippines and he was outstanding. He was patient and honest. This is the type of person you want to work with. He will get an outstanding review.If anyone knows of a GB router I might consider replacing this with please let me know based upon my above concerns. Unfortunately, at this time I am going to return this router.

I've had this for several months, and it's decent, but not great.It apears to be rock solid.  Stays up, keeps reliable connections, does what it says it's going to do.However, it appears to drop it's information about wireless devices regularly.  I have a Canon MX870 that is connected via WiFi.  When I turn it on, the device shows up on the router, but after a while, it just disappears.  Can't print again without resetting the printer.  I've seen similar behavior with other wireless devices.The devices continue to work, and can access the network even after they've been 'forgotten', but you just can't really find them on your own.It appears that accesses to the network initiated by the devices themselves (such as playing music, downloading a video, whatever) work fine, but you have trouble initiating a connection to the device (ie, trying to print a document to the network printer) because it just doesn't really know where to send it.

When i was buying a router i was looking for good range, fast, dual-band routers and i found this. However this router has terrible range and i would not recommend you buy it if you are living in a big apartment with many walls or a multi-floor house. The price set for this router is absolutely ridiculous for such a bad product.

I've been using this router for about two years now, and for a long time it worked just fine.  The range is quite good as well; I have the router on the first floor and have a good connection on the second floor and in the basement and garage.  However, in the past few months I've noticed issues with the connection, mostly to the high speed.  Suddenly the high speed connection gets lost on my iPhone and iPad, and sometimes both connections disappear (My new TWC modem also has WiFi built in, so sometimes I notice that my wireless devices are connected to that instead of the router).  I recall that with my iPhone 5 there was no problem with the connection, and when I went to Netgear's website they have a notice that says'Wi-Fi issues with iOS 6There have been widespread reports of wireless connection and speed problems with devices using Apple's newly-released iOS 6 connecting to NETGEAR products. The problems that you are experiencing may be due to a recent upgrade of the Apple iOS 6.  While the nature and extent of the iOS 6 and Wi-Fi connectivity issues are unknown, NETGEAR will do our best to continue to monitor the updates from Apple and continue to work with our customers to ensure that we can help provide support and work-arounds (when possible) to get your devices connect properly.In the mean time, please check out the following websites and forums discussions for additional updates and information regarding this Wi-Fi issues between your Apple iOS 6 devices and NETGEAR wireless devices:'It's nice to know that I'm not going crazy, because I kept restarting the router to try and fix the problem, but it doesn't seem like they are too concerned with the issue.  The upgrade was a number of months ago; if they cared about the customers I would think they would work with Apple to address the issue and not just 'monitor' the situation.  The connection seems quite good with other items I have that use a wireless connection (Roku, Sony bluray player) and the wired connection seems solid as well, but considering that I use my iPhone and iPad constantly for work it's a bit of a deal breaker.  If Netgear doesn't fix the situation, I'm upgrading to the Western Digital router which seems pretty awesome (they were at NYCC and the sales pitch was pretty good).  If you don't have any Apple devices (or are using an older iOS), then this is a good choice for you.  Just remembered, I sometimes use the wireless connection on my Mac mini and that worked fine as well.  So let me actually amend my statement to say this is great if you don't have any iOS 6 devices.

ended my relationship with ATT for internet: did not realize their modem had wifi; so needed router to stream netflix, etc.  now we lose the stream after about 3 hours, and have to reset modem and it takes about 5 minutes and it is a pain in the neck. So I would suggest that one should really know their routers before buying.This was too much $$ for me to replace soon...
Works okay, but the range isn't very good. My old, slower Netgear router had better range.Should have spent more for better range.

The netgear works good for online gaming and live chat but for web search its slow and I dont kbow why I can solve the problem. Other then that is fine just web search it slow. If someone know why I have this problem let me know

the router works fine and faster than the cheaper version with single band. the problem is advertised readydlna which won't be able to read through all files and be streamed to video box. very disappointed. have to buy another cloud storage to compensate this lacking function.

column9: Good router with lots of features
column10: There's only one reason I didn't rate this five stars, and it's a bit of a doozy. Well, I should say it WAS a doozy. The original firmware was causing a major issue: Many devices would lose connection CONSTANTLY to the router, and SSID would nolonger be broadcast. I had this router for months with this issue. I wanted to replace it, but the network storage link was such a handy feature that I kept it.Finally they released a firmware update that addressed the issue, and I haven't had a problem since. My advice, if they're not shipping them with the latest firmware, is to update the firmware the moment you connect it. Once you do that, you're not going to have any issues with this router.

column9: NETGEAR Wireless Router - N600 Dual Band Gigabit (WNDR3700)
column10: I consider this to be a good router, but now that it's out of warranty; I question Netgear's customer service tactics. I recently had a problem when I purchased a Roku streaming video player. Apparently, the DNS settings needed to be changed in order for the Roku to operate correctly. Roku connected me to Netgear and explained what needed to be done. Since the router was no longer under warranty; I had to listen to a long sales pitch, in which Netgear wanted me to pay $129 in order to get 2 more years of live telephone support. Despite my telling the representative that I could buy a new router for less than the cost of the live telephone support, he insisted that I get it. I finally hung up out of disgust, and asked a friend to change the DNS settings for me. It took him all of 2 minutes to do so, and saved me a ton of money to boot.

column9: Product description was not product received
column10: I am revising this review because they were very apologetic and speedy about handling how I could return the item. I had been hunting for a specific and affordable router that is compatible with time warner services.  The item received was a different model as described and incompatible with my service.  I am not sure if it would have been replaced with the right product, bc I requested a refund. I have had to reschedule my service installation due to the delay, and considering this was the first day I could take off in four weeks to sit at home and wait for utility installation... I am probably overly frustrated at having to cancel and continue for another week without internet. They seem like nice people and I understand we are all human, but hopefully the other models are not incorrectly marketed as mine was.

column9: Very good router but has its flaws (READ FOR A SOULUTION TO FIX FLAWS)
column10: Bought this unit about two weeks ago, setup was very hassle free, and not a lot of tech knowledge was needed for the original setup.  Router ran great unbelievable speeds, both wireless and wired, but after a couple of hours I started dropping connection, and would have to reset the router to get it back up.  For a couple of days I tried my own troubleshooting, and googleing for a solution, and came up empty handed (apparently a lot of people have this issue but have not figured it out).  So I made the dreded call to netgear, where I was received by a man who had a heavy accent, and not communication skills.  After hanging up on him due to the communication issues, he called back and asked me to hold so he can transfer me to an engineer (woo-hoo another guy who has no idea about the unit, except what he reads out of his manual, or gets from another engineer).  After three hours of doing everything I have already done on my own they decided the unit was defective, and wanted me to send it in to amazon for a replacement.  Gut check time, to send in and get a replacement or get a refund.  I was so impressed with the unit when it did work I decided to chance it and get the replacement.  A couple of days later the replacement arrived, I hooked it up , and this time instead of setting the whole network up I just hooked one computer to it, to test if it had the same problem.  So I ran the unit for 48hrs, and no disconnects, and I began to hook everything back up.  A couple of hours later dropped connection.  So I had a hunch that something on the network was killing the unit, and I started testing everything by disconnecting one device at a time and running until it died again.  Final I found the culprit, it was my 3tb Seagate Go-Flex hard drive that was being shared through the ready share feature.  So to continue this I decided to see if it was the drive itself or if it was the ready shard functions.  I test several hard drives, that were freshly formatted, and ranged from different sizes, did not have the problem on any of them.  So in conclusion what I believe the flaw is with this unit that Netgear has not discovered at this time is that you must reformat your hard drive before you attach it, I have since reformatted the seagate, and slowly started putting everything back on it, (I am currently putting data on it now), and it has ran non-stop for 48hrs, and I have put almost everything back on it.  So if you plan on using the media share function make sure you format the drive, and you should not have a problem.  Unit is a very good unit, very fast and very user friendly, and for the price it is untouchable, with the information that I have giving you.  If the unit did not have this flaw, or if someone was kind enough to figure this out before I bought it, I would give it a 5 star rating, but considering the time I placed into figuring out the problem, and hoops I had to jump through I can only give it a three star rating.

I was having problems with the router and had worked with Netgear to get the problem resolved but it didn't work. After writing my review here, Netgear contacted me to try to resolve the problem though I was now past the 90 day free Tech support. After quite a bit of trouble shooting and tweaking the settings my router seems to be working good now so I'm raising my rating from 1 star to 3 for the router but I would have to say that Ana at Netgear was a pleasure to work with on resolving the problem. That seems to be getting rare with tech support these days. I'm pleased with Netgear's willingness to try to please their customers. I will say that this router is fast and that speed was not a problem even when it was dropping internet connection. Now it is even better and is functioning like it should have from day one.

I like the router- I wasn't getting good reception in my home office from my AT&T U-Verse router and this was suggested as a solution.  I set it up and now I can use wireless devices and a TV with Netflix streaming/ Youtube, etc...My Brother wireless printer doesn't communicate with my computer however.  I called brother to troubleshoot.  Couldn't get the settings configured correctly.  Called NetGear and they tried to sell me some service plan for $129.  A short chat last night with NetGear was equally disappointing.  Customer service department is one of the worst I have encountered in a while.

column9: A beast of a router, but not customizable
column10: The specs on this router are very good, especially for the low price point.  I bought it with the intention of putting DD-WRT on it, but I also had hope that I wouldn't need to.  Recent routers I purchased from Cisco/Linksys actually run a stripped down version of DD-WRT, so I was hoping Netgear would do something similar.Unfortunately, no.  The Netgear router interface is very basic.  It worked out of the box as expected, but its feature set was extremely basic.  A basic feature I was looking for was the ability to assign static DHCP leases to specific machines on my network.  The Netgear doesn't have this feature.  It doesn't have a number of other common advanced features, either.  If I was buying this router for my parents or a basic Internet user, it'd be great, but for user with more advanced needs, it's lacking compared to the combination.Like I said, though, I planned to replace the stock Netgear firmware with DD-WRT to get those advanced features.  The v3 WNDR3700 has a newer chipset that DD-WRT does not yet support (and as of this time, no ETA is given) and so that router I received would not even work for that.  If you're considering this for a DD-WRT-based router, realize that you'll need to look elsewhere for an older v1 or v2 model of this router.  Amazon does not print part or version numbers for this hardware, so you can't tell what you will get, but they'll likely ship you the newest hardware revision.So, in the end, it's a great router if you don't want to do anything advanced with it.  For the very short time I had it running, I had no problems.  Don't consider this router, though, if you want to run an alternate firmware or are looking for a router with more advanced features.

Great device for connectivity with multiple networks and multiple different card types(N,G). With that being said, i just have one complaint. I purchased this for the main purpose of having the UPnP usb connection on the back, which is basically having NAS. The problem is, that it works beautifully with any PC/Mac connecting to it through the network, but when you try reading data from it with the Xbox or PS3 it will only show about 1/3 the files within the drive. Saddening when it comes to Music and Movies. If I purchased it for any other reason, it would get 4/5 stars.

column9: Router seems fine, tech support was a nightmare
column10: I actually like those folks in India. They're always been courteous to me and they seem to try hard. Well, that past experience was shattered with this router. Router was shipped just fine, packaged just fine, hooked up just fine, and then the software configuration is where the problem started. Even though I'd upgraded to the latest version, the software screen did not match the instructions on their website. So for instance I went to Netgear's tech support, entered the exact model number of my unit and it would say 1) do this, 2) do that, etc but what they were saying did not match the software screens at their web page driven configuration. So calling tech support I explained all I wanted to do was change the login password for the network from 'password' which is the default to my own password. This was like something new to them, the gal tried to help me and then moved me to an upper tier tech support person who was one unhappy camper, he was surly and short tempered, and just plain nasty. I really didn't care, so I went through it step by step with him and we couldn't do it either. I finally had an friend of mine who's a network pro come over and he showed me how it's done in 60 seconds. I showed him the discrepancies between what they said to do and the screens I had to work with, and he said he sees this all the time.So far it's running just great but their tech support made me want to pull my hair out. I worry about older Americans like my parents who have to call and deal with these tech support people that are so angry and hateful.

column9: A good product with short live
column10: I have been happy with this router until it suddenly die a few days ago. Bought it  in Dec. 2010. It only last one and half year. I paid $150 for it. It is really short lived. For a router at this price range, I expect it would last longer. I have to bring out my old Linksys WRT54G that never die. My previous one before WNDR3700 is Linksys WRT310N,which is a nightmare. It has overheat and dropping connection problem.Beside short lived, this router performance is good. It does not drop connection at all. It happened once or twice in one and half year. The range of 2.4GHz is good. I get strong signal in my bed room closet that is at the other end of the house that WRT54G had trouble. The 5GHz channel is short. At half of the distance of my house, signal drops to half. After that, signal drops quick.Overall, it is a good unit with short live.  It absolutely does not worth $150. At current price range around $100, you can decide. I do not think it even worth that as you need to shop another one pretty soon.

column9: Good Router - Beware of USB Storrage Limitations
column10: While I  am pleased with the routing functions of this unit, I  was frustrated and disappointed with the Readyshare USB Storage limitations. Netgear advertizes this feature as allowing one to 'Wirelessly access and share USB hard drives'.  If this is a feature you wish to use, be very careful to track down Netgear's list of compatable devices and make sure the precice USB storage device you have is as supported. For example, because Netgear includes the Seagate 2TB Free Agent GoFlex Desk 3.5inch as a compatable device, I thought it was fairly safe to assume that the 3TB Seagate GoFlex Desk 3.5 inch drive should work. It does not, and a call to Netgear support confirmed that there is no work around such as formating a smaller partition. I was simply told that if its not on the list as supported, it will not work.

Have had this for just over 6 months now...  wonderful!  Set it up initially without any problems.  Nice being able to setup a guest network temporarily when we have a bunch of family in town for the holidays.  Also really like the fact that I can reduce the power output of the radios to save a little bit of power.  I walked around the house with my tablet that has a signal strength check program on it to make sure I had adequate signal strength after turning down the power on the 2.4ghz band.  What I really like is that I just hooked up an external USB drive to it and put all of our music library on it as variable bit rate mp3s.  We can now listen to all our Jimmy Buffett and Jack Johnson in the bedroom via our blue-ray player without having to bring up the actual CDs.  Three cheers for DLNA!July 17, 2013Router's 2.4 ghz radio just died.  Had to replace with a new router.

column9: The absolute worst customer service on the planet
column10: I have just spent over three hours with three separate reps to handle a NETGEAR wirless router setup issue. Disconnected twice, gave all the infomation 3x and when disconnected they only called back once.You simply can not understand them. The first two reps did not even address the issue after almost one and half hours on the phone!!! all they wanted was my information, put me on hold and disconnected me.Absolutely do not go near this company if you want service. when I called them back, I had to go through the IVR craziness again. There is no sense of urgency, and it is impossible to undertand them unless you repeat  the question several times.AWFUL. JUST AWFUL. I WILL NEVER, NEVER, NEVER....BUY NETGEAR OR BEST BUY AGAIN.....NEVER

The only set-up instruction accompaning the unit was a paper saying Netgear no longer included instructions with this unit and that one should check their website. Nothing wrong with that, I guess, if the instructions are easily accessible.I had to piece together various bits of info from their site to end up with adequate set-up instructions and it was discouraging to start the process and find my particular model wasn't even listed in the pop up model list of current models. It is now set-up and working fine. I'm not sure how to rate as the unit itself is performing well but I'm sure, for some, set up could be frustrating.

column9: WNDR3700 v3 does not work for CeroWrt firmware
column10: For all you firmware folks, the v3 model of the WNDR3700 is not supported by CeroWrt ([...]). The WNDR3800 is widely available (through Amazon!) and is supported. (I've not tried this model, so give it a neutral rating.)

EDIT, 1-31-2012:After a tip from a buddy of mine with an older-version of this router, I did, in the end, on the most recent firmware, (V1.0.0.22_1.0.17) find the Static DHCP option, not on the 'Basic' configuration tab, but under the 'Advanced' tab, Setup -> LAN Setup -> Address Reservation.Rating remains the same, as printing through this router is like printing using through molasses. Still need to get that v2 router to test.ORIGINAL REVIEW FOLLOWS:Was expecting v2 router, received v3. v3 uses a Broadcom chip, as opposed to Atheros, rendering it (currently) incompatible with custom firmwares, a la DD-WRT, OpenWRT, Tomato, etc.Flash memory is halved, relative to the previous version, from 16 MB to 8 MB.Lacks features I deem essential in a $99+ router: Static DHCP, (Used to ensure that devices will always get the same IP address whenever they try to get a new IP address.) and bandwidth meters. (Graphical tracking of network activity is nice.)I am considering returning it and trying to find a v2 off a Best Buy shelf somewhere.

I took a chance on purchasing this based on mixed reviews. I have experience working with Enterprise Cisco routers as well as home/office routers. I purchased the 3700 solely for the 5gz signal. The lower band is crowded in my neighborhood, and there is no one broadcasting on the upper band. I set up the router manually and was disappointed in the lack of manual controls. The router sits about 15 feet from my laptop with no obstructions. I know that you can set up with custom firmware, but did not go this route. Using multiple settings, updated firmware, more than one laptop, and searching various forums I could not get the 5gz to hold a steady signal. I could see the signal oscillating slightly using software made for that purpose. Unfortuneately, this was enough to cause the transmissions to constantly fluctuate between 150 and 270. The lower band was always solid.I have an older MIMO Trendnet 2.4 only router that I was replacing, and I used it to compare signals and rates. It would sometimes fluctuate between 150 and 300, but it is competing with 5 to 6 of my neighbors operating in the same range.Maybe I got a dud, but I'm not willing to take a chance on a replacement; will be boxing for return to Amazon as soon as I finish this review. My next choice will probablly be one of the Cisco/Linksys routers, but since several articles rated the 3700 highly, I thought I would give it a try.

column9: WNDRMAC appears to be better and cost effective than WNDR3700 / WNDR3800
column10: After my research I was about to buy the WNDR3700; just at last minute I came across WNDRMac. This model appears to have better features than the WNDR3700, and is similar to the WNDR3800; plus special support for Mac. I have a MBP so I liked it at first look. On Amazon I got it for $85, which is cheaper than 3700 model. All the features that WNDR3700 offer are already part of WNDRMac. Below are the features 3700 doesn't seem to have which are in WNDRMac model. The one I received is WNDRMacV2 which has very similar hardware config as WNDR3800. (As a matter of fact, WNDRMac is much closer to WNDR3800, only missing things are the firmware features like ClearChannel Selector, Tivo compatability etc).Features in WNDRMac which are not in WNDR3700:- Rapidshare USB Printer support- Genie dashboard control- Video Mode- Time Machine compatible- CD-less install (not that it really matters)To my surprise, WNDRMac model nicely worked with an externally powered USB drive! From several reviews and user comments, the 3700/3800 models did not seem to work with a USB drive which was externally powered. It uses Bonjour for the Printers - so connecting printer should not be as difficult as other models (Bonjour can be installed on Windows as well).Overall, I feel WNDRMac has more features than WNDR3700 (much closer to WNDR3800), plus closer to Mac and works well with PCs - with lesser cost than either of those models.

UPDATE 2011/12/2: Going strong for half a month now. As far as I recall, no reboots, or maybe one for an unrelated reason. I am raising my rating from one star to three stars. It would have been four if I wouldn't have had to go through all of this hassle to get it to work right. Netgear should have left well enough alone with firmware v1.0.4.55NA and hardware version 1.UPDATE 2011/11/15: Smallnetbuilder dot com stuck with firmware version v1.0.4.55NA according to one of their articles that referenced the WNDR3700v1 test results. That version was still available on Netgear's support site (just click 'show all versions').  I loaded that with the following ritual:Hold reset switch 30 seconds with power on (still 1.0.16.98-dnsNA firmware).  Keep holding, turn power off, hold for 30 seconds while power is off.  Still holding, turn power on. Then turn power off and let go of reset switch and wait 10 seconds. Boot up, leave on for at least two minutes, and do software factory reset (from backup menu in web GUI). Let it reboot. Then upload and install v1.0.4.55NA from web GUI. Then do a software reset again. Then re-upload and install v1.0.4.55NA.  I don't know if all of this is really necessary. It is my compilation of all the posted paranoia out there. Now set up your preferred SSID names, Port Forwards, DHCP range, etc.  I didn't change any of the QOS or WAN settings.  I left NAT as secure. I set up the 2.4GHz radio as G (54Mb/s) with WEP, the 5GHz radio as N single band (130Mb/s), WPA2 Personal AES. You can probably set it up for 300Mb/s (double wide) if you want. Now everything with youtube and IPTV have been fine for about a day.  l already received an RMA number.  But if all goes well for another couple of days, I'll keep the unit. If not and I return it, I will let you know here.The rationale behind the paranoid flash procedure is to make sure that another firmware version's setup (usually a slightly different size when backup-stored, with slightly different options) doesn't corrupt the the new firmware footprint (I guess). I don't know if someone had a rational method of coming up with it (e.g., ex-Netgear engineer with some inside knowledge) or it was just someone's gut feeling.  END OF UPDATE.I searched out a WNDR3700 VERSION 1 because that is the version that got rave reviews at smallnetbuilder.com. [Netgear screwed up the version 2 by skimping on the antenna array.]  I found this 'Refurb' version 1 and thought I had lucked out.  The seller was very helpful in making sure I got the right version.I suspect Netgear takes defective returns, wraps them in new plastic, and labels them 'Refurb,'  and hopes they work or that whatever defect they had would not be noticed by the new buyer.  For some reason, they scratch out the serial number to signal that they won't support their refurbs. Why not? Cisco-Linksys leaves serial numbers on refurbs and give them limited warranties. Or maybe Netgear so screwed up the firmware for this device that it doesn't know what to do.This router started out looking good but then gradually slowed down to the point that even standard def youtube videos and highly compressed IPTV from Hulu Plus would slow down and freeze or stutter.  I tried at least three versions of firmware and continued to have the same problem (1.0.6.98NA as shipped, and then 1.0.7.98NA, 1.0.4.68NA, and finally the latest 1.0.16.98-dnsNA).  The labeling of firmware itself is a mystery and suggests that this company is just scrambling to put out fires. What happened to everything between 1.0.7.x and 1.0.16.x for example? And why was 1.0.16.98 label reused for the beta 1.0.16.98-dnsNA instead of calling it 1.0.16.99NA? Also, the auto-update only shows up to 1.0.7.98.The internet is filled with similar complaints about slow downs and freezes, trying various firmwares, and doing various magic spell rituals before upgrading (holding reset button for 10 seconds, or 30 seconds, or doing it twice, unplugging with reset pushed, and so on).  I tried the most burdensome rituals in case there was something to them.Just in case anyone gets one of these, the only way I could get even initial acceptable results in youtube was to change the NAT setting from 'secure' to 'open.' Not so safe.I have applied to return this piece of garbage.  It is back to my old Linksys WRT600n with DD-WRT for now. My only complaint about that dinosaur is that it suddenly looses the 5Ghz wireless connection when streaming a lot of video, probably because of overheating. It is about 3 years old. So I am still looking for a reliable replacement.

column9: Be Careful! Previously used and sold as new
column10: Purchased from Amazon in September because of the great reviews and duel band offering. The delivery was prompt and the package was shrink wraped with inside contents sealed with a Netgear seal. When I went to set up the router I was having problems and discovered that tech support will only help after you register your Netgear product.  When I tried to register the router's serial number it kept rejecting the registration. I got in touch with Netgear customer service who informed me that the product had been registered previously in March and the free 60 day tech support timeframe was up.  Only after you can prove that you recently purchased the product from Amazon will you be provided any set-up or tech support.Do yourself a favor and avoid wasting time on the phone dealing with used routers that were returned 6 months earlier.  If you value your time spend a few dollars more and shop at some place that sells new Netgear products.  Also, a quick note if you are thinking of buying a refurbished Netgear product be aware that they will not provide any tech support unless you pay for it in advance.

I bought this for my dad when he changed from DSL to cable Internet. Although I've been using Draytek for many years, I decided to keep the costs down for my dad. Even so, $120 is not inexpensive and I had high hopes for this router.Installation and set-up was a breeze. I didn't bother using the 'wizard' but went through everything manually and it was up and running in about 10 minutes.Range was somewhat disappointing compared to my dad's old Draytek 2800G. The Netgear doesn't seem to punch through walls as well and the signal to the guest house on his property -- about 50 feet away, is much poorer than the Draytek. This is true on both the 2.4 and 5GHz bands, although when connected, performance and throughput is fine. The Drayteks have 3 external antennae and the Netgear's are internal. Maybe that's the difference? I've seen no evidence of the Wifi disconnect issues that others have, but I immediately updated to the latest version of firmware when I set the router up.Netgear position the N600 as a high end performance router. Compared to my Draytek 2110n, the feature set is limited. If you need VPN, VLAN, IGMP, or RADIUS capability, more sophisticated NAT, firewall, QoS, or NAT capability, then the Draytek is a much better choice.In conclusion, I think the Netgear will be acceptable, signal coverage issues not withstanding. However in retrospect, I wish I'd spend the extra $20 for the Draytek 2110n.

column9: Excellent range but not the greatest life
column10: I purchased this router several years ago.  At the time it was "the best", it had the greatest range and cutting edge tech.  The router worked excellent, however I will note that my Asus laptop with built in Intel 6200 AGN wireless did take a while to connect to it each time you turned it on (I do not experience that delay with my current router).A few months ago the router started intermittently not connecting to the internet, and sometimes the SSID would not show.  This was easily correctly by unplugging and restarting the router.  Unfortunately for me, the router is in the basement, and this was a pain.  So, I bought a new router.  Actually, two, I purchased a new Asus AC68U.  The range was not as good as with this Netgear WNDR3700.  I did return the router and purchased a TP Link router.  It is decent (and much better priced) but again, the range is no where near what the Netgear had.

column9: Too much money for too little
column10: I wanted a good dual N/G router that would also would act as a media server. Guess I was asking too much. Even after several updates to the firmware, the media server still hangs every few hours. Guess it can't handle 5000 songs and videos. After the latest firmware update, at least the NAS works. I plugged in a USB powered drive (Seagate GoFlex) formatted FAT32 and it seems to work fine as a NAS only.Did some further testing and found that for me the N band is no more effective than the G band. I have the router in an adjacent room about 25' from a Nintendo PS3 and Apple AirPort Express Base Station. I set the AirPort to N and used it's Ethernet port on the PS3 during testing. I'm getting around 1.5 to 2.0 megabytes/s transfer rate with both G and N. I tried raising the router and receiving devices up higher (4'-5' above grade), but this made no difference. I'm disappointed in the N band. Perhaps the receiving devices need to be closer, but then what's the point? I can run cables over short distances easily enough.Not sure what the problem is, but next time I think I'll stick with G unless I see reports that N will work better than G in my application. Who knows what technology may be around the corner, however.

I purchased this router based on good reviews and obsessive research. It replaces an old super basic Netgear WGR614.  I am underwhelmed so far with this router, aside from the pretty blinking lights.  The 5Ghz channel is essentially worthless beyond 30 feet in my home, and the 2.4 Ghz ('g') band has no better range than the ancient router it replaced.  It also refused to connect with a fairly new Vizio HDTV for streaming, which was 25 feet away (and one interior wall).  The tv connection finally succeeded after an hour with a helpful Netgear tech rep, during which we had to use the 2.4 Ghz band, lower the security level and lower the transmission mode to only 54 kbps. So much for a high end 'rangemax' router.  Another 45 minutes with Netgear tech support on another day proved of no help in trying to see if the poor range in the 5 Ghz band could be improved -- I was basically told that my wifi adapters on my laptops might be the problem.  This while I sat in a room 40 feet away in direct line of sight to the blinking router, with only 2-bar 'fair' reception on the 5Ghz band, on each of 2 new Dell laptops and a older Toshiba. That is only 1 bar more than I can pick up on a neighbor's 'N' band router signal which is about 100 yards away.  Something is goofy. I will continue to work on it, but I just don't seem to get what the big practical advantage is to these routers if the range can be so poor.  Yes, I know your mileage will vary based on other appliances, interference, walls, etc, but there is a minimum of such things in my home.  On to the forums for help.

column9: NETGEAR Wireless Router - N600 Dual Band Gigabit (WNDR3700)
column10: Quick shipment, item was in good order and ready to use when received.  Plan on getting good use out of it.

I bought this to replace a TrendNet AC1200, which was total garbage.  I am happy that Netgear didnt disappoint.  The router works great, the only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5, is because of the incredibly long boot time.  This router takes several MINUTES to cold boot, its ridiculous.If your area is prone to power bumps or regular outages, you will definitely want to plug this into a UPS...
bought this because I was experiencing intermittent outages.  set up was relatively pain free and the outages have gone away.  can't speak to reliability because have only had it 2 weeks.

The WNDR 3700 wireless router is easy to use. Easy to setup. I connect my new Sony Bravia TV, my Sony Bluray, my Laptop, and my other desktop computer. I can internet in my laptop in my bed in another room. I can stream Netflix movie in my living room.

As other reviewers have mentioned, this is a great piece of hardware, but the firmware leaves a little to be desired.  Based on the caliber of hardware this is, I was surprised to see that the built-in firmware does not give you the option of forwarding a given WAN port to a different port on the LAN (e.g. forward port 8080 to port 8081 or whatever).  It only allows port 8080 to be forwarded to port 8080, and so on.  Of course, I hadn't seen this until I had already bought it (I guess I didn't spend enough time reading reviews!)  Based on suggestions by other reviewers, I installed DD-WRT firmware, which was very easy.  Now the device does what I want and quite well, I might add.

Intallation was pretty straight forward. i am an old guy so am somewhat computer challenged, but I installed this with no problems on my own. It is running three computers, sometimes 4 with my wifes work computer feeding off the wireless. It is fast and so far has not given me a single hiccup.. i rated the features/reliability and range at 'ok' because i have no use for them, have not tested or used them...  I will say one feature I like, is the ease of access to set it up or change settings.. other than that, I did not fuss with any of the other extras...  I have not had it very long, so cannot comment on the reliability as of yet.. and the range....  well, we use the wireless within the confines of our own house, so extra range really wouldnt matter to me at all and hasnt been tested...  the wireless connection does seem to be more reliable and faster.. at least.. my wife hasnt yelled at me about being disconnected, and no mumbling or cursing about speed from her since this was installed.. so at this point I have to give it a good review! it remains to be seen if this is going to DIE like the linksys routers I used to use between one and two years of age...

column9: Slightly more range, much better speed
column10: Range on the 2G band is much better, but the range on the 5G band seems the same or perhaps even worse.Speed overall is much improved over my old wireless router, as it should be.Solid product, plus it looks nice.

I'm not a geek, so installing a router can be problematic. This wasn't too painful. It's all working smoothly now, but I'll admit I still do not fully understand the security features, what they do and how they can be changed, etc. One thing I found really irritating was that when I wanted to know what the lights on the router represented and signified, I could absolutely find nothing that told me. Not even on Netgear's website. My main concern was the lowest two which have to do with making the router discoverable. I still don't know if the bottom green light should be flashing or solid. But, most importantly, it's all working. It's not cheap, but I think it's going to prove a good purchase.

column9: This is a great wireless router
column10: I love the Netgear brand. I got this router a few months ago and its great. I run it with my cable modem. Solid connection, easy to setup guide and a helpful homepage online. This is a must if you have a big home or a place with a lot of corners. All the laptops in my home run on the 2.4 while the 5 GHz frequency is great because you can isolate it to be just a video network which you can use for Blu-Ray players or anything that streams video wirelessly. It reaches every point in my house. Plus its a good starting place if you want to expand to their powerline series of wall connectors which i plan to be getting soon.

column9: Nice so far. DD WRT compatible !
column10: Bought this last month. Loaded DD WRT. No problems so far. Havent tried the N wireless speeds so far.The DD WRT page for the router : [...]I didnt know how set up ddwrt to access the usb drive attached to the router. used the settings suggested by jason5641 on this page -[...] . worked like a charm. Am still figuring out how to access that drive via internet from outside the home. Will update the review once I find out. If anybody knows , pls let me know.

column9: Junk the CD setup program; login and do it yourself
column10: Having owned a Netgear WGT624 for years, the WNDR3700 was a natural upgrade choice.  However, the many negative reviews it had accumulated gave pause.  I considered other brands but in the end stuck with Netgear, at least in part to avoid the aggravation of learning another user interface.  Having bought it, I should have just plugged it in, logged on, configured it for my network and started working.  But instead I let the supplied Netgear setup and documentation CD lead me through the supposedly idiot-proof setup procedure.  Well, it turns out that the idiot is the programmer who developed the setup procedure.  Here's what happened.First, the setup procedure went through a four-step process to detect my current WGT624 setup.  Worked like a champ -- all OK.  Feeling confident, I let it lead me through the simple task of reconfiguring cables from old router to new.  OK, fine, did that in about 10 seconds.  Then the frustration began.  The next part of the setup was another four-step process wherein the setup program supposedly detects and configures the new WNDR3700 router.  Only it didn't.  At step 3 of 4, the detect-the-new-router step, it hung up. Half an hour later, it was still chugging along, doing who knows what, but certainly not running to completion.  Worse, the little X in the upper right corner that lets the user shut down the setup program was grayed out so I couldn't stop the setup program gracefully.  Time to nuke it with Task Manager (on the app tab, not the process tab, if you're wondering).  That's when things got ugly -- the setup program fought back by freezing my xp machine colder than an iceberg.  Nothing left to do but hold the power button in until the computer shut down -- hardly a polite way to behave.So, restart and now what?  After mulling it over, I decided to give the idiot setup CD another chance.  I wasn't sure what to expect, but it readily found and verified the WNDR3700 in the first stage of the process -- which it surely must have thought was my 'old' router at this point.  Skipping the cable switching part of the setup CD, I proceed to the new router discovery phase.  At this point, I was confident that even the idiot setup program would get it right.  After all, it had just finished verifying the WNDR3700, which was now in the circuit.  Well, not so fast.  After whirring for awhile, it came to a grinding halt and informed me with a smug error message that 'this setup program only works with a WNDR3700 router' (isn't that what it had just verified??) and that what I had in the circuit WASN'T a WNDR3700 (huh?), so I should remove it and put the proper router in place before proceeding!  GRRRR!I guess at this point I would have ripped the cursed thing loose and thrown it out the window except for a bit of serendipity.  I happened to have my smartphone sitting on the table beside me. Amazingly, a message was showing on its display asking me if I wanted to select NETGEAR as my Wi-Fi network.  Finally, as Hercule Poirot might have said, the little gray cells began to catch on.  Sure enough, the WNDR3700 was alive and well despite the setup program's best efforts to hide that fact. I found the setup manual on the CD, located the password and logged on, downloaded the latest firmware, configured the router for my network and it's been running ever since -- no thanks to the Netgear setup program.As far as performance is concerned, the WNDR3700 substantially exceeds the capabilities of its predecessor.  It is located in a back corner on the second floor of a two story house.  With the WGT624 and an older laptop (g-based), signal strength diagonally opposite at the front corner on the first floor was usually two bars out of five.  Now it's five bars.  Can't speak to N-based performance because I don't yet have gear operating in that range.  The user interface is virtually the same as previous versions and is easy to use and to configure.  Good choice there.  But as to the setup program. . .  well, I won't giving that a good rating any time soon.  P.S.  Haven't tried the USB interface and don't intend to; that seems to be a source of some of this unit's problems.  I already own network disks and don't need to network my USBs.

I got this item off my wish list from my parents, and it was extremely easy to set up, the install disk could say 'Installation for Dummies' :) After set up i noticed that all my devices, PS3, XBOX 360 (New slim one), Smart Phones, Computers, and My Kindle all only saw the 2.4GHz signal... i called tech support who was very easy to speak with, and they explained that not all devices yet accept/detect the 5GHz signal yet, and i would have to upgrade or modify my equipment... They do sell a dual band USB stick, but i'm not sure it will work with my PS3, or XBOX 360... i wanted this device because of the dual band capability, and the wireless video stream/gaming superiority of the 5GHz over the 2.4GHz, but will have to wait until devices come with this built into their wifi cards (Which you can buy now, but i'm not going to open up the game systems, or my laptop) in the future. Works great though! I had all my devices running video, and no problem on the one signal, but would prefer it if i could run my PS3 and XBOX on the 5GHz.

column9: Very easy to install - hope it lasts longer than my last NetGear!
column10: Even with the FREE Shipping received the unit in 2 days so my network was not inaccessible for too longThis unit looks pretty slick and sharp with a shiny black finish and a sturdy base to remain standing on a horizontal surface. It has a modern tech look to it.  Can also be installed horizontally on a flat surface on the small rubber pads that are part of the router.  In the back it has an on-off button so that whenever you are done using the router you can turn it off to prevent unwanted hackers from using your internet access.  But of course you should always have it secured with a password to gain access to your network.Right out of the box it was very easy to install and worked right away. I followed the setup wizard and it was painless.  Afterwards, I just logged into the router set-up and further familiarized myself with all the settings possible so now whenever I need to change anything I can easily do it manually and more fine-tuned to my needs.I've only had it for about 1 month and so far so good. My last NetGear router only lasted two years which was disappointing and if it happens again I'm through with Netgear!My only complaint is that I felt it was too expensive compared to other brands of routers, and the lettering corresponding to each light on the router can't be readily read due to the shinny glare and small letters. But I guess you don't need to read each light's nomenclature too often!The network speeds are great for what we need and connection to the internet through a broadband cable modem works great and at fast speeds.

This is a great router.  Easy to install and setup.  We have multiple devices which link up to this router (Hardwire iMAC, MAC Laptop, multiple DELL laptops, iPODs, iPad, gaming console, etc).  No compatibility problems.  I sometimes think the router belongs to a union; it seems to take a lot of 'rest breaks', but it wakes up after a couple seconds of asking it.  The dual band was not intuitively obvious to set up, but could be my own ignorance in the technology.  All things considered, I would buy this router again in a heartbeat.
I use the router to download movies from Netflix and for a wireless laptop. This router is fast so I get mostly uninterrupted Netflix downloads and a good wireless range for my laptop.

I saw this on Maximum PC's 'Best of the Best' items, and I needed the best, so I purchased it.  It is definitely fast.  My only gripes are a couple of quirky things that, hopefully, I'll iron out in the course of owning this.  I have a PS3 plugged directly into one of the gigabit ports, and I get some strange behavior from streaming video.Hulu Plus shows will randomly skip ahead a couple seconds in the show, causing me to rewind.  It happens 2-3 times in an hour-long show, which is frequent enough to be annoying, but is remedied by rewinding.Netflix doesn't skip, but it does restart an instant streaming show 2-3 times before finally buffering enough to play all the way.  Again, not a huge deal, but a nuisance.Overall though, I'm pretty happy with the router, and I can live with a couple of quirks over issues that I have seen people comment about with the Cisco routers.  I would probably buy it again if given the choice.

I got this router for speed, distance of signal and USB drive connectivity. I had to struggle initially to setup my USB drive as a network drive which had only Mac OS Extended (Journaled) partition. But once I set the drive up with two partitions on DOS and the other just Mac OS Extended (NOT Journaled). They I was able to read/write to all partitions. Just one less star for the struggle and solution hunting I had to do by myself.

I had read many of the reviews online before purchasing this router and was somewhat hesitant to purchase one due to quite a few low opinions of this product.  Having been a netgear user for over 6 years now, I know their products can be hit or miss.  My biggest worry from reading the reviews/issues of this router were the VPN problems that were reported since I use VPN everyday to work from home.I am happy to state that I have yet to have any major (or minor for that fact) issues with this router.  I was able to set it up quickly manually (without the wizard) as I had print screens of my previous netgear routers settings and just plugged them all into the new router.  It took very little time and I was back on the internet.  On thing I did not do however was perform the router upgrade yet.  From the reviews I read, some users had problems once they upgraded the firmware.  Since I have had no issues yet, I am waiting for a newer version of the firmware before I upgrade.  As for VPN, my company uses Juniper and Citrix and I have had no problems connecting and working from home.  I am on 8 hours or more a day (VPN) and have yet to lose the connection as some have reported.The router itself is a good looking piece of hardware, all in black with a stand to have it stand on edge, taking up much less space than my previous one laying flat.  I find the LED's rather subdued myself compared to my last netgear rangemax router with it's 'disco lights' anttenna.  My PC's are all on the 2.4ghz band so I can't comment on the 5.0ghz but I did notice a slight increase in signal strength.  Speed through the wired connection is the same as with the old router.I did purchase an external USB drive from Iomega, although I have yet to set it up with the router.  From what I have heard speeds are very slow but at this point I can't commment on that since I have yet to try it though the router.  I did buy the router for this feature (USB) since Windows 7 has back-up problems writing to my other Iomega USB drive.  I am hopeful that if I can get this one up and running, it may solve that problem by going through the router, we shall see.My only complaint so far about the router is some lack of documentation.  There are two buttons on the front which I cannot find any explanation as to what they do.  I was hoping one would turn off the wireless since I don't need the kids on the net during my work hours eating up bandwidth.In closing, my experience so far with this router has been all good.  I realize I don't use it for all it's features but for a wired/wireless router with USB it works for me.
It has some sort of dislike to comcast modems, you have to use a crossover cable to get it to grab an IP.
Shopped all over for a system capable of 802.11b/g/n simultaneously....this is harder to find.Definitely easiest, best, fastest product available.,

The router works great (speed: simultaneous Netflix streaming & cloud backup on two different computers no problem, connection reliability, range perfectly fine for 3-bedroom house & small backyard) once one manages the setup. Following the setup instructions helps only to a very limited extent, at least when using a 2010 MacBook Pro running on OS 10.6. Instead one has to go through quite a bit of trial-and-error and some disappointing crashes during the online setup procedure. Eventually one gets there but easy setup is different, that's why it gets only a 4- and not a 5-star rating.

column9: router works good after hours of set up
column10: this works much better than my linksys wireless n router. i have a large house (3000 sq. ft.) and it is very spread out, i could only get connected with my linksys in a few rooms of the house. now i can get online anywhere in the house and we can play playstation online and stream movies in another room, and get online in another all at the same time. the connection speed is better too. the only negative i can say is that it was not a plug in and go set up. after we spent 3 hours trying to get it to work, and finally giving in and calling the toll free number for help we got a limited connection, pretty much  the same quality we had before. so my son came over (these young ones know so much more than we do when it comes to electronics) and tried to help us figure out what was wrong, he did a speed test and discovered the problem was with the router, so we called the toll free number for help, after he explained the problem we finally got transferred to the correct department that could help us, i really think that we never would have gotten the problem solved if my son had not known so much about it, and  he did have to argue with them a bit, but they finally did some changes in the settings and problem solved.

After having argued with one of the top of the line Linksys's for almost 6 months this router is a delight to have.  The Linksys was constantly dropping the connection to our DSL modem or the wireless computers.  Unfortunately the only way to correct that was a hard re-boot. (gets old fast)  Thus far the Netgear has done nothing but work as advertised.  Wish it had a slightly longer range and 1 more USB port but otherwise no complaints.

I really like this device - so much that I have recommended it to a number of people.This was purchased based on recommendations from smallnetbuilder (dot com).  The local network throughput is outstanding with very high lan-to-wan speeds (for those with extremely high speed internet connectivity).  Further, the range is just fantastic, and these have just about every bridging and repeating feature that one could ask for.I purchased mine on August, 2010 and have been running it nonstop for the last 7 months without a single hiccup.  I have also deployed these in a number of home-offices, and they work very well.We did run into some trouble with the WPS function, as the Intel WPS client was blowing up some of our custom config.  Further, the router kept on automatically re-enabling WPS.  To resolve this, we switched back to the Windows wireless configuration, which didn't use WPS.Overall, I would highly recommend this device to anyone who requires a fast, reliable wireless router/firewall with very good range.

I am pretty satisfied with the router, but it does have its problems. The main thing is that it sometimes kicks people off the network when there are about three or more devices on it. One or two will stay connected, but the others will have to reconnect. It's not because we (my father and I) move too far away; we don't even move. It just decides to boot a couple of our devices off now and then. It's not a huge issue, just a little inconvenience. When it is connected though, it works very well. It really helps us get the most out of our comcast high speed connection, which our previous router didn't. It's range is pretty good, which is a big part of why we made this upgrade. The price was a bit high, but well worth the quality. Overall, I'm happy with it and I would recommend this to most anybody.

column9: Nice upgrade from the standard blue Linksys Router
column10: My Linksys Wireless-G Broadband Router WRT54GL was on it's last leg dying after over 5 yrs of use.  It was time to get a new one.  Several reviews outside of Amazon said that this was a good buy.I've had it for about a month and the download speed has greatly improved.  We'll see how it goes in the next few months.

My Belkin was going bad so I upgraded to the 'best' one. My laptop (samsung which I bought at Amazon) was getting 3 bars wireless connection is now at 4 bars. So range is better but not that great. For my Toshiba 55in TV (Which I also bought at Amazon which is closer to my router than the laptop) it does not pick up the wireless signal. But I blame this more on my Toshiba TV. I do like the router because I haven't had any problems but for $150 I wish the range was better. My laptop is probably 25 to 30 ft away from my router with three walls in between.

column9: Great -- if you're using an opensource firmware
column10: I was looking for a replacement for my tired old Linksys WRT54G, of which I'd used several for almost ten years. On the recommendation of several friends and positive reviews, I picked up the WNDR3700. Unfortunately, when I purchased it, Netgear had decided to push out a 'v2' model shortly before I purchased, which included a few hardware changes for the better, but the unit shipped with an atrocious firmware. The system was nowhere near stable, and the code was in 'alpha' stage at best. The router would close any open connection after about 2 minutes, meaning that telnet/ssh and numerous games would suddenly disconnect. The interface was atrocious; several elements simply didn't work at all. Netgear barely acknowledged these problems in their support forums and took nearly three months to release a lazy patch that addressed the worst of the problems, but the unit still ran poorly, and the interface left much to be desired.The WNDR3700 had been supported for some time in various opensource projects like DD-WRT and OpenWRT (in fact, Netgear used OpenWRT as a base for their firmware) but with a hardware change between the original and the v2, the newer model wasn't supported, at first, and I had to wait a few more months for a reliable release. As of this writing, OpenWRT has a stable release for this model, including a 'factory installer' that can be used to easily flash the router to OpenWRT by using the default interface, very little muss or fuss.My initial review of this product was rather vitriolic given the then-$130 price tag and the utterly atrocious stock firmware. Since installing OpenWRT, this router has performed fantastically. The difference is night and day. Connections are fast and stable, and the router can handle a large amount of traffic without seizing up or crashing. Perhaps best of all, it's very approachable for a non-techie to use OpenWRT; the 'factory installer' images that allow you to easily install OpenWRT are truly painless and require only a little bit of fiddling within the interface afterwards. For those more technically-inclined, a very feature-rich hardware platform awaits your exploring and experimenting.One of the best features of this hardware platform is its full VLAN control and multiple SSID support, which makes possible several more-complex access control rules. For instance, my primary network covers one SSID and all gigabit ports on the router itself, all stations sharing an IP pool. The secondary or guest network is only served via wireless on a differend SSID/passkey, is not bridged to the physical ports (except WAN), and uses a separate IP pool from the primary network. This means you can supply a guest network with internet access, but without the ability to see any network shares or other machines on the private network. Netgear supplied this type of functionality with the stock firmware, but it's execution left much to be desired; with OpenWRT, it's a bit more involved to configure this setup, but it also gives you much greater control. Anyone with Linux sysadmin experience and a bit of google-fu could knock out just such a configuration.Overall, I give this unit 4/5 stars, mostly due to the rather abysmal firmware and support provided by Netgear. While the hardware is great, the stock firmware has left much to be desired. I recommend this for anyone with a moderate-to-high level of skill, someone who doesn't mind getting their fingers dirty with tinkering. Despite my initial misgivings (not to mention the stress headaches from the first two months stuck only with the initial firmware), I could scarcely be happier with its performance lately.

column9: Perfect replacement for my old LinkSys
column10: I purchased this wireless router to replace my aging LinkSys router purchased almost 10 years ago when I was still in college. That router was a champ but age (and the 20+ networks within range of my condo) were catching up with it. Long story short, I was in need of a replacement and did my research.This router, and the brand as a whole, was highly recommended by several sources. I'm a technologist by trade, so I rely on recommendations from friends and colleagues. I also scour the Internet for independent ratings and reviews. This Netgear was at the top of the list.Things I love:- Ability to broadcast multiple SSIDs for different network protocols and guest networks. I have frequent visitors who use my network and it's nice to now give them Internet access only and not access to the rest of my personal network.- Antenna power throttling. This is great! I don't want to have my entire neighborhood see my wireless access point, so I can provide less power and keep the signal close. On the other hand, I might be fighting for coverage in the densely populated area, so it's good to boost power. I like the control!- Automatic channel selection. On the old router, as people would move in and out, the network channels would become cluttered and empty out in different ranges. I'd have to manually adjust this on the old router when I was getting a lot of interference and noise. This Netgear does it automatically and seamlessly. Nice touch!- USB to plug in an external hard drive. This is an awesome feature and I no longer have to move my external backup drive around with the laptop as I move from room to room. Plug it into the router and voila; I have NAS! If I map the drive, however, I've found that it won't always connect immediately if I restart my computer. Minor annoyance and most likely due to my own configuration. I'll fix this later.Things I like:- The user interface in the admin pages is nice. Not the prettiest I've ever seen, but wonderfully usable. It's easy to figure out the admin pages without so much as a glance at the help guide.- No external antenna. Call me old fashioned, but I'm usually dubious about devices like this not having external antennas. Netgear has done it right, though, and I have absolutely no signal issues (even in my dense condo) and there's now nothing for the cats to chew on, or me to bump out of place. I'm a convert to antenna-less devices!- The thing is just pretty. It's a slick looking box and looks good sitting on the desk. I usually don't care about it, but it's actually worth mentioning here.Things I don't like:- I paid $150 for it. A little steep, but it's actually worth it. As I write this review I see it's $20 less. That would be a little easier to swallow.- Uhm... that's it.In conclusion, I love this router. I felt sad letting the old Linksys go, but this new router is so awesome that I quickly got over parting with my old college buddy! If you're thinking it might be time for an upgrade, do yourself a favor and look into this router. I believe you'd be hard pressed to find better.

column9: MAC Users May Need a PC to Set This Router Up
column10: There have been some questions regarding whether this router works with a Mac.  The device specs say that it is compatible, however, a word of caution: I COULD NOT get the router to recognize my internet connection (Comcast cable modem) through my 27' iMac running Snow Leopard. It was frustrating because if I bypassed the router by plugging the network cable straight into my Mac, the connection was fine.In frustration, I fired up my ancient Dell Inspiron 1501 running Windows XP, and using that computer the router setup worked fine, and I have all my devices (including the iMac) connected and all is well. (I did all this just last week, so the experience is recent.)Sooooooo... just a word of caution to you Mac users!

column9: The FASTEST router I have ever used
column10: Easy, quick setup, works just like the advertising says > very fast, the USB port is wonderful for a network backup drive.

This product is great with alot of features:Cons:-the setup is alittle stubborn with saving the settings and updating in real time as fast I would want.-Seems like the router needed or wanted to be setup by the cd that came with it-The ftp login only give you two logins - Admin and Guest - wish there was optional logins and more settings-Wish it had print server optionPros:-So many features for a great price-Supports Ftp/Http internal/external file sharing-File sharing format supported by most streaming networking devices-Has multiple access points for network for personal use and guest- separate one for wireless G/N/B network 2.4ghz and one for 5ghz for both SSIDS-Easy to setup access for file sharing-Traffic meter is a plus especially for isp like comcast and their bandwidth limitations keeps the nasty letter being sent to you-Wireless is fast dependable and great range!Worth every penny
One of the LED does not lite and 5G band does not stay on all the time (irregularly drop off).
Easy to setup. Great coverage, and reliable. Had to send back a different company's model that clamed great coverage. This one fit the bill. Very happy.

Heavy home use with many connected devices and users; performs flawlessly.Great things:- Outstanding range.- Manages 11 devices without issue: 4 laptops, 1 desktop, 2 iPads, 3 wifi phones, and a PS3 connect to this with no connectivity issues.- The device never drops/resets.  It just works.- Easy to set-up.- USB port for external drive.Possible drawback:- I wanted to plug in my external hard drive to this for network storage.  The drive turns off when connected to this router, rather than simply going to 'sleep' when connected to my laptop.  This is a problem because I want network storage that is always accessible without going into the other room to turn on the drive.  Not sure if this is an issue with the hard drive or router, but it is the only reason I cannot give it 5 stars.
This was a nice upgrade from my old router.  The look is sleek and the increased amount of features gives me many options to use as my network expands.

I have purchased and installed several of these routers.
