If you are planning on using one of them as a simple router, it is a great device; powerful, reliable, great range and lots of features, including the ability to enable/disable the 2.4 or 5Ghz spectrums, as well as enable/disable a separate guest network.The interface is pretty clean and easy to use, and I like that you can have the device check for firmware updates itself right through the configuration interface; no need to go to the manufacturer's website, figure out exactly which model and hardware revision you have, manually download the file, manually upload it to the router, etc. etc.Updating the device firmware on this Netgear router is far easier than with most other brands, as the router handles it all itself and defaults to checking for updated firmware every time you login to the device, which is nice, and can be disabled if you need to frequently login to the device.Speaking of firmware, that brings us to our big, gaping flaw and the reason I only gave this device a four-star rating:The repeat function absolutely does not work. Do NOT plan on purchasing two of these routers with the intent of using one as a base station and the other as a repeater to extend the range of your wireless network, because as of Nov. 2010, there is a firmware bug that simply doesn't allow this feature to work.After driving myself insane messing with it, I did some research online and on Netgear's support forums, it is clear that there's a known bug that prevents the repeat function from working.This has gone unresolved for months - I don't recall the exact dates of all the threads I read, but Netgear, through their support forums, has been aware of the issue for many months and still no new firmware, at least not as of Nov. 2010.That's a real shame as Netgear is one of the only companies whose networking products I trust, the other being Linksys/Cisco.I do hope they will address this big issue very quickly, as this seems to be their flagship consumer router.Anyhow, again, if you are looking for a single, simple router, this guy is great, just don't plan on buying a twin to use to extend the range of your network, as it won't work. If you need to do that, Apple's Airport actually does that quite well.

So far, I am satisfied with this unit. However, I do have one problem which I have not corrected yet and that is the duel band wireless connections. Of the 2 wireless options you can connect, we can only connect to the faster speed. When we attempt to connect to the slower wireless connection, we never connect.I had heard that the USB input was slow. I have not had a chance to stream a movie or something but I have hooked up a thumb drive and have no speed access issues there. * Edit - see comments - no printer support.The biggest upgrade for me was not having this router hang all the time as my Linksys and Belkin cheaper models had. I consider this top of line personal router and lower range commercial. In other words this should be a good unit for a small business.

This device replaced my Linksys router/G-wireless. I have some network experience so set up was routine; I just copied my hand written configs to the new unit and was setup in about an hour. I did not have any issues with the box not doing what its supposed to do. Now for the down side; everytime I save a category page of settings, the router takes a long time (30-40 seconds) to reboot. This is really nothing to complain about because it does not affect the performance, but if you are trying to plow thru the setup to get online and working, this is a major speed bump.The wireless performance I believe is good, I'm in a 3 level townhome 1800 sq feet (wood & stucco construction) and it works fine in all areas. As distance increases speed goes down. My speeds on the 5 Ghz band was at 120 M-bit rate while downstairs on the 2nd level. The router is on the 3rd level, highest in elevation so I believe its well placed. Most wireless performance is dictated by many external variables, such as distance, interference, transmit power, obstructions, and the laws of physics. So given all of these variables, I am satisfied with the router's performance.  Wireless technology and innovation will continue improve over time so this probably won't be my last purchase.One problem noted when used with the Silicon Dust HD Homerun streaming wireless to a laptop, the video at times breaks up or crashes. This is an IRD that outputs IP video for use with SageTV or a Snapstream PVR setup.  The problem is probably that the HD Homerun is not designed for wireless uses. Its happy on a wired LAN.  With my other video servers (Ready-NAS raid), the wireless works fine and is transparent. I could not tell the difference between wired and wireless. The IP video was wireless streaming to VLC player on my laptop with out any noticeable freeze frames. that data rate was around 19 M-bits/s continuous, recorded tansport streams from HDTV off air recordings.I ultimately bought this router based on the write up in the Dec 2010 issue of MaximumPC magazine. It earned a 9 rating. The router at the time of my review is working and meets all of my expectations.

i purchased this router after spending weeks reviewing some of the top routers on the market, i chose this one as a replacment for my rt-n12 that i only had for about 3months that started dropping wireless signal nearly every 10 miniutes.PROS: sleek design, gigabit ethernet, dual band for future proofing, ready share usb port, and gets just as good if not better range than my rt-n12 did with its 8dbi antennasCONS: not alot of options to customize how the router functions

column9: Great product, but beware of Netgear's customer service
column10: I've owned my WNDR3700 for just over five months, and up until a few weeks ago it had been running flawlessly.  However, I recently noticed that I was getting increasingly poor pings to any servers I connected to (Team Fortress 2), regardless of when I tried.  I confirmed this by pinging Google: 'ping -t google.com' showed constant, massive fluctuations in response time, ranging from sub-20ms (normal) to 500+ ms.  I eventually traced the problems back to the WNDR3700: connecting my PC directly to the cable modem solved the problem, and while erasing the WNDR3700's firmware and restoring the saved settings cleared up the problem temporarily, the latency/lag issues returned within a few hours.Upon calling Netgear's customer service, I was told that I would have to contact the store I purchased my router from to get a new replacement.  Otherwise, Netgear said they would only send me a refurbished device as a replacement, since they did not ship new devices via RMAs.  This is despite the fact that the online store I purchased from (not Amazon) only offered replacements within 30 days.  I eventually got them to comply with my request for a new-unit replacement, but not before telling them that if they didn't I'd dispute the charges through my credit card & use the funds to purchase a competing product (ConsumerSearch.com recommended the Linksys WRT610N).In summary, the WNDR3700 is a great product -- if nothing goes wrong.  However, I shouldn't have to browbeat the company whose product I'm purchasing for support.  Defective hardware is a fact of life, and I was surprised that getting a new replacement was an issue at all, considering I'd had less trouble getting a new replacement for a $60 8-port GS108 ProSafe switch, which cost almost $100 less.  That's the only reason this was a four-star review, instead of five.

I have used WNDR3700 for almost over 9 months. I have no complains and so far it has worked very well. I have no drop connection or degradation of the service. I used both bands 2.4 and 5 GHz for my wireless connection. I used 5 GHz for my XBOX 360 and 2.4 band with everything else. So, far it has worked out great for me.

column9: Awesome Router - Beware if you have a baby monitor though
column10: This is hands down the fastest, best-ranged router I have owned so far. Installation was SUPER easy and hassle free. I would have given this router 5 stars, but my wife and I found one flaw with it - it interferes with our baby monitor. If you are not a parent to any young ones, this obviously won't be an issue for you. But if you are, just keep that in mind.This router has made our baby monitor virtually unusable due to the static coming from it now. We didn't have this problem with our previous router, so we're going to try and tweak the router settings a bit and see if the problem goes away. Until then, I give it 3.5 stars.

Let me start out saying the WNDR3700 is a good choice, not saying the other brands are not as good for a lower price but I do believe it is a good value for what we have at our home/set up. After 8 months of use I can only relate to what we have or what we have experienced so far with this router. Our set-up consist of 3 computers ( 1 wireless the other two haed hooked directly) a wireless blu ray player ( for Netflix ) and a wireless Logitec squeezbox player upstairs. I intended this router for our daughters wirelss laptop (64bit) that she recieved for Christmas but then have since added additional items to it. At first we had a few troubles to get the laptop to hook up to the router but after an update and a call to Netgear service all worked out good, but it does time to time drop a signal to her laptop. Netflix on the LG bluray player for the most part works great, it does once in awhile seem to stream at a lower rate and then boost back up. It connection to the squeezebox has no trouble at all. Now take in mind, the 'drops', 'slow rate' or conection lost may be do to the other devices ( in which they are most likley ) but I would at least throw that in, nothing is perfect. At the most ( the area with the squeezebox player ) has 3 bearing walls to go through as 40ft would be the distance. The other items have the same if not a bit less. So far I am very pleased with this router as it has performed as I had expected it too. This router has a very good range, mostly dependable as it would offer most anything you can add to it. Worth the monet I would say!

Replaced a DLink 80211g with this one, on the recommendation of Maximum PC for building a home theater PC.  The unit was very easy to set up and replace my previous unit, none of my equipment noticed the difference once it was up and running.... unfortunately that was also one of the problems as it is certainly not a noticeable shift in download speeds from my g router.  I have not yet tried out the gigabit port or the on board USB port to stream video... will update when I try them out.PRO: Easy to setup/install (didn't need the enclosed CD with Win7, just used the internet)  Definitely increased range.CON: not a noticeable speed difference from g.

column9: Netgear WNDR3700 Dual Band Wireless N Gigabit Router
column10: I chose the router to provide both b/g/n and a/n coverage. It is working well, fairly easy to setup there are some features I am still to setup.
What I expect for this product. I recommend for everybody.No complaining points.O que eu esperava, recomendo a todos.

Purchased the WNDR3700 to replace my old netgear WGR614 to support a new Windows 7 desktop and laptop.  The router was installed and running in five minutes, took longer to decide an appropriate password.  Would recommend the router if asked.  The only hicup so far is the backward compatibility of the 3700.  I have an old laptop, 802.11 b, compatible that I have not been able to synch with the 3700. Next step is to install an USB harddrive to the router to be able to stream some video.

At first I was a bit hesitant to order this router, mostly because of the negative comments in the reviews.  But after my current 5+ year-old Netgear router dropped my VPN connection for the umpteenth time I decided to take the plunge.I shouldn't have waited as long as I did...it was simple to install and configure.  Sure, I had to download the latest firmware before I could successfully configure my guest networks - but once that was done, I was able to complete the configuration through the web interface.  I didn't bother with the installation CD, since I already had experience with the web interface with my old Netgear.The only thing that I had a problem with, was getting the 300Mb/s link on my 5GHz band.  After a bit of searching on the 'Net with Google, I found out that you can't get 300Mb/s with PSK.  Once I changed to AES, the wifi on my laptop indicated a 300Mb/s - cool!The router does run a little hot, but since I have it on end using the supplied stand it doesn't seem to be a problem.  Granted it's only been a couple of weeks in use, but (knock on wood) so far, so good!And did I mention the cool look of the different colored blinky lights?Haven't tried QoS or traffic monitoring, so can't comment on that.  But overall I'm quite satisfied with this product and would readily recommend to anyone.  I still have older 100Mb/s wired and wireless-g equipment, neither of which makes use of the 1Gb/s wired or 300Mb/s wireless capabilities, but as the old stuff ages and gets replaced...this router will be ready to support the next generation equipment on my LAN.

column9: Great range but doesn't work with firewalls
column10: If have a firewall on your computer, don't buy a Netgear router.  The internet won't work for more than a few seconds, if at all.  I unfortunately didn't learn this until after I'd bought my second router from them.  The first died after about three years when it was fried by a power surge caused by our electricity coming back on after an outage.  I've always used heavy-duty surge protectors, so I couldn't believe that killed it.  Nothing had ever happened to anything before.I kept thinking my problem had something to do with my firewall settings, so I talked to their tech support many times and changed several settings without success.  They told me their firewall (Zone Alarm Internet Security Suite) hardly ever has problems with routers, so I finally decided to call Netgear.  A bit to my surprise, they admitted that their routers generally don't work very well with firewalls, so they tell their customers to turn them off before going online.  They're working on the issue and hope to have it solved someday, so I should keep checking for firmware updates.  Kind of unbelievable if you ask me.  Why should I have to turn off my firewall and lose my protection?  If other people in my house didn't rely on the router for internet access, I get a different one in a second.As of 1/3/11:I recently bought a new Dell XPS 9100 that came with a McAfee firewall, and as bad as the router worked with my old computer, it works just as well now.  I guess it depends on what firewall you have, but NetGear tech support really dropped the ball by telling me their units don't work with them in general.

Excellent when I have internet connection.  I am still experiencing connectivity problems, though I suspect that it might be my cable modem or my laptop that is causing this.  I'm planning on replacing my cable modem next in an effort to eliminate the problem.  The installation part is fairly simple and when I made a mistake along the way, their service department was excellent and helped me step-by-step to completion.  Highly recommended.

column9: Best router i've had, usb not so great
column10: This is my second net gear router. It replaced and old 802.11b router (white one), which was great until it developed a humming sound, and around that same time started running very slow. I decided to stay with netgear since it was way better than my dlink and linksys experiences.I've had this for probably a year now.Solid router, never have to restart it. But as many have said, the USB is slow for hard-drives. This is one of the reasons I bought this in the first place. I could have spent a lot less on an asus that's hackable, and after putting up with the poor performance of the USB I kind of regret spending the money. Money aside, its been a great router so far.I've heard reformatting could improve performance, but I don't know if its worth it.

This device works fine and better than two separate routers (one a/b/g and the other n) because the setting up of the second device can be pretty complicated for most people or if you need to reset things for some reason it can still be a pain.Don't expect a vast increase in download speed unless you have the internet connection to support it. However, it could help you a lot if you have the n-band wireless cards on your devices to support transfer of media or large or streaming files from one PC to another.Setup was not difficult, but then I have not had any problems with my netgear hardware with any wireless card. My netgear routers have always worked well (except due to lightning strikes -- completely out of their or my control).Bottom line - worth your consideration if you are looking for a dual-band wireless and wired router.

this has some trouble running full time but has fast gigabit ethernet port wifi speed is great but the fastest wifi router is the new airport extreme 802.11n base station as this one it has dual band and has gigabit ports but not as fast this is a great router but any wifi router cant compare to the airport extreme

I researched a number or wireless routers before making the final decision to purchase this one. I've been a long time advocate of linksys and making the transition to Netgear was a leap of faith. Thankfully, I was not disappointed. I'm familiar with setting up wireless networks and was not afraid to go through the painful process of setting up each wireless device to work with the router, however, I was pleasantly surprised how easy it was to add devices to this router. Just a simple press of a button and the required wireless security information is quickly transferred over to the new device and your connected. Once the connection is made, I was extremely impressed with the overall range. The main selling point for me was the range and the addition of a usb storage device. This device has been criticized for the speed of the USB port, however, I have had no issues using the port for a central storage device for pictures and music. I'm not sure I'd recommend it for storing movies or for watching movies directly off the drive.Overall, I've been very happy with the performance and would recommend it. The dual band range is limited, but unless your looking to stream HD movies it shouldn't be a concern.

column9: Good router, but with some issues
column10: For those of you who want a nice dual-band class N router, this is a great little piece of gear.  It was easy to install and set up, and it has a wireless setup and wireless startup and shutdown button which is useful if you do not want wireless on all the time.  The web-based setup utility is second to none in features and control, and is easier to use and understand than my previous Linksys.Some of the features, however, do have issues and I have to admit that Netgear does not seem fast to correct them.The USB network storage capability is ok (not better than that though) if you just want a network drive without sharing from your PC.  It is on the slow side - but then again, I haven't seen one that wasn't.  Netgear does include a media server function... but unless the amount of media files you have is fairly low (I'd say 100 GB tops), this feature can cause problems.  I have a 1.6 TB external drive connected to the router - it has about a 800 GB of media on it - a combination of audio and video files.  The router attempted to index these for the built in media server, and this promptly caused the router to lock up.  Resetting the router always brought it back online, but it kept freezing whenever the drive was connected and the router was attempting to index the files.  I checked with Netgear - the solution?  Turn off the media server as it cannot index more than so many files.  This will be fixed in the next firmware fix.  This is May 29th 2010 when I checked this, BTW.  I checked their forums and saw that this has been a known issue since at least as far back as September 30th 2009 - and there have been firmware updates since then which apparently have NOT resolved this issue.  Not good, Netgear.I haven't tried the 'guest' network function, but reportedly (and in these reviews) there are issues there as well.So I have mixed feelings about this router.  As a dual-N rooter, it is solid and fast, and has some nice features to it.  If that's what you're looking for, fear not - this is a good device.  However, if you want to use the built-in media server or guest network functions, before you buy check to see if these issues have been resolved - if not, there may be better options for you.

column9: great not excellent for one reason
column10: Range, Range Range. This thing is fast, but if I go downstairs I loose signal strength, that is my only complaint, otherwise fantastic.

column9: Does the job, after a bit of configuration
column10: I bought this router to replace a Linksys WRT54G running dd-wrt, with the specific aim of improving the wireless signal from the router (upstairs) to my Xbox 360 (downstairs). The Linksys performed adequately for laptops used downstairs, but the signal to the Xbox (using a Linksys WGA54G game adapter) had always been poor and unreliable, especially bad for streaming Netflix over Xbox Live.Setup of the WNDR3700 was quite easy, but I was quickly disappointed to find that the N signal was still extremely poor at the Xbox (now using a Microsoft Wireless-N game adapter), fluctuating constantly between one and three (out of four) bars. Repositioning the wireless adapter using a USB extension cable didn't seem to help. The G signal, however, was extremely strong--noticeably stronger than the Linksys router had been. The Microsoft adapter is dual-band, so I figured it would not be the end of the world if I had to use the Xbox with the G network. (I was mildly irritated because I could've bought a much cheaper Wireless-G router, but oh well.)It was suggested on the Netgear forum to lay the router flat (rather vertically, on its stand) to better reach clients on different floors--allegedly to get a better 'spread' of the signal--and also to configure the N network to use a higher channel than the default. I did both of these, and it did indeed seem to help a lot--now getting four out of four bars on the Xbox (after repositioning the wireless adapter a bit). Multiplayer and Netflix streaming have been working perfectly so far.It's only been a week, so it's a bit early to rate the reliability, and I haven't tried using the USB storage feature. If it continues to perform as it is now, however, I'll be quite happy with the WNDR3700.

Got this to replace my old Belkin 54G-Mimo router.  I swore off buying Netgear routers with the old rounded badly ventilated cases many years ago after going through several different series.  In contrast, this one uses a new case design, runs cool, and has been reliable after several months use.  Setup was OK- typical Netgear.  The power plug can come loose and does not snap in.  The 2.4Ghz signal is great going through 3 plaster walls and around a large fridge. I can't say as much for the 5Ghz (maybe 15ft).  The same 40 ft distance from router  to bedroom 'o!play' sucks at 5Ghz, but works great at 2.4G via a Buffalo N-adapter.  The laptop connection at rear of house always says 300Mbps, and O!PLAY-R1 multimedia player video/audio performs without any problems.  My wired desktop surfs super-fast via the gigabit ports.  The rear power button works too. I like it, but it's not cheap.

While this router took a brief phone call to finish installation, it was otherwise a breeze to setup and solved all my internet/router issues immediately. Not gorgeous, but handsome to look at.  Highly recommended.

column9: Great WiFi device, avoid if you have iPhone 3GS
column10: I love this router and all of its features.  However, be careful if you have an iPhone 3GS - Netgear and Apple are not working well together on that device.  My iPhone 3GS always has an EXTREMELY slow WiFi connection on WNDR3700, with bandwidth consistently under 300 kbps.  My old iPhone 3G however always reaches more than tenfold speeds on the same router.  Because of an unrelated hardware problem on the new iPhone I tried many things, even resetting the network settings, restoring the phone from backup and setting it up as new, and none of these steps fixed the slow wireless access problem.  Ultimately, Apple replaced my 3GS because of a touchscreen failure and the replacement unit still has the same exact issue.  In addition, I had the same exact problem between the iPhone 3GS and my old Netgear WPN824v3 router.  Consequentially, when I'm at home I just disable my iPhone's WiFi because it's much faster on 3G.There are some posts online from people with similar troubles and their fix was to set the Fragmentation Length to 2304 (or 1024) and CTS/RTS Threshold to 2305 (or 1500) under Netgear's advanced wireless settings.  Some people also suggested changing the channel to 11 (I'm unaware of their affiliation with the Spinal Tap band).  Although some users reported great results after applying some or all of these changes, I systematically applied all of the recommended settings in different possible combinations on both my Netgear routers without any significant improvement in WiFi performance of my iPhone 3GS.  The only way to resolve this on my old WPN824v3 Netgear is to disable g mode and stick to b only.  However, WNDR3700 doesn't offer an option to disable g and n and use the router in a b-only mode.  Netgear tech support wasn't helpful at all, stating that since my router works with other WiFi devices (laptops and PS3) that I should call Apple, in spite of my positive experience with its performance with other wireless routers (Cisco wireless at work and Linksys at my sisters where its bandwidth consistently reaches above 10 Mbps and works just fine).  Since both Netgear and Apple keep playing the finger-pointing game, I feel betrayed by both. My recommendation is to stay away from Netgear wireless gear if you already own an iPhone 3GS, or to stay away from buying an iPhone 3GS if you already own this router (iPad might have similar problems as I've seen some early reports about WiFi issues).  Other than that:Pros:- Dual radios, configurable for separate home and guest SSIDs on each band (a/n on 5 GHz and b/g/n on 2.4 GHz)- Guest SSIDs can be configured either for internet-only or with access to the entire home network- USB storage port can use an external HDD or a flash drive for home network storage without much trouble.- USB is configurable for internal and optional external http and ftp access in addition to standard Microsoft Networks share (for that one you need to set up your Netgear router, laptops and desktops to the same network/workgroup name in order to see the storage on your local network).Cons/suggestions to Netgear for improvement:- Inability to run 802.11b only- Inability to change beacon interval settings- Shared USB storage can't have more than two accounts - admin and guest.  Admin is stuck with the same password as on your router's admin account and guest with no password. I expected more granular storage space administration capabilities- Problems with iPhone 3Gs

The device is powerful, looks cool, has tons of features, and overall, is one of the best wifi routers I've owned.I'd easily have given it a 5 if it had but one feature, the ability to use the best security combined with repeaters.  Unfortunately, when configuring a repeater, it required no security at all.  Which in this day and age seems totally ridiculous, and left my 2nd wireless router upstairs gathering dust.  They released an update that added WEP security, so I still have hope that with the powerful processor on this router that they'll add the full range for repeaters, but as of yet, they have not.

Have had no issues with this wireless router. It has great range and is consistent. Our last router had issues with a weak connection at times. We would have to sign off and back on several times to get internet. Not with his netgear router.

column9: Works good, could have better features
column10: Pros:It seem to work good, didn't have to reboot it yet.Cons:I don't like the interface, I would prefer it simpler. Why frames with loads of java script for such a simple task?  Three scroll bars on the unit's admin page to navigate around?Not happy with IP address reservation, I expected IP address ASSIGNMENT as my old router had. I reserved IP for my laptop, but router would not assign it after reboot or IP renew. I had to enter IP into laptop's settings.Service blocking allows only one schedule. In my old router I could define multiple rules, each with it's own schedule.
Works well right out of the box. Haven't tested range yet. Required 2 resets in 2 months so far.

This router has been good so far,I have had it for a few months now.The setup disc I throw out on all routers I set up, 192.168.1.1 is much faster and easier then the silly disc they send out. With a little reading anyone can do it.Set up was typically straight forward, there are more features then my previous routers.There is a pin number on the router, that seems new? for those that use the CD to setup look for that.There is a feature for wireless repeating, which I used and set up, it asked for that pin number?This router has some interesting features, aside from the dual band broadcast.The media share, usb device is great, I have movies on the attached drive and they play flawlessly.I have upgraded my wireless card in my laptop to N, and my home to 1gig nic card.The wireless card will get to 300mbps on the 5GHz a/n side, and up to 180mbps on the 2.4GHz b/g/n side. For those that cant seem to get more that a 54mbps connection, might want to up grade their wireless card.there is even a guest Network Settings b/g/n... it separates that from you main LAN, allowing other people to connect to your internet connection without seeing your network....It has all the typical block sites, ports, port forwarding etc etc..Not all routers have the QoS Setup, this one has QoS sometimes a very helpful feature.Comcast is now limiting my internet connection to 250 gigabit per month, thankfully this has Traffic Meter, and I can watch my traffic usage..SO far this router has been good, no complaints about the lights, I dont care it is hidden away.The distance it can reach is sketchy? There are many variables that will determine this, (walls, nic card etc) in my case tt works well around the house, I cant go out side or into the basement.If they made this where I could attach an external antenna, that would be great, in fact I might just take it apart and do some soldering...all in all good router.. Is it worth the money, the usb media server almost makes it worth it..

column9: Some good things and some bad
column10: One of my criteria for selecting the Netgear WNDR3700 router was to avoid issues with installation, however, the setup disk did not do the job and it took a call to the helpdesk.  The first call was with a tech who did not speak english very well and the second call was received from a tech who knew his stuff and was easy to understand.  Still, it took him an hour and fourty minutes to get everything going just right.The product does works well and I am pleased with it, however, if I need any tech support after my warranty period runs out, I will be in trouble.

I used to get spotty coverage with my linksys and belkin routers. Both happened to be the 2.4MHZ Wi N. So got this and everything works like a charm.The only annoying piece about this was the installer couldn't run on vista and vista 64 so had to go borrow a laptop with Win XP on it. Once installed it has been the best 200 bucks i have ever spent. Not a single drop in coverage and get the full 300 MB all over the house. My netflix movies plays instantly and gets the HD bar always. Havent even reset the router once that is impressive. I am sold on this piece of hardware.Thanks Netgear hopefully you will get the installer fixed soon.

The main reason for buying this product was in the hopes of getting a more stable connection.  Previous networking hardware was about 5 yrs old. Well, we not only got a very stable connection, but we got a much faster one as well.  You get a stable connection in two ways.  You can connect within the 2.4 Ghz freq, OR within the 5.0 Ghz freq.  So if one isn't connecting at that fast a speed or is having trouble connecting the other freq does connect (our 5ghz freq wouldn't connect after a snow storm, but the 2.4 Ghz did connect).  speed of connection has ranged from 300Mps down to 264Mps (your mileage may vary).  Still it's much better than the typical 52Mps from a 5 yr old network card and router.  So I would definitely give this hardware a thumbs up.

Bought it last night as our D-Link start failing after 2 years w/o problems (started to have to reset many times a day for 3-4 days when my patience ran out).Installation was fairly simple although on the first trial it said it did not find the internet connection (although skype was on green). Clicked on 'try again' and no problems.We have a Asus netbook (1mb ram) with a n band and Sype video call works better. In fact even this laptop (g band) I write you from seems better. We are also considering a skype phone, so we got this unit.I read quite a bit about new router. Decided on this one. Bought at best buy because wanted right away and we have silver RZ which gives a 12% discount. Otherwise would buy it here. I went there to pick up this unit but ended up asking the best buy guy just in case. He pointed to this one and a cisco one 20 bucks more. He said he has seen very few of the cisco returned and none of these. But he said both were good. the ones returned were usually the lower end ones...Only thing I don't know is that I asked me during installation to name the two wirelles (2.4 and 5 ghz) I named them the basically the same with a '2' and a '5' in the end of the names. But both of our computers as well as the wireless printer we have only found the one with the '2'... not sure if this is something with our stuff or I'm not having the '5' wireless network. If somebody knows please leave us a comment.Anyway, wanted something in the upper end. We got it. I'm not the geek guy. To me it's working so far. If nothing goes wrong in a month should be 1 more star added.hope it helps you.

column9: Perfect choice after a misfire with another product
column10: I needed a high-speed wireless network for a heavy-use home office.  This product splits my lower speed wireless printer which runs on 2.4ghz and my pc's running on 5ghz (otherwise, without Dualband, my pc's would have been reduced to the slowest common denominator speed).The product was reasonably easy to setup, it did take a few passes through the installation software but nothing I haven't experienced before.  Setup took a little over an hour.  I've done multiple wireless routers from other manufacturers and have had to use their tech support.  I did not with this one.Also, it replaces a LinkSys product that I had for a month which kept needing to be reset/rebooted when the connection would drop...and even then the pc's would not pick up again.  I have not had to do this a single time after running this Netgear product after for a month.  This was my first Netgear purchase and I am now a fan.

I have several Linksys wireless routers and decided to purchase the Netgear WNDR3700 to add wireless-n connectivity in addition to attach my external hard drive via the USB port included in the router.  I have had this router for a couple of months and it has performed flawlessly with the exception the media sever feature for the external hard drive.  Netgear recently release a firmware upgrade to address this issue but it still is not working when the external hard drive contains a lot of media files as I have.  I hope Netgear addresses this issue in a future firmware upgrade.  By the way, if you do enable 'media server' on this router with a lot of media files, the router will lock up and thus far, the only way to fix it is to reboot the router.  Other than the aforementioned media server issue, I would highly recommend this router!

Now that everything is hooked up I love this router.  The range and strength of signal are a vast improvement over my old Linksys G.  Setup was fairly straightforward and my new computers and game systems were up and running in about 30 min.  Two of my older computers would not connect to the wifi signal.  Many hours of internet research and a phone call to Netgear later and I was told that my old wifi adapters could not keep up and would need to be replaced with a new Netgear USB adapter. (I still might do this just to get the faster N signal). I later figured out that my wifi adapters just needed to get updated drivers.  If you have older equipment update your drivers first to save the hassle.

I purchased this router because I wanted to put my Drobo on my network without having it go through a computer. I also didn't want to pay for the insane price of the DroboShare.  This was the latest N Dual Band router, had some good reviews, so I purchased it.I got the router up and running with no problems, but it locked up shortly after connecting my Drobo to it.  I did some quick research and found out that if your attached USB device has many many files, the index of the files may be too big for the 'Media Server' functionality, and it will cause the router to lock up.  After rebooting and disabling the 'Media Server' feature, the router has been rock solid.  I have had no lockups in 4 months, which is a record for me.A new firmware just came out for the router which supposedly fixes this issue, but I haven't tested it yet:[...]Note that the USB speed will not blow you away with this router, and I have had to plug it into my computer directly at times when doing things like photo editing due to poor performance.  But for doing things like streaming music and viewing photos it works just fine.It's the best router I have owned so far.

This router is pretty cool. I am a gamer, so this does an EXCELLENT JOB, for signal strength and speed. I did a bunch of research before purchasing this router. I made sure that all the features that I wanted were included in this router. Overall, this router is pretty good, however there are some cons that go along with it.Pros: Stylish with the black lacquer finishN-wireless router (allows you to have a faster transfer rate of signal than G or A routers)Easy to set up (just called the customer service rep and they are very helpful and make the setup job feel like a piece of cake)Multiple functions that allow you to choose whether or not you want to share your wirless signal with other peopleAllows you to delegating the amount of signal you want for certain devices (i.e. I am a gamer so I want more of the signal going to my Xbox 360, than my computer, when I am playing a video game.)Cons:My landlord lives right up stairs from me. Yet he can not get a strong signal. This is the big downfall that this router has because it claims that it has AMAZING SIGNAL STRENGTH THAT REACHES FAR! But it really does not. He still only gets 1 bar wireless and has to plug directly in and only gets 2 bars. So in this case...the distance is not good. But the range is okay atleast from 10 feet.

I bought one of these about 2 weeks ago.  It was easy to set up and so far all the features work.  I have only ised it wireless. I haven't attached an external HD to  the USB port or tried the gigabit ethernet.The only problem I have noticed is that my connection  speed frequently drops from 54 to 24 Mb for a computer in the same room 15 feet away.  I don't lose my connection but when I check my speed it does fluctuate.  I have never been dropped by the router.  I am not sure that the issue is not with my computer  (it is 4 1/2 years old) but I have been too lazy to check with my wife's (It is newer) from the same location.Overall I would say that this is a pretty good router and I think that when I  get aroud to setting up my desktops and adding gigabit  cards to them that it will prove more usefull.

I bought this router to replace my old TrendNET (which replaced a Dlink) router.The problem with the old router was I didn't get enough speed, and I have a lot of data going internally in my home between computers. Any router that does 802.11 N and is not dual-band is basically a joke. If you have any wifi-enabled phone (iPhone, Android, etc), then it won't work with 802.11 N. So you will have to put the router in compatibility mode with b/g, so you will never get the 'N' speeds you paid for. So if you want 'N', buy a dual band router (like this one :) ).The router, once installed and set up, is a solid performer. I don't remember exactly, but I think that the CD that came with it was useless and buggy, so just install it using the web interface.I used to get ~1-2 MBPS on my old router (transfering files internally within my home network), and it went up to 7-8 MBPS with this one. Also, as this is dual band, the N and G networks are completely separate so the iPhone doesn't slow down my laptop.I have not tried the file sharing part, but at this price, I will totally expect to get printer sharing. It is competing with the Apple Airport router, which is pretty solid too.

column9: Setup Wizard on the Cd doesn't support Vista 64 bit.
column10: I got this router because the reviews were good. The Setup Wizard on the enclosed CD doesn't support Vista 64 bit. I spent 45 minutes on the Netgear support site and found it confusing. The link to download the latest CD was busted. There is a firmware update (that supports 64 bit) but I couldn't find a download for a compatible setup wizard. I don't feel like going through a manual setup so I'm returning the item. It's probably a good router; I'm just put off by Netgear.Addendum: I may have been too hasty writing the above. I decided to keep the router and try a manual setup. It was easy (see: WNDR3700_SM_28May09.pdf). The firmware updated nearly automatically and the setup wizard could be run from the router once the basic hardwire connection was made. I'm getting a good wireless connection on a laptop located several rooms away from the router. I haven't tried streaming anything yet. Also, see the comment and reference (much appreciated) submitted by Ulises.Update: 1/25/2010. I still have the router and am quite pleased. I have a four split-level house and am streaming Netflix diagonally from one far corner of the house to the other. Previouly I used a power line connection which proved erratic. I'm getting an excellent picture (with no buffering) streaming to an Insignia Blue Ray player with built in Wi-Fi. The connection to my X-Box works well also.

Just received the router yesterday.  Setup was extremely easy.  The only issue I had was when I went through setup it kept saying it couldn't connect with my cable modem.  Since my machine was hardwired into the modem I just opened up a web browser to connect to the internet.  Then went through setup and all worked well.  The CD it comes with is easy to follow - they really show you every step.  We got a new modem because connectivity was intermittent.  We bought a new Blue Ray dvd player and the Netflix feature wouldn't work.  Now with the new router it works great - very fast.  And our Roku in the other room is faster too.  Worth the money - easy to setup and increased performance - just what we wanted.

column9: Great Router but range lesser than expected
column10: Bought this device about two weeks ago.  Setup was a snap.  I consider myself a medium-advanced user.  This unit replaced a Linksys Wrt54GS wireless G gateway router.  What I have enjoyed about the new router:  (1) gigabit speed on my home network, (2) the guest network capabilities on both 2.4 and 5.0 Ghz, (3) the ability to connect wirelessly on a 2.4 Ghz and 5.0 Ghz simultaneously.  I also enjoy the automatic firmware update on the device.  Whenever you access the setup port (192.186.1.1), it automatically checks to see if there is a firmware update and will download it and install it automatically if you allow.  My only disappointment with the router is that I can not consistently use the wireless signal in my bedroom, which happens to be the furthest point in my house from the router (3100 ft).  I can use it there occassionally, it depends on weather, atmosphere, etc.  I was surprised that my range actually decreased from the version 1 WRT54GS I had previously, but that device had two small antennas and this one has none.  Overall, I am very pleased with the device and recommend it.  Caveat, until a wireless N repeater is available, it may not meet your range requirements.

Ok, for starters I love this router and have used many through the years. As far as functions, features, speed, ease of use I couldn't say enough. I figured I would try and take the lazy man's way and use the accompanied software wizard to set it up however I just couldn't get it to work or work properly on Windows7. But to play a little devil's advocate here it was not advertised to either. I logged into the router with no problem and manually configured it with ease. The separate wireless network feature is outstanding. The control it gives me per user is even better. This router protected me during a severe Winuke attack and held its ground. Highly recomend at this time. ASIN:B002HWRJY4 Netgear Rangemax WNDR3700 Dual Band Wireless-N Gigabit Router (Black)]]

Very good product. Excellent range.Included software doesnot support installation in 64bit systems.This is what i did........connected the router, logged into [...], updated firmware, it worked.So far ...no problems.Yet have to meddle with usb storage.

column9: Netgear Rangemax WNDR3700 Dual Band Wireless-N Gigabit Router
column10: very fast, good router but drops signal for a few minutes once and a while not often,, but other than that pretty reliable.

column9: It works but software won't run on 64 bit
column10: This router seems to work good so far, the wired connections and the wireless seem to be running faster. The install cd will not work on 64 bit systems so be forewarned (since this is newly introduced I am surprised it doesn't work with the 64 bit). I had trouble installing it at first, my main computer is 64 bit so I tried another wired computer and it couldn't find the signal at all. So I did the web address [...] and it could see my network but wouldn't connect to the internet so I had to do a reset of my cable modem and when it got done flashing it's lights I was connected. It would have been nice to have some written instructions with this, it is to all be on the cd. Luckily I had printed some information before I tried to install this.I wish it was easier to do the security stuff also, I am new to this stuff and I have to search a lot for how to set up the security, print out pages.. I live in an area that isn't heavily populated so I can get away with the WPA security which seems to be the easiest to set up. It take a few minutes for the router to connect to the internet also if you pause the cable modem then come back and want online again, my other one was almost instant. So far I haven't experienced any dropped connections but I haven't had it long either (that was the problem I had with my other one).I have tried about 3 or 4 new linksys routers lately and just couldn't get them to connect to the internet at all, at least with this one I was able to get connected to the internet without too much trouble.For those newbies out there like me try resetting you cable modem if you can't get connected to the internet, I learned that in trying to get the linksys to work but even that trick didn't do the job with them?This is a little pricey but it seems to deliver the speed and the install isn't too bad so to me it is worth it.

My household is mostly mac, and my previous router was an older version of the airport extreme, so that is what this is going to be compared to.Essentially comparing specs to specs, the airport extreme (the current new version) and this router are essentially the same.  They offer dual band Wireless-N, they offer guest access, a usb port for hooking up hard drives, etc.  The good news is that this router seems to be a step away from the netgear of the past (where I would try to avoid their products) and into something that's mostly worthwhile.The router performs mostly up to task, some reviews have issues with wireless-n speeds, and while I'm not seeing the full potentially of wireless-n, it could be something in my setup as well, and it's faster than the wireless-N 2.4ghz (non-dual band) that I was previously using.  The other feature is bandwidth monitoring, which with the advent of metered broadband, is a great idea.  However it seems to reset randomly, and have some other issues, hopefully in a firmware update this will be rectified.This is a solid netgear router, with only a few small drawbacks.  If you're a mac user I'd recommend still going for the Airport Extreme, but Windows usually should definitely take a look here.

This high-end wireless router by Netgear is well-designed and comes with a lot of features out of the box.  I loved the ability to skip the 'insert this CD rom in your computer' installation for dummies method and go straight to the web GUI to set it up.  The feature I was most interested in is the USB storage sharing.  This feature allows you to plug in any external USB drive, and then share it over the network.  This was a convenient target for pushing automatic backups to.  If our computer's hard drive catches on fire, I still have backups that I've saved on the USB drive attached to this router.  Unfortunately, I ran into a bug when trying out this feature.  Netgear support was helpful, however, and helped me get it working in a day.Pros:- Feature rich, high-performance.- Nice vertical stand included.- USB storage feature turns your external drive into a network share.- Comes with QoS (a must for VOIP), dynamic DNS, firewall, features.- Easy to upgrade the firmware and it will automatically check for updates.- Good documentation.- Dead-simple installation and you can skip the Insert This CD-ROM install method.- Ability to set up 'guest' network with separate settings in addition to your main network.Cons:- Traffic bandwidth monitoring is rudimentary. It is actually very good for an off-the shelf router, but I'm spoiled by my home router which runs Tomato firmware: it has pretty graphs.- USB storage feature needs work.  You can only use your router's admin password to protect your shares.  Configuring settings with Google Chrome or non-firefox, non-IE browsers may silently fail (as it did for me).  The workaround is to reapply settings with IE or Firefox.All in all a very solid product.  I give it 4.5 stars, as I wasted time chasing down the Chrome/Web GUI bug.  I have no doubt this will become a 5-star product as Netgear pushes out new firmware updates.

column9: Very Good Router. Netgear still won't support Wake-On-Lan
column10: The RangeMax WNDR3700 has an excellent range and sends signal much further than D-Link DGL-4500 that I had before. The RangeMax WNDR3700 supports simultaneous dual-band Wireless-N providing twice the bandwidth with better connection and less interference, and that shows.With NetGear RangeMax WNDR3700, it is possible to create a dedicated video network in 5 GHz band for streaming high-quality HD video, while letting guests to use 2.4 GHz at the same time, making it possible to share internet connection without comprimising the security of the local network.One item that disappoints me with RangeMax WNDR3700 is that it does not support Wake-On-Lan from the internet. Specifically, Netgear has disabled in the firwmare the ability to forward UDP packets to x.x.x.255 IP address. Why they've done that on purpose is beyond understandable.Other than issue with WOL, the RangeMax WNDR3700 is overall an excellent router for both advanced and novice users, providing easy to use interface, excellent range and QoS monitoring for those times when an extra bandwith is needed for specific applications.

column9: Was the long wait for this router worth it?
column10: I have been waiting for this router to come out and it is finally here after the many delays. This router has all the bells and whistles which any gamer or computer tech savvy guy or gal would want. It is fast and has an excellent signal which can be adjusted on both 5ghz and 2.4ghz to save money on the electric bill if you want. There are so many settings you can mess around with, to optimize the performance for your needs. This router is a must for those of us who live in an apartment building with a lot of wireless networks in the building and a lot of wireless devices to go off of your network. I have a ps3, xbox 360, wii , two iphones, psp and macbook pro connected to my wireless network with no drops yet. Games and other downloads on my game systems seem to download faster. Videos on the Internet like youtube are playing simultaneously with very little buffering or none at all on my Macbook pro. It also has an Internet traffic counter to let you know how many gbs you are downloading every month. Which is key especially with Internet providers like Comcast who is going to start having a 250gb cap on the Internet every month starting in October. I can go on and on about this router because of all it has. There is one big problem for me though. I was under the impression that this router would have usb printer support so you can share your usb printer throughout your network but once I tried to hook up my printer it was a no go. I am very disappointed about this because I was looking forward to have both an external harddrive and my usb printer on my network. One more thing that bothers me is it is a finger print magnet like the ps3 but other then that I would highly recommend this router.Update:After a week of using this router I ran into a problem with the traffic meter. The traffic meter does not seem to be very accurate. I check it every day and it seems to reset itself every day or every couple of days instead of once a month like it is suppose to do. Today for instants I checked the traffic status add it says I used 1385 mbs this month so far and yesterday it said 3234 mbs used. This is not right because the total mbs used should be higher today not smaller. This is quite annoying because this feature is one of the reasons why I bought the router and it does not work right. I have the most up to date firmware so it is not a out of date firmware problem. I just hope Netgear fixes this problem before next month because Comcast is going to start using caps every month and it sure would be nice to have this tool working right, by then.

I just bought this item and will update this review as time goes by if I find any problems. Installation was really easy. I currently have an Ooma device connected to my cable mode. This wireless router connected directly to the Ooma device. The installation documentation comes in a CD and is really basic. Once you have plugged everything in, you can just use a web browser to access the router. The first thing it does is to look for any firmware updates which means you have to wait for a little bit before being able to access the control panel. You can configure it later so that it doesn't check for updates every time. The address used to access the device is routerlogin.net. This, however, I've noticed doesn't always work. Sometimes it brings me to my router's control panel, sometimes (most of the times) it takes me to [...] instead. I can ping the [...] address and it does resolve to 192.168.1.1 so it is the router the one that is redirecting the connection there. You can always type the default IP address, however.The control panel provides detailed help on the right side so you know what each option is for. I like the fact that you can name devices in your IP address reservations and MAC filtering so that you remember which devices they were. Applying any changes does take some time.I haven't had any problems with the range. I'm operating at 2.4GHz and it works just great.
the wireless on/off light doesn't work. But other then I don't want to wait for a return ,this is a great router

This router has been hooked up less than 24 hours, not ready to give it 5 stars yet, but so far so good.The Netgear replaced a D-Link router I had for quite some time that was giving me problems. I am not very tech savvy. The D-Link was a nightmare to hook up. The Netgear as advertised was up and running in 5 minutes--really all you have to do is follow the instructions, which they provided, thank you, and were not provided by D-Link.My I-Phone gets a much stronger Wifi signal than before. An old Toshiba laptop a good 40 feet away in the living room seems to be surfing the net faster. Haven't streamed any movies yet, but my wifi blu ray connected just fine.All in all very pleased so far.
Works well, nice and easy to use interface.  I seem to be getting the speeds advertised.  I've always owned a linksys router and this was my first Netgear one.

column9: Bought this router used, happy with performance.
column10: This router is better than the belkin I got a few years ago at walmart for 20 bucks, faster speeds on home network, better streaming for home entertainment and music.  Very happy so far with purchase.

Needed to update my very old wireless router this seemed to fit the bill.  I don't take advantage of the dual band feature so I can't speak to how well that works but everything else seems to be fine.  Signal strength is good, and it seems to always work.  I gave it 4 out of 5 stars because the instructions could have been much better.

column9: Works great with lightening fast speed even with lots of users online at once.
column10: I needed a more secure wireless router to replace my ages old Netgear from the late nineties that did not have a secure firewall built in.  This one did the trick and because it has dual bands it makes it better for multiple users in our home who are all on the internet at once without affecting performance or speed.  The reason I gave it a 4 instead of a 5 is because in the directions for set up they didn't explain that you needed an ethernet wire to connect your main desktop computer to the router the first time and I thought I had to go out and buy some special cable because they didn't say "ethernet" cord.  That would have saved me some aggravation setting it up the first time. After I figured that out on my own, it was smooth sailing.
Been using it for about a month. No problems so far. Wish it has more ports but that is about it!
but be sure to flash it with alternate firmware.  Then you get a real work horse and lots of options.
Daughter move into a new house and her old WIFI router worked but I wanted her to get something better.  It works.She is using the 5GHz for TV/Video, and 2.4MHz for laptops and tablets.
I have been looking for a router that gives me the ability to regulate my bandwidth per device. This one works well at doing that and I like the additional feature of the 5GHZ band.

column9: Be prepared to call the help desk
column10: This dual band router is relatively sophisticated for a home use product.  It is a far cry from plug-n-play though.  I spent two hours in an online chat to set it up initially and then a subsequent one hour chat two weeks later to get the 5 gig band to function by manipulating the advanced settings.  I must say that my old Belkin router didn't come up the first time either without the help desk.  This must be symptomatic of these types of home network devices.  The Netgear Genie software is pretty easy to use - as long as you have the Netgear help desk guiding you through it.  Otherwise you'll need to be a journeyman network administrator to set this up.  I suppose most people just lease a home router and have their internet provider deal with it.  Where's the fun in that?

The product works flawlessly. Easy set up, installation and you're ready to go. I would recommend that if you are upgrading the system to back up and print your network settings information from the existing network.
Works fine like Netgear equipment.Have used Netgear router before work very well well.Very easy to hook up. Thank you

column9: I found this one to be the best so far.
column10: I have had my share of upgrades with regards to networking over the last 8 yrs. Each time I would gain a bit, but never working 100% to my satisfaction. I have had several Motorola modems coupled to older Netgear or D-Link routers, newer D-link routers, and a combo Zoom router and modem. I have had so many issues and time wasted with all this especially when used with VoIP telephony. I have a long background in the electrical and communication technologies making me to be an early adopter with a constant replacement attitude to make whatever, better.After exploring what my Comcast would except, I choose this Router to fit my budget and current needs. One of the first things it gave me was video streaming that I never had before that worked. I used this to test a complete movie while also operating my PC. No flaws at all. The wireless distance works well for my needs and the setup was easy. I'd recommend it!
I have used this router for several months and it is doing great! No issues.Setting it up was a bit tiresome since I don't do this every other day - lots of things forgotten and to re-learn.
I bought this router to replace my old one and I am extremely happy with N600 router. with amped extender I am enjoying a good signal all over my house
very easy setup. works well in costa rica. compatible with ipad ipod and pc computer. range is very good. fast and strong signal
Was looking for a router that was easy to set up and painless to operate on my home network.  Product is that and more at a reasonable price.  Has good coverage in the house and outside.

Update: 17 Oct 2013. Router still going strong. Haven't had to touch a thing. Activated guest wireless when a friend watched the house for 3 weeks. Easy to do.  Easy to stream movies through Kindle.  Think it rates a rating increase to 4.5 stars.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Trying to make a decision on what router to buy to replace my old one was somewhat daunting. The list of features I thought I needed/wanted is too long to list here. A few of the important (to me) features were; it had to have an easy setup, good security, have dual Wireless capability, be IPv6 compliant, reliable, not a budget buster, and be 'liked' by a lot of users.  So, after doing extensive research/making comparisons/reading lots of reviews I finally selected this router.  Amazon got it to me free in 2 days (thanks to prime membership) and I had it up and connected to everything on my home network including all the wireless stuff in about 30 minutes. Its been a week (July 23) and so far everything is working smoothly. I'm not a network guy so I had some trepidations, but it proved to be an easy setup.  It seems that the Genie app was preloaded so I didn't need to deal with that. The unit only comes with a very short, but illustrated set-up pamphlet so it was pretty much a no-brainer to connect. Because of the reviews I knew the detailed manual was online at Netgear and didn't come with the unit. It was easy to find and download, and  I suggest you download it and read the setup steps before you activate the unit.  Its very helpful to see what's coming before u turn it on.  You will probably need to do a firmware update when u first activate the unit through the dashboard.  That process was seamless. The Genie dashboard is really nice to work with unlike my previous Linksys WRT54GS where u could only see a limit area. The dashboard displays the Internet, Wireless, attached devices, parental controls, readyshare, and Guest network (I like this feature because most of our guests/family have wireless devices with them. Now I can provide them access to the Internet without sharing my personal network) icons in one easily viewable location.  With a glance I can see the status of each of those items. Click on any of those features and you'll get more detailed information. Click on the advanced tab and you'll get more information than a average user may need or want.  I found the user manual a good tutorial for some of the advanced stuff.  I didn't do any tech analysis of the routers capabilities.  I will say that our wireless devices are scattered about the house and they don't seem to have any problem with signal strength or speed.  I think Netgear went out of their way to make the users manual and the unit easy to use. Time will tell if the hardware stands up as well. I only give it a 4 star rating for now, but I will revisit it after using the router for awhile.
It was easy to set up and the coverage seems to be about like our other wireless router, so no complaints.

Will write again, once I've something to offer. Set-up went smoothly, the 5G is working GREAT with a 8X on T-Mobile, a HTC Flyer, EliteBook 2740p convertible tablet and a Asus Zenbook all logged-on simultaneously.

I have purchased two of these over the years. This first one is still going strong, despite poor power grid spikes and outages. The only reason I bought two, was so I could donate one to our church to use as a repeater to their existing system. As a router and as a wireless bridge, this had proven to be a very effective/durable unit.
I was having trouble receiving the wireless cable signal throughout the house.  When this was added the reception was improved.

Running rock solid on 2.4Ghz band with many devices running.  The configuration itself is a little slow and UI feels like it came from a previous century however it is straightforward and functional for the most part.  There are no super complicated options to be configured but then again this is not an enterprise grade router.Even at 25% power the router provides ample coverage and signal strength throughout my home.

We bought one of these a bit over a year ago when we first moved into our apartment.  We were not disappointed.  I've never had any problems with it and the neighbors all love me for turning on the Guest network option and letting them use it when they want to.I'm about to purchase a second one actually because ours (along with our modem) died during a storm.
Very easy to install and works well.  Have been using this router now for a month and have had no issues with it.
Replaced an old D-Link and NETGEAR has no problem connecting our laptop and iPad.  We are happy we got it.

Finally had to upgrade from my Linksys WRT54GL. Couldn't afford an AC router so this was the next best option which as it turns out was the best option. I have it installed in a Leviton in wall media cabinet which affects the wireless range significantly. I am not sure that AC would have helped. I still have a signal but ended up turning the wifi off and just use 2 other routers as APs only in other parts of the house.Also, I have nothing against the stock Netgear firmware but DD-WRT had to be installed in very short order. Throughput is very good and no issues with the router hanging or doing anything unexpected. I run dozens of simultaneous P2P downloads but the router handles QoS extremely well and absolutely no noticeable slow down on web traffic which has higher priority.This is a very good router that I can highly recommend.

I had no problem with this router, it's really fast to setup and the long distance wifi is also great. I was sceptalcal about buying this sense I never had a NETGEAR router but when I got this router and set it up it worked fine. In short terms, you really should buy it if you're going to stream videos, movies, or gaming.

SUMMARY:  Excellent Wireless 2.4GHz range, No VPN.Easy plug and play IF you are happy with default setting.Otherwise, Obvious Wireless WPS security bugs related to Wireless Guest account and MAC ACL. Lost time in setup but they can work eventually - I hope!!.My heart winner: USB port powers and supports FAT32 or NTFS HDD drives for DLNA media playback over network. (Looks like a NAS)Possible Chinese Solder Joint degradtion.This is a first impression review of the WNDR3700v4, firmware V1.0.1.32.There appear to be four versions of the product all lumped under the same Amazon heading so you have no idea if a review applies to your unit.I love my Lynksys Small Business WRVS4400N Wireless-N Gigabit Router.  Virtual Lans for up to 4 SSIDs allow incredible flexibility with Wireless Guest and Private topologies along with MAC access control for each; VPN capable.Sadly Cisco chose to end of life the unit after Acquiring Linksys.  Will Cisco's replacement products hit the same high level - too early to tell, but apparently not. Many happy reviewers of the Netgear WNDR3700?? seem to think this was the ultimate Home (small business??) Wireless router.PROBLEM 1  Out of the box, unit proudly announced it could access Internet.  It went down hill from there.  Using the Web 'Genie' interface, the unit would not allow any changes to the Wireless setting (SSID, Channel etc).  It continually reported a 'WPS process is in progress, please apply the changes later' when in fact the WPS status lite showed it was not.  This is an intermittent problem which makes it hard to diagnose.The unit has no clear option to turn off WPS. However, an unconfirmed internet rumor is that disabling the WPS PIN id under advance settings disables WPS.PROBLEM 1 Fix (sort of): Tech support said push RED 'Restore Factory Settings' button.  How could that work. that's what doesn't work now?  That leads to Problem 2, but that did fix the problem FOR ONE wireless setting change only.  You have to hit reset for each change.  Until you turn SSID broadcast off. Then it seemed to fix the problem because that kills WPS.PROBLEM 2:  The erroneously labeled RED reset button does what designers call a soft reset and restores LIMITED settings.  It apparently does not restore Wireless settings.  Only a Genie factory restore actually restores to Factory settings.PROBLEM 3:  When you setup the MAC access Control in Genie and hit 'apply' it come back after a lengthy time and appears normal.  Job done. Unit secure right? Wrong.The security changes deceptively don't take place until you reboot the 3700.PROBLEM 3 FIX Suggestion:  Allow DHCP control of each connection.  There is no status or time limit for the connections.  My guess is that the security changes are stored somewhere but the current  DHCP connection is never updated until reboot.  Linksys allowed complete control of each DHCP connection with a default of 24hrs per connection.GUEST ACCOUNT, GOOD: Setting up the Wireless Guest Account was error free and easy.  The Linksys Guest approach uses VLan and is simple and elegant.  The Netgear approach is complex and relies on Genie to hide a lot of complex things happening under the hood. Where there is complexity there is room for error. However,  I verified that the Guest account was isolated from the Private Network.WIRELESS EVAL, GOOD:  I used the 'InSSIDer' app on a Laptop to evaluate Linksys 4400 v  Netgear 3700 Wireless range.  At my favorite long distance spot, InSSIDer gave the connection a 5 (Linksys)  it gave the Netgear 3700 a 10.  Linksys didnt support 5GHz, but 5GHz range of the Netgear 3700 may be faster but its range is about 1/10th that of the 2.4GHz. InSSIDer recommends DISABLING WPS  for security reasons.USB SHARE: My DLNA renderers (HDTV and Denon Network Media Player) simultaneously played different songs/streams from an 3700 installed with USB/SD Card. I could not find Amperage rating for the USB port but it also successfully POWERED and played gapless flac audio files over DLNA from 2.5' HDD in a SIIG enclosure.  Video (M2TS) plays well.CHINESE SOLDER JOINTS:  A review of the posts on Amazon show a trend for this Chinese manufactured unit to work well for a while and then develop a host of problems. My new unit works for now, but I recently had a similar problem with my Chinese HP Laser Printer.  The culprit: bad solder joints.  The fix, bake the printed circuit board at a certain temperature and time and reflow the solder joints. Time will tell on my unit. Manufacturers are not in China for the German like craftsmanship.

column9: Good dual band wireless gigabit router
column10: I switched my laptop over to a nic card that runs on the 5.0 band and the speeds doubled. I have 1500 square foot home, single story and I only get 2 bars at opposite ends of the house, but the full 5 bars within 20 ft. of the router. Easy to set-up, if you do not have a set-up disk, you can download it from Netgear's support page. I got the version 2 and in 6 months I have only needed to reboot once due to a firmware update. Other than that, it's plug and forget. All devices easily find both 2.4 and 5.0 bands. WiFi never drops, always constant. I have a total of 6 devices showing and none of them have any lag in the WiFi's performance.
Very stable and good throughput on both bands..range could be a little better!Easy to set up and has a very practical Wi-Fi on/off button.

column9: Has a fast connection especially with 5G band
column10: Product has fast connection choosing either 2 or 5G band. I used the technical support o a couple of occasions for setting up since we had multiple devices to connect. Some of the support people were more knowledgeable than others and of course there was the factor of understanding their broken English. I would probably purchase this product again. One disappointment was difficulty in connecting an external hard drive via a USB cable to share on the network. I was not able to do this because the technical support person said I had to re-format the hard drive. I chose not to do this but will use another option.

I think I have owned this router for about 2 months now. I am pretty computer savvy, but installing this router was not very intuitive. I had to call the customer service line to get assistance. The issue I had was resolved in 10 minutes and the router has been working flawlessly since then. I love in a two-story condo and my signal is strong throughout my home.

the Router works fine but th box says: to madium-Large Home, I  have a "madium" house and the signal is poor in some areas. I'm looking to add a couple of External Anntenas.In other hand. It's too easy to configure and it's excellent the Guest Access, but it doesn't have any firelwall Configuration. I think that it's important. For that 4 Stars.

I bought this product with WN3500, range extender. Its price is under just $100 but seems to work better than my exsisting wifi access point (AP). Although it took some time to use it as AP, I am greatly satisfied. I wish it had an additional physical switch that could  select either router or AP mode.
Had it about a month.  Easy to setup, strong for 3-bedroom apartment.  WiFi started to fluctuate recently, but is generally good.

column9: Decent Router at the Price Point
column10: This is the newest WNDR3700v4 router, so it has the increased CPU, RAM, ROM and better DD-WRT support compared to the previous V3 model (it also returns to the superior Atheros wireless chipset, compared with Broadcomm on the V3). It replaced an Ubee modem/router device from Time Warner, and I can easily tell a massive difference in wireless range and performance. Wireless range has increased noticeably, and I have far fewer timeouts when streaming multiple media sources. My over network transfer speeds have also quadrupled, which is just fantastic.The administrative interface isn't too bad out of the box, and it does support some nice features, like the mounting of USB devices for basic NAS functionality. Overall, the stock firmware gives all the features and functionality that would be required by normal users, and most of what power users would like to see.Con:I had to reboot this router once so far, but that's not the end of the world. It is also IMPOSSIBLE to fully disable WPS device pairing on this router with default firmware. You can ax the WPS PIN, which would technically stop connections, but the WPS protocol is still being broadcast. This will be remedied when I change over to  DD-WRT firmware at some point in the future. The only other 'con' is a USB wi-fi adapter (D-Link WNA-125, which is pretty old all things considered) I had in one of my HTPC's would not connect to this router if the router was set to automatic channel selection. Immediately after I manually chose a Wi-Fi channel, it connected and worked like nothing was wrong. Not necessarily the routers fault, but still something worth mentioning that was odd.Overall, I would recommend this router to friends and family compared to some of other similarly priced Linksys or D-Link routers on the market today. I definitely prefer this over my parents Asus RT-N56U, which I didn't think would be the case.

This is a great product that was easy to install.  I had no problems with getting my home network running, basically selecting (finding) the new device and a password change.  It is working just fine so far after a couple of months.

I replaced my existing router because the extensive parent control options only worked about every other firmware update, which didn't include the latest release.The  Netgear WNDR3700 parent controls use OpenDNS.  Going this route provides solid protection using site categories to block general website types.  The parental controls also allow multiple schedules to be set and you can also add individual sites to a whitelist.  There's a bypass utility for mobile devices and desktop systems.  The OpenDNS solution is not as comprehensive as some other routers I've used, but it's not as complicated and so far, always works as advertised.

column9: Good performance at a reasonable price
column10: I have been using this router as a dual-band wireless access point for several months and I am very happy with its performance and reliability. It has stayed up continuously and I have had no compatibility issues. The web-based administration UI leaves quite a bit to be desired, but I was able to do everything I needed to, maybe just not as convenient as I would have liked. Be sure to upgrade the software right away, some features (e.g. connection logging) didn't work well until I installed the latest software.

column9: Nice to have a spare on hand!
column10: I wish this could be a super techie review on this router, but thanks to the support at ATT it's not.  It all started when I called ATT support because the 2Wire gateway we had was rebooting every 2 minutes.  After talking for awhile we decided it was the gateway.  I told him we had a Actiontec modem for just such a emergency, along with this Netgear router.  But I was unsure on how to connect to the internet. He told me he would walk me through the whole process.  After all the devices were plugged in we went to work.  The Actiontec modem found the account and then set up automatically.  Next step was to connect the Ethernet cable from modem to router. The next thing we knew one of our wireless computers was asking if we wanted to name our network with the name it had come up with and the passphrase.
