Also if the encryption was what we wanted or something stronger.Amazed, we clicked OK and went forward.  We were on the net, but didn't know how.  Of the few times I have had to set up a network to be able to use the net, this is the first one that almost did it for me.  After getting off the phone with ATT support I had to go into the router interface to see what had happened.  Once inside the router I could retrieve the network name and the passphrase.  Now we were able to set up the rest of our wireless computers.I like what this router has to offer.  The only device I can use the 5G on is an iPad so far.  But I do notice that because of the multiple antennas that computers coming out of sleep connect to the net faster than the 2Wire and the distribution of bandwidth is much better.  Would I get another Netgear router again, you betcha.  That time I hope I could go through the setup a little more.  I like to know why things are happening.I have to give it 4 1/2 stars, only because once in a while I have to reboot it.  Not sure why, but that's all it takes to be on the net again.  The internet has been working the majority of the time since installing this router; we're so glad we had it on hand!  :-)
This product works fine. Its configuration is easy. Besides it comes with a nice software that gives more information related with networks. On the other hand, Its is slowly to start Up .

Bought this after CIsco linksys E2000 began giving 1/4 of ethernet internet speeds..  set was very easy and router works like a charm. I havent yet been able to use all its features yet, but so far matches the internet connection speed on ethernet which is very good performance. Since these are still early days, I will update the review after giving it sometime.

column9: A Good Router. But Will Become Worst Nightmare With Interference.
column10: I got this router, do to the fact that I needed a WIFI in the house. Considering I can't sit in one spot for too long. So I got this Netgear N600 Gigabit router to tend to my needs. It's a respectable router for the price. Considering the REALLY REALLY swell ones run up to 200 bucks a pop. The Genie is a cute little feature. Although it could do a little more. And it's a good slick looking little device. But the pet peeve I have with this router is interference. If a cellphone gets near the router, or one little power surge happens. Everything gets KNOCKED out of whack. Either the speed starts to slow down drastically to dial up speeds, or my two laptops and Playstation 3 lose connection all together. The WiFi will refuse to pick up again. Which will lead me to unplugging the router, getting it in closer contact with my two Acers and Playstation 3 to pick up the routers IP signal again. Then everything's back to normal. For the moment.Thanks to this draw back, and do to the fact that this unplugging and plugging back in thing is starting to become a weekly routine. I can only give this router an 'Okay' rating for only 3 stars. Not bad, but could be better for a 100 bucks.Just a little note. If you have any smartphone/cellphones. KEEP THEM AS FAR AWAY FROM THIS ROUTER AS POSSIBLE. Make the devices avoid each other like the plague, if you do that you'll be fine. But so far, it's a good little router. That can either be a dream on good days, or your worst nightmare on the bad ones.(EDIT)Well the router seems to be working like a charm now. All I did was reset the whole router to factory settings. Moved the router itself to another location. And now it's doing just fine. The constant unplugging and replugging problem is now gone. I only had a problem just once. But it wasn't the router itself, their was a problem with my Internet provider. The Genie seems to be doing something weird like saying 'Internet Connected' one minute. Then saying 'Internet Disconnected' the next. But those messages is not that serious, considering that I stay connected and logged on.And their for I am rising my score one star. Still think it's silly that a router of this price could easily be interfered with. But if you just be smart, and keep harmful objects away from it. You'll do fine.
Bought it mainly for the parental control but also needed a faster router. Has worked out great in all ways for us. Has only bumped us off line once or twice in all the months we have owned it

Just got this.The Ready/share 'faux' CIFS file server feature is really nice.Unfortunately, it did not work out of the box.  It was very frustrating.I finally got an external USB hardrive to work as intended.I am going to pass on a MAJORLY HELPFUL tip.Put an EXT3 filesystem on the drive and then connect it to the netgear.It turns out that many users have had problems connecting a USB external drive to the usb port on the router.In my case it would not detect the USB drive, giving some generic error message, ' please attach a USB drive'.  It did however, detect a 32GB usb flash drive, and my windows 7 laptop could read/write there as a share.I did a search and found a tip on a linux forum that said laying down an ext3 filesystem on the external drive would solve the issue.It DID!.  This could have been very frustrating.The best way to do this is install a virtual machine on your host OS and load some linux distribution -Fedora,Ubuntu,Redhat,etc,- on it.  Attach the usb drive to the linux machine and run the mkfsext3 or other appropriate commands.No, it's not necessarily for beginners, but some forums can help you through it or perhaps you have a Unix/Linux savy friend.Must be ext3 not ext2.I can now do a wireless backup of my laptop!The general network speed is very nice.  Now have 42mbps download wireless at laptop, where the old router was a bottle neck at around 15mbps.Pleased overall, so far.

I returned Airport extreme to get this because it had the option to disable 2.4ghz radio as most of the devices in my home can operate in 5ghz band. Its also easy to setup. Network genie software to manage this router looks ok, but not great and it can be improved.

column9: Netgear WNDR3700 N600 Wireless Router: great, feature rich router but...
column10: I purchased this product two months ago and I've had no issues with it whatsoever. It's very easy to setup and does what it's supposed to do. HD video streaming is fast and it's able to handle 12 devices at the same time with ease. I'm giving it 4 stars because the Guest Network doesn't work; I can connect to the guest SSID but no access to the internet. I have tenants renting one of the rooms in the house and I don't want them having complete access to my network, hence the Guest Network. But I haven't succeeded in figuring out what's bugging this feature. If anybody from Netgear is reading this, your help will go a long way.

This router was suggested to me by my son who is a computer expert.  It seems to be fine except that the password that came with it worked for a while then someone else had trouble connecting wirelessly so we had to change the password.

column9: NETGEAR Wireless Router - N600 Dual band Gigabit
column10: It works great! Have had no problems with this router and expect to use it for a very long time. However, I saw this item for less right after I ordered it.

Don't give it 5 stars because sometimes the 5Ghz band drops and don't know for sure why, wich also was an issue I had with the D-Link Dir-850 router I had to replace with this one (after only six months because it just died), issue I addressed by doing some tweak, I think, but not sure if it was the tweaking or something else that solved the problem at that moment.  However, in general it seems to be a high quality product.  I have some technical skills and what I most appreciated about this router was the absence of a CD to install anything but a flyer where I could find all I needed to go to the web interface and change the default settings for the two networks this dual band router brings.  The web interface is neat and intuitive, Netgear really did a good job in this and I really appreciate it.

column9: Firmware needs a lot of help
column10: This the WNDR3700v4 - that's version 4, which was something of a surprise when it arrived. I love DD-WRT, but this one is not yet supported by that 3rd party firmware. I'm really looking forward to when they release a port for this H/W (see the Con comment below).Pros:- Very fast, both the wireless and the wired- If you have your computer and your modem connected to the router when you power it up, the 'genie' does a pretty good job at a first shot attempt at connecting to the internet. But, really, you're going to want to 'get under the hood' and lock this down just a bit.Cons:- I received the first one and the WAN port died in a couple of weeks, well within the 30 day RMA window. I have to say that the Amazon RMA process was painless - they even paid shipping for the failed unit back to them and for the replacement back to me.- The firmware needs a lot of help. Configuring the router is a Very, Very, VERY slow process. It seems as if when you update a configuration page of values that the router does a complete re-boot. And, in fact, on a couple of pages, the LEDs seem to indicate exactly that. Some pages are a bit faster .... but not by much. Setting it took the better part of 45 minutes and this isn't the first router setup I've ever done.- The unit comes with a CAT5 patch cord to connect between your modem and the router. I could not get the router to see the modem with this cord (yes, I did the power them all down, start and wait for the modem, then start the router .... twice). Bounce the modem and router after replacing the supplied patch cord with one of my own - success. The supplied cord is now in file 13.It's much to early to determine if I would recommend this to others. I'm hoping it is as dependable as my WNR3500 - which I've had for years!

I purchased this to upgrade my older G router and it is not only easy to setup it is much faster and has greater security and range.  Multiple devices are connected to the router wirelessly and have great speed when streaming.

column9: Great - but not more than 2 years
column10: I purchased the NetGear N600 WNDR3700 in Sept 2010 after a lightning strike killed most of my electronics :-(.  Up until 3 days ago, this thing was greased lightning with the following equipment:4 iphones1 itouch1 ipadPC laptop - ether #1 (priority) (work from home for a software company, so pour data thru this all day long)MAC desktop - ether #2Canon printer - ether #3PS3 - ether #4 (priority)occasionally, guest smartphones for kids friends...So for just over two years, this thing performed as advertised.  Very disappointed that warranty expired Sept 2011 (one year) and I'm left to purchase another router.  I am not going with NetGear for this next purchase - just Primed Asus RT-AC66U 802.11ac for a Gigabit experience - will let you know.I suppose if I think about it, the Airport Extreme prior to this NetGear was humming along as well until the lightning strike, so maybe two years for a high use, high performance router is all one can expect for a home focused router...nkr

I love this router.  Immediately after unwrapping, I had the SSID and network key.  These are listed on the device.  The directions were clear to change the security settings, connect all other wired routers/connections and wireless devices. The new router has a sturdy way to turn off the wi-fi when not in use.  My previous device had an flimsy button to turn off the wi-fi.  That button eventually caused the wi-fi to reset to factory setting and to eliminate ANY security key/local control of the device when the router was in use!!!  This router can even support devices on the first floor or in the garden!!!

I just got this a few days ago. Setup was a breeze and my network was up and running in less than 10 minutes. Range and reliability, so far, seems better than the Netgear router I replaced.I upgraded to the  dual band router so that my devices downstairs could run separately from my devices upstairs. Unfortunately, after I set up the network I discovered that the Playstation 3 doesn't have a 5 GHZ radio so that the dual band was essentially moot. I guess that's on me for not doing my due diligence. Knowing that, however, I would have purchased a single band router if I were to do it over again.... so double check the compatibility of your devices.

This wireless router is plenty powerful enough to easily connect my laptop and desktop to the I-net and at a decent price. Good value and much more reliable (so far) than the previous Netgear model I had, the N300. No problems.

column9: NETGEAR Wireless Router - N600 Dual Band Gigabit
column10: Arrived quickly. Easy to set up.Tip: when adding wireless components, use only one of the two gig set-ups. I used the 5G. Every works well.Only negative comment is I think the range is not as good as the G router I replaced. Maybe no antenna?
This Product has multi feature that I need , and  its price is not expensive , So I think it is a great product!!

column9: NETGEAR Wireless Router - N600 Dual Band Gigabit (WNDR3700)
column10: I like the router because after the initial installation I have not had any problems with it. When I had decided on the router for my home use I believed that it would provide many features that I could use such as the sharing of a USB hardrive as well as autosensing of the baud rates of the connected external devices. Many of the router's other features that are available will be there when I get the expertise to know how to use them.

column9: Wireless Range is not as good as expected
column10: I bought this router expecting a lot of improvement over G. However, it seems the range is not as good as previous netgear model. My daughter complaints frequent signal drops at her room which sits at the cornner of a large home.Nearby performance is very good.ReadyShare was a good selling point but in reality, performance was not so good for a large amount of files. For few files, it is not bad.

column9: Superb product, works as intended, great performance and looks
column10: PERFORMANCE:Very fast unit that supports more that 25+ devices at my location. Dual bands (5GHz + 2.4GHz) support different devices so make sure yours is compatible.  Easily the best throughput router I have owned.  Range is superb, covers a 10,000 square foot warehouse and office no problem, even with steel beams and thick concrete walls.SETUPThe setup is okay.  I instead just went straight the the web interface and set it up.  No issues.  Setting this up as an accesspoint takes some time since there are a ton of menu options and settings.  As for dual band, I set both networks to the same SSID and password.  Devices choose which connection they want automatically.

My 7-year old D-Link router was starting to take strain when doing video streaming, Internet phone calls, and few other problems.  So, I started researching for a new router and decided on Netgear N600 based it's features and other user reviews.  The setup was pretty simple.  I like that is it Dual Band, so i setup some devices on 2.4 gHz channel while a couple on the 5 gHz.  The video streaming is smooth now.  Also our VoIP phones are working much better.  The reason I only gave 4 stars is because, I expected the wifi range to improve as well with this new router, but not so in terms of signal strength.  However, performance in those rooms with the weaker signal is certainly better than with my old router.

column9: Great little, feature rich, wireless router!
column10: I recently purchased one of these bad boys to replace my old RangeMax WPN824 Wireless Router (also from Netgear).  It has a similar look and feel from the GUI/configuration perspective but bumps the LAN ports up to 1 Gig speed from 10/100 Mbps, adds N to the wireless landscape (at either 2.4 Ghz or 5 Ghz frequencies), A is also available in the 5 Ghz space AND adds a USB port that essentially allows you to provide a method for file sharing or a small network attached storage (NAS) capability on the router.  Additionally, it has the NETGEAR genie App for your iOS or Android devices so you can have a 'personal dashboard' to monitor, control & repair your home network.  Furthermore, it has 'Push `N' Connect' using Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS) capability for guests that are visiting.It's really pretty cool!  Great buy!!!  Pick one up today.

This router is great for basic home needs. The part I like the most about the router is the fact that it has a 5g connection and the regular connection allowing for you to separate your devices to prevent speeds slowing down.
very fast wireless connections.  external usb hd connection speed is not very fast but it's ok.  user interface is easy to use.  Overall a good router.

This was a 2nd router purchase after the Belkin we picked up had some connection issues.Strong signal, easy set to set up, etc.1 draw back (cost it a star): The USB port doesn't support Printers. Can't understand why that wasn't included in this model, but you'll have to upgrade/pay more for the 3800 or higher if you want to run a Printer through the USB port.
Works as advertised and I am satisfied with the product. this was an upgrade from my previous ab AP that well for me for many years.

column9: Not Perfect, but worth the money
column10: My previous router was a D-Link Dir-625. It had adequate speed, and range for my needs, and I also liked the D-Link interface. The problem I was having was that it required a reboot at least once or twice a day. This may have been because I have over a dozen devices that connect to my network. Another problem was that because my wireless webcam only had the B & G wireless protocol, I was prevented from using my router in N mode. After a little research, I zeroed in on the Netgear n600 Dual Band Gigabit. I was very tempted to go with a D-link dual band router (dual band lets you operate both N compatible and non-N compatible devices). The deciding factor in switching to Netgear was that I had been using the very useful Netgear Genie router utility. This free, downloadable utility will function with any router, but some of the features are only compatible with Netgear routers.Setup was pretty simple. I hate reading manuals and found the Netgear interface pretty intuitive. I would recommend you use your browser and URL [...] to access the router's interface. If you are a beginner, you should use the Genie utility and follow instructions. After connecting all the cables, remember to reboot your modem before booting up the router the first time. You should also turn off other devices that are connected to your network.  The dual band set up is a little confusing and I am still not sure I am using it correctly. I might just have to read the manual.The reason I am only giving 4 starts is that I cannot say that I have noticed any super increase in range or speed, although I can now use the N mode on my laptop thanks to the Dual Band feature. I was a little worried that with no external antennas, range would have been compromised, but so far no problems.The biggest benefit is that after two days, I have not had any dropouts requiring a reboot. I will keep you posted if this changes. I also like the interface which is easy to navigate with a multitude of features, and easy to configure. It's as good, if not better than the D-Link. It  also includes a built-in help feature.Oh yes, the router has an actual on/off switch so you don't have to struggle with the power cord every time you need to do a reboot. That alone could be considered the fifth star.
column13: 0_.png" alt="Click to watch this video" id="cv_mo1ZSYDXA4HKGCOpreplayImageId" />

column10: This product was easy to install and set up was a breeze.I needed to upgrade to a faster more intensive Router to run Windows 7 at 64 gigabit.Thanks NetGear!
Had to configure it by calling net gear geeks rather than after 2 hours of manually getting it functionally organized it worked great.  Come on work out of the box.....

I purchased this router after trying couple of big named and high end routers. All the previous ones worked well for couple of days and then started disconnecting automatically and would not come up. This one so far has been very stable for me since I got it. I would highly recommend this one if you are looking for dual band router. The 2.4 and 5Ghz works perfectly fine and I have some of my devices connecting to 2.4 and some to 5 GHz band. It also has a usb port to attach a network drive which is working great.

This router is pretty good so far.  The box is kind of deceptive.  It sounds like you can share your printer via USB, but that is not the case.  When I brought that up to their support they were not very helpful nor informative.  The Netgear genie software is useless.  It kept telling me that my internet connection was disconnected.  It was not really necessary to have this software to use the router.  It works fine for our house.  We have 2 iPads and an old Macbook.  They are all able to connect to the router without too many drop issues.

I ordered this router and when I received it, the setup was absolutely seamless!  I have never had a new piece of hardware to setup for my network that didn't require a disc-based install, so that is refreshing.  Also, this router works great on both the 2.4 Ghz and the 5 Ghz bands.I only have one complaint, and it might be something that can easily be remedied by the supportive staff at Netgear.  This router is not supported by the Netgear Genie app, which was really a selling point for me on the router, so I'm a bit disappointed by that. I hope they'll patch it in soon!Other than that, extremely satisfied customer here! My old Netgear router never killed on me and they have good customer support, so if you get these products,you won't go wrong.

column9: Just as good as what I had
column10: No problems with it, very easy set up. But its no better than the other one I had. Would recommend

This item performs as advertised.  It was fairly easy to set up and functions as advertised.  My network speeds are faster and the settings are easy to change.  Checking the system to see how it is functioning is easy to do also.  I've had a couple of netgear routers - each generation it better than the last.

This is a second router I bought from Netgear after 4 years of using an older version with no technical problem. Love this dural band router where I can use 5 GHZ for iPad.  Installation was very easy, and easy to set up password protection.  It works well, so far so good.
I was hoping the signal would be stronger on the opposite side of the house. It was very easy to set up

I am very happy with this router which I bought new and not refurbished.  I had purchased a refurbished router by the same company and it just stopped working after about 6 months.  Even though I had to call the company to help me install it, I have found it to be a good product

This is a great router but I also had problems  with dropping the Internet and later loosing its Wi-Fi signal output all together. I downloaded inssider a free program that lets you see the wireless signals and analyze them. To cut to the solving of the problem it was the wall wart power supply. The 12 volt DC was not clean. Replacing it with a good wall wart solved all the issues.

column9: An excellent router and access point
column10: I am an I.T. Consultant with over 20 years experience - this is a great router and access point for home and small business use.  If you are installing it behind an already-configure router or firewall, be sure to plug the network in to one of the 'ethernet' ports - NOT the 'internet' port.The 2.6ghz radio has excellent range - I can still get the signal at my neighbor's house - over 200' away.
I used this router for about a year until I replaced it with an ASUS type AC router (which Is the best I have used to date).  The Netgear was very stable and had a very good range.

I've had this router for about a year, and I have not had it fail on me once. Never had to turn it off reset it, or anything. It just sits there doing it's job. I like the USB option where I connect my hard drive. It performs very well, and I have had no issues at all.I wish all electronics worked like this. I'm looking at you, microsoft.
Bought router to upgrade and have been very happy....easy to install and has worked very well....both the wired and wireless

At first I thought it installed in a breeze, but then I found out that an older computer I had on the system couldn't log on.  It took many days and many trials to get it to log on (although it was running XP) and in the end I am not sure why it finally did log on.  Then there was the matter of getting my wireless printer on line.  Having to unplug it completely, lug it upstairs and hook it up to the router and computer and give it a mac address (although not a mac) and finally it could be seen.  Then to find that only one of my computers would actually download faster than the 54 mpbs that I got with the old one, and that a new HP Probook and could only get 130 mpbs when I was expecting more...so it was OK, worth what I paid for it, and hopefully with time and as computers get upgraded around my house we'll get more of its speed capability...after some voltage fluctuations after storm Sandy, it stopped working and is now junk!

I only gave this unit a four as I don't know how dependable it will be in the long-run.  However, first of all, performance wise, so far this unit is 'head and shoulders' above my prior Netgear routers.  They too were supposed to handle four 'hard' connections from my computers plus 'wireless' traffic from the others. But the cheaper units would go 'offline' killing my internet connection, usually in the middle of the night, after just a couple of hoursBut the WNDR3700 is holding it own with three 'hard' connections and 'wireless' traffic from two other computers.  Which is a huge improvement. As I need the reliability of a uninterruped internet connection for five computers engaged in various research projects.I found this unit from a vender that was shown on Amazon. So don't be put off by it's 'asking' price elsewhere.

I got this Netgear N600 WNDR3700 router today at a garage sale for $2.50!!! My previous router was a linksys wrt54g that is 5 years old but is still working good. The web based 192.168.1.1 setup menu is a bit messed up and confusing(not like linksys) Factory settings include by default a lot of useless options 'on' and it takes a lot of time to disable them and keep only the one you need. It takes 20-40 seconds for the router to apply each setting that you change!When connecting to 'A' wireless band 5.0ghz, 300mb option, the latency is amazing, the wireless coverage is great. No cons here. It gets to my full 18mb/s download speed just in a few seconds. Web pages open faster than usual. My Previous linksys router latency is good, but it's 2-3 times slower, and it gets only 17mb/s out of 18mb/s full speed.But the b/g/n 2.4ghz wireless band of a netgear router is crappy. I tried every option, disabled all other bands including guests with no changes.Top speed is not more than 8mb/s out of 18bm/s. the coverage is 2-3 times less than my previous linksys wrt54g which is unacceptable.I wanted to have 5.0ghz band that only my laptop supports but didn't want for other devices in my home to have crappy netgear's 2.4ghz wireless. What i did was installing first my previous linksys wrt54g to cable modem, setup its QOS with lan port1 priority to 'high', and netgear's mac address 'priority' device. Then i connected netgear to lan port1 of the linksys router. On netgear i disabled any possible option except the main 5.0ghz band. So for now, i have both 2.4ghz and 5.0ghz at great speeds, latency and coverage, until i get one good router that will do both.If you have b/g/n 2.4ghz only devices in your home, don't but this router.

I owned version 2 of this router for about 4 months and it worked great.  Then suddenly the wireless signal disappeared.  Tech support had me jump through a few hoops and at the end told me the router needed to be replaced but they didn't have any in stock and they couldn't tell me when they could ship me another one.When I asked to speak to a supervisor, I was then told they did have some in stock.  It took a week to reach me and when it did I discovered it was version 1 of this router.  I'm not sure of the differences between the two, but so far the router has been stable and I've had no issues.

column9: WNDR 3700 is a great router, for us.
column10: Hi.I have this router for just about 2 years now and we are very pleased with it.I have the most current firware installed as determined via the routers 'firmware check' utility.  I know there is one newer on the Netgear website, but it's technically a beta and so... i wait.  My current firmware works and so i leave it alone.The range is pretty good.  I wish it were a touch stronger though and i've been researching range extenders or upgrading to a new netgear router thinking i'd get a stronger signal, but... not sure.  There's a ton of negative reviews about Netgear support and that they've tanked.But the range, ultimately, is pretty good.The router is in a corner in the basement.  I get very strong signals on the main floor and then decent signals upstairs.Upstairs, my wife uses 1st generation Ipad and has no problems.  I also have used ROKU as well as a bluray player on wireless and have not had problems.  The ROKU streams HD even when on wireless and again, that's upstairs.I also have a printer that is wireless and it works fine too.I have Vonage (ugh), wired printers, wired DTV receivers and wired computers in my home.  They all work flawlessly.I run a gigabit network throughout my home.So between the phones, printers, laptops, roku, bluray, pc's and server... i'm happy.  I do not get disconnects or drop outs, i get a solid connection at almost all times.  IN fact, it is not uncommon for me to go more than 45 days before getting a new IP address from my ISP.  I have a utility that emails me anytime the ip address changes.  I know when the router drops out because the IP address changes... and this happens maybe 2 or 3 times in a year... which makes me think the issue is ISP related and not the router.Ironically though... even though my wife can connect her ipad from upstairs, estimated 30 feet from where the router is, in a straight line... she can't connect only 12 feet from outside, on the same side of the house where the router is located.  Go figure.I have an old Dlink Access Point which i hook up then when she's outside and that does the trick, but it messes with my network so i don't run it all the time.And because of the age of that A.P. i've been researching the newer Netgear models.I've been a life long Netgear fan!  I have a 24 port switch, multiple 8 port switches and i've had several Netgear routers over the years.I've also used Linksys (not a huge fan, but that's just me) and i've used Dlink (i am a fan of their older Gaming Routers, but their newer GREEN switches are junk.  EIther they burn out or their power adpaters do and there is no such thing as technical support with dlink once you're outside the warranty period.  Kinda like HP... their support stinks too, even when under warranty.).Anyhow, the Dlink Gaming was my favorite router for years until i wanted something newer and found this one.  I really am pretty happy with this router.So now the question for me is whether to get a range extender or upgrade to a newer Netgear router, in order to get that extra bit if signal outside.My concern though with upgrading to a newer Netgear are the reviews for the newer Netgear products.People who read these reviews, sometimes get upset when customers base their review on technical support experiences vs. pure product experiences, but i am of the opinion that technical support experiences is a part and should be a part of the review.I am fortunate, i have not had the need for tech support in years.  But, when reading the reviews for the newer routers, peole are sharing their horror stories with Netgear... and so i think it's worthy of mentioning here, what people are reporting.Netgear's support people are not fluent in English.  So if English is your native language, good luck communicating with Netgear support.Netgear considers firmware as software and therefore, if after 90 days of ownership they release a firmware update and it has a problem and messes up your router, they will not support it unless you BUY technical support.Netgear is now more like HP and is more concerned about getting every extra $$ out of people vs. actually caring for their customers.  THis is why i will not bring HP into this house any more.  I wrote them off 3 yrs ago.  So to hear that Netgear charges more than $150 for support when they messed up someones router... is wrong.  Especially when that's nearly the cost for a new router.Lastly, i see where Netgear has read almost all reviews for their stuff and they reply.  The replies seem genuine enough until you've read a few dozen of them.  Then you start to see that they are all the same.  Paraphrasing, 'sorry for your experience with tech support, we want to investigate to make sure it doens't happen again, send us your case number and we will help you get this fixed.'  and then you look and the customers report back here, in their feedbacks, that they then never hear from Netgear again.That tells me that Netgear is trying to do public facing damage control via Amazon reviews and it's all about marketing and NOT about their customers.So, i need to put this out there for anyone considering this router or any other Netgear product.Their support is not what it used to be, based on dozens and dozens and dozens of reviews here on Amazon.So i'm torn.  I REALLY WANT TO UPGRADE... because i like NEW and FAST... but i'm torn as i don't know what to do.  I'm really afraid i'm going to have a problem on their HIGH END routers and i just can't count on Netgear support.  They are not customer focused anymore.That all said... this particular router... i recommend it all the way.  Just flash the firmware immediately by following the instrudtions... and then set it up and you're done.I love this router.  I just wish the signal was a touch stronger.I hope this is helpful for people and if not, sorry for being long winded.T

column9: It is a nice router, just a small problem
column10: It was delivered quickly. I really like this new router. The only problem is that some laptops when they are turned off and you turn them back on, the wifi have to be selected and not automatically like it used to be with my other router. The speed it is really nice and fast, but no every corner in my apartment is covered by it. Some dead spots here and there but no big deal. Overall a pretty nice router.

column9: A good router for a lot less than what I paid several years ago.
column10: But, that's the way PC pricing goes. 2 years ago it was around $160, now - $89.95. This router worked very well for us (in two different floorplan scenarios), with the 5Ghz band being used strictly for Streaming to our Roku boxes, leaving the 2.4 segment for the usual wifi stuff.Once configured, I didn't have to go back in to change a thing (even after the big move, it was plug'n play). I've had linksys (pre-Cisco and post-Cisco), D-links, and other brand wireless routers give up the ghost and drift into bit-limbo, but this was a solid device. I've never had a reason to consult or talk to their tech support so I can't comment on that experience.For the keen-eyed reader, you've noticed I wrote '...this WAS a solid device'. Technically it still is, but I replaced it with the N600 3800 for that routers dedicated video mode. As with the 3700 - no complaints.

Bought this router December of 11 and first thing I did was put DD-WRT on it, which seemed like a good idea because Netgear paid DD-WRT for 'special support' for more advanced features. I found the beta builds to be fairly unstable compared to my old WRT-54GL and with a few soft bricks I decided to revert back to stock. Since then I have not ever thought about going back to DD-WRT, I don't use any of the advanced features because my NAS does everything for me so good ol' stock firmware has been rock solid with no drops running straight 24/7 for 8 months and counting. Couldn't be happier but 4 stars for less than stellar DD-WRT distro even though Netgear paid for it.
easy to install  I like the unit . Wish it would have had more range. I had to buy a new range extender to work correctly

Very fast compared to old linksys-n,, Resource CD kept kicking out on my iMac superdrive,But it also has a 'No CD installation', after that its a no brainer install. So far very good. I would recommend based on performance, price and simple install.(i have cable internet, so not sure what adsl install is like)

I am not using all the features but the ones I am using are working. It works well on all 4 computers in my house. Transfers data between 2 computers easily while not slowing the internet connection on a third computer. Much better then the older one I replced with this one.

This is a nice replacement for my now failed Belkin that only lasted 91 months.  I do have to reboot it every day because the router stops responding on a regular basis, the 2.x responds 100% of the time, the 5.x does not work all of the time until you reboot it.  So I put the router on a timer to reboot once in the morning and once in the evening.  That appears to be working for now.While its a good replacement, its NOT reliable with its default settings.UPDATE from yesterday:  I dove deeply into the settings of this router and discovered the QoS featuer, I enabled it and DELETED any IP Phone crap and the router has been ROCK SOLID!  Would I buy another one again, yes, if they keep this setting available to the end user!  :)  Now I'm _VERY HAPPY_ with this router.  Albeit, the novice computer user might not find this setting.

I purchased a refurb version so paid half of what it cost brand new. It has performed well. Speed tests have been spot on with what my speeds are suppose to be. Its dual band (2.4ghz and 5ghz), but in fact each band has an optional guest network as well so you can actually have 4 different networks set-up which is a bit too much but at least you have that option. Have only had it for several days and so far so good. Not a huge deal for people that use this at home but it can also keep track of usage and you can have the router auto disconnect once it reaches a certain data cap that you set. Again most ISP's don't have capped data so not sure most would need this. This replaced a D-Link DIR-815.The one minor complaint......the USB readyshare is a bit slow at read/write speeds, as some others complained about. A big seller for me was the USB, which the D-Link lacked, because it would allow me to share an external drive across the networks but speed was an annoyance. Its still an excellent router nonetheless.For those that are experiencing connection issues, I have found with experience that you may need to update the firmware. The first thing I did when I set this up was search for a firmware update, which was available.

column9: A great step up from my last router - but if you are networking, go for the WNDR 3800
column10: The router is solid and has been operating very well.  The only complaint, as others have noted, is the read/write speed of the usb to my 1TB hard drive.  It's abysmally slow - which seems crazy considering that it can transfer to a remote computer, wirelessly, and write tot THAT hard drive much faster.But if you aren't hooking up a hard drive, this router should be perfect for you.
I really like how much this has helped my wireless connection.  I am not happy with the price I paid.  I went to Walmart 2 days after receiving this and they had the exact item for $20.00 less.

column9: Nice but took a little doing to set up
column10: Not as easy to set up as some routers I've had. The setup Genie kept telling me I had a static IP address. NetGear Customer Service agent 'Paul', after some testing, rebooting, and cable swaping told me I had to call my IP provider, Verizon, for internet connection issues. Before calling Verizon I reasearched the issue online and found if you are using Verizon then Verizon must release the MAC code and let it reassign to the new router. Try explaining that to 'Joseph', who sounded remarkably like 'Paul', in the Verizon overseas Call Center. After an hour of 'Joseph' having me reboot, recable, and re-everything, 'Joseph' told me my computer was broken and I needed to call the computer manufacturer for repairs. I loudly convinced him my computer wasn't broken and got him to release the MAC code. The new router quickly accepted the code and after that the set up was simple. My home is a large 3 story with my office in the lowest level. I run 2 computers in my office, a Smart TV on the second floor, and two computers on the 3rd floor, two Smart Phones all around the house, and can sit on my deck or patio and use my laptop and Smart Phone without a hitch so the WNDR3700 seems to have enough range to do what I need it to do. I am giving it 4 stars because I am pleased with it's performance, albeit brand new. I took away one star because I don't think NetGear Customer Service did enough to research the issue.  I would recommend this item, just remember if you are using a VERIZON router you will have to deal with 'Joseph', 'Paul', or 'Peggy'.
Set up was easy and the range was better than my previous Netgear router.  After one month of use, it have been very reliable.
I like it. It has a nice strong signal and is very fast. I was using it with my Azus tablet the other day and was just zipping along.

I've had no issues at all with this router and the range is on par with other routers in this class.  The only ding is that the 5ghz range is quite poor, but I believe that's the norm for 5ghz.I'm a bit of a computer geek (have a NAS in my home) so setup was a breeze.  I can see where the setup may be tricky for someone without a computer background.
Although there are a few quirks in learning the router software that it installs, it's generally a great router and one that I would recommend.

After 4 years, my old Linksys 54GS Router stopped working reliably so I thought I'd reevaluate my current home network workload.  I currently run a Toshiba laptop with an i7 processor, an iPad 2, a Canon Wi-Fi Capable Printer, and a Playstation 3 through my network.  Rarely, I bring home my work laptop which is an Apple Macbook Pro.  Since I watch a lot of streaming video, play online video games, and online chat with my friends, I figured I'd buy an upper tier wireless router to put the package all together.What I've found was a headache.  But let's get to the positives first.1.  Good customer support.  Ok, I'm no pro but when I first started having this issue, I spent a lot of time back and forth with their customer service and they seemed to be quite knowledgeable and friendly.  They even emailed me detailed instructions of what they said to do so I can refer to it easily (the person I talked to offered to do it but you might have to ask for it).  My issue went all the way to RMA and the process was seamless.2.  Setup was easy.3.  Range and speed was good when it was working.Cons:1.  It randomly has DNS Server Not Responding errors.  Most of these errors would just crash the internet in my apartment.  I'm not sure if some of it was related to my crowded environment but anyways...  Most of these went away when I stopped using Firefox.  However, I've not found anyone else who has had this issue.  To make matters more odd.... the best way to replicate this error is to visit ESPN.com.  I cannot tell you why, but my best guess is the embedded Flash videos in their website crashes my router.  And by the way, it doesn't matter whether or not I'm wired in or wireless.2.  The 'new' router has the same issue as the old one.Would I recommend this router?  YESUPDATE:  I responded to the manufacturer's link below and what happened was interesting.  What little I got before turned into a whirlwind response.  I ended up RMA-ing the original router and getting a new one.  The problem did not get resolved.  It was a never ending process that NETGEAR handled very well, even if it took quite a while.  In the end, 1 RMA and 2 firmware updates later, it works with no complaint!

column9: Update on Warranty and customer service- satisfactory outcome
column10: I email tech support as suggested by V42. After a few emails, it was determined that the range issue is due to hardware failure. Received my replacement router yesterday. Set up was simple taking only 10 minutes to update firmware, setup password, SSID etc... and am now getting 5 bars throughout the house. No drop signals and blazing speed. I really like the guest network feature which allow guests to use a separate network thus avoiding access to shared hard drives in your private network. I hope this refurbished router that I got will last me a while.All in all, I am now satisfied with Netgear's response to my problem. It would have been a better experience had phone support been better. Either way, faith in Netgear restored.

Really does the trick.  I was trying to get internet into my office which is outside of my house.  I shut the wifi on my isp router off, hardwired this router and connected my voip phone to the 5g and the computer to the 2.4g...works grrrreat!

column9: Product died within the first hour. Replacement working fine.
column10: the WND3700v3 works great with a few undocumented quirks:1. Fragile, device shorted out within one hour of installing it.2. Unable to change device IP to reside on 172.31.x.x network. Device must be reset to restore functionality.Still, it's a vast improvement over my Linksys WRT54Gv5.

column9: 2nd N600 purchase to expand my network coverage
column10: Purchased this second N600 so I could expand my network coverage to an area that my first one couldn't really reach well. But when I tried to set up wireless repeating I found out you cannot use WAP, only wep coverage.I have a wired connection available to connect the two devices so I used that instead but still had problems. Wasted over an hour with netgear support only to be cut off and never receive a return call.Finally, after googling the problem I was able to set it up as a wired extension to me network. To set this up you have to connect a wan port from the first to one of the wan ports on the second n600. Give the 2nd one a different ip address (not 192.168.1.1) I used 192.168.1.2. Do not set up the wan settings on the second. Turn off DHCP on the 2nd so all wired and wireless devices get an address from the first router, then duplicate your wireless settings exactly as they are on your first one.Once I had it up and running it is working great.I would have rated this 5 stars if netgear had allowed me to set a gateway address so the 2nd one would see that there is an internet connection and check for updates, but with no wan settings the 2nd one doesn't think it has internet connectivity.

Had a US Robotics and never had a problem.  This has been a POS.  I bought to get a 'N' connection, but end up having to restart it at least twice a week.  Never again will I buy a Netgear anything.edit...Did upgrade firmware and working better.

column9: Pretty decent router for the money
column10: Originally, I wanted to post a scathing review on this item, as I had so many issues just getting a new boxed item from Amazon. However, they did all they could and eventually got me a new boxed item. Now that I have the router, I'm glad I didn't try to get another one. This router replace an older TrendNet router that kept loosing it's signal and kicking everyone using it off the internet. This Netgear model is easy to set up and the online site to change the settings is easy to use. I'm enjoying that I can now have two different bands of internet to use so that my PC isn't being bogged down by all the other things in my apartment using the internet. My only real issue with this router is that, in places where there are a lot of other routers such as an apartment, the range becomes terrible. Changing what channel the router operates on helped some; however, the range is still not as good as I'd like it to be.

column9: NETGEAR N600 Wireless Dual-Band Gigabit Router WNDR3700
column10: Works extremely well when finally installed which was a bit of a problem.  Company support over the internet was available. A state of the art unit!

I was browsing the internet less than 16 minutes after I opened the box. Setup was phenomenal.I give it 4 stars pending its longer-term performance. I've used earlier models with success, so I'm not terribly concerned.

For some reason no router makers seem to be able to write stable firmware for their products, that seems to be left to the people who make things like dd-wrt and open-wrt.  With that in mind and having no patience for unreliable connections I started looking for the fastest, most reliable open source compatible dual band router I could find, cost wasnt really an issue.Reading various forums a lot of people were saying the 3700 was the one to get to run open source so I decided to give it a shot.With the latest stock firmware and everything setup properly I was getting lots of packet loss and my transfer speeds on the LAN and Wan sides were about half of what I got from my older routers.  I then installed the latest Gargoyle build of OpenWrt (loads just like the stock firmware since the stock firmware is actually a version of OpenWrt netgear has somehow managed to ruin).  Now my speeds are at least doubled, in some cases quadrupled(video file transfer), there's no p/l, the router so far is rock solid and and the connection from anywhere in the house is great.  Doing 20mbit/s transfers from the internet over wired connection while transferring video files wirelessly (72mbit/s sustained) the router runs completely stable.Bottom line, stock this router is a turkey, I'd give it one star and would have returned it the next day, but since it works so well with gargoyle it gets a 4 from me.Couple of quick notes:1.  The 3700s now out there for sale are all v2 like mine, from what I've read there was a slight drop in wireless performance compared to v1 at I think 2.4ghz, but I am still happy with the speed2.  It's completely identical to the WNDR37av, only the box is different, the router therein is still marked as a WNDR3700v2.If anything changes I'll update this review.

I've had this router a week now.  It replaced a 5 year old Linksys WRT54g.  Installation was pretty easy except the installation disk took a couple tries to get working. I only have an Ipod touch 4 that uses N, so I can't confirm that this router is that much faster than my old one, but I do know my wireless connection isn't dropping out like it used to.  The gigabit ethernet has made a slight improvement in my connect from my desktop to my cable modem. So all I can really say is it's working fine.

I ordered this product refurbished;  the seller listed it as a V1 (there are 3 versions):[...]I decided to go with the V1 because I was sure it was well supported by openwrt.I'm glad I did, since the default software was really pretty basic.  If all you need is WIFI and maybe a USB media server, it should work fine.  If however you want to do more complex things, including using the device as a WIFI client, you're better off replacing it with DD-WRT or OpenWRT.Range is at least twice as good as my WRT600N;  It also seems better at holding stable fast connections on BOTH bands.5 stars if it the software had been better :)

Before I bought this item I read numerous reviews.  I even looked at websites that rank wireless routers and this was almost always in top ten for different sites.  The price at the time was considerably more expensive than other routers which gave me pause but the real reason for that is the dual band feature (I'm sure Netgear would say other reasons but that is the reason from a consumers perspective).  I didn't realize when I bought it how much that feature would come into play later on, in fact I figured I was making the same mistake that I made when I bought a high end VCR back in the day (all the bells and  whistles that run up price and ultimately just use it to watch movies).  Not true for this device the dual band really comes in handy if you get a lot of people coming over and you don't want to give out your password to you're primary network.  Just enable the second band (use the fastest one for your network and the slower for everybody else). I see a huge variance in reviews another reason for my hesitancy in purchasing this product.  What I think is really happening there is a lot of people (me included when I purchased the product) just know this allows you not to be tethered via a cord.  I suspect they don't really understand the setup procedures an sort of muddle through it (I was guilty of this) well there are several Youtube videos that walk you through step by step and go through the functions how to set up/how they work and the pros/cons.  For me this made a huge difference for one I'm a typical guy I only read directions as a last resort but will watch a video in a second and two making the leap from reading/following/understanding directions doesn't always happen(guess I should have been the remedial class in school)  So if your having trouble use the YouTube video's.I never had problem remaining connected only on two occassion did I lose connection the first year (both times I suspected I lost my cable connection and the router did not pick it back up automatically).  The third occassion I hit the key on laptop that disables wireless don't laugh spent two hours trying to figure out and thought the router was the problem.  Signal strength for me is off the charts on 5GHZ  I do recommend placing in a strategic location (general rule the higher the better) looks as far as other routers not bad does show fingerprints one cleaning after setup and you shouldn't have to touch it again that being said I've never looked at any router and said thats attractive I think I'll put that on the table as a centerpiece just do the best you can being discreet and elevated unless you have a monster size house or lead walls you should be covered.  I bought mine refurbished as price was too high for a new one at the time.  I've always had success doing this and since its doesn't have moving parts I figured on the retest at the factory working order would be verified (I assume they go through all functions when they get something sent back of course some flunky making minimum wage is probably doing the testing and the likelyhood of him taking a shortcut seems high.  Either way it came looked brand new one thing to note when you do this some directions/cd did not come with it that was fine you have to update from the internet anyway.  They do take the off the serial number and you can't register it with Netgear (your warranty in this case actually should come from the seller and it won't be that long) but most things tend to break right out of the box or soonafter if not then you typically get normal life with that product.Pro'sDual bandGreat signal strengthCan be setup discreetlyConsPriceSetup is a little complex

Very good router, but definitely not the best. The 5.0GHZ freq has a much faster speed but much smaller range then the 2.4gHz. Works great none the less. The USB port doesn't support every format HDD. It does not support printers at all, only higher end netgear routers do. If I were to recommend a new router, it would probably be the Asus n900 ones.

column9: Good stable router, but screwy cableing instructions
column10: If you followed the instructions on the included CD to the letter, you would plug your computer into the WAN port of the Router, and the modem cable into a LAN port. If one didn't know better, one could spend hours trying to figure out why it wouldn't work. Luckily, I knew better, so I had no problems. A simple picture would be a lot clearer. And I sure miss printed manuals.The router seems fully featured, is easily set up with intuitive software, it has good range, is fast, and seems very stable. Ive got 3 other wireless routers cascaded from it to give wireless coverage over 5 acres and Ethernet in a couple of outbuildings. My previous primary routers would need rebooting every couple weeks or so. Ive only had this one up a few days, but it seems stable and if it ever needs a power cycle, the off switch in the back will be handy.Update:after a couple months, I really like this router. In fact, I never have to think about it. It is stable as a rock and the signal is excellent. Ive got an app on my phone that measures signal strength and it nearly makes the 3 other routers cascaded off of it redundant.
Has been great being connected to outside world from all over house. This procuct I should have purchased a long time ago.
Love this router and have recommended it to friends and family. Great signal, lots of features. You wont be disappointed.

So far, it's been great.  It takes about 10 minutes to gain full connectivity if you have to reboot; unsure if the delay is related to the modem, router, or my Airave device taking it's time coming back up, so can't give 5 stars.

I got this on a whim since I have an Apple Airport network (3 actually) that works very well for me. But if I can try out something else for free, well why not? So, it's as fast and reliable as my Airport stuff, at least for the short time I used it. Easy to set up with Macs. I cannot speak to its interface with IBM-type PCs. So, if you need a 802.11n router, the current price of 99-bucks seems like a great deal. It is an outdated model (N900 is the latest, I believe) and some of the printed specs seem to indicate you'd be better off with the newer model for 80-bucks more.

I did a lot of research online before choosing this router, and at least for now, I am happy with my choice. Set-up was very easy, albeit a bit slow. I thought that the onscreen instructions guiding me through the wireless encryption process were especially user-friendly ... a real breeze, contrary to my experience with my previous, now 4-year-old, CISCO/Linksys WRT54G router, which this one replaced. The most impressive feature of this model, however, was its lightning-fast wireless signal throughput speed that almost matched the wired throughput rate. Again, this was a very pleasant surprise because the wireless:wired ratio for my old router had been about 1:4. This router is bulkier than most I have seen, but not heavy; stood upright on its stand, its footprint is very small. All, in all, my experience thus far has been very positive and I highly recommend this model, especially for users with multiple WiFi devices.

column9: Great Router. Just no device running5 Ghz.
column10: Replace my older dlink router. So far no issue, using iPhone connecting to it.Have not try media streaming, or other features yet.

column9: My 16 yr old set this up easily
column10: I bought this to replace my current router which couldn't handle online gaming a pc and various Apple products running at the same time.  We used a MacBook for the initial set up and everything went very smooth. We didn't have any problems connecting other devices.  I like being able to dedicate a network to gaming.

It is a good router. It has good range and a rich feature set. But if you are buying this router to use with an external USB hard drive be warned that it is painfully slow. You can move data from the NSA drive connected to the routers USB port at around 11 megabits per second. That is about 1/3 the speed that you would get if you connected the hard drive to a USB port on your computer, and that's the good news. transferring data from another computer to the hard drive connected to the router averages around 2 megabits per second. That works out to around ten minutes per gigabyte.If you are mostly copying small files to the NSA hard drive, that is a barely tolerable amount of time, but I can live with it. If you are thinking of using the NAS drive to receive large files, for instance Acronis True Image backup files, forget about it. A single file can take over eight hours copy to the NAS drive. It's the closest thing to going back to dial-up modem speeds that you can experience with modern computer technology.If you just want a great WI-FI gigabit router without the NAS hype, then this is a good piece of gear. It sets up easily and it perform admirably. Netgear should disclose the very slow speeds for NAS usage.

column9: Best Router I've Ever owned. Just don't rely on customer service if you have any problems
column10: Awesome product, a pretty sweet upgrade from my old D-link router. I recomend this product highly if you want the best bang for your buck.But...... if you have any problems you're better off looking up a solution on the internet. Customer sercive is horrible took 5 days and having me return a perfectly good router because they said there was a hardware issue. Still they did not solve anything, just had me jump through hoops. They even elevated it to the 'next level' of tech support and said they would call me back in 15 min..... no call, called back the next day and they had closed my case saying it was resolved......Turns out the only problem I had with it was not seting my DSL Modem to Bridge mode (which is a 5 min fix). Once again a problem not solved by a weeks worth of NETGEAR Tech Support calls but just seaching the web (found it on a AT&T forum).But like i said, best router for $100!

column9: Netgear router ok, Netgear Tech Support Horror Story described here:
column10: I forgot the password for my Netgear wireless router, and due to making a change in the Intel wireless adapter window, I lost the connection between the computer and the router, and therefore access to the internet.The written installation instructions of my wireless router do not mention how to reset the password / modem. I did know the default username and password.I called tech support about resetting the router and password. The internet would have given me the answer in a few seconds, i.e. 'press a needle in the tiny hole in the back of the router', but I had no access to another computer at this time, because I live in the country.What happened then is a Tech Support Fraud Story. I was told that the only option I had for 'resetting a password' was to subscribe to either a one-year tech support contract for $ 99, or a life long subscription.I said that for the $99, I could buy a  new modem. The Indian agent at the other end said, literally, that 'this would not help with this issue' (although a new modem comes with a 90 day support, i.e. he lied).I asked him if there is no cheaper way to solve this. He said 'no'. As I said, I live in the country and did not have access to the internet at this moment, and wanted the problem solved.After some back and forth with two more agents, I signed up for the one year support.The tech agent told me to open and close countless windows, and after an hour of this, I was finally told me the solution, i.e. resetting the modem with the needle.When the internet was re-connected, I went straight to the Netgear Tech Support site. There, under the button 'Service Offerings' it states clearly that Netgear offers a 'pay-per-incident' tech support option for $39. I had spoken to four different agents, and none of them told me about this possibility, even when I asked for cheaper alternatives to the '$99 yearly contract'.This means I was lied  to by the Netgear Tech Support agents. They obtained my agreement to this contract based on lying. In my view, they obtained this contract through fraudulent means.I called them back to complain and to ask for a refund. I asked to pay the $39 'pay-per-incident' option instead, and to void the one-year contract that was obtained after not telling me the truth about my tech support options.  The agent answered in a very condescending manner: 'in two months, you will have the same problem again', 'you will be glad to have this contract later on'. He also said that 'everyone who signed up today has signed up for the yearly contract'. This is  no wonder, if the other customers were manipulated in the same way as I was. My request to be put through to the manager / supervisor was ignored, as the agent kept  talking back to me.I have dealt with other computer tech support in India / Asia at previous times, and at no time have I experienced this kind of unethical behavior. I call it fraudulent.So far, messages that I posted on the tech support 'contact' form, as well as an e-mail message to the company here in the US have not been answered.I wonder how many other victims of these 'business practices' are there. I would advise Netgear to clean house in your tech support department.

good quality, strong constant signal optimal for multiple streaming and downloads, the only bad side would be that for some reason some times but not often i lose connection to the internet in my computer but anyone streaming or using wify are ok so i guess it may be just some thing wrong with this particular unit i gat because i have looked into it and haven't found any similar problems.

It's been running smoothly for a month straight without any issues. The only reason I did not give it a 5 star rating is because of the much weaker 5G band. I can run the 2.4G band at 50% power and it is still stronger than the 5G band at 100% power reported by the same laptop. I have a 2008 Dell laptop and a 2011 Mac Book Air (option-click the wifi wave symbol), both show the same effect. Another interesting thing I noticed about the 5G band is that the default channel 44 will show a lower received signal strength than channel 153 but channel 44 would give me much higher data rate than channel 153, typically 270Mbps vs 54~160Mbps.Anther issue I found was that when I bring my laptop out of standby/sleep, sometimes I get a warning or error when it tries to re-connect to the network, I later realized that the router would reassign a new ip address to the device if there was another device that joined the network during the sleep. This problem was easily solved by assigning each device a static ip address through the 'LAN' tab in the router setup page. Hope this tip can help you with reconnect issues.

Update: Now that I have solved my problem with stalled web page loading (Lowered the MTU setting) I must say that my browsing is much faster. All web pages, even those with heavy graphics such as ESPN and NASCAR) load fast. I'm getting 1 gbps on my hardwired PC and up to 300 mbps on my wireless laptop. Very happy with the router overall. I love the USB which I have a large external HDD plugged into. Great for backups and saving files from either of two locations to a single location. No cons as of now. Great price on a refurbished unit that works as good as new.

This router performs well, and was a good upgrade from my previous unit (a Netgear WGR614 b/g wireless router).  The wireless radios on my purchased unit died suddenly after about a month, and Netgear replaced the unit under warranty.  The replacement unit has been trouble-free.  I use the dual-band capability to do some basic traffic management, connecting my Roku XDS streaming media device on the 5 GHz band and keeping laptops, iPods, and other devices on the 2.4GHz band.  The signal is very strong; with a direct line-of-sight to my house, I can keep a wireless connection from nearly 100 yards away.One thing to be aware of is that the LEDs on the unit are very bright.  The router is in my bedroom, and the lights were bright enough to be bothersome at night until I faced the unit toward the wall, which muted the effect.Netgear's tech support was frustrating to deal with.  I'm an IT guy, and when the wireless went bad, I could tell what the problem was.  The wired ports worked fine, so the routing hardware was OK, but a laptop sitting five feet away would get almost no signal.  Netgear tech support went back and forth with me for several weeks, having me upgrade the firmware, and change various settings on the router (such as MTU size)--all of which were a waste of time because the radios were bad.  It got to the point where it seemed like they were just trying anything they could think of to avoid replacing the unit.  Finally I told them flat-out that I wanted it replaced, and they did so.Overall, I am happy with the router, and would buy it again.

column9: Works flawlessly, but make sure to use the right firmware
column10: I had connection problems when I upgraded firmware to V1.0.7.98.After downgrading to V1.0.4.68 everything was okay again.So, if you use this router make sure to use the right firmware.For me this is V1.0.4.68 and the router works flawlessly.

column9: Great Router with Features to Spare
column10: I bought this router to replace an older modem/router combination unit and the difference has been night and day!This router has speed to spare, as well as some fairly advanced routing features I've not even had reason to use.The only quibble I have is that I could not get the auto-setup process to complete on my PC (perhaps due to some combination of Privoxy and other tweaks) although my brother's Mac booted via BootCamp into Windows had no issue whatsoever and had us up and running in less than five minutes!We do not have separate uname/pword combos for the dual bands and have experienced no problems whatsoever.
Signal strength wasn't as strong as hoped but was easy to set up and works good. Perfect for home office use

The router was easy to configure, performs well (all our files are stored on a separate, dedicated NAS), and provides very good signal strength throughout our sinlge-level condo (up to 50 feet).  However, it failed once within the first month of use, losing connectivity to the cable modem.  Cycling power to the router restored operation.  Netgear tech support was unhelpful--all they could offer was to reconfigure the router.  Though the router reported that its firmware was up-to-date, I found and installed a more recent version (V1.0.7.98NA), and the it has since operated for 4 months without failing.

Received, packaged well except for the generic software. (which I have not used)I usually use Netgear after having bad luck w/Linksys 2x.Set up was a breeze as I have set up WEP/WPA/WPA2 on several routers.Set this up w/in 5 minutes.Love the extras on it, like guest wifi for 2.4ghz and another guest wifi for 5ghz. Nice!I have Netgears Access Point/Bridge with WPS and are actually 5ghz as well and boy was it easy using that WPS (after I figured it out LOL!!!) I've gotten transfer speeds of up to 12-14mbs per/sec. Took 24hrs or so to transfer 1 terabyte.Haven't test streaming yet or global access, would be my first time setting that up so I need to figure it out first.I purchased refurb. big risk but seems to be working well!Def. recommend this router to others that like options!Wouldn't really recommend for n00bs though, can seem convoluted!

I upgraded from an old Buffalo HP-G54 running Tomato and I can notice the difference.  Web browsing is so much more responsive!  Games have a lower latency.  I just wish I could run Tomato on it.Just acouple cons.. the ui isn't pretty and looks dated.  I was running Tomato on my old router.I don't want the wireless on all the time.  I prefer to use the button.  The problem is, I have the 5.0 GHz disabled but when you press the button to turn on the wireless, it turns on both.  Also, I don't think you can disable wireless admin access into the router.

I bought a refurb and it arrived yesterday in the mail.  Yes it's annoying that it does not come with the manual, but just download the PDF before you start to hook up the router (i'm assuming this is a replacement :))The setup is the similar GUI to most Netgear routers so if you've done one...you've done them all.  This router was a replacement for my previous NetGear WNR2000...and let me just say it's soooo much better.  I'm getting 4x the download speeds and 2x the upload speeds compared to my old router.  Also to note, the range is also really good.  My apartment isn't too large 1000 sq. feet, but like anybody else that knows about old New York City apartment buildings..the cinder block walls are a little tough for a wifi signal to traverse.I know some people aren't big on refurb items, but I have had really good experiences with Amazon refurbished resellers.

column9: First impressions are very good, be cautious with negative reviews
column10: First off, ignore the old reviews!  Hardware and firmware are upgraded often enough that nothing more than a few months old is likely to be very valuable.Second, ratings for ease of installation are always subject to user knowledge (I've done tech support for more than 20 years) so 'geek speach' for one is 'baby talk' for others... in most cases, it's just a matter of actually READING exactly what you are being told to do instead of the skimming that many users do!Setup - I first installed this using my desktop computer on a wired connection and was up and running in less than 15 mins.  I had another desktop and two three laptops to setup and the only thing I ran into was that in the initial setup of the router I had to enter the full hex key for my wireless network and when I went to connect the wireless devices I had to go back into the router config manually and change the passphrase back to my original 4 letter phrase and tell it to generate the key.  Once that was done everything else connected with no issue.The USB port is nice, but usable for connecting storage only, I would've rather been able to connect a USB printer, but hey... my previous router didn't even have the USB option.Speed - noticably faster, even on my wife's laptop which can only connect to the 2.4Ghz band with a G connection, and on the desktop I keep in the garage with a very old Linksys USB adapter passing through two interior and one exterior wall.Dropped connections - I haven't had any, but be aware that many dropped connections have NOTHING to do with your router.  It could be your ISP, but even more likely is router location and other electronic devices in your home (i.e. Microwaves, garage door openers, cordless phones etc...)When you see a product with so many 5-star reviews, you really have to take the far smaller number of very negative reviews with a grain of salt and look for other reasons why they may have had issues.  In my experience, failure to read and follow directions, lack of patience and failure to pay attention to system requirements lead to most technical issues!Oh, and someone complained about issues using this with Apple devices - if you do your research, you will quickly find that almost all reviewers recommend that you use ONLY Apple routers with Apple devices... they are noted for being VERY proprietary!  People bash Microsoft for 'monopolizing' their market but Apple is far more hardware dependent.  I can build all my own Windows PCs and upgrade them at will, but my Apple friends are tied to their more expensive Apple hardware.Yes, it's more expensive than some other routers, but you get what you pay for and this router delivers.  Again, so far as I can tell, every advertised option works as described so those old firmware 'bugs' cited in the older reviews likely no longer apply and Amazon really needs to consider removing old reviews on computer related devices since anything over a year old is practically a dinosaur!

I've had 2 of these running for about 2 years each. One at home, flawless and only ever had to reboot when I did firmware updates. One at work, it's been rock solid, even in a manufacturing environment with lots of dust and oil in the air.

Purchased this NETGEAR when I need to upgrade/replace an 8 year old router. Arrived quickly, easy to set up and install and have noticed how much faster my internet is with it. Overall very happy with this purchase!
I had to factory reset it since it was used...and turn off cable router including battery and turn on each one separately....but works great now!
Got tis to replace a Linksys router that I just could not get to set up right.  This was easy to set up.
Easy set up for somebody who isn't very tech savvy. I'll never run another ethernet cable through the house again.

My phone companys wireless router would not always work and wouldn't work at all in one of our bedrooms.  We also live in a small house.  I would get extremely frusterated.  Decided to try this out while it was on a lightning deal.  All of the older reviews were quite negative but i noticed the more recent ones were positive.  Lets just say I LOVE this router.  Its been a month now and has never let me down.  Bonus:  You dont have to load any software and it literally took me 2 minutes to plug into my other router.  (The directions confused me at first since it was explained for someone without a pre existing router, but once I realized i could just plug it into the other one, One minute later and done.)I'm not a technical person by any means and this router is idiot proof, literally a child could get it to work.
The unit does it's job. I have only tried it once, waiting for the cable that never came and I reordered. I have faith in Netgear, so should have zero trouble. Thank You

column9: Not a modern router , but will do the job !
column10: This not a modern router but it will work fine ! Some people a obsessed about having the latest technology, and it costs them at least 100-200$ more ! Be realistic there's a limit WiFi can deliver without turning your house into a microwave oven ! Some people buy very powerful routers, however I think having an extender or several hard-wired access stations if the right and more safe solution for a large house.
This router was super easy to set up and has great signal strength all throughout the house and even reaches a good distance outside.
I would recommend this product, because it has worked for me. Didn't want to go the route of having Wi-Fi through a carrier, just wanted to have the router and be done with it. Satisfied.

After two months I am still enjoying this router. It is truly dual band, meaning it has two radios and two antenna systems. It has a very functional admin interface. The gigabit ports perform solidly as well. It has worked well with airplay. I have the appletv connected via ethernet, and my devices connected to the 5ghz band. QOS works well to give high priority to the appletv for streaming while other devices surf.

I have to say, I was a bet skeptical when buying this router. I heard a lot of mixed reviews about it. However, I have to say the investment was worth it. I'm going to break my review down into chronological order to show the 'steps of usage.'--Setup--The setup was very easy. I may be a technical person, but this is something so easy that I would trust even my technologically illiterate grandfather to be able to set up. All the cords are color coded, so that's easy. When you've plugged it in, you pop a cd into your computer and it finishes the setup for you! It doesn't install anything on the computer, so those who are worried about bloatware can be at rest.--Connecting Devices--This router is WPS compliant.
