Fast a Furious. My Comcast connection was slow and I didn't think it was my old router. I was wrong. This new router gives blazing speed allows me to fully use my network. It is easy to use and has all the needed features.

I had a linksys WRT310N router and that was the worst thing I ever bought, so I switch to this Netgear router and I love this thing, I have had many routers and this is the best router I ever purchased, I totally recommend this router to anyone that wants constant connection with no drops in signal, just keep in mind if you have WIN 7 64 bit OS download the installation software from the website before hooking it up, other then that this router ROCKS!!!!!

Was going to buy the Linksys, but got scared by the people who had problems with installation.  Had a Netgear before and it was no problem, so I went with another Netgear.  Glad i did.  I am not a techie, and even for me, the installation etc. was do-able.  Works fast with 4 laptops and a desktop running at the same time.  No hiccups. Didn't use encryption on the old one as i didn't figure out how to do it, but this model incorporates the password into the installation instructions, so it was simple.  To add a laptop, just throw in the password and you are connected.  Sorry this isn't very technical, but for those out there like me....just want to get the job done without stress....it is an easy to hook up, reliable, and I am happy with it.  Only criticism is the appearance.....unit lights up like a Christmas tree!!!!!PS  Desperate for a replacement, so ordered one day shipping......Amazon was amazing.

I just installed this after having several different routers in the past.  I'm very impressed in the range and speed already.  It's not only able to handle 50mb of full bandwidth, it does so with ease while streaming from a few different computers at once.I live in a townhome where my modem is on the top floor (with main router) and different wireless connectors around the house, including the basement.  While my wife watched netflix on my main computer while browsing the internet, I still had incredible connectivity in the basement (3 floors down), when playing XBOX.  The QoS option is pretty reliable as well, for those who like to game.  Throw in your port for XBL and it'll make sure it gets priority over anything else.One of the only problems I had was with the software, which wasn't compatible with 64bit or Windows 7.  If you know much about routers, it's not really a problem.  Just plug it in, go to the standard address and log in with an admin user/pass... the wizard is in there (if you want it).  Nonetheless, setup was still easy.The Dual band option requires a separate SSID and seems to not have as much range for 300 as 150.  Sitting 10 feet from the router I get 4 out of 5 bars, which tends to be standard with dual band 5gz routers.  It still screams from 50-60 feet though.Overall, it's the best router I've used (outside of Cisco 800 series and up).

I bought this router primarily for the wireless N and gigabit local ports.I am a techy and have a Microsoft Windows Home Server that my other desktops and laptops are connected to at home. I recently bought a small pc to connect to my television which would allow me to watch movies that are stored on the home server wirelessly streaming them to my TV. When I tried this with my old wireless G router, I was getting stuttering and lag.I wanted the gigabit ports so that pc backups and large file copies like movies would go as fast as possible.This router has not been a let down. I read some of the negative reviews before buying the router, but a lot of the complaints were regarding features I wasn't planning on using.As soon as I got the router and connected it, I checked for a newer firmware version. One was available. The setup was easy. I don't bother with the setup wizard as I've owned at least six netgear routers over the years and the setup doesn't change much.I like the looks of the router, I doesn't have a bunch or antennae sticking out (none at all, actually), it comes with a stand so you can set it on end, vertically which helps conserve desktop space. It does have holes on the bottom to wall mount it, it that's your desire.I connected two wired pc's and a wired printer to it. They all came up immediately. The port lights come on a green if the connection is gigabit or amber for anything slower.Next I set up the wifi connections. I had no problem at all setting up wireless G and wireless N networks. Right off the bat, I have three laptops, a tv, a wii, and two iphones connected simultaneously. I like that the wireless N and G traffic are actually on separate networks and not slowing each other down at all.After about a week of running flawlessly in this configuration, I decided to try setting up a guest network. The guest network allows you to have a network that is isolated from your internal network so no one on it can access your other computers (unless you choose to open it up), but allows access to the internet. This is handy if you have friends that come over and want to use your wifi to connect to the internet, but you don't want to put them on your internal network. Now they can have access to the internet and nothing else. This feature can also be nifty if you are setting it up at an office and want to allow wifi connections to clients or visitors without them also having access to your sensitive internal computers.I had read some reviews here saying that the guest network didn't work for them. I had no problems at all with it. I really just turned it on and it worked. I left it wide open so that when friends and family come over they can just connect without any passwords or hassle and my network is protected - BRILLIANT!I especially love this feature as I fix a lot of computers and always hated having to setup the pc with my passwords and security settings before I could download updates off the internet.As for the USB device feature, I don't use it at all (as mentioned I have a windows home server) so I can't comment on it.Based on every feature I have enabled and tried, I have had no issues and the router has been rock solid.

this router is basically 100x better than the linksys wrt610n. it has over 3 different SSIDs to customize for certain wireless products. the range is great but still can be improved. price was ok, i still wish to only pay $100 for a router instead of $150. all in all, this product is great and worth getting.

Easy setup, strong reliable 802.11n speeds, simultaneous bands works perfect.Just had a linksys 802.11n router die on me after only 2-3years (while giving me hell for half the time I had it.) This is my first Netgear router, and it works great.Highly recommended.

column9: Best simultaneous dual band router on the market
column10: I actually purchased two of these routers and am extremely happy with them.  They perform as advertised and have a feature-set that far surpases the competition (I'm speaking primarily of the Apple Airport Xtreme and the Cisco WRT610N).  This router has the following features:DynDNS, Guest network, SPI FW, Qos, USB drive sharing, simultaneous dual band N/G, 4-port Gb switchFor detailed info on this device, check out the following link:[...]

column9: Big improvement on the speed and range of the router.
column10: I replaced my Linksys G router with the Netgear Rangemax and couldn't be happier. I download movies from NetFlix and the router works great with the Roku recorder. I can receive my wireless signal even in my yard outside.

column9: Best WiFi router you can buy!!
column10: Perfect for the home user that wants/needs the power and performance.  Extremely easy to install, comes with the most simple step by step instructions and user walk through to get you up and running in no time even if you don't really know what your doing ;) NAS works just as advertised and is such a great benefit.  I'm running all of the networks for various different laptops, B/G/A/N 2.4/5 so I have connected and used all connection types using wpa2-psk aes.  N has an extremely better range than the normal A/B/G.  The best I can get at the far end of the house with A/B/G is around 24mb's but with N I can get between 90 - 120mb's and a very strong connection while the A/B/G is pretty weak. Warning though, after you use N you'll never want to use A/B/G again...

I've had this only two days but it seems to be working great.  Very easy to set up (about 15 minutes)and now my wifi connection to my iPod is 4 times faster than with my old Linksys router. And no more dropouts. To make the setup even easier, I just used my old name and password from the Linksys router. This looks like a winner and I would highly recommend it.
I am very impressed. I needed a new router that avoided NAT issues for use with VOIP applications. This does the trick and has been rock solid since installation. No reservations.

column9: One of the best routers you can get, Loaded with features.
column10: I did a LOT of research before buying this router, if your looking for a top performing router with all the best features this is it. I've been using it for about 3 months, the speed lives up to it's promises I usually have a solid transfer rate. The range is very good, I have not notices a huge improvement with my stock G internal laptop adapter but it's definitely a good 150 - 200 feet through a few walls and a good 80% signal anywhere around the house.I did recently buy the WNDA3100 dual band USB adapter and have never seen the signal go below 90%, I have not tested it but I bet it could go up to 300 feet through a few walls as promised. I always have a good 300 MegaBits/sec wireless transfer rate, and get about 1.5 - 1.8 MegaBytes/sec rate when transfering to/from my USB hard drive I have plugged into the router.I NEVER get dropped connections (like I did every 20 minutes with old my crappy d-link router), and I only have to power cycle it maybe once or twice a month.Some awesome features I like are the ability to add a USB hard drive, and the built in server so you can access your USB hard drive (read and write) from any computers web browser or an Iphone/Blackberry anytime without having to leave your computer on at home. It has a built in Media Streamer so you can stream videos/music/pictures off a hard drive to any computer on your network (I have mine streaming through my xbox 360). There are so many features there is almost no limit.The gigabit ports have super fast transfer rates through the wired connection (at least 6 megabytes/sec) but make sure you have a gigabit lan adapter on each of your devices and use cat6 ethernet cables.I don't like that you can't plug a printer into the usb port to share with your network, but I really don't care since I don't print that much anyways.I spent a bit more money then I wanted to for a router, but I wanted all the best features and I was sick of dealing with cheap routers that didn't work right all the time, so it was totally worth it to get this router. If your highly technologically inclined and have your entire house's tvs/computers/laptops/phones networked you definitely want the best router and this is it. If you just have a few devices and don't need the extra features and mostly are wireless I would go for the WNDR3300 router which costs a lot less and has the same wireless speed and connection.

Although the CD the router came with would not recognize my computer operating system when attempting to load up, I manually installed it without problem. Since then it has been working like a charm. I would recommend this product.

The Good:- Easy to setup- Fast- Good range (using laptop indoors and out)- Attractive design- Lots of data easily seen from just the lights on the front- On/Off switch- My N desktop connects at 300Mbps, unlike my previous router which only ever connected at 130Mbps- Push-button PIN feature- The UI for setup is easy to follow and intuitive- Automatically checks for updates for firmware- Not a single problem with connectivity with multiple devices (mix of G/N desktops and laptops)- EXTREMELY reliable so far. Not a single problem with dropped connections or slowdownsThe Bad:- A bit pricey, but that is relatively offset by how great this product is- It refuses to make sandwiches for me. I have complained to Netgear and they are promising to add that in the distant futureThis is simply a great router. I have had ZERO issues with it, even after a firmware upgrade (unlike that previous D brand I had, which was a nightmare to own). No need to use the setup CD that comes with it. The settings IN THE ROUTER are all well explained in the detail pane and are pretty much self explanatory to begin with. I like the fact that it shows which machine is using UPnP and on which ports (so I can easily track down which machine is doing what when no one is looking). If you are hesitating on this router because of the relatively few bad reviews on it (like people claiming is isn't 64 bit compatible) then hesitate no more! I did a lot of reading on this router before buying it and so far, it as EXCEEDED the reviews I have read.Just a note. Anyone who says this router cannot be used with a 64 bit copy of Windows just simple does not understand what they are doing. This is not an insult, it's just a fact. The setup CD is not needed because you can simply log into the router through its IP address of 192.168.1.1 and set it up from there. It's super easy. Remember.. the router does not care what OS you are using. It only cares about the traffic you are routing through it.Definitely would recommend this to other people. I know it's a tad on the expensive side, but it is worth every penny so far.

I bought this after a lot of research on the Web. Usually I buy immediately after I do my research, but this time I waited before I leaped because of the heavy price tag. I really needed a dual band simultaneous radio router since there are two users in my house - the second laptop is a piece of junk and I was not planning to buy a separate N adapter for it, so I knew it would be using G while I used N. The simultaneous dual radio in this router was ideal for this situation. Note that if you connect with G and N on a single radio router or on a dual but non-simultaneous router, the router will default to the lowest common speed, which is G. So with that, I finally ended up buying it when my old D-Link router dropped me 30 times in 1 day. I have been using this router now for the last 30-40 days and so far so good. BTW I have Windows XP and I am using a WNDA3100 v2 wireless adapter (which I set up AFTER I set up this router).Setup: I had to replace my old router with this one and the color coded steps made it very easy. In fact I did not really follow the steps and ended up disconnecting the old router 1 step before they ask you to and still the process worked fine. I had to restart my router one additional time though, but I see that as my fault for not following instructions. All in all, it is a very simple setup.Features: I use the WPA2-PSK security feature. Thats about it. I have other tools for my monitoring needs and have not tried much of what is offered in the admin portal for the router. However read next.Unintended consequences:1. I have a wireless printer, which was originally setup to recognize my old SSID. So next day when I go to print, obviously it doesnt work. Rather than fooling around with the printer (its HP and very buggy), I thought it may be worth some time to see if I can change the SSID of the new router to that of the old. And needless to say, that is indeed easily done through the portal. Next I went to the printer admin portal through USB connection and changed the security key. A restart on that and we were on.Range: I am about 80 ft away from the router. I am on the 2nd floor, router is on the first. There are numerous walls and a floor in between. Also I have hidden the router behind my solid wood entertainment center. Makes no difference. I get 270MBPS on the router consistently at that distance. Its not 300MBPS. But that is supposed to be normal. I get 300 if I am very close to the router. Frankly, you should not care about this - the difference is not noticeable.Connections: No drops at all. Not a single one. But I should give the kudos on this point to both the router AND the WNDA3100 v2 adapter. They are made for each other.Price: Yes its high, but totally worth it. I have not regretted my decision to purchase.

I first got the Netgear WNDR3700. I chose this because it is much faster than the older 3300 version and a little bit faster than LinkSys WRT610N. I can't find the web site but one really good one did comparisons for different distances and thru walls and floors. The 3700 replaced a 2.4 Ghz D-Link G router. The D-Link was very complicated to set up a couple years ago but the Netgear was so simple and automated. Follow directions exactly on when to power on/off and disconnect. I picked the 3700 because it had 5 GHz.I used this with WNHDEB111. I bought the pair to use with my HDTV. It was tested to be faster than  the powerline ethernet adapters. I used one WNHDEB111 as a bridge to a Panasonic Plasma G10 in the bedroom (thru 1 wall about 20 ft away) and used the other as a bridge to a Sony 46z5100 LCD in my living room (thru 1 wall about 45 ft away). Have streamed HD and regular movies from Netflix with no problems. Setup was also very easy. Directions aren't straight forward but once you understand that all one has to do is push a button on the B111 then push one on 3700, they automatically sync up. Easiest network setup I've ever had!I've also used wireless with 2.4GHz with my son on X-Box 360 with no problems.

I bought this router after I had major problems with a Linksys always having IP address conflicts with the security settings always resetting to default and having connection problems. This router was so easy to setup. My house is full of wireless and wired machines. I have video game systems and laptops/pc's everywhere. I have excellent connection speeds and I honestly have to say it is well worth the money for the router. I have not had 1 problem with the router. I honestly have to say that most of my laptops/pc's run Vista 64 bit or higher and the installation CD won't work with those. Instead you can go to their website and actually get the software for the newer OS. I love the speeds and it actually broadcasts those speeds because it is a gigabit ethernet router both on wireless and wired. I love the USB port because I have a 2 TB external hard drive connected for a network backup drive. All my computers are setup to backup to this drive and it works perfectly. I love this router and am excited to see new enhancements coming to this router and more coming from Netgear.
Great product. Thought it was a little pricey but it had the features I wanted. I like that it has a guest network and I can access my external hard drive.

A great wireless router, super easy to setup I had it installed and working in twenty minutes, it replace may previous netgear g router, have had for over a month and not one problem with it, the price is a little high but worth it.

This is a pricey router, and I know I would have been OK with a cheaper option, but I am thinking of the future and wanted to have a router that will not obsolesce in a couple of years.  I was lured by the dual frequency, the gigabit ports and, particularly, the ability to have a guest network.  On top of that, I liked the on/off button and the possibility of turning off the transmission when not in use.  The router has performed great in all fronts except one, which I'll cover later.  Installation was a breeze. The guest network is fantastic.  No more jitters with providing your password to visitors.  Gigabit ports: this is a feature designed for businesses.  I have no equipment (nor internet connection) that reach that throughput... but I might in the future.  I really like how easy it is to turn the transmitter or the router off; in addition, you can adjust the energy of the signal by frequency, which also saves energy.  It most likely saves only pennies in amonth, but it feels good to avoid wasting energy. The ability to connect an external storage unit is yet another plus. The only feature that puzzles me is that the 5 Ghz signal is not as strong as the 2.5 Ghz one.  I find that weird, but irrelevant.  I find that my connection drops sometimes, but I would bet that's more a problem of Windows 7 than the router's.  I just have to click on the connection icon on Windows and it fixes it right away.  I read a lot of reviews before deciding for this model.  Both Netgear and Linksys have spotty issues according to the reviews.  I upgraded from another Netgear router that worked great until... I 'upgraded' to Windows 7.  That one worked fine for years, so I wanted to stick to Netgear. So far, I am happy. I feel I am covered for years to come.  Overall, a solid piece of equipment.  And gorgeous! I would recommend it to anyone who wants a solid, flexible wi-fi experience.  One final comment: read some reviews that bash Netgear's customer service.  I haven't experienced their customer service, but that's the same frustrating experience I am getting from almost every company/brand I need to call.  Company's don't have an idea how much damage they are doing to themselves by underestimating the importance of customer service, and over-estimating the ability of overseas sweatshops to perform such a critical, strategic function.  In order to save a few bucks today, they are alienating their customers and jeopardizing their own future.  Trust me: no cost saving is worth putting your customers, your bread and butter, through hell.

column9: Easy instalation and idiot proof use
column10: My first router and it works flawlessly so far. I'm not sure I need the dual network capability or range offered by this model, but it's nice to have. Router is plug and play, and no real installation is required. It comes with a software disk but you don't need to use it. Turning it on and off it takes about 10 seconds to reconnect. I like the glossy black of the unit and the fact that you can lay it flat or stand i on its side, a nice space saving feature. I do wish that they had a power button in front or on top of the unit rather then in back, but it's not a big deal. The unit works fine with my LG390's built in N adapter, my Tivo G adapter and my Xbox live N adapter. All connect with ease and I have not experienced any problems.

column9: Outstanding! but BEWARE of the firmware upgrades!
column10: Arguably, This is one of the best home networking routers out there, but with a CAVEAT. To my router experience, no existing home networking router can beat this one. I have been using it for a month now and have never felt better about using wireless but beware of upgrading the firmware.The previous day, I upgraded to newer firmware only to rollback to initial version 1.x.31N.I have setup NAS (Network Attached Storage, a.k.a Ready Share by Netgear) after installing the router. The initial firmware was great, working fine with NAS. Logged on to the router the previous day and it suggested the availability of newer firmware and asked if i would upgrade and i happily hit the upgrade button.Now starts the issue after upgrading to version 1.x.49N, the router started dropping packets and the internet connection altogether. Then upgraded to 1.x.55N and it again started crapping out on me. Internet connection used to drop and i had to reboot my router (loop this sentence a few times). Can someone imagine how frustrated i was? This thing wasted my precious couple hours.Later rolled back to initial version and it started working as before with no issues with internet and NAS.Few GOLDEN rules worth mentioning here:1. People's time counts, so enough testing must be done before releasing firmware.2. If encouraging to upgrade to newer firmware, one MUST provide appropriate instructions along with rollback instructions and make the previous firmware versions available at disposal, so that people don't have to waste time searching for them in case they need to rollback.3. It is advisable to list chronological versions of firmware the router had, when logged on to the router using [...]4. If good sales are expected at the prices one is expecting and targeted for non techies/common people, the product must be flawless. Tech junkies like me can fiddle things out. Do Apple products ring a bell?Bottom-line:Would prefer this router over Linksys routers, with which i had numerous signal issues. My home is now tangle free. It is a next generation router with Gigabit capability and should last long. Expensive, but will cover the price of changing many routers over next few years. Heed my advice and do NOT upgrade to newer firmware versions unless they are stable.
Works flawlessly. So far only have it operating a PS3 but it is at the other end of my house and you can't tell the PS3 isn't hardwired. Next will get a netbook to hook into it. Buy it and love it!

I turned to Netgear after struggling with and returning three Linksys/Cisco wireless routers that Cisco tech support decreed defective.  The Netgear WNDR3700 got a very credible rave review on [...] and the feature set more than met needs.  The Netgear router has a solid, no nonsense feel, better range than any of the many Linksys routers I've used over ten years and web based configuration utility really works.Pros: Good ranges, 'green' features, easy to set up separate networks, solid performance.Cons: Minor dings here: - The desktop setup reported my Windows 7 64-bit as an unsupported OS, so I had to use the 'advanced' setup by going directly into the web interface. - Because the wifi network defaults to open (as it does with all makers), I picked up an intruder before I could apply the security. - While the feature is very welcome, the push-button power on/off switch is easy to bump by accident.  A slide switch would be a better design for an appliance like this. - The power cable slips out easily.  It should be tighter and some sort of safety clip would be good.  I use a small strip of Gorilla tape. - The status lights are very bright; a dim setting would be a nice 'green' feature

Expensive but you get what you pay for.  My suggestion is to leave out using the disk, set it up, and log into the IP address and make the settings you want.  Has work flawlessly for a month.  Very easy setup also.

column9: The Best I have ever had
column10: I am not tech savvy. I just read all the reviews for a dual band router and this one sounded like the easiest one to install.I got it.I plugged it in.I followed the instructions (VERY EASY and simple).I set up a secure wifi connection throughout my house.It took a total of 10-20 minutes.It has worked reliably since installation 6 weeks ago.I have not had a single issue.I would highly recommend for a very fast and very simple wireless dual band router.

Netgear got it right with this model.  Adjustable power output, 802.11nfinal,gigabit wired ports.  Speed is better than expected.  Set up and adjustmentsare easy and each area of the setup has unique explanation/example/helpsection to guide you.  I set up the router manually, but it looks like thesetup CD will guide you through a normal setup with ease.  Storingconfiguration changes is slower than expected and you must be patient (very), but changesbecome effective immediately.  The guest account feature is valuable if youwant to share your wireless with friends or clients.  It protects yourprivate network while allowing them access to the Internet.

Overall this has been a good router so far. The only problem I have had is with using the USB port for an external disk. Supposedly firmware 1.0.4.49NA fixed problems with this, but it appears that there are still problems in this area. The only stability problem I had was when I attached a drive (just to check it out) - the router would periodically hang. As I have a dedicated NAS, I just left the drive off. From published performance results in test reviews, I wouldn't plan on using this router as a NAS anyway.When a drive is not attached, I have not had a single stability problem in the month or so I have been running it - the only time it was down was one power outage that exceed my UPS backup time.The wired ports worked great, and as most of my boxes have gigabit ports, I have noticed the improved speed. The different colored port status lights allow you to see at a glance whether you are running at 100 or 1000. (I was able to visually identify one marginal cat 5 cable and replace it.)It is running behind a DSL modem in bridge mode - i.e., it does the PPoE login. No problems. I have DMZ set up to the NAS which runs a web server as well as a common file/backup server. External access through the DMZ is fine.Wireless has both 2.5 and 5GHZ set up. I have run with both WPA/TKIP and WPA2/AES (at different times) with no problem. I have not done any specific distance or speed tests with the wireless so I can't comment on that. Also, I have not extensively tested the QoS or UPnP functions.There appears to be work in progress to bring dd-wrt up on this box which would allow additional features (like VPN) - I wouldn't expect this to be available until mid 2010 at the earliest. However, the factory firmware appears to work fine unless you need the extra features.The price is a little expensive but you get both gigabit ports and simultaneous dual band wifi. All in all, I am glad that I spent the extra money to get this model.UPDATE: After experimenting with wireless range a little I can verify the many comments that 5G is poor. At about 50 feet and through 2 walls I get about twice the speed on G (at 2.5) as I do with N on 5G. (In the same room about 10 feet away, I get good throughput on 5G, however.) I still like the router because of its stability (so far) and the gigabit ports, but don't expect the 5G capability to be a lot of use to you.

C-Net did not have a 4 or more star rating (3.5) on it but since a great portion of customer feedbacks were positivewherever I searched online, I chose this one.  It took a while to arrive from Amazon but not too long while I could not find it on BestBuy or Fry's shelves which suggested it is definitely selling good. Generally the negative feedback was on less important features for me or as is geneally true, many people just do not know how to operate or optimize the router and fail to get it working correctly.The set up was a breeze for me (I am a techi and am using Win 7 Ultimate 64-bit) through the web interface which has help documentation automatically avaialble for any feature that one wants to set up.  I used the documentation on the CD as well and the documentation was pretty good. I have both channels (2.5 and 5) operating with a guest netwrok, basically three wireless networks at once.  All my devices have 802.11G cards (PS3, Tivo, laptops) and the router is located on the edge of the house (I can not set it up centrallyany). Still I get coverage at all the places (100+) though the 5GHz network has smaller range. I presume if I had the N standard for my wireless devices, the range and throughput could have been better.Per other comments and reviews, the 5 GHz range is a bit disppointing in terms of the range. I do not have a use for the USB but I have heard that the throughput is slow (have to try it once but I do not care about that). Appart from wireless features (it supports all security standards), this is a fast reliable router as well and I believe it should be able to handle many devices at once (I have 10-11 devices connected at once to it).  That was one of the reasons I purchased this because of the faster processor and the ability to handle many devices at once (I had noticed my previous router could choke on taht).I use a ADSL modem (5Mbits/600Kbits) and I have not had any disconnection through the router which I use it to dial the dsl account (dsl modem is in bridge mode). All standard routing features are available for set up through the web interface like port forwading, DHCP address reservation, content filtering, Dynamic DNS, QoS, etc.Overall, I have had this router for about 10 days and aside from the range of the 5GHz channel, I have not noticed anything to complain. On the price, It is somewhat expensive but again $160 on a piece of equipment that connects you to the rest of the world and connects all devices at your home together is not much assuming it works fine which this one has done so far.I recommend this product to those that not only want wireless connectvity but also great/reliable routing functionality.

column9: Best router I own by far!
column10: The initial setup was very easy, and even with all the port forwarding and various other settings I had to tweak I was up and running in well under 10 minutes. Within a few more minutes I had updated the firmware which also went very smoothly.The user interface is adequate for what I use it for. It doesn't have the bells and whistles of dd-wrt, which isn't compatible with this router at the time of this review. Even if dd-wrt was available I would probably still hesitate and think before upgrading as the router is very stable and does what it is supposed to at this point.The network connection is a solid and unwavering 300Mbps, and I even noticed better bandwidth as far as downloads go. The guest networks worked fine for me when I tested it by flawlessly connecting a Sony PSP.I would highly recommend this router. Its better than anything Linksys is putting out at the moment....I refuse to buy another Linksys router after a string of disappointments.For those that left negative reviews, please check your settings again or RTFM. I've had nothing but a good experience and can't imagine why that would change from one user to the next unless they received a defective unit.

Bought the WNDR3700 over a month ago. Installed easily and manually configured a dual-band network for N and G in just a few minutes.Range is improved, but N still drops in speed as distance from the router increases. Better G reception than my previous router.Not disappointed at all - has worked flawlessly and was a good investment.

This was my first experience with a wireless router.  It pretty much worked right out of the box. I didn't use the setup disk as I already had experience setting up routers and switches. I brought up the web page interface to the router and it immediately recognized that my DSL modem used an IP that was the same as the default IP for the router. The software automatically configured the IPs for the router and attached computers to a non-conflicting IP range. From there it was just a matter of following instructions and entering the settings. The two wired XP computers connected with the router right away as they were already set up to get their IPs and DNSs from the router after I edited the settings to Zone Alarm to accommodate the new network IP range. I then fired up the new laptop computer with Win 7, it recognized the new WNDR3700 router and after entering SSID and passwords for the router we were up and running. So far, there have been no problems with the router, but Win 7 gave us fits for awhile until I set up the laptop/router combination to use a static IP for laptop.I'm pleased with the range of the router. I've got it set up on a far wall downstairs to be close to my DSL input and wired computers on the network.  The G/N band 2.4 Ghz signal is very strong everywhere in the house, and the 5 Ghz N band signal is also strong enough to use anywhere in the house. We use the 5 Ghz band to avoid interference with our 2.4 Ghz wireless phones.  Connectivity seems to be a lot better with the WNDR3700 then it was with the old LINKSYS BEFSR41. During the day we often were disconnected from our DSL connection with the LINKSYS and had to force a reconnection. So far with the WNDR3700, the connection has been very stable.

If you read my previous review of the Linksys WRT400N wireless N router, you understand how pleased I am with this Netgear router.  I can't say anything bad about this router and can only say fantastic things.  After receiving this router, I installed it and was up and running within 20 minutes.  I have no dropped uploads or downloads, great speed, and tremendous range.  Configuring the router was easy and monitoring the status is easy as well.If you are looking to upgrade to a wireless N router, go nowhere else but Netgear!

This is the sixth router I've owned in the last 2 years including a Linksys WRT400N and 610N and this NetGear is by far the best.  Why so many routers?  I have a very demanding network setup including numerous computers, Xbox 360, all running Windows Media Center, plus six wireless security cameras, iPhones, two DirecTV DVR's running MRV (multi-room-viewing) across the network, etc. All must work properly on the network and I've found issues with the other routers but not this NetGear.  Recent upgrade to my cable internet to 40/5 Mbps speeds necessitated a replacement router that could keep up.  Went with the buggy WRT610 which has major security issues where it would just spontaneously revert to factory defaults leaving an open 'LinkSys' network, returned that, and got the WNDR3700.  This is the fastest, most stable router I've ever owned and has by far the greatest range!

This router replaced my solid and dependable (but not quite so inspired) Linksys WRT54GL.Its hard to know where to begin with the comparisons - if the WRT54GL is a Toyota Camry, then the WNDR feels like a Lotus Elise.Right from the outside, there is a sleekness to the device, that I haven't associated with routers in a very long while. When you have its nine lights blinking various shades of amber, blue, and green, its almost like geek heaven! There's just as much of a generational difference on the inside.Here's a quick synopsis of this review encapsulated in one word - 'Wow!!!' - hence the 5-star rating.Now, let's dig into the details.Installation:####################This was by far the easiest intall process I've had with a wireless networking product. The software is truly neophyte-friendly, and is complete with animations of the removal of power plugs and connection of ethernet cables. This is an impressive feat and will very likely meet the needs of most first time networkers.Unfortunately, the software won't run under Vista 64-bit.In addition, it got confused when trying to investigate the final setup as I had not powered on my router. Even though I hastily corrected that situation, it simply hung there for an eternity - and committed the cardinal sin of not letting me abort the interrogation.Fortunately, after I killed and restarted the process, it very kindly allowed me to skip the preliminary steps and proceeded to successfully verify the network details.Configuration:###################The setup software was also smart enough to accept key configuration parameters such as the network SSIDs for the two networks (it is true dual band after all), as well as network security parameters.The user-friendliness of the setup routine was apparent in how the wireless security options are displayed, in increasing order of security (WEP64 through to WPA2).One silly design decision, was that it wouldn't accept a passphrase that contained special characters. As a workaround, I specified a simpler password here, and updated it to the final version later.A nice touch was the automatic registration built into the setup process which even retrieved the device's serial number - which is often painful to transcribe correctly.Firmware Update:######################Another example of Netgear's thoughtfulness is the seamless manner in which the router updated its own firmware. On the very first access to the web based administration utility, it automatically detected that I had outdated firmware, and without any further ado, downloaded and installed the latest version, with no user intervention!Advanced Features:########################This router has every imaginable feature that I could ask for, in a single package.1) Worried about sharing your network passphrase with guests wishing to use your network? Worry no longer. The WNDR lets you setup two guest networks, with or without encryption.2) How about installing a NAS device accessible from the various computers in your home? This little WNDR lets you connect and share any USB drive. As a bonus, you can access files over the Internet using a standard browser or FTP client.3) Upset that you have to leave a computer on in order to stream media to your TV or gaming device? The WNDR is a DLNA compliant media server. Simply copy media files over to the attached USB drive!4) Want to discover why you *need* a hardware firewall? The WNDR has detailed logging that lets you see what and who is knocking at the gates of your firewall castle. You'll see entries such as port scanning that have the potential to make you hyper-paranoid.5) Want to keep tabs on your Internet usage stats? The WNDR will do it for you using its nifty traffic meter.6) Want to restrict when the kids can use the Internet? No problem.If its something you can name (say, support for dynamic DNS), then there's a good chance that this router will let you do it.Conclusion:################My only complaints relate to areas that aren't directly connected to the router itself or are not quite so critical - hence my decision to award it a full complement of 5 stars.First, the manual, while sufficient for normal setup descriptions, is woefully deficient when it comes to the advanced features. Be prepared to spend time online if you need to get the most out of this device.Second, while you can access your NAS drive over the Internet, you cannot upload files using the HTTP interface. Furthermore, the only choice when securing it, is to use the router's admin password - a silly decision.Third, adding a read password seems to disable the media server - my PS3 couldn't even detect it any more.Finally, I had trouble with accessing a password protected NAS drive via Windows Explorer, until I simply recycled the notebook, router, and modem while I was on hold with a rather confused tech support agent. The problem then mysteriously went away.Despite these minor blemishes, this is a wonderfully designed product, and is worthy of all the attention that it has received.Happy Networking!

column9: I'm really glad I spent the money for this
column10: I've had a lot of trouble finding a router which would give me flawless wireless-N (i.e. high speed) connectivity.  Reading the reviews of routers in the $50-100 range, or even more, it's been distressing to see how many suffer dropout problems, in particular.  I had another brand router that frequently dropped out on me, finally conking out altogether after about four months.  Reading the reviews on this item prompted me to buy it, despite the higher price (about 160), and I'm really glad I did.  Setup was extremely easy; the disc walked me through step-by-step even to the level of telling me when to unplug the current router and replace the new one.  Setting up a secure signal was simple too.  The whole process took maybe a half hour.  Since then, in two months I don't think I've had a single dropoff, and the bandwith (which I check periodically using an online tool) has been consistently strong.  It also has worked consistently sending a signal to my wireless printer about 30 feet away on the other side of my condo.  The other cool feature which I didn't even think about when I bought it is the USB port; my external hard drive now is plugged into it so I can backup files to it wirelessly.The best thing I can say about the router is that I no longer think about having to get a better router.

I had the DIR-655 which started to give me problems ever since upgraded to the latest firmware.  I havwe several laptops and a wireless printer as well as my gaming consoles and media server connected via wireless. I have a two floor house with the router upstairs, and most of the use downstairs. My media server, printer, and hard-drives are upstairs.  The DIR-655 was working fine, though sometimes some of the laptops would have spotty reception. I now use one of the bands with the WNDR3700 for the media serving and the other for laptops. I also have my vonage VOIP connected to the router.  BTW I am using this behind a AT&T Uverse router/modem. So far no issues. My xbox 360 using Windows Media Center extender no longer stutters and NetFlix always shows HD when available. My laptops also now have full-bars and no longer have intermittently slow internet connections, as I sometimes had with the DIR-655. overall, i am pretty satisfied with the purchase. I have been using it for almost a month at the time of this review.

This router is reliable with dual band feature.  I have quite a few wireless electronics requiring wi-fi reception, the dual-band is nice for this purpose.  I have not found any problems with this router yet.  I expect it will have none in the future.

This router is excellent bang for your Buck. Its inbuilt media server works amazingly well with my PS3. Not to mentioned I've attached a 500GB external hard drive, and creating a wireless network is a breeze. I moved from Linksys G-router and so far I've got absolutely no complaints. I have my older Win XP PC running on 2.4Ghz, while my Thinkpad runs at 5Ghz at the same time without any issues. My PS3 recognizes the 2.4Ghz connection and not the 5Ghz, still I'm able to stream movies wirelessly from the attached USB storage on my router to my LCD TV without any issues or interruptions. I would recommend it over DLink or Linksys, if you need attached storage.If you looking for Dual band router that doesn't drop your connection very often. This is for you.

This is my first Wireless N Router. I purchased this after some fairly good online search. I have to mention that I'm not a big gamer. So, I do not know how this will perform for gaming. But download speed was my biggest factor to consider. Regardless of whether I really download that much or not, I wanted one that supports very good download speeds and helps me make the best use of my internet connection speed.This router excels in all that I expect of it. Set up is fairly easy. I did not expect to have much flexibilty in controlling or configuring the Router. But this router has a great set of features that can be configured and controlled very easily through a web page. Spam control can also be enabled. One important thing is not to forget the Router login credentials. If the password is forgotten, then only way to set a new password is to reset the router completely. A CNET Review mentioned that the Router does not perform all that well in the 5GHz band. I cannot comment technically, but from a layman's perspective - it performed ok. I was able to download approx 3.5 GB of data in about 30 minutes, using the 5GHz mode. (The modem I've used is Motorola's SB6120 DOCSIS 3.0 Cable Modem.)Overall, I am very satisfied with the router !!

I had this router set up in minutes. It could hardly have been easier. I think about all of the time I spent on the setup of my old 802.11g router, and I am thankful that technology has become easier to deal with.I set up the 5 GHZ and 2.4 GHZ networks and connected my devices wirelessly. My laptop is about 35 feet away with a couple of walls in between, and the 5 GHZ network signal alternates between Very Good and Excellent. If I connect the laptop from more than about 50 feet, the signal drops to Good, and it gets iffy around 65 feet.I can't believe how this has improved my 2.4 GHZ range. I have a Roku Radio set up downstairs and on the other side of the house from the router. With my old Linksys Wireless G router, the Roku was getting signals in the -75 dBM range at best. In fact, it dropped out quite a bit, and I got a range extender and set it up downstairs fairly close to the radio. That improved the signal to an average of about -50 dBM. When I set up this new router in the same place as the Linksys, I got rid of the range extender, and checked the Roku signal. It had improved to -43 dBM. I couldn't believe it, so I checked it several other times over the next few days. The worst signal I got was -49 dBM. The signal quality hovers around 99% which is also much better than it was with the old router and range extender (90% or so).The Quality Of Service (QOS) features of the router work great as well. You can set it up using MAC addresses, ports, or a few other criteria. I connected my Ooma phone system to a port and tested it out. I was getting some latency and annoying feedback. I then set up the QOS for that port to give it 'highest' priority. I checked the phones again, and they were as clear as a bell. I had not experienced VoIP that clearly until that point.This router has easily handled everything we've thrown at it. I was using my laptop to wirelessly backup my desktop while one kid was wirelessly streaming Netflix using the Roku Netflix player, the other was using his iPod Touch on WiFi, and my wife was on the Ooma phone. Nobody had any hiccups at all. I'm very satisfied with this purchase, and I hope it remains reliable.

I brought this router because I wanted the best router to stream netflix to my tv using an HDMI cable.  This is a Draft N verson 2 (5gig) so it can stream at 300 mps. It also operates on  version 1 is at 150mps, and on the G standard (54mps)I like this router.  I never have had trouble with it.  It's range is great (even though I only have a 800 SQ apartment (more than enough for a G) I have recived my singal at the end of my hallway which must be about 400 to 500 ft away.  However that was only on the 2.4 gig band.  the 5 GIG band does have less interfearance but it has rather short range but is faster.  Due to the lack of interfearence and the fact I'm close I constantly recive a 270 mbs singal. (thats because thats all my wireless adapter in my laptop can take in.To give you a feel I can download from this router wirelessly HP software an avg of 400MB in about 2 min's and I'm downloading more than 2MBS IT'S ACTUALLY 2.30 MPS wirelessly which is awsum.  T;ve tried the linksys routers and the dlink and I've have found that this router produces the best bandwith output to my laptop.With this router there is a lot more custom control you can do over the linksys routers. This router just like other higher end routers has DHCP Reservation, you can adjust the QOS via ip address or Mac address and I have no problem reading my print server static when it's outside the DHCP range.I did have an issue but I also know that my oringnal wireless print server was a defect from e-bay but the issue would have made sense.  Most of your print servers operate on the G standard.  this router operates on 2.4 which is G and N 150 (verson1)  And this router also operates on the 5 gig standard. which means if your laptop is on the 5 Gig side It might be considered on a different network than what your print server is on so you might not be able to communicate with your printer unless your laptop or wireless comoputer is on the 2.4 band and which again is the (N Verison 1) or G standard.  Again this print server was a defect from e-bay it froze up so I may not be accurate because my other thought is if the print server is commicating with the router wirelessly the router should be issuing the commands on both bands. I didn't try another wireless print server. I'd like to because I'm curious. but first I need to get a working one from the store.What I did to resolove the issue was get a wired print server set it up static and it communicates with my 5 year old G standard laptop, and my N standard laptop at 5 Gigs which means I can opeerate on both bands at the same time wired.I recomend this router I think it's stable and fast it has great range.  For most of you that do care only about the basics one flaw it does have is it has a slow boot up time thing but oh well. other than that one of the best routers I've had

column9: Best router I have ever owned
column10: I have owned a router from every major company over the years but so far this is easily the best I have ever owned.  Even under extremely heavy load this router doesn't get bogged down.  I have a mixed network with a computer connecting at a 2.4ghz N speed, a 5.2ghz full 300mbps speed, and an old wireless G connection.  All function perfectly at the same time.  I do not notice any performance hit on my 20mbit internet connection due to the router.  So, in short, its expensive but I highly recommend this.

I recevied this gift from my wife this christmas!! Wow...I was the happiest kid ever. This is an awesome router it controls everthing,I have my laptop's running on the 2.4g GHz G network and video (netflix) on 5 GHz N network with a NAS hookup thru a the GB ports. I highly recommend this router....

column9: Great for Roku and Netflix streaming
column10: I recently purchased a Roku (streaming movie) box to watch Netflix movies on.Using my old router, a Netgear WPN824v2, either in wired or wireless mode, the Roku box provided what can only be kindly called poor performance.  I could only get two 'dots' out of a possible four, for movie quality... and downloads were frequently interrupted by long pauses while I waited for the movie stream to catch up.Thinking I could partly improve the situation with a new router, I did some research and decided to get the Netgear WNDR3700.This router didn't just provide 'partly improved' performance; it delivered impressive results and solved my Roku problem completely.  On the Roku box I now get the highest quality, streaming HD movies with no interruptions.  And that is in wireless mode, penetrating at least four walls from one end of the house to the other.  My Internet browsing and downloads are also considerably faster;  here, all along, I thought I had been getting the maximum bandwidth possible from my ISP.  The Netgear WNDR3700 proved me wrong.The attached USB drive feature is also nice, though it requires a little bit of configuration.  As a browsable share, it's a little slow, but reasonable for automated backups (and may be as a media share but I didn't test it that way).Your own experience in speed improvements may vary depending on your ISP's bandwidth caps or what router you previously used.  But for me, this router has delivered an excellent performance improvement.  In increased speed alone, it's already paid for itself.

After upgrading to a 50Mbps Internet Connection, I discovered that my old WRT54G v3 could not handle LAN/WAN switching faster than 22Mbps.  I selected the WNDR3700 after quite a bit of research because of its excellent performance as shown at [...].  I have not been disappointed. Despite the relatively short amount of time that this unit has been on the market, it has impressively stable firmware.The one con is that NetGear technical support is almost useless if your hardware fails. I had to deal with them recently after a Netgear GS108 GigE Switch failed after one week. I ended up throwing away the Netgear switch and buying a Dell PowerConnect 2708 instead.
If your looking for a router that's easy to set up, fast and has great range then Netgear WNDR3700 is it. I'm completely satisfied with mine.

I bought this router to replacing an aging Netgear WGR614, which was starting to have DNS server resolution issues.  The good reviews, gigabit switch, and the N feature really appealed to me.  I have been running this for almost 2 weeks and have been very impressed.  The router setup was almost identical to my old 614 (in manual mode), which made it a breeze.  In addition to the security encryption, I really like the ability to not broadcast the SSID and limit the connecting computers/devices via MAC address - keeps most of the novice hackers in the neighborhood out.  My daughter and son's laptops (running Vista 32 and 64 bit versions) have connected flawlessly and the newer computer is pinging away at 300K Mbps consistently.  Wireless range or dropping signal has not been an issue.  The wired computers are all running gigabit speeds without problems, but I'm not pushing tons of data or streaming over them either.  Have not tried the guest account features since I don't have a requirement for that function.  Unlike others, I've never had issues with Netgear's customer service.  Little bit on the pricey side, but I would recommend the router to others.

column9: Great replacement for my old G router
column10: I purchased this router because it had all of the features I was looking for - Dual Band, Wireless N, USB Storage, and Media Server. If I had written a review a week ago, it wouldn't have been as positive. Everything about the router worked great except for an issue where the unit would lock up if you connected a USB drive that had a lot of media files. This was a known issue by Netgear (it's posted on their website) and the only workaround was to disable the Media Server feature. Since the Media Server functionality was one of my top reasons I purchased the WNDR3700, I was disappointed this did not work. Fortunately Netgear has just released updated firmware on 12/16 and it seems to have resolved the problem.Performance has been great. This router replaced an older Linksys G router and the range on the WNDR3700 is much better. I have several wireless G devices connected on the 2.4 GHz band (Wii, Roku Soundbridge, cell phones, printer, and a few laptops) and have had no problems at all. I have another laptop connected using wireless N on the 5 Ghz band and it connects at 270 or 300 Mbps and maintains a solid connection during use. I have also found the router to work well with VPN on both mine and my wife's laptops.I use Vonage VOIP and have had no problems. Unlike my old Linksys router, I did not need to configure any QOS for the VOIP. As a matter of fact, I was using the phone for quite some time while I was in the process of transferring around 75GB of files to the USB drive attached to the router and did not experience any delays, dropouts, or quality issues with the VOIP.The USB storage and Media Server capabilities are key features for me. Beside needing a Wirelss N router, I also wanted to replace my aging NAS that I use for backups. I'm still in the process of setting up backups for my PCs, but so far the transfer rate seems adequate. It took about 2 or 3 hours to transfer around 75GB of data using SyncToy (Microsoft utility). A few things I picked up on various sites/forums: Netgear notes a known issue with write speeds on NTFS formatted drives so I formatted my new USB drive as EXT3 (this is a common file system used with Linux). If you have slow transfers, do a search for 'Remote Differential Compression'.I often like to stream music to my Roku Soundbridge. Previously I always needed to turn on one of my PC's to serve up my music. The Media Server feature in the WNDR3700 eliminates that need. I haven't used this feature extensively yet, but streaming music to my Roku worked great and was actually quicker at buffering the music and selecting songs.Overall this is a great router and I can easily recommend it. The new firmware resolves the Media Server/USB problem and also adds setup support for Win7 and 64bit OSes (see Netgear site for details).

I purchased this for my houses on the Caribbean. The houses are approximately 60 feet apart, the router is in the back house, on the second floor. Signals are still strong on the beach, which is another 40 feet from the front house. Speed is excellent, signals are strong, worked even with my older Mac computer as well as the newer PC. My renters are extremely pleased too!  I would recommend this router especially for anyone upgrading from an older one (my original Lynksys that was about 4 years old.)I give this 5 stars, even if you don't want to work on your Caribbean vacation, you can!

I live in a plaster walled house which has always had difficulty with WiFi. This router pushes through it with little difficulty and gives good signal strength throughout the house. Previously (802.11b) this required two access points. Features include everything that you would expect in a router like this including a few extras like USB drive sharing. It may be an expensive unit, but it's worth every penny.Note: I'm a computer professional, so my perspective on ease of use may be a bit skewed. However, the router automatically detected that Verizon was using the 192.168 IP range and reconfigured itself to avoid conflicts. I would call that very user friendly. The device practically configures itself.

We upgraded from a Belkin Pre-N Router to the Belkin WNDR3700.1.  It was easy to set-up. Nice, clear instructions on the install CD; Also, the color coded cables make it easier too. If we can set-up this thing, almost anyone can (smile).2.  Have only used it for a day, but works great.3.  Very pleased with purchase.  (did not purchase at amazon.com, but may have if it were not out-of-stock at the time).Only complaint is, it is a bit over priced. We feel it should only cost about $99, but what do we know. ;)

I researched wireless routers a month ago in preparation for a purchase. Then, in the meantime, my son-in-law's router died so he needed a new one. I told him about this model. He'd never used Netgear in the past but also checked the reviews on Amazon, bought, and immediately started raving about this product. So I bought this month with high confidence.I have to say that the product is even better than I expected. Setup was a breeze at 30 minutes. That's for the router and testing the 7 network devices (mix of wired and wireless) we use in our home. Everything worked like a charm. In that short time we have 3 network signals to use. High speed wireless, lower speed wireless, and a lower speed Guest wireless signal that lets visitors use the connection but not poke around our devices.This is our third Netgear router and it's really a jump forward - good job guys! The last two were also great for their day but I'm glad to give up the blue disco ball on my last Rangemax for this unit. Netgear includes everything you need in the box and even labels items 1 2 3 so you can easily identify what you need at each step. Simple and brilliant. But then aren't the best things usually that way?

column9: Worked well...  Nothing bad, it just worked
column10: The only minor issue, which was probably more of a user issue, was identifing which 'button' was the add another secure wireless device versus the button to turn off the wireless support.  I couldn't find anything in the minimal documentation explaining which was which.  Thus, I wasted some time sorting things out when I added another wireless bridge to connect the Sony Bravia TV and accidently turned off the wireless connectivity to my 3 laptops instead of adding the new device!

column9: Netgear Rangemax WNDR3700 Dual Band Wireless-N Gigabit Router
column10: I was using a 5-year-old Linksys Pre-N router whose range was lacking before I purchased this. When using my ipod touch in bed, I would frequently have to hold my arm towards the door to pick up a better signal. Recently, I would lose the connection frequently and have to reset the router numerous times a day. After doing a bit of research, I settled on this Netgear router which arrived at my door last night. I followed the instructions on the website and it was so quick and easy to set up that at first I did not realize I was done! I think the entire process from opening up the box to testing the wireless on another device took about 7 minutes. The range seems really good - strong signals throughout the house (have not tried the basement yet).By the way, I am on comcast cable internet - in response to one of the other reviewer's comments, the modem supplied by the cable co has a reset button - on mine you activate it by inserted a pen. You can also call the cable co and they will reset your box. The cable co told me that you should not unplug the modem to reset.

column9: a nice upgrade from my previous pre-N mimo wireless router
column10: My trusty Belkin wireless router never gave out on me, but it was starting to show its age. So far this router is solid. No dropped connections so far. I have 4 computers, 1 media server, and 2 cell phones accessing wireless connection (three 802.11n, three 802.11g, and one 802.11n pre-N draft 1). Setup was a little harder compared to my Belkin router which had better descriptions on what each function does. To Netgear's credit, it had a fully automatic setup option, but unfortunately it did not find the correct settings when I used it. I had some heartache, but after copying my Belkin's setttings, I finally got the Netgear's to work...albeit manually. Once it was running it was a strong performer. My laptop (which can acces either the 2.4ghz or 5.0ghz band) got around 46 Mbps (5.75 MB/s equivalent) on average by downloading a 100mb video file from a powered WD500 external hard drive connected to the router (using ftp local network access) so that I know its not the internet bottleneck (but it may be my laptops wireless card). My other computers got around the same. Connection is pretty good, not much better than my MIMO Belkin router (which had three atennaes). The router is in a different room from all my computers (each of them in separate rooms as well) if that gives any idea of the distance. I can't vouch for the gigabit ethernet connections but thats one of the reasons why i wanted to upgrade (to connect a network-attached-server in the future).Things I liked:-Dual band with independent atennaes (so you can have two wireless networks)-Separate Guest network (so you dont have to give out your password)-QoS and WMM (Wi-Fi multi media) prioritizing traffic-Usage meter-Ftp and http local and remote access to an attached external hd (router acts like a simple NAS device)-Media server-Linux based firmware (not sure) so possibilities for 3rd party customizationThings I didn't like/didnt care for:-The router, Ftp, and http access (currently) uses only 1 password..meaning once someone knows your ftp access they can access your router settings too. So really, it acts like a NAS but no support for multiple users.-Incorrect automatic setup (at least for me)-Basic user interface (but if it works, it works)-Haven't tried the secure push-connect featureOverall, I WOULD recommend this router to a friend. AND i would but it again if i had to.
Works great!!!  Easy setup.  Very Fast.  No dropped connections.  Very Happy!!!

This is connected to a PS3, Xbox 360, MAC, PC, PSP, iPhone and the Netgear ReadyNAS 2110. It handles everything like a champ. My average connection speed from my wireless laptop to my readynas for data transfer is 180-200 Mbps which is very fast. All of them can be running at any given time and I never miss a beat.I did read some other reviews by others, about it not connecting, I am going to tell you that they probably have Cable, and they have not realized that you have to call your cable company to have them reset the modem, if you can see the network but can't connect to the internet, your modem needs to be reset from the cable company.They will try the first step which is to unplug the modem for 10-20 seconds and then plug it back in, then plug in the router, doesn't always work but when I call them and have them send a 'hit' it works with in seconds.
until now, the product is still living up with its forecasted excellent performance. a bit pricy but hey, its worth it. head-ache free surfing.

When my old trusty Linksys/Cisco WRT54G router reached a point where daily reboots became necessary, I decided to take a look at other options.  It turns out NetGear has come a LONG way with the WNDR3700.Since I don't have a 'vanilla' network, I set it up manually, so I can't comment on the Setup Wizard, however, even manual setup was a breeze.  The administration functions are straight forward, concise, and offer much more than what was available to me on the Linksys.1. Speed.  The obvious upgrade was wireless N.  However, the integrated GB switch ports were also a nice surprise.  The WNDR3700 gives you, essentially, 4 networks. 2.5GHz, 5.0GHz, and two Guest networks at various speeds, which allow you to give isolated access to visiting friends without handing out your security keys (and the 3700 offers all the latest wireless encryption standards -- however, keep in mind, your wireless laptop NIC has to support the same standard and speed).2. Lockout functions.  The administration screens allow you to lock out specific services (i.e. by TCP, UDP, port, and by specific IP addresses.  Additionally, you can schedule time windows for the lockout to occur.  You can also block sites by keyword, or domain, while still allowing your own 'trusted' IP to visit those sites.  One item I would have changed, was to be able to perform the lockout by MAC address as opposed to IP.  MAC addresses don't change, IP's are dynamically (usually) assigned, and change.3. Logs. Big improvement over the Linksys. The logs give you access by access reporting of sites, by which IP, as well as filtered scans, DoS attacks, connects, and disconnects, attempts to access blocked sites, etc.  It leaves little to guess at when doing an analysis of your internet usage and external attempts to access your network.  Additionally, you can have the logs (and attempts) e-mailed to you, if you want.4. QoS.  You can control bandwidth usage and priorities (I had limited capability on the Linksys for this).  In addition, there is a Traffic Meter, which gives you historic usage values.5. USB Storage.  Very flexible ability to plug in any USB drive (or thumb drive), and set shares, access privileges, etc., for local or remote (LAN or WAN) sources.  Extremely simple to use, and it creates a single repository for all of your network users to share files.There are many more functions available, such as backing up, Port Forwarding and Triggering, etc.  A few very advanced functions for those that like to tweak and optimize their networks, as well.I've yet to have any issues with this router, and I'm thoroughly pleased with its performance.  It doesn't seem to generate as much heat as some of the other Linksys/Cisco routers I looked at, and it seems to be very tolerant of exceeding switch hops, cable distances, and other networking no-no's that many of us abuse.  All in all, a very good choice.  Cisco had better keep an eye over their shoulder.REVIEW UPDATE 02-14-2010Whenever I buy a product for which I've read the reviews, I make a mental note of going back to the 1-, and 2-star reviews to see if I've experienced any of the complaint issues.In this case, I've experienced absolutely none of them:1- The Guest networks work EXACTLY as advertised.  They have been a major triumph, since my kids have friends over with their own laptops, and it's now a simple matter to allow them temporary access without handing out WP2 security keys from our main networks.2- Transferring files between computers (I'm a consultant, so I have a number of them), used to be a 1-copy to thumbdrive, 2-move the thumbdrive, 3-copy to system effort, when I wasn't running a private server.  Now, I keep a small (500GB) USB based backup drive attached, and it acts not only as a local repository for sharing files between systems, but I'm able to access files on it (with authentication) remotely from across the country, if need be.  I've yet to have a single issue with it.3- I've never had a single lockup on this router since installation, and it hasn't been down or powered off for a single minute since its installation.4- I've been able to block specific sites, schedule access times to the net (when the kids didn't want to hang up their laptops at 2am), and even set QoS bandwidth priorities so my work isn't interrupted by multiple accesses and downloads by other family members.  Works like a charm.5- I've been able to set port forwarding for specific purposes (IP cam, certain games, etc.) and it's worked exactly as it should.6- It has self-upgraded itself since the purchase, since it automatically checks for new firmware whenever I access the management utility.7- I've even been able to temporarily set up an FTP server, and put it in a DMZ for access from an external client, when I needed to.Bottom line, every function is working flawlessly.  I've watched the Linksys quality (overheating, limited functionality, etc.) decline ever since Cisco bought them out, and couldn't be happier with the NetGear.I can't comment on support, since I've never had a problem requiring me to call them.If I had ANY possible improvement suggestions, I would say to reconfigure the 'Schedule' function in the Management utility, so different times can be applied to different logged-on clients; and make the references to those clients by MAC address instead of IP (IP addresses change in a DCHCP environment).Otherwise, I'd recommend this router to anyone.  It's worth every penny.
We bought one for the house and then two for our businesses because the first one worked so well.The second and third ones worked just as well as the first.We love ours.
Amazing router for the price. its lightening fast and has good range. Don't buy one for $129 when you can grab this one. def a good buy.

column9: No issues in last 1 year. Works well.
column10: Using it for last 1 year. You configure it once with the password and stuff and just forget. No glitches, no dropped connections. Super fast. I can't expect more.

column9: One of the best routers I have ever used.
column10: I got this to use with my Docsys modem and was not disappointed. Now I can stream movies to any room in the house and have a wireless guest connection as well . What a great Router.

column9: Great router with easy hook up
column10: Works great speedy internet now.  I am very pleased with this router and recommend it to other users.Elliott Polansky

Excellent router! I wanted to step up to a dual band and I'm happy I did.  On the 5ghz band I get nearly the same download speed as I do when plugged in directly with an ethernet cable!!!  On my old router, I would get HALF of the speed (standard 2.4ghz band).  I used to be Linksys all the way, but Netgear has really stepped up and makes some of the best routers today as rated by PC Mag and CNET.
Works instantly and flawlessly. Excellent value and quality performing as well if not better than more expensive devices.  Perfect for the home network.

It works beautifully and has a lot of great networking controls and options. I have guest wifi which prevents them from accessing the rest of my network, and I have a great wired and wireless network for my printer, computers, and smart devices to communicate securely with each other.
Router works great, and easy to flash DD-WRT firmware onto.  I like having the USB port so I can plug in a thumbdrive and share files on my LAN.

I HAVE BEEN SEARCHING FOR A WIRELESS ROUTER WITH A STRONG WIRELESS SIGNAL.  BANG, I FOUND IT.NETGEAR MUST HAVE DECIDED TO BUILD THE BEST ROUTER THAT TECNOLOGY COULD ALLOW FOR.THE INSTALLATION WAS DEAD EASY AND I HAD NO PROBLEMS AT ALLIM SO USE TO HAVING TO TRY AND RE TRY INSTALLS THAT THIS ACTUALLY CAUGHT ME OFFGUARDI HAVE A BUNGALOW WHERE THE UNIT IS ON THE MAINFLOORAFTER HOOKING IT UP THROUGH MY SIEMENS SE567 ROUTER/MODEM MY SIGNAL STRENGTH TO MY NEW LG WI-FI BLU-RAY DISC PLAYER INCREASED SIGNIFICANTLY SO I CAN NOW VIEW YOU  TUBE VIDEOS WITH NO LAGALSO, MY WII IS ALSO IN THE LOWER LEVEL AND THE SIGNAL IS VERY STRONG AS WELLPROBABLY THE BEST MONEY I'VE EVER SPENT ON A ROUTER, AND DEFINITELY THE MOST TROUBLEFREE INSTALL I'VE HAD FOR A LONG TIMEWASN'T CHEAP, BUT YOU USUALLY PAY FOR WHAT YOU GETIN THIS CASE THIS IS TRUE !!

column9: Excellent choice for the home network
column10: This is a very good router with some exceptional features:Pro:- From the documentation I was unable to determine if this thing worked with my older 'B' laptop. All the writing referred to the ultra modern 'N' capabilities. I discovered that it does function with the 'B' protocol, but it works better with 'G' or 'N'.  I achieved the best speeds with the 'G' protocol, but keep in mind that any home internet connection speed will be far less that the wireless network speed. Based on my experience, I would suggest a 'G' protocol as a minimum.- The router supports both 5GHz and 2.4 Ghz speeds. I actually prefer 2.4; it seems to work better in my situation for some reason.- It has a really nifty feature that allow you to connect an external USB hard drive, and then find it with any browser on the network by typing in '\\readyshare\USB_Storage'. It can be password protected for read or write. This is very useful, providing a home networked backup location. I hooked up my USB drive and now use it from any computer. Very well done.- Along the same lines, the router provides the capability to connect to a media server, including automatic scan for new files at regular intervals. This is used to allow a media player to access your media files over wireless. I did not try this feature.- The device sets up easily if you have a 'default' installation. More on this later.- Included security protocols are what one would expect: WEP (not recommended!), WPA-PSK (TKIP and AIE), WPA-PSK [TKIP] + WPA2-PSK [AES], and WPA/WPA2 Enterprise. I'm using WPA2-PSK [AES] and it works fine.- If one is so inclined, the router includes the capability to provide a guest account, perhaps useful in a business situation.- The router supports remote administration, which is really useful.- There is a neat feature that automatically checks for firmware updates when you enter the administration mode. I haven't seen any updates yet, so I can't say how well this works.- It is possible to backup the router settings to your local hard drive, useful in case you need to reset or something.- The router has pretty extensive settings for content filtering, including the capability of blocking sites or services, and the capability to send emails for any filtering events. The filters can be scheduled as to when they are applied.- I did not have a need to modify the other settings, so I will just mention them here: Port forwarding/triggering/QoS support, static routes, UPnP support, and URLs for web support built into the router menus.Performance:Very good. I have excellent signal strength and the throughput is such that I don't really notice that I'm on wireless rather than wired connections.Con:- In my particular situation my internet modem used the same IP address as the default router address. I had run across this before with other routers, so I got past it, but it was not a simple installation. I had to manually set up the router - but I can report that this function works well.Summary: This router is a good choice if you have the need for network storage, media storage, B/G/N compatibility, or all the above. It works very well, but may need some tweaking during installation. Recommended.UPDATE 3 Dec 09:I have just found out that you can access the files on your USB connected drive via the Internet. So this router can be the key to shared storage that can be accessed from anywhere. Very nice.

I have been on the lookout for a capable consumer-class router for some time. Over the years, I've used and tried a number of different products from D-Link, Linksys and Netgear, so I've gotten a good experience with functionality and reliability of the various brands. Yet, the last few years, I've tended to run into snags with all the various routers.
